Row.Cell: <paragraph>Black books, also called bad luck, blood or, contained information and records about offenders and suspects of throat crimes. The records were kept by the scribe of the city court, and criminals were also confessed in the torture chambers. Among the oldest surviving ones are the books of bad luck from the beginning of the 16th century.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Black books, also called pitch-books or blood-books, held information and records of delinquents and people suspected of capital crimes. The records were kept by the clerk of the municipal court of the interrogation of the prisoners, sometimes under torture. The oldest preserved black books date from the early 16th century.</paragraph>

Set out on the trail of the legend of Prince Brunswick, who won the heraldic lion for Bohemia. With the help of a series of clues, embark on a journey across the Trosky Region to track down Brunswick's armour. But beware! Only a true knight is worthy of it.

<paragraph>Czech physician, lawyer, provost of Vyšehrad and archbishop of Prague.</paragraph><paragraph>Since 1399, he was the personal physician of Wenceslas IV. Until 1411, he taught medicine at the Faculty of Medicine of Charles University in Prague, where he not only dramatically raised the professional level of the entire faculty, but also its prestige (medicine was not yet recognized as one of the 'arts').</paragraph><paragraph>After the death of Wenceslas IV., he became the personal physician of his brother Sigismund of Luxembourg, who promoted him to the nobility for his merits. During the Hussite wars, Albich was forced to abandon all his possessions and flee the country.</paragraph><paragraph>The most important of his rich literary legacy are the <italic>Compendium medicinae</italic> (Medical Compendium) and <italic>Regimen sanitatis seu Vetularius</italic> (Rules for the Preservation of Health), also intended for the general public.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Czech physician, lawyer, provost of Vyšehrad and archbishop of Prague.</paragraph><paragraph>From 1399, he was the personal physician of Wenceslas IV. By 1411, he was teaching medicine at the Medical Faculty of Charles University in Prague, where he dramatically raised the professional level and prestige of the entire faculty (medicine was not yet recognized as one of the 'arts').</paragraph><paragraph>After the death of Wenceslas IV, he became the personal physician to his brother Sigismund of Luxembourg, who elevated him to the nobility for his services. During the Hussite wars, Albich had to abandon all his properties and flee the country.</paragraph><paragraph>From his extensive literary legacy, the most significant works are <italic>Compendium medicinae</italic> (Medical Compendium) and <italic>Regimen sanitatis seu Vetularius</italic> (Rules for the Preservation of Health), intended for the general public.</paragraph>

<years>before 1377 - approx. 1414</years><paragraph>Otto III von Bergow was a prominent Czech nobleman of Thuringia-Saxony origin who held royal offices at the provincial court and was the Burgrave of Prague in 1388-1393. Later, as the leading member of the League of Lords, he served on the royal council, where he actively opposed his king, Wenceslas IV, and during his captivity in Vienna, held the post of the Subchamberlain of the land, which had been entrusted to him by King Sigismund of Luxembourg. In this position, he was responsible, for example, for collecting taxes from the royal towns and some monasteries, or for approving the appointed councillors.</paragraph><paragraph>Otto's original estates included Biela (Bílina) and Seeberg (Žeberk) in the northern Bohemia, before he sold them off and bought the Rohozec estate and Trosky Castle, which he rebuilt expensively. After the return of Wenceslas IV to the Czech throne, he was removed from his posts and died in 1414.</paragraph>

<years>before 1377 – circa 1414</years><paragraph>Otto III von Bergow was a notable Czech nobleman of Thuringian-Meissen origin who held royal offices at the provincial court and served as the burgrave of Prague from 1388 to 1393. Later, as a leading member of the League of Lords, he served on the royal council, where he actively opposed his king, Wenceslas IV. During Wenceslas IV's imprisonment in Vienna, Otto held the position of the highest provincial chamberlain, a post entrusted to him by the Hungarian king Sigismund of Luxembourg. In this role, he was responsible for tasks such as collecting taxes from royal towns and certain monasteries or approving appointed councilors.</paragraph><paragraph>Otto's original domain included Biela (Bílina) and Seeberg (Žeberk) in northern Bohemia, which he sold to purchase the Rohozec estate and Trosky Castle, which he extensively rebuilt. After Wenceslas IV returned to the Czech throne, he was removed from his offices and died in 1414.</paragraph>

<years>1388(?) - 1419</years><paragraph><accent>young Lord Capon</accent></paragraph><paragraph>Son of Ješek Capon and Hedvika of Dauba. After the death of his father, Jan Ješek, the lords of Leipa (uncle Henry, his son Hanush and his brothers) became his guardians.</paragraph><paragraph>After the imprisonment of Master Jan Hus, he signed a petition in his defence. In the Hussite wars, however, he initially sided with the League of Lords against the Hussites in a few minor battles (in 1419 he took part in the battle against the Hussites at Knin), apparently due to the influence of his close neighbour Lacek of Kravař from Šternberk. There are no records indicating he took part in the war later.</paragraph><paragraph>He was the lord of Rattay and Polná. He acquired Rattay from his guardians only in 1412. He held positions in the provincial offices and his son is the famous Hynce Capon.</paragraph><paragraph>Unlike his historical precursor, however, we took the poetic license of making Hans Capon a twenty-year-old man in our game.</paragraph>

<years>1388(?) - 1419</years><paragraph><accent>young Lord Capon (Jan Ptáček) </accent></paragraph><paragraph>Son of Ješek Ptáček and Hedvika of Duba. After the death of his father, Jan Ješek, the Lords of Leipa (uncle Henry, his son Hanush and his brothers) became his guardians.</paragraph><paragraph>After the imprisonment of Master Jan Hus, he signed a petition in his defence. In the Hussite wars, however, he initially sided with the League of Lords against the Hussites in a few minor battles (in 1419 he took part in the battle against the Hussites at Knin), apparently due to the influence of his close neighbour Lacek of Kravař from Šternberk. There are no records indicating he took part in the war later.</paragraph><paragraph>He was the Lord of Rattay and Polná. He acquired Rattay from his guardians only in 1412. He held positions in the provincial offices and his son was the famous Hynek Ptáček.</paragraph><paragraph>Unlike his historical precursor, however, we took the poetic license of making Hans Capon a twenty-year-old man in our game.</paragraph>

<years>14 May 1316 - 29 November 1378</years><paragraph>Charles IV of Luxembourg, son of John of Luxembourg, was the second king of Bohemia (1346-1378) of this dynasty and the first to be emperor of the Holy Roman Empire (1355-1378). In addition to holding many other titles, he was Margrave of Moravia and Count of Luxembourg, King of Italy, Germany and Burgundy.</paragraph><paragraph>He was known for his diplomatic skills, and actively sought to ensure his position in Europe - especially in Bohemia, Moravia and Germany. He was fluent in foreign languages and was taught at the French court by the future Pope Clement VI himself.</paragraph><paragraph>During his reign, Prague and the Bohemian territories underwent a major transformation. His father's neglected kingdom became the centre of the Roman Empire. The period of cultural and economic prosperity of the Bohemian lands is therefore called the<italic>"Golden Age"<italic>. Charles was therefore very popular and is still considered one of the most important rulers of the High Middle Ages.</paragraph><paragraph> He married four times and had thirteen children, most of whom died in their youth. The most famous were his <accent>sons Wenceslas and Sigismund</accent>, who ruled the royal lands after him - Wenceslas in Bohemia, Sigismund in Hungary.</paragraph>

<years>14 May 1316 - 29 November 1378</years><paragraph>Charles IV of Luxembourg, son of John of Luxembourg, was the second king of Bohemia (1346-1378) of this dynasty and the first to be emperor of the Holy Roman Empire (1355-1378). Besides this he held many other titles, being Margrave of Moravia, Count of Luxembourg, King of Italy, Germany and Burgundy.</paragraph><paragraph>He was known for his diplomatic skills, and actively sought to secure his position in Europe - especially in Bohemia, Moravia and Germany. He was fluent in foreign languages and was taught at the French court by the future Pope Clement VI himself.</paragraph><paragraph>During his reign, Prague and the Bohemian territories underwent a major transformation. His father's neglected kingdom became the centre of the Holy Roman Empire. The period of cultural and economic prosperity of the Bohemian lands is therefore called the<italic>"Golden Age"</italic>. Charles was therefore very popular and is still considered one of the most important rulers of the High Middle Ages.</paragraph><paragraph>He married four times and had thirteen children. The most famous were his <accent>sons Wenceslas and Sigismund</accent>, who ruled the royal lands after him - Wenceslas in Bohemia, Sigismund in Hungary.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The first mention of the Cimburk family dates back to 1142, when the alleged ancestor of the family Miroslav founded the Sedletz monastery - the oldest Cistercian abbey in Bohemia. His origins are unknown and the coat of arms of silver and red battlements is documented only on a seal from the 14th century.</paragraph><paragraph>The original family seat is unknown, but according to legend the Cimburk family themselves considered it to be a castle above the Vrchlitz valley near Poličany. However, research here has only documented a nameless prehistoric and early medieval hillfort. Two other castles of the same name were founded by the family during the 14th century in Trnávka and near Koryčany in Moravia.</paragraph><paragraph>The brothers <accent>Jan Balšán</accent> and <accent>Miroslav</accent> of Cimburk, who got into a dispute over their inheritance with their uncle Aleš and became infamous as robber knights and mercenaries during the Hussite Wars, were important members of the family.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The first mention of the Cimburk (Zimburg) family dates back to 1142, when an alleged ancestor of the family, Miroslav, founded Sedletz Monastery - the oldest Cistercian abbey in Bohemia. His origins are unknown and the coat of arms, of silver and red battlements, is only documented on a seal from the 14th century.</paragraph><paragraph>The original family seat is unknown, but according to legend the Cimburk family themselves considered it to be a castle above the Vrchlitz valley near Poličany. However, research here has only documented a nameless prehistoric and early medieval hillfort. Two other castles of the same name were founded by the family during the 14th century in Trnávka and near Koryčany in Moravia.</paragraph><paragraph>Notable members of the family were the brothers <accent>Jan Balšán</accent>(Posy) and <accent>Miroslav</accent> of Cimburk, who got into a dispute over their inheritance with their uncle Aleš (Alesh). They became infamous as robber knights and mercenaries during the Hussite Wars.</paragraph>

<years>? - 1415</years><paragraph>Following the death of Henry III of Pirkstein in 1402, Hanush of Leipa became <accent>the guardian of the former's son, Hans Capon</accent> and thus the acting governor of the surrounding region. He completed the construction of Pirkstein, the fortifications and the local church of St. Matthew, which contains a shrine to his family.</paragraph><paragraph>When Sigismund of Luxembourg invaded and burned Skalitz, the town's Burgrave, Radzig Kobyla, and the survivors of the raid found refuge with Hanush. Hanush subsequently took action against scattered groups of brigands and Cumans.</paragraph><paragraph>His relationship with the king was peculiar to say the least, judging by often contradictory sources. It appears that in 1410 crown forces descended on the town of Rattay in Hanush' domain, probably after he became a robber baron and rebel, who may also have participated in the siege of Jihlava in Moravia. Nevertheless, in 1414 he became a Provincial Marshal and dwelt together with his wife Markéta of Sternberg at Špilberk in Brno.</paragraph>

<years>? - 1415</years><paragraph>Following the death of Heinrich III of Pirkstein in 1402, Hanush of Leipa became <accent>the guardian of the former's son, Hans Capon</accent> and thus the acting governor of the surrounding region. He completed the construction of Pirkstein, its fortifications and the local church of St. Matthew, which contains a shrine to his family.</paragraph><paragraph>When Sigismund of Luxembourg invaded and burned Skalitz, the town's Burgrave, Radzig Kobyla, and the survivors of the raid found refuge with Hanush. Hanush subsequently took action against scattered groups of brigands and Cumans.</paragraph><paragraph>His relationship with the king was peculiar to say the least, judging by often contradictory sources. It appears that in 1410 crown forces descended on the town of Rattay in Hanush' domain, probably after he became a robber baron and rebel, who may also have participated in the siege of Jihlava in Moravia. Nevertheless, in 1414 he became a Provincial Marshal and dwelt together with his wife Margaret of Sternberg at Spilberg in Brno.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The presence of Italians played an enormous role at the court of the Luxembourg dynasty, both Wenceslas and Sigismund. They brought news concerning papal politics, but above all they strongly influenced who would be elected emperor of the Roman Empire. While Wenceslas IV was supported by members of the Visconti family of Milan, Sigismund was backed by the wealthiest Florentines. </paragraph><paragraph> Important positions in Sigismund's royal court were administered by, among others, Pippo Spano, known in Czech as Pipa Vlach. In a short and politically unstable period, he proved to be not only a capable merchant but also a military tactician. He was the first to organise a defensive system of defence in the Hungarian towns against the attacks of the Ottoman Empire, for which Sigismund made him the leading commander of the Hungarian army. </paragraph><paragraph> In 1403, Pippo saved the king from death during an attack by Hungarian barons, later commanded soldiers in a campaign against Venice or the Hussites, and was also admitted to one of the most prestigious knightly orders of the time, the so-called <italic>"Order of the Dragon"</italic>.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The presence of Italians played an enormous role at the court of the Luxembourg dynasty, both under Wenceslas and Sigismund. They brought news concerning papal politics, and significantly influenced the election of the Holy Roman Emperor. While Wenceslas IV was supported by members of the Visconti family of Milan, Sigismund was backed by the wealthiest Florentines. </paragraph><paragraph> Important positions in Sigismund's royal court were administered by, among others, Pippo Spano, known in Czech as Pipa Vlach. In a short and politically unstable period, he proved to be not only a capable merchant but also a military tactician. He was the first to organise a defensive system in the Hungarian towns against attacks from the Ottoman Empire, for which Sigismund made him the chief commander of the Hungarian army. </paragraph><paragraph> In 1403, Pippo saved the king from death during an attack by Hungarian barons. He later commanded soldiers in a campaign against Venice and the Hussites, and was inducted into one of the most prestigious knightly orders of the time, the so-called <italic>"Order of the Dragon"</italic>.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Johannes von Gelnhausen was a lawyer, upper scribe and archivist of the imperial office.</paragraph><paragraph>As the second-born son of a German noble family, he went to study and before 1365 he obtained the post of upper scribe in Kuttenberg. In the following years, however, he was already serving the most powerful men of his time and travelling around the empire with the imperial court of Charles IV. Later, as an expert in both laws, he was in charge of the office of Bishop John of Neumarkt in Olomouc and then was a city scribe in Brno until 1389.</paragraph><paragraph>It was only towards the end of his life that he created his seminal work known as <italic>Gelnhausen Codex</italic>. It is an illuminated legal treatise for the upper town of Jihlava, and Johannes made full use of his experience here, taking inspiration from the Upper Code of Kuttenberg, Ius regale montanorum.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Johannes von Gelnhausen was a lawyer, mining scribe and archivist of the imperial chancery.</paragraph><paragraph>As the second-born son of a German noble family, he went to study and before 1365 he secured the post of mining scribe in Kuttenberg. In the following years, he served the most powerful men of his time and travelled throughout the empire with the imperial court of Charles IV. Later, as an expert in both types of law, he led the office of Bishop John of Neumarkt in Olomouc and subsequently was a city scribe in Brno until 1389.</paragraph><paragraph>It was only towards the end of his life that he created his seminal work known as the <italic>Gelnhausen Codex</italic>. An illuminated legal treatise for the mining town of Jihlava, Johannes made full use of his experience here, taking inspiration from the Mining Code of Kuttenberg, Ius regale montanorum.</paragraph>

<paragraph>One of the most famous and controversial figures in the Czech history. The man who gave a face to the Hussite Revolt.</paragraph><paragraph>Unfortunately, only the last six years of his life have been more thoroughly mapped historically. We do know that he lost an eye in his youth and that in 1408, Zizka worked in the ambush company of a certain Matthew the Leader and supported himself as a bandit in the mercenary service of various noblemen. The activities of his band, according to the speculations of some leading Czech historians, were not so much of a pecuniary nature as of a political nature.</paragraph><paragraph>We know from surviving records that when he was later arrested and sentenced, King Wenceslas IV granted him a pardon. There is therefore a suggestion, that he may have carried out at least some of his activities at the instigation of someone in the King's entourage.</paragraph><paragraph>His most famous historical phase follows the beginning of the Hussite Revolt, when he led the rebel armies and gained a reputation as a brilliant strategist and never-beaten warlord, leading the Hussites from victory to victory.</paragraph>

<paragraph>One of the most famous and controversial figures in Czech history. The man who became the face of the Hussite uprising.</paragraph><paragraph>Unfortunately, only the last six years of his life are thoroughly documented. We know that he lost an eye in his youth and that in 1408, Zizka served in the sabotage unit of a certain Matthew the Leader and made a living as a bandit in the service of various nobles. According to some leading Czech historians, the activities of his band had more of a political than a material character.</paragraph><paragraph>From existing records, we know that when he was later arrested and sentenced, King Wenceslas IV granted him a pardon. There is a theory that at least part of his activities might have been carried out at the behest of someone from the king's entourage.</paragraph><paragraph>His most famous historical period follows the outbreak of the Hussite uprising when he took command of the rebel forces and earned a reputation as a brilliant strategist and an undefeated military leader who led the Hussites from victory to victory.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The wife of our Hans Capon, the daughter of Erhart the Elder of Kunstadt and Jitka of Medritsch.</paragraph><paragraph>Unfortunately, we do not know how exactly the marriage was arranged, however, there is information that thanks to this marriage, Hans Capon expanded his domains in Moravia. He had a son named Hynce with Jitka, later nicknamed the <italic>"King of East Bohemia"</italic>, a tireless organiser of the Bohemian political scene and the predecessor of the Hussite king George of Podiebrad.</paragraph><paragraph>Otherwise, all we know about Jitka of Kunstadt is that in 1408, Hans Capon granted her a dowry of 1000 schocks of Prague groschen.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Future wife of our Hans Capon, the daughter of Erhart the Elder of Kunstadt and Jitka of Medritsch.</paragraph><paragraph>Unfortunately, we do not know exactly how the marriage was arranged, but it is recorded that thanks to this marriage, Hans Capon expanded his domains in Moravia. He had a son named Hynce with Jitka, later nicknamed the <italic>"King of East Bohemia"</italic>, a tireless organiser of the Bohemian political scene and a predecessor of the Hussite king George of Podiebrad.</paragraph><paragraph>Otherwise, all we know about Jitka of Kunstadt is that in 1408, Hans Capon granted her a dowry of 60,000 Prague groschen.</paragraph>

<years>1354 - 18 January 1411</years><paragraph>Jobst was the Margrave of Moravia from 1375 and of Brandenburg from 1388. He even reigned as the emperor of the Roman Empire for 15 weeks (1410-11). He was the son of John Henry of Luxembourg and nephew of Emperor Charles IV. He gained his position in Europe through military and political intrigues against family members, especially against Wenceslas IV.</paragraph><paragraph> Initially, he supported Sigismund of Luxembourg in his quest for the Bohemian crown, as this gained him and other lords many privileges and ensured his influence in the future if king Wenceslas IV was dethroned. In 1402, however, the situation changed, perhaps due to the imprisonment of his brother Prokop, and so Jobst eventually stood against Sigismund and played one of the leading roles in king Wenceslas's deliverance.</paragraph><paragraph>Jobst even ran for imperial emperor against Sigismund towards the end of his life - and won the election. He did not enjoy the title for long, however, as he died shortly afterwards. Although he was very able both politically and economically and had great support from the nobility, by the time of the events of our play he was up to his ears in debt.</paragraph>

<years>1354 - 18 January 1411</years><paragraph>Jobst was the Margrave of Moravia from 1375 and of Brandenburg from 1388. He even reigned as Holy Roman Emperor for 15 weeks (1410-11). He was the son of John Henry of Luxembourg and nephew of Emperor Charles IV. He secured his position in Europe through military and political intrigues against family members, especially Wenceslas IV.</paragraph><paragraph> Initially, he supported Sigismund of Luxembourg in his quest for the Bohemian crown, as this granted him and other nobles many privileges and ensured future influence should king Wenceslas IV be deposed. In 1402, however, the situation changed, perhaps due to the imprisonment of his brother Prokop, and Jobst eventually stood against Sigismund and played a leading role in king Wenceslas's liberation.</paragraph><paragraph>Jobst even ran for the position of Holy Roman Emperor against Sigismund towards the end of his life - and won. He did not enjoy the title for long, however, as he died shortly thereafter. Despite being very able both politically and economically and having significant support from the nobility, by the time of the events of our game he was deep in debt.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A cumulative term for persons who were not settled in one place and changed their location of residence depending on their livelihood, seasons of the year, security situation, or as a result of forced displacement. Because of their unsettled lifestyles and foreign customs, they were often viewed with distance or were targets of discrimination and prejudice.</paragraph><paragraph>In the majority of society, the term <italic>gypsies</italic> was adopted for nomads in the Czech lands, which later became a pejorative term, although in its original meaning the word referred more to an unsettled person and did not refer primarily to any ethnic group.</paragraph><paragraph>In our game, the Nomads' camp is a mixture of people of different nationalities and fates brought together by the journey.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A collective term for individuals who did not settle in one place and changed their location depending on livelihood, seasons, security situation, or forced displacement. Due to their nomadic lifestyle and foreign customs, they were often viewed with distance or became targets of discrimination and prejudice.</paragraph> <paragraph>In the majority society of Czech lands, the term <italic>gypsies</italic> became established for nomads, although later it turned into a pejorative term, even though originally it simply referred to a non-settled person and did not primarily refer to any specific ethnicity.</paragraph> <paragraph>In our game, the Nomad's camp is a mixture of people of various nationalities and destinies brought together by their journey.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Konrad of Vechta had a rather illustrious career: he started as a priest, but because he was skilled in handling finances, he entered the service of King Wenceslas IV and was a member of the royal council from 1398 to 1400. Later, he was appointed the royal mint master and also held the offices of the Bishop of Verden and Olomouc and even the Archbishop of Prague.</paragraph><paragraph> As the highest-ranking Bohemian clergyman, he crowned Sigismund of Luxembourg as King of Bohemia after the death of Wenceslas IV, but he never became Sigismund's ally. After the outbreak of the Hussite uprising, he supported its ideals and ordained Hussite priests. However, this had fatal consequences for him.</paragraph><paragraph> By joining the Hussites, the property of the Prague archbishopric was secularised; the bishops of Olomouc and Leitomischl and most of the Catholic priests renounced their allegiance to Konrad, and the Pope imposed an interdict on him. He also lost the support of the Emperor. Konrad was deprived of his office only in 1425 and died forgotten in seclusion.</paragraph><paragraph> At the time of our game, Konrad was a mere royal official, his dramatic career as a high-ranking clergyman was yet to come to being.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Konrad of Vechta had a rather illustrious career: he started as a priest, but because he was skilled in handling finances, he entered the service of King Wenceslas IV and was a member of the royal council from 1398 to 1400. Later, he was appointed the Royal Mint Master and also held the offices of the Bishop of Verden and Olomouc and even Archbishop of Prague.</paragraph><paragraph> As the highest-ranking Bohemian clergyman, he crowned Sigismund of Luxembourg as King of Bohemia after the death of Wenceslas IV, but he never became Sigismund's ally. After the outbreak of the Hussite uprising, he supported its ideals and ordained Hussite priests. However, this had fatal consequences for him.</paragraph><paragraph>By joining the Hussites, the property of the Prague archbishopric was secularised; the bishops of Olomouc and Leitomischl and most of the Catholic priests renounced their allegiance to Konrad, and the Pope excommunicated him. He also lost the support of the Emperor. Konrad was deprived of his office in 1425 and died forgotten in obscurity.</paragraph><paragraph> At the time of our game, Konrad was a mere royal official, his dramatic career as a high-ranking clergyman had yet to come.</paragraph>

<paragraph>We composed The Kuttenberg City Council, according to the surviving records, mostly of names that actually represented it. However, historically we often know nothing about the actual bearers of the names.</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Andreas Plumel</accent>, in 1403, a bailiff of that name did indeed serve in Kuttenberg</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Wenceslas Vorsucher</accent>, wealthy burgher, real person (his real name was Christopher)</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Prokop Eldris</accent>, gun forger, fictional character</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Jerome Naaz</accent>, representative of the Kuttenberg patrician family, probably never served on the council</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Franz Rosenthal</accent>, wealthy coiner, was not on the council until 1412</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Enderlin</accent>, swordsmith, burgher of that name actually lived in Kuttenberg</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Nicholas Krondel</accent>, armoursmith, fictional character</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Havel</accent>, innkeeper, fictional character</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Fridusch Kumel</accent>, wealthy burgher, real person</paragraph>

<paragraph>We reconstructed The Kuttenberg City Council primarily from names documented to have actually been on the council. However, we often know little about the real bearers of these names.</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Andreas Plumel</accent>, in 1403, a bailiff of that name did indeed serve in Kuttenberg</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Wenceslas Vorsucher</accent>, wealthy burgher, real person (his real name was Christopher)</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Prokop Eldris</accent>, gunsmith, fictional character</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Jerome Naaz</accent>, representative of the Kuttenberg patrician family, probably never served on the council</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Franz Rosenthal</accent>, wealthy coiner, was not on the council until 1412</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Enderlin</accent>, swordsmith, burgher of that name actually lived in Kuttenberg</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Nicholas Krondel</accent>, armoursmith, fictional character</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Havel</accent>, innkeeper, fictional character</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Fridusch Kumel</accent>, wealthy burgher, real person</paragraph>

<paragraph>In Kuttenberg, as in other towns of that time, the nobility did not rule, but rather rich townsmen, the so-called <italic>patricians</italic>. The total estates of the patrician families in Kuttenberg are estimated to be the second largest in the kingdom, after the estates of the burgesses in the capital city of Prague.</paragraph><paragraph>The most important family were the <accent>Ruthards</accent> with the fortress of Maleshov and several parish churches, then the <accent>Piseks</accent> with their fortresses in Kouřim and Suchdol, the <accent>Adlers</accent> and the <accent>Vorsuchers</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>The families lost their power during the Hussite wars, when they had to flee from the town to the countryside and lost some of their estates. Perhaps the only exception was the Adler family, who managed to regain their estates after the war. </paragraph>

<paragraph>In Kuttenberg, as in other towns of the time, it was not the nobility who ruled, but rather the wealthy townsmen, known as <italic>patricians</italic>. The total wealth of the patrician families of Kuttenberg is estimated to be the second largest in the kingdom, second only to the wealth of the burghers in the capital city of Prague.</paragraph><paragraph>The most prominent family was the <accent>Ruthards</accent> with the Maleshov fortress and several parish churches, followed by the <accent>Píseks</accent> with fortresses in Kouřimsko and Suchdol, the <accent>Adlers</accent>, and the <accent>Vorsuchers</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>These families lost their power during the Hussite wars, when they had to flee the town to the countryside and lost some of their properties. The exception was the Adler family, who managed to regain their properties after the war.</paragraph>

<years>1386 - 1412</years><paragraph>A member of the Council of the Moravian Margrave, Jobst of Luxembourg, who, as one of only a few Moravian Lords, did not fight against the King alongside Jobst. The Liechtensteins were a wealthy family, owning estates in the Styrian and Lower Austria regions from the 13th century onwards, their main seat being Mikulov (Nikolsburg).</paragraph><paragraph>The Liechtenstein Princes were in close alliance with the Habsburgs and Luxembourgs. In the war against Sigismund, John of Liechtenstein supported Wenceslas, helping to rescue him from captivity, but by so doing fell out of favour with the Austrian Dukes, who confiscated his estates around the Danube River and took him prisoner.</paragraph><paragraph>After the death of Wenceslas, the Liechtensteins aligned with Sigismund.</paragraph>

<years>1386 - 1412</years><paragraph>A member of the Council of the Moravian Margrave, Jobst of Luxembourg, who was one of the few Moravian Lords not to fight against the King alongside Jobst. The Liechtensteins were a wealthy family, owning estates in the Styrian and Lower Austria regions from the 13th century onwards, their main seat being Mikulov (Nikolsburg).</paragraph><paragraph>The Liechtenstein princes were in close alliance with the Habsburgs and Luxembourgs. In the war against Sigismund, John of Liechtenstein supported Wenceslas, helping to rescue him from captivity, but by so doing fell out of favour with the Austrian Dukes, who confiscated his estates around the Danube and imprisoned him.</paragraph><paragraph>After the death of Wenceslas, the Liechtensteins aligned with Sigismund.</paragraph>

<years>1360/70 - 27 December 1402</years><paragraph>He was the Hetman or Governor of Prague, who, much like those members of the nobility disgruntled with the reign of Wenceslas IV, saw in Sigismund of Luxembourg a better potential King.</paragraph><paragraph>His motivation, however, had more to do with money and power - nothing was to come his way from Wenceslas, while helping Sigismund promised a better position in the future. Therefore, it was not difficult for him to change sides and in 1402, at the call of King Sigismund, he joined the siege of Kuttenberg as the leader of the Prague troops.</paragraph><paragraph>It was here that he was killed by an arrow after only few days. For our purposes, we have decided to delay his departure to the other world a little longer.</paragraph>

<years>1360/70 - 27 December 1402</years><paragraph>He was the Hetman or Governor of Prague, who, much like those members of the nobility disgruntled with the reign of Wenceslas IV, saw in Sigismund of Luxembourg a better potential King.</paragraph><paragraph>His motivation, however, had more to do with money and power - he saw no future gains from Wenceslas, whereas aiding Sigismund promised better prospects. Therefore, it was not difficult for him to switch sides and in 1402, at the call of King Sigismund, he joined the siege of Kuttenberg as the leader of the Prague troops.</paragraph><paragraph>It was here that he was killed by an arrow after just a few days. For our purposes, we decided to delay his departure to the other world a little longer.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The travelling scholar Musa, who often has more respect for a pretty bathmaid than a powerful nobleman, may be a fictional figure, but his origins, name, and even character are based on real people.</paragraph><paragraph>The first of these is King Mansa Musa, ruler of the Mali Empire, who lived in the early 14th century. Musa contributed significantly to the spread of Islam across North Africa and the Middle East and to the development of the city of Timbuktu, where he built a mosque and university that still stand today. According to current estimates, Musa was the richest man in history, with a fortune estimated at the current 500 billion dollars.</paragraph><paragraph>Our other model for Musa is Ibn Battuta. An Arab scholar and one of the most important travelers and cartographers of the 14th century. He spent nearly thirty years on the road, during which time he covered much of the then known world. He visited the countries of North Africa, the Middle East, India, China as well as Europe and surpassed all his contemporaries in the length of his travels. At the end of his life, he dictated his experiences in the travelogue Rihla (Journey).</paragraph>

<paragraph>The travelling scholar Musa, who often has more respect for a pretty bathmaid than a powerful nobleman, may be a fictional figure, but his origins, name, and even character are based on real people.</paragraph><paragraph>The first of these is King Mansa Musa, ruler of the Mali Empire, who lived in the early 14th century. Musa contributed significantly to the spread of Islam across North Africa and the Middle East and to the development of the city of Timbuktu, where he built a mosque and university that still stand today. According to modern estimates, Musa was the richest man in history, with a fortune estimated at the current equivalent of 500 billion dollars.</paragraph><paragraph>Our other model for Musa is Ibn Battuta. An Arab scholar and one of the most important travelers and cartographers of the 14th century. He spent nearly thirty years on the road, during which time he covered much of the then known world. He visited countries of North Africa, the Middle East, India, China and Europe, surpassing all of his contemporaries in the scope of his travels. At the end of his life, he dictated his experiences in the travelogue Rihla (Journey).</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Pope is the highest figure of the Catholic Church, the representative of Jesus Christ on earth. His word is sacred to Christians and his office irrevocable. </paragraph><paragraph>But we have seen more than once in our time that this is not always the case; as a result of papal schisms, several popes were sometimes in office at the same time during the Middle Ages - invoking and cursing each other and claiming to be the one, sovereign and true head of the entire Catholic Church. For secular rulers, then, adherence to a particular pope was more a matter of politics than faith.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Pope is the supreme head of the Catholic Church, the representative of Jesus Christ on earth. His word is sacred to Christians and his office irrevocable. </paragraph><paragraph>However this has not always been the case, as we have seen multiple times through history. As a result of papal schisms, several popes were sometimes in office at the same time during the Middle Ages - invoking and cursing each other and claiming to be the one, sovereign and true head of the entire Catholic Church. For secular rulers, then, adherence to a particular pope was more a matter of politics than faith.</paragraph>

<years>1354/5 - 24 September 1405</years><paragraph>Prokop of Luxembourg, son of John Henry of Luxembourg, was a provincial governor of the kingdom and Margrave of Moravia from 1375 to 1405. Together with his brother Jobst, he was to rule Moravia, but most of the time they fought disputes over the succession and the future of the Luxembourg dynasty, which had ambitions to win the Polish and Hungarian crowns.</paragraph><paragraph>After the death of Charles IV, he initially supported the policies of Sigismund of Luxembourg and fought against Wenceslas in the so-called <italic>Margraviate Wars</italic>. But after the Bohemian nobility imprisoned Wenceslas, he sided with him and became his ally. The relations between the Luxembourgs, Prokop and Jobst illustrate very aptly the intrigues of the time. Jobst and Prokop waged wars against each other for years, only to ally themselves with Wenceslas against Sigismund and then betray the King and side with Rupert of the Palatinate.</paragraph><paragraph>When Sigismund once again kidnapped the King and imprisoned him in 1402, Prokop was also captured as his ally in Pressburg (Bratislava) for two years. His illegitimate son George of Luxembourg was the last descendant of the Luxembourg dynasty, who could not inherit any property or titles.</paragraph>

<years>1354/5 - 24 September 1405</years><paragraph>Prokop of Luxembourg, son of John Henry of Luxembourg, was a provincial governor of the kingdom and Margrave of Moravia from 1375 to 1405. Together with his brother Jobst, he was to rule Moravia, but most of the time they fought disputes over succession of the Luxembourg dynasty, which had ambitions to win the Polish and Hungarian crowns.</paragraph><paragraph>After the death of Charles IV, he initially supported the policies of Sigismund of Luxembourg and fought against Wenceslas in the <italic>Margraviate Wars</italic>. But after the Bohemian nobility imprisoned Wenceslas, he became his ally. The relations between the Luxembourgs, Prokop and Jobst illustrate very aptly the intrigues of the time. Jobst and Prokop waged wars against each other for years, only to ally themselves with Wenceslas against Sigismund and then betray the King and side with Rupert of the Palatinate.</paragraph><paragraph>When Sigismund once again kidnapped the King and imprisoned him in 1402, Prokop was also captured as his ally in Pressburg (Bratislava) and held for two years. His illegitimate son George of Luxembourg was the last descendant of the Luxembourg dynasty, who could not inherit any property or titles.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Botschek of Kunstadt, whom the player meets at the council of the lords loyal to King Wenceslas, is a combination of two real men of that name. </paragraph><paragraph>The first was <accent>Botschek of Kunstadt and Podiebrad</accent>, a Moravian nobleman. We know of him that in 1353 he was given the title of a favourite and a royal cup-bearer to Charles IV. Besides Podiebrad and many estates in Moravia, he owned a splendid house in Prague, which the king exempted from all taxes and fees. Later, because of his castle Obřany, he got into a cross with the Moravian margrave and brother of Charles IV, John Henry. After the king's intervention, he had to demolish the castle and reconcile with the margrave. In 1371 he took possession of the important castle of Lititz.</paragraph><paragraph> His son, <accent>Botschek of Kunstadt</accent>, followed in his father's footsteps and became one of the richest and most influential nobles of his time. With his two wives he fathered four sons. The son of the third of them, Victor, was the later famous Czech king George of Podiebrad. </paragraph><paragraph> The Lords of the House of Kunstadt continued until the 16th century, by which time one of the most numerous families had died out.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Botschek of Kunstadt, whom the player meets at a council of lords loyal to King Wenceslas, is a composite of two real men of that name. </paragraph><paragraph>The first was <accent>Botschek of Kunstadt and Podiebrad</accent>, a Moravian nobleman. We know that in 1353 he was given the title of favourite and royal cup-bearer by Charles IV. Besides Podiebrad and many estates in Moravia, he owned a splendid house in Prague, which the king exempted from all taxes and fees. He later clashed with John Henry the Moravian margrave and brother of Charles IV, over his unfinished castle at Obřany. After the king's intervention, he had to demolish the castle and reconcile with the margrave. In 1371 he took possession of the important castle of Lititz.</paragraph><paragraph> His son, <accent>Botschek of Kunstadt</accent>, followed in his father's footsteps and became one of the richest and most influential nobles of his time. With his two wives he fathered four sons. The third of these, Victor, was the father of the famous Czech king George of Podiebrad. </paragraph><paragraph> The House of Kunstadt continued until the 16th century, when having been one of the most numerous families up until then it died out.</paragraph>

<years>February 14 1368 - December 9 1437</years><paragraph>Sigismund of Luxembourg, son of Charles IV and his fourth wife Elizabeth of Pomerania, was king of Hungary and Croatia, then king of Germany, Bohemia and Lombardy.</paragraph><paragraph>His upbringing at the Hungarian court taught him the hard rules of politics. After being abducted by the Hungarian nobility, he hardened towards them and tried to increase his prestige by gaining the imperial title of his brother Wenceslas IV.</paragraph><paragraph>Sigismund was rather positively received by the Bohemian nobility. However, some of them continued to support Wenceslas IV, which sparked a long-lasting war conflict. Sigismund, with the help of Bohemian and Moravian lords and an army reinforced by Cuman mercenaries, pillaged Bohemia in an attempt to destroy Wenceslas' allies. Eventually, however, he was forced to retreat back to Hungary to suppress a noble rebellion there.</paragraph><paragraph>He entered Bohemian history as an erudite, pragmatic ruler. He acted as a defender of Christianity against the expanding Ottoman Empire. After the death of his brother, he fought against the Hussite uprising, which did not acknowledge him as the rightful king and called four unsuccessful crusades against them. He died shortly after them, just after being crowned Roman Emperor and signing agreements with the Hussite reformers.</paragraph>

<years>February 14 1368 - December 9 1437</years><paragraph>Sigismund of Luxembourg, son of Charles IV and his fourth wife Elizabeth of Pomerania, was king of Hungary and Croatia, then king of Germany, Bohemia and Lombardy.</paragraph><paragraph>His upbringing at the Hungarian court taught him the hard rules of politics. After his abduction by Hungarian nobility, he hardened towards them and tried to increase his prestige by gaining the imperial title of his brother Wenceslas IV.</paragraph><paragraph>Sigismund was rather positively received by the Bohemian nobility. However, some of them continued to support Wenceslas IV, which led to a prolonged military conflict. Sigismund, with the help of Bohemian and Moravian lords and an army reinforced by Cuman mercenaries, ravaged Bohemia in an attempt to destroy Wenceslas' allies. Eventually, however, he was forced to retreat back to Hungary to suppress a noble rebellion.</paragraph><paragraph>He entered Bohemian history as an erudite, pragmatic ruler. He acted as a defender of Christianity against the expanding Ottoman Empire. After the death of his brother, he fought against the Hussite uprising, which did not acknowledge him as the rightful king. He called for four unsuccessful crusades against them and died shortly afterwards, just after being crowned Holy Roman Emperor.</paragraph>

<years>February 26 1361 - August 16 1419</years><paragraph> Wenceslas IV, son of Charles IV and brother of Sigismund of Luxembourg, inherited the throne of Bohemia and the Holy Roman Empire, but was not nearly as successful a politician as his father. He was criticised for his rule and behaviour during his lifetime. Although he had been prepared to rule since childhood, he was plagued by many illnesses and later preferred to spend his time entertaining rather than fulfilling his duties.</paragraph><paragraph>This resulted in many conflicts and wars, especially with his relatives. With his cousins Jobst and Prokop of Luxembourg he fought the so-called <italic>Margraviate Wars</italic> over estates in Moravia, and with his brother Sigismund he fought for the kingship. His legitimacy as king was repeatedly questioned by the nobility. Because of his unwillingness to keep his commitments, he was even captured - first by the Bohemian nobility, and then by his brother Sigismund.</paragraph><paragraph>Wenceslas initially supported the reformist proposals of Jan Hus, but later sided with the Pope. In effect, he let the largest civil uprising in Europe - the Hussite Wars - break out, but he did not live to see it, as he died in 1419. After his death, Sigismund took the crown.</paragraph>

<years>26 February 1361 - 16 August 1419</years><paragraph>Wenceslas IV, son of Charles IV and brother of Sigismund of Luxembourg, inherited the throne of Bohemia and the Holy Roman Empire, but was not as efficient a politician as his father. He was criticised for his rule and behaviour during his lifetime. Despite being prepared for leadership since childhood, he was plagued by many illnesses and later preferred spending time in leisure rather than fulfilling his duties.</paragraph><paragraph>This led to many conflicts and wars, especially with his relatives. With his cousins Jobst and Prokop of Luxembourg he fought the so-called <italic>Margraviate Wars</italic> over estates in Moravia, and with his brother Sigismund he fought for sovereignty. His legitimacy as king was repeatedly questioned by the nobility. Because of his unwillingness to keep his commitments, he was even captured - first by the Bohemian nobility, and then by his brother Sigismund.</paragraph><paragraph>Wenceslas initially supported the reformist proposals of Jan Hus, but later sided with the Pope. In effect, he allowed the largest civil uprising in Europe - the Hussite Wars - to break out, which he did not live to see, as he died in 1419. After his death, Sigismund took the crown.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Alchemy was a discipline combining mysticism, hermeneutics, chemistry, physics and many other spheres of learning. Medieval alchemists worked in laboratories, often situated at noblemen's mansions or in Royal cities. They found application in smelters, mints, mines, glass-works and wherever industrial production needed assistance.</paragraph><paragraph>The work of <accent>alchemists</accent> was challenging and costly, and so required the support of patrons. Successful alchemists earned wealth and fame, while the unsuccessful ended up in prison or were sentenced to death. Two fundamental alchemical objectives persisted through the entirety of the Middle Ages: to find the mystical "philosopher's stone" and to transmute base metals into gold.</paragraph><paragraph> In KCD we use a genuine preserved alchemical laboratory as our model, though the actual potion brewing has been modified a bit. Instead of processing mercury and sulphur, our alchemists work mainly with herbs, just like herbalists and other folk healers would do.<paragraph>

<paragraph>Alchemy was a discipline combining mysticism, hermeticism, chemistry, physics and many other spheres of learning. Medieval alchemists worked in laboratories, often situated at noble mansions or in Royal cities. They found employment in smelters, mints, mines, glass-works and wherever industrial production needed assistance.</paragraph><paragraph>The work of <accent>alchemists</accent> was challenging and costly, so it required the support of patrons. Successful alchemists earned wealth and fame, while the unsuccessful ended up in prison or were sentenced to death. Two fundamental alchemical objectives persisted through the entirety of the Middle Ages: to find the mystical "philosopher's stone", and to transmute base metals into gold.</paragraph><paragraph> In KCD, we use a genuine preserved alchemical laboratory as our model, though the actual potion brewing has been modified. Instead of processing mercury and sulphur, our alchemists work mainly with herbs, just like herbalists and other folk healers would.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A local legend says that Apollonia was the daughter of a wealthy landowner who fell in love with a poor boy. Her father was against it, so he arranged for her beloved to be conscripted into the army for seven years, where he also lost his life. When Apollonia learned of this, she went mad with grief and left for parts unknown. Her mother later found her in a sick and wretched state in a cave in a rock town, which the girl now called her home. The girl refused to come home and died in her arms.</paragraph><paragraph>This is not a “town” in the true sense of the word, but a complex system of sandstone rock formations near the <accent>Trosky</accent> castle and the village of <accent>Troskowitz</accent>.<paragraph></paragraph>There are many paths between the rocks and caves under the rocks, and there have been many exiles or people on the edge of society throughout history who have found refuge here, just like the villagers when an enemy army approached.</paragraph><paragraph> Due to the great devastation of the weathered sandstone, public access has been completely restricted and the site has become a protected nature reserve. Visitors can, however, visit other very similar rock towns that are literally peppered throughout <accent>Bohemian Paradise</accent>.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A local legend says that Apollonia was the daughter of a wealthy landowner who fell in love with a poor boy. Her father was against it, so he arranged for her beloved to be conscripted into the army for seven years, where he lost his life. When Apollonia learned of this, she went mad with grief and left for parts unknown. Her mother later found her, sick and emaciated in a cave in a rock town, which the girl now called home. The girl refused to come home and died in her arms.</paragraph><paragraph>This is not a 'town' in the true sense of the word, but a complex system of sandstone rock formations near the <accent>Trosky</accent> castle and the village of <accent>Troskowitz</accent>.<paragraph></paragraph>Many paths wind through the rocks with caves underneath them that historically provided refuge for outcasts and exiles, as well as villagers seeking shelter from approaching armies.</paragraph><paragraph>Due to severe erosion of the weathered sandstone, public access has been completely restricted and the site has become a protected nature reserve. Visitors can, however, visit other very similar rock towns that are peppered throughout the so called <accent>Bohemian Paradise</accent>.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The apothecary prepared medication according to a carefully studied prescriptions that were passed down the generations. It was one of the few professions that was not organized into guilds.</paragraph><paragraph>The production of medicaments was quite hard work and a great responsibility. The apothecary had to have studied at the University and would be schooled not only in Latin, but also in Greek, had to be able to carefully measure out precise dosages of medication and to ensure the ingredients were always available.</paragraph><paragraph>If there was no apothecary in town, there would be the monastery infirmary. And if that was not available, people turned to the services of herb-women, lay herbalists, quack healers or medicasters, called <italic>charlatans</italic>. Their methods of healing were controversial, because in making lotions and potions they made use not only of herbs, but of spells, amulets and sometimes even very unusual raw materials such as ‘frog poison' or ‘hanged man's finger'.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The <accent>apothecary</accent> prepared medicines according to carefully studied prescriptions that were passed down through generations. It was one of the few professions that were not organized into guilds.</paragraph><paragraph>Making medicines was a difficult job and carried a lot of responsibility. An apothecary had to be university-educated and knowledgeable not only in Latin but also in Greek, and had to be able to carefully measure exact doses of medicines and ensure that ingredients were always available.</paragraph><paragraph>If there was no apothecary in town, a monastic hospital would be available. And if neither was available, people would use the services of wise women, folk herbalists, and lay healers or ointment makers, who were called <italic>charlatans</italic>. Their methods of treatment were controversial because, in addition to making elixirs and ointments, they used not only herbs but also spells, amulets, and sometimes very unusual ingredients such as “frog venom” or “a hanged man's finger.”</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Second Lateran Council (1139) forbade priests from wearing luxurious clothing, nuns from singing alongside monks, and good Christians from using crossbows against other Christians and Catholics.</paragraph> <paragraph>The crossbow was dubbed a <accent>diabolical weapon</accent> (in Latin, <italic>arma diaboli</italic>) because it could easily pierce even the strongest armour of the time and, unlike the bow, a hit from it almost guaranteed death. However, the crossbow continued to be used and improved. The original wooden limbs were gradually replaced by stronger (and stiffer) composite limbs, and eventually by steel. Along with these developments came the introduction of several new drawing mechanisms, ranging from human arm power to levers and windlasses.</paragraph> <paragraph>Even the strongest crossbow, however, could not pierce high-quality steel breastplates and ultimately the title of the most lethal weapon passed to firearms.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Second Lateran Council (1139) forbade priests from wearing luxurious clothing, nuns from singing alongside monks, and good Christians from using crossbows against other Christians and Catholics.</paragraph> <paragraph>The crossbow was dubbed a <accent>diabolical weapon</accent> (in Latin, <italic>arma diaboli</italic>) because it could easily pierce even the strongest armour of the time and, unlike the bow, a hit from it almost guaranteed death. However, the crossbow continued to be used and improved. The original wooden limbs were gradually replaced by stronger (and stiffer) composite limbs, and eventually by steel. Along with these developments came the introduction of several new drawing mechanisms, ranging from human arm power to levers and windlasses.</paragraph> <paragraph>Even the strongest crossbow, however, could not pierce high-quality steel breastplates and ultimately the title of the most lethal weapon passed to firearms.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, alchemy and apothecary were naturally linked with astrology, which was regarded as applied astronomy.</paragraph><paragraph>Since ancient times, <accent>fate</accent> had been considered the expression of divine will, emanating from the heavens and giving mankind signs in the constellations of stars and planets. Indeed, the Arabs and Ancient Greeks had made tables, schemes and catalogues of stars and constellations, as well as calendars used for navigation.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>movement of celestial bodies</accent> had an influence on political issues, on decisions about war or marriage. Even medical treatment, food preparation or tasks associated with agriculture were deemed to be subject to celestial mechanics. Based on the constellations, every person was assigned a <accent>sign of the Zodiac</accent>, which determined his health, career and even social relationships throughout his life.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Astrologers</accent> used many devices in their work, such as astrolabes, sextants, quadrants, sundials and other devices for accurate monitoring of the skies. Unlike today, astrology was a highly regarded and respected science and many astronomers of that time were also astrologers.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, alchemy and apothecary were naturally linked with astrology, which was regarded as applied astronomy.</paragraph><paragraph>Since ancient times, <accent>fate</accent> had been considered the expression of divine will, emanating from the heavens and giving mankind signs in the constellations of stars and planets. Indeed, the Arabs and Ancient Greeks had made tables, overviews and catalogues of stars and constellations, as well as calendars used for navigation.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>movement of celestial bodies</accent> had an influence on political issues, on decisions about war or marriage. Even medical treatment, food preparation or tasks associated with agriculture were deemed to be subject to celestial mechanics. Based on the constellations, every person was assigned a <accent>sign of the Zodiac</accent>, which determined his health, career and even social relationships throughout his life.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Astrologers</accent> used many devices in their work, such as astrolabes, sextants, quadrants, sundials and other devices for accurate monitoring of the skies. Unlike today, astrology was a highly regarded and respected science and many astronomers of that time were also astrologers.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Although everyone in the village would know how to make bread and flapcakes, in the larger cities and noblemen's residences, there were bakers.</paragraph><paragraph>Initially the term baker referred not so much to the man who baked, but the one who took the pastries to market. Over time, they specialized in the baking itself and acquired guild status, which, of course led to the rights disputes, because the bakers objected to pastries and bread being sold at markets by country-folk not in the guild. It was only later that the regulations were laid down to make the sale of bread the exclusive domain of the guilds.</paragraph><paragraph>The quality of baked goods was supervised by Councillors, or the municipal mesurier. If the flour was bad, they didn't like its colour or the baker scrimped on weight, he was fined. If there were recurrences, he was expelled from the guild and made to suffer cruel physical punishment. Apparently King Wenceslaus himself used to go to the municipal market to oversee the quality of Prague baked goods, and punished dishonest bakers by publicly dunking them in the Vltava River.</paragraph><paragraph>The bakers often owned their own mills, whilst not encroaching on the millers' craft.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Although everyone in the village would know how to make bread and flat breads, there were bakers in the larger towns and noble courts.</paragraph><paragraph>Initially the term 'baker' referred not so much to the person who baked, but the one who took the baked goods to market. Over time, they specialised in baking itself and acquired guild status, which, of course led to rights disputes, because the bakers resented baked goods being sold at markets by non-guild villagers. It was only later that regulations were laid down to make the sale of bread the exclusive domain of the guilds.</paragraph><paragraph>The quality of baked goods was supervised by Councillors, or the municipal measurer. If the flour was bad, they didn't like its colour or the baker gave short weight, he was fined. If there were recurrences, he was expelled from the guild and subjected to harsh physical punishment. It is said that King Wenceslas himself used to visit the town market to inspect the quality of Prague baked goods, and punished dishonest bakers by publicly dunking them in the Vltava River.</paragraph><paragraph>The bakers often owned their own mills, which encroached on the millers' craft.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Where hygiene and bathing was not up to scratch, the public baths were on the rise. Public baths in central Europe came in from about the 12th century. There were baths quite literally in every town, and not just in small numbers. Sometimes a town would have three to four bathhouses.</paragraph><paragraph>Here, people had access to hot water: for bathing or steam baths. In those times, steam was produced by pouring water onto heated bars of iron or stones. Bodily cleanliness was in the care of male and female bathing assistants, overall washing was done in bath tubs, coopered wooden vats and tanks.</paragraph><paragraph>In Bohemia, there were baths in operation since the early Middle Ages and their numbers rose steadily. In Prague in the second half of the 14th century there were 47 public baths and by the 15th century the baths were attended not just by the better off, but also by the poorer social strata. There was even a regulation that the bath-keepers had to open their doors once a quarter to the poor and to students.</paragraph><paragraph>Bathhouses typically belonged to the municipality, and were leased to the bath-keepers. In addition to municipal and private baths, there were also private baths in the houses of the nobility and wealthy townspeople.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 13th and 14th century, the bath-houses were very much associated with prostitution. In the 13th century particularly, bath-house prostitution became widespread and there were scarcely any that did not provide sexual services. In the richer urban baths there would also be pharmacists, massage therapists, boiler stokers and cleaners. In the villages the bath-house keeper had to do all the jobs himself.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Wherever hygiene, and thus baths were lacking, public baths became popular. Public baths in Central Europe appeared from about the 12th century. Every town had them, often in significant numbers. Sometimes a town would have three to four bathhouses.</paragraph><paragraph>Here, people had access to hot water for bathing or steam baths. In those times, steam was produced by pouring water onto heated iron or stones. Body cleanliness was taken care of by male and female bath attendants. Overall body washing was done in bath tubs, coopered wooden vats and tanks.</paragraph><paragraph>In Bohemia, there were baths in operation since the early Middle Ages and their numbers rose steadily. There were 47 public baths in Prague in the second half of the 14th century and by the 15th century the baths were attended not just by the well-to-do, but also by the poorer classes. There was even a regulation that the bath-keepers had to open their doors once a quarter to the poor and to students.</paragraph><paragraph>Bathhouses typically belonged to the municipality, and were leased to the bath-keepers. In addition to municipal and private baths, there were also private baths in the houses of the nobility and wealthy townspeople.</paragraph><paragraph></paragraph><paragraph>In the 13th and 14th century, the bath-houses were very much associated with prostitution. In the 13th century particularly, bath-house prostitution became widespread and there were scarcely any that did not provide sexual services. In the richer urban baths there would also be pharmacists, masseurs, stokers and cleaners. In the villages the bath-house keeper had to do all these jobs himself.</paragraph>

<paragraph>During the Middle Ages, bee-keeping was distinguished by how the honey was obtained, as either forest or domestic. The domestic bee-keeper kept bees in hollow trees or in straw skeps (wickerwork hives) and were not subject to any regulation. Conversely, the forest bee-keeper, called <italic>'brtník'</italic>, kept bee colonies ‘in the wild' in a hollowed-out trees. The forest bee-keepers formed a fellowship similar to a guild and paid a fee to the owners of the woodland for every bee colony they took over.</paragraph><paragraph>Beeswax was the main raw material for the production of candles right until artificial wax (paraffin wax) was invented. Honey was used as a sweetener, and fermented to make mead.</paragraph>

<paragraph>During the Middle Ages, beekeeping was distinguished by how the honey was obtained, as either forest or domestic.</paragraph><paragraph>The domestic beekeeper kept bees in hollow trees or in straw skeps (wickerwork hives) and were not subject to any regulation. Conversely, the forest beekeeper, called <italic>'brtník'</italic>, kept hives ‘in the wild' in hollowed-out trees. The forest beekeepers formed a fellowship similar to a guild and paid a fee to the owners of the woodland for each hive they managed.</paragraph><paragraph>Beeswax was the main raw material for the production of candles up until the discovery of artificial wax (paraffin wax). Honey was used as a sweetener, and fermented to make mead. </paragraph>

<paragraph>The word <italic>bezoar</italic> originates from Persian and means <italic>protection against poison</italic>. Known as a <italic>bezoar stone</italic>, it is an animal formation created from indigestible food remnants and other materials in the stomach of herbivores or omnivores. Gradually accumulated and compressed residues form a ball the size of a pea or sometimes even an egg. The largest specimens have been found in the intestines of chamois, gazelles and camels.</paragraph><paragraph>Since ancient times, it was believed that this formation possessed magical healing properties. It was used either ground into powder or soaked in liquid and was considered a powerful remedy against various poisons, nausea, pain, digestive disorders, epilepsy and even evil spirits.</paragraph><paragraph>Thus, in the Middle Ages, bezoars attracted the attention of the wealthy and were often set into gold, richly decorated jewellery or other everyday objects.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The word <italic>bezoar</italic> originates from Persian and means <italic>protection against poison</italic>. Known as a <italic>bezoar stone</italic>, it is an animal formation created from indigestible food remnants and other materials in the stomach of herbivores or omnivores. Gradually accumulated and compressed residues form a ball the size of a pea or sometimes even an egg. The largest specimens have been found in the intestines of chamois, gazelles and camels.</paragraph><paragraph>Since ancient times, it was believed that this formation possessed magical healing properties. It was used either ground into powder or soaked in liquid and was considered a powerful remedy against various poisons, nausea, pain, digestive disorders, epilepsy and even evil spirits.</paragraph><paragraph>Thus, in the Middle Ages, bezoars attracted the attention of the wealthy and were often set into gold, richly decorated jewellery or other everyday objects.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Smithing has been one of the most important professions since ancient times, as iron was a very valuable raw material. At that time it was not mined, but only collected in opencast mines - nothing was allowed to go to waste, and people even kept used nails.</paragraph><paragraph>The blacksmith was located in every large outpost or village and made almost everything needed for agriculture (knife, axe, grain sickle, but also plough, ploughshare, etc.). Some blacksmiths specialized in swords, helmets, spears, harness forging, smokes, locks or jewelry.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>forge</accent> was most often a shelter with a wall. Their essential equipment included a large bellows, anvil, pliers, hammer, punches, files, etc. In a well-equipped forge, a blacksmith could develop a heat of up to 1400°C.</paragraph><paragraph>It is worth mentioning that the Romani blacksmiths carried the whole forge with them during their nomadic journeys, and a fireplace and basic tools were enough to shoe their horses or make minor repairs to their tools.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Blacksmithing has been one of the most important professions since ancient times, as iron was a very valuable raw material. At that time it was not mined, but rather collected in opencast mines - nothing was allowed to go to waste, and people even kept used nails.</paragraph><paragraph>Blacksmiths were located in every large outpost or village and made almost everything needed for agriculture (knife, axe, grain sickle, but also ploughs, harrows, etc.). Some blacksmiths specialized in swords, helmets, spears, harness fittings, snaffle bits, locks or jewelry.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>forge</accent> was most often a shelter with a wall. Their essential equipment included a large bellows, anvil, pliers, hammer, punches, files, etc. In a well-equipped forge, a blacksmith could develop a heat of up to 1400°C.</paragraph><paragraph>It is worth mentioning that the Romani blacksmiths carried the whole forge with them during their nomadic journeys, and a fireplace and basic tools were enough for shoeing horses or making minor repairs to their tools.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Religious services in the Middle Ages were held quietly and in Latin. A Middle Age <accent>mass</accent> differed from today's in its language, approach and the relationship between the priest and the congregation.</paragraph><paragraph>People stood or moved around, while the priest said the liturgy alone, without servers, without a sermon and without Communion. He stood with his back to the congregation, facing the main altar at a distance from the faithful. The <accent>sermon</accent> was held quite apart from the mass in keeping with a special rite and in between services of worship. Holy Communion (the <italic>Eucharist</italic>) was available to the common folk only at Christmas and Easter.</paragraph><paragraph>The inaccessibility of the sacred ritual, along with disgust at the state of the Church, later led to the revolutionary Hussite reform movement, which opened up both the mass and the Eucharist rites to the wider populace.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Religious services in the Middle Ages were held quietly and in Latin. A Middle Age <accent>mass</accent> differed from today's in its language, approach and the relationship between the priest and the congregation.</paragraph><paragraph>People stood or moved around, while the priest conducted the liturgy alone, without acolytes or sermons and without Communion. He stood with his back to the congregation, facing the main altar at a distance from the faithful. The <accent>sermon</accent> was held quite apart from the mass in keeping with a special rite and in between services of worship. Holy Communion (the <italic>Eucharist</italic>) was available to the common folk only at Christmas and Easter.</paragraph><paragraph>The inaccessibility of the sacred ritual, along with disgust at the state of the Church, later led to the revolutionary Hussite reform movement, which opened up both the mass and the Eucharist rites to the wider populace.</paragraph>

<paragraph>During the high Middle Ages new elements of combat techniques as well as weapons and armour were coming into their own. The curved sabre grew in popularity and chain mail gave way to plate armour. Knights took to heavier longswords, crossbows and strike weapons, such as maces, flails etc.</paragraph><paragraph>A complete suit of armour was affordable only for a wealthy nobleman. Most often the armour worn was only of partial metal cover, more reliance being given to good combat technique for protection.</paragraph><paragraph>Accordingly, sword-fighting developed in two directions:</paragraph><paragraph>a) <accent>knightly swordsmanship</accent> – fought with a spear, sword and shield in full heavy armour</paragraph><paragraph>b) <accent>commoner swordsmanship</accent> – for lightly armoured footsoldiers, who fought with swords and home-made weapons, e.g. daggers, flails, scythes and bludgeons.</paragraph><paragraph>In combat between the lightly armoured and the ironclads it was often swiftness, agility and cunning that made the difference. Hence swordplay drew interest in the poorer echelons of society. Over time, they gained their skills in swordfighting schools. The training was not very professional, based more on agility, readiness and use of all and any advantageous resources available apart from weapons.</paragraph><paragraph>Accurate period descriptions of battles are lacking, so historians rely on records preserved in the literature or illustrated material.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the High Middle Ages, new elements of combat techniques and weapons and armour emerged. Curved sabres became popular, and chainmail was replaced by plate armour. Knights preferred heavier swords, crossbows, and impact weapons such as maces and flails.</paragraph><paragraph>Only wealthy nobles could afford full armour. Usually, only partial metal armour was worn, and more than for protection, the focus was on combat technique.</paragraph><paragraph>For this reason, swordfighting developed in two ways: </paragraph><paragraph>a) <accent>knightly swordsmanship</accent> – fighting with a spear, sword, and shield in full heavy armour</paragraph><paragraph>b) <accent>common swordsmanship</accent> – for lightly armoured fighters who fought with swords and common weapons such as falchions, flails, scythes, staffs, etc.</paragraph><paragraph>In battles between lightly armoured and heavily armoured fighters, speed, agility, and cleverness often won. Therefore, swordplay also interested the poorer parts of society. They gradually started to be educated in swordfighting schools. The training was not very professional, being based more on dexterity, readiness, and the use of various available means besides weapons.</paragraph><paragraph>Precise contemporary descriptions of duels are lacking, so historians rely on mentions in literature or preserved visual material.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Apart from resolution by municipal or territorial courts of justice, up to the 14th century it was common (though unofficial) in Bohemia to turn to <italic>God's judgement</italic>, or <italic>trial by ordeal</italic>. Guilt or innocence was proved by appealing to God – He had to judge guilt or innocence.</paragraph><paragraph>A typical ordeal was the test by fire, hot water, poison or duelling with the counterparty. The trial often ended in injury or even the death of the accused or the accuser.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Besides being judged by municipal or regional courts, in the Czech lands up to the 14th century, it was also common (though unofficial) to use so-called <italic>trial by ordeal</italic>. Guilt or innocence was determined by appealing to God – who was supposed to judge the guilt or innocence.</paragraph><paragraph>A typical ordeal might involve a trial by fire, hot water, poison, or combat with the opposing party. The trial often ended with injury or even the death of the accused or the opponent.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Duchy of Brabant was a geopolitical county, located in the historic Netherlands, on the territory between the Senne and Dender rivers.</paragraph><paragraph>Its founding was decided in 1183, by Frederick I Barbarossa, the Holy Roman Emperor at the time. He elevated Count Henry I of Brabant, to the position of Duke of the Brabant Landgraviate. This political decision was intended to resolve the administrative confusion with the imperial fiefdom, that had arisen after the death of the previous Count of Brabant, Hermann II.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1430, Philip III the Good, inherited the duchy, which became part of the Burgundian Netherlands, along with Limburg and Lower Lotharingia, and then from 1482, part of the Habsburg Netherlands.</paragraph><paragraph>At the end of the 16th century, the <accent>Dutch Revolt</accent> brought about the division of the territory of the Duchy of Brabant between the Netherlands and Belgium.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Duchy of Brabant was a geopolitical county, located in the historic Netherlands, on the territory between the rivers Zenne and Dender.</paragraph><paragraph>Its founding was decided in 1183, by Frederick I Barbarossa, the Holy Roman Emperor at the time. He elevated Count Henry I of Brabant, to the position of Duke of the Brabant Landgraviate.
