This political decision was intended to resolve the administrative confusion with the imperial fiefdom, that had arisen after the death of the previous Count of Brabant, Hermann II.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1430, Philip III the Good, inherited the duchy, which became part of the Burgundian Netherlands, along with Limburg and Lower Lotharingia, and then from 1482, part of the Habsburg Netherlands.</paragraph><paragraph></paragraph><paragraph>At the end of the 16th century, the <accent>Dutch Revolt</accent> brought about the division of the territory of the Duchy of Brabant between the Netherlands and Belgium.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In 1384, thanks to the financial support from the bequest of the townsman Heinlin Perksmid, the Kuttenberg Brotherhood of Corpus Christi was founded. Its predecessor was a similar brootherhood founded earlier in Prague.</paragraph><paragraph>The Brotherhood convinced the elite of Kuttenberg that by financially supporting the construction of religious buildings such as chapels, churches, hospitals, or at least altars, it would secure a permanent and respected position in the town. In this way, the townspeople could supposedly gain not only social recognition but also heavenly salvation.</paragraph><paragraph>Until then, the Sedletz Monastery decided on all church buildings in Kuttenberg, as well as on burial places or the choice of patrons. However, the members of the brotherhood decided, to the dislike of the Abbot of Sedletz, to first build a chapel dedicated to the cult of their choice, and then they planned to begin construction of a new temple to serve as a parish church, that would also ensure independence at the monastery in Sedletz.</paragraph><paragraph>The members of the Brotherhood of Corpus Christi were mostly townspeople, members of important Kuttenberg families such as the Kauffmanns, Polners, Rosenthals, Naazes and Piseks. Sources also mention four priests whose participation ensured the townsmen proper spiritual legitimacy.</paragraph><paragraph>The brotherhood was able to obtain funds and papal indulgences for the building of the temple thanks to its ties with the Prague Canons and the Prague Chapter. This allowed the members to make decisions on spiritual matters, while at the same time defend their other interests of power.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In 1384, thanks to the financial support from the bequest of the townsman Heinlin Perksmid, the Kuttenberg religious brotherhood of Corpus Christi was founded. It was modeled after a similar brotherhood founded earlier in Prague.</paragraph><paragraph>The brotherhood convinced the elite of Kuttenberg that by financially supporting the construction of religious buildings such as chapels, churches, hospitals, or at least altars, they would secure a lasting and respected position in the city. According to their beliefs, through these means, the burghers could gain not only societal recognition but also heavenly salvation.</paragraph><paragraph>Up until then, decisions regarding all church buidings in Kuttenberg were made by the Sedletz Monastery, as well as on burial places or the choice of patrons. However, to the displeasure of the abbot of Sedletz, the members of the brotherhood decided to first build a chapel dedicated to the cult they had chosen themselves. They then planned to begin construction of a new parish church which would also ensure independence from the monastery.</paragraph><paragraph>The members of the brotherhood were mostly townspeople, members of important Kuttenberg families such as the Kauffmanns, Polners, Rosenthals, Naazes and Piseks. Sources also mention four priests whose participation ensured the townsmen's proper spiritual legitimacy.</paragraph><paragraph>The brotherhood obtained funds and papal indulgences for the building of the temple thanks to its ties with the Prague Canons and the Prague Chapter. This enabled the members to influence spiritual matters, while at the same time defending their other power interests.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Butcher's professions appears only in the 13th century, because prior to this each townsman or villager would butcher cattle in their own back yard. In later centuries this led to conflicts with the professional butchers, leading to the sale and importation of meat being brought under statute with regard to guild rights.</paragraph><paragraph>The main tasks of a butcher was to slaughter cattle, to carve and portion up and preserve the meat outside the city. Raw meat was not allowed into the city, selling from home was severely punished – which was intended to prevent the spread of diseases, in particular, from out-of-date or poorly treated meat. Incoming butchers often had to slaughter cattle only once it was at market.</paragraph><paragraph>In time, the butchers' guild split into different specializations, such as those who worked only with lard and suet (tallow butchers), then small cut specialists, cured meats specialists or those dealing in horns, hooves and mucilage. The butcher's craft also spawned tanners, saddlers and cobblers.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The profession of butcher appeared only in the 13th century, because prior to this each townsman or villager could raise and butcher livestock on his own land. In later centuries this led to conflicts with professional butchers, leading to the trade of meat being brought under statute with regard to guild rights.</paragraph><paragraph>The main tasks of a butcher were to slaughter animals, cut up meat and preserve it outside the town limits. Raw meat was not allowed to be brought into the town and domestic sale was severely punished. These measures were intended to prevent the spread of disease from old or badly processed meat. Butchers from other areas often had to slaughter cattle directly at the market.</paragraph><paragraph>In time, the butchers' guild split into different specializations, such as those who worked only with lard and suet (tallow butchers), small cut specialists, cured meats specialists and those dealing in horns, hooves and mucilage. The butcher's craft also spawned tanners, saddlers and cobblers.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A settlement 1.5 km southwest of Kuttenberg built along Bylanka Creek.</paragraph><paragraph>According to archaeological findings, the history of the local settlement dates back to the New Stone Age (about 4000 BC). The first written mention of the village is from 1143, when Miroslav of Zimburg donated it to the Sedletz Monastery. The village later passed from the monastery into private hands and often changed owners.</paragraph><paragraph>The Spring of St Adalbert (pramen sv. Vojtěcha), which supplied the whole of Kuttenberg through wooden pipes starting in the Middle Ages, is located near the village.</paragraph><paragraph>To this day, massive cinder heaps lie in the village along the Bylanka Creek. These are relics of medieval mining, when they brought surplus and waste material here from the nearby mines.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A settlement 1.5 km southwest of Kuttenberg built along Bylanka creek.</paragraph><paragraph>According to archaeological findings, the history of the local settlement dates back to the New Stone Age (about 4,000 BC). The first written mention of the village is from 1143, when Miroslav of Zimburg donated it to the Sedletz Monastery. The village later passed from the monastery into private hands and often changed owners.</paragraph><paragraph>Near the village is the Spring of St Adalbert (pramen sv. Vojtěcha), which supplied the whole of Kuttenberg through wooden pipes, starting in the Middle Ages.</paragraph><paragraph>To this day, massive slag heaps lie in the village along the Bylanka creek. These are remnants of medieval mining, when surplus and waste material from nearby mines was deposited here.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Herbs played an important role not only in medieval cuisine, but also as the foundation of the healing arts. Knowledge about herbs was disseminated either by word of mouth (between herb-women in the country), or between monks and scholars via ancient scripts.</paragraph><paragraph>Many herbs could be taken in the form of teas, <accent>concoctions</accent> (by prolonged cooking), <accent>infusions</accent> (in scalding water), as <accent>extracts</accent> (macerated), <accent>tinctures</accent> (alcohol-leached) or steeped in vinegar, juices or concentrates for gargling. Adding honey or sugar did nothing for the efficacy of herbal salves, but it did help them go down better.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to ingestion, herbs were applied in the form of <accent>creams</accent>, <accent>ointments</accent>, <accent>poultices</accent> or <accent>oils</accent>, dissolved in water. In certain cases the advice was to sleep on cushions filled with dried plants.</paragraph><paragraph>It was believed (especially in rural areas), that the properties of the herbs were affected by the particulars of when and how they were gathered (for example on Saint John's Eve, at midnight etc.) accompanied by special formulaic incantations or enchantments.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Herbs played an important role not only in medieval cuisine but also formed the basis of herbal medicine. Knowledge about them spread either through oral tradition (herbalists in rural areas) or among monks and scholars from ancient texts.</paragraph> <paragraph>Many herbs could be administered as teas, <accent>decoctions</accent> (long cooking), <accent>infusions</accent> (steeping in hot water), <accent>extracts</accent> (cold maceration), <accent>tinctures</accent> (soaking in alcohol), steeped in vinegar, juice, or concentrates for gargling. Adding honey or sugar did not enhance the effectiveness of herbal products but improved their taste.</paragraph> <paragraph>In addition to internal use, herbs were applied in the form of <accent>creams</accent>, <accent>ointments</accent>, <accent>compresses</accent>, or <accent>oils</accent>, dissolved in water. Sometimes it was recommended to sleep on pillows filled with dried plants.</paragraph> <paragraph>It was believed (especially in rural areas) that the properties of herbs were influenced by the time and occasion of their harvesting (e.g., on Midsummer's Eve, at midnight, etc.) and the use of special incantations.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Czech lands, any practices (especially by women) connected with magic that were intended to harm rather than help were regarded as witchcraft. In the early Middle Ages, witchcraft was differentiated into <italic>white</italic> magic – beneficial and associated with healing, and <italic>black</italic> magic – curses, hexes and abuse of magic for iniquitous purposes. Magic encompassed divination, necromancy, alchemy, herbalism, entrenched pagan customs and rituals, which had originally constituted an integral part of medieval society.</paragraph><paragraph> By the end of the 15th century, efforts to eradicate witchcraft culminated in senseless witch-hunts and persecution of anyone involved with magic. The persecutions peaked around the end of the 16th century, when hundreds of people fell victim to the zeal of the witch-hunters.</paragraph><paragraph>Many superstitions and half-truths have arisen concerning <accent>witchcraft</accent>, as well as the <accent>Inquisition</accent>, though only a few are grounded in truth.</paragraph><paragraph>Although many were convicted and condemned during the period, most of those accused of heresy or witchcraft got off unscathed. On the contrary, it was often those who had denounced them, with acquisitive intent, and whose accusations proved to be false who were punished. More people fell prey to lynch mobs and fanatical self-proclaimed inquisitors than to institutionalized witch-burnings.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Czech lands, any practices connected with magic that were intended to harm rather than help (especially by women) were regarded as witchcraft. In the early Middle Ages, witchcraft was divided into white magic – beneficial and associated with healing, and black magic – curses, hexes and abuse of magic for iniquitous purposes. Magic included divination, necromancy, alchemy, herbalism, and entrenched pagan customs and rituals, which had originally constituted an integral part of medieval society.</paragraph><paragraph> By the end of the 15th century, efforts to eradicate witchcraft culminated in senseless witch-hunts and persecution of anyone involved with magic. The persecutions peaked around the end of the 16th century, when hundreds of people fell victim to the zeal of the witch-hunters.</paragraph><paragraph>As well as the Inquisition, many superstitions and half-truths have arisen concerning witchcraft, though only a few are grounded in truth. Although many were convicted and condemned during the period, most of those accused of heresy or witchcraft escaped unscathed. On the contrary, it was often those who had denounced them, with covetous intent, and whose accusations proved to be false, who were punished. More people fell prey to lynch mobs and fanatical self-proclaimed inquisitors than to institutionalized witch-burnings.</paragraph>

<paragraph><accent>Carpenters</accent> were engaged in the construction of castles, courts, churches, bridges, dwellings, but also when making rough-hewn furniture or siege contraptions. Although construction in the Middle Ages did include brick buildings, the residential houses or utility structures were still made of wood, so the carpenters were kept busy.</paragraph><paragraph>A master carpenter would guard his art carefully and pas on his knowledge only to a chosen colleague, typically, to his own son. He would be particularly wary of his own journeymen. Important work, such as the drafting of roof structures would be done in seclusion. The most challenging jobs were the preparation of Gothic roof trusses and beams – they finished beams weighed hundreds of kilograms, and the technology at their disposal made their work onerous and dangerous, too.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Joiners</accent>, like carpenters, worked with wood. They mainly made furniture (chests, cabinets, chairs, cradles, …). They made their planks either very painstakingly by hand from fallen trees, or the ‘more modern' way on water-driven sawmills where the watercourse was deployed to power an automatically driven saw-blade.</paragraph>

<paragraph><accent>Carpenters</accent> were involved in the construction of castles, courts, churches, bridges, dwellings, and even in making rough furniture or military trebuchets. Although stone buildings were already being constructed in the Middle Ages, residential houses and farm buildings were still made of wood, ensuring that carpenters always had plenty of work.</paragraph><paragraph>An experienced carpenter carefully guarded his skills and passed them on only to a chosen colleague, usually his son. He was particularly cautious with his apprentices. Important tasks, such as drawing roof plans, were always performed by the master carpenter himself. Among the most challenging tasks was preparing Gothic roofs or trusses – the individual frames, which could weigh hundreds of kilograms, made the work both difficult and dangerous due to the techniques used.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Joiners</accent> worked similarly with wood like carpenters. They mainly focused on furniture production (chests, cabinets, chairs, cradles…). Boards were either laboriously sawn by hand from felled trees or more "modernly" at water-powered sawmills, where a diverted river stream was used to automatically drive the saw blade.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The early Gothic buildings in Bohemia drew inspiration from France and the Rhineland. Among the earliest were the monastery in Předklášteří by Tišnov, South Moravia, the chapter house in Osek, North Bohemia, the monastery of St Agnes in Prague and many parish churches and monasteries such as those in Kolin and Kouřim in Central Bohemia.</paragraph><paragraph>At the turn of the 13th and 14th centuries, Czech architecture diverged from its western counterparts. There was a burgeoning of Cistercian monasteries, e.g. in Zlatá Koruna and Vyšší Brod in South Bohemia, and churches and castles, e.g. Bezděz, North Bohemia. The <accent>High Gothic</accent> period was in full swing during the time of Charles IV and Wenceslas IV, with its rectangular windows and portals, rayonnant traceries and quadripartite or sexpartite, or cross-ribbed vaulting.</paragraph><paragraph>The most significant buildings of that time are University of Prague, St Vitus Cathedral, Charles Bridge, Prague Old Town Hall and New Town Hall, stone houses in Prague and the castles of Karlštejn, Kost and Kašperk.</paragraph><paragraph>We find the first records of construction works fellowships: the most famous are those of Master Peter Parler and his family, and Matthias of Arras, who also worked on the reconstruction of Sasau Monastery.</paragraph><paragraph>New castles no longer served just a defensive function, but were also intended to serve as sovereign residences. They were therefore more spacious and elaborate and had extensive gardens.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Early Gothic buildings in Bohemia were inspired by France and the Rhineland. Among the earliest were the monastery in Předklášteří near Tišnov, South Moravia, the chapter house in Osek, North Bohemia, the monastery of St Agnes in Prague and many parish churches and monasteries such as those in Kolin and Kouřim in Central Bohemia.</paragraph><paragraph>At the turn of the 13th and 14th centuries, Czech architecture diverged from its western counterparts. There was a burgeoning of Cistercian monasteries, e.g. in Zlatá Koruna and Vyšší Brod in South Bohemia, and churches and castles, e.g. Bezděz, North Bohemia. The <accent>High Gothic</accent> period was ushered in during the time of Charles IV and Wenceslas IV, with its rectangular windows and portals, rayonnant traceries and quadripartite, sexpartite, or cross-ribbed vaulting.</paragraph><paragraph>The most significant buildings of that time include Charles University, St Vitus Cathedral, Charles Bridge, Prague Old Town Hall and New Town Hall, stone houses in Prague and the castles of Karlštejn, Kost and Kašperk.</paragraph><paragraph>Records of <accent>construction work</accent> fellowships first appear during this time: the most famous are those of Master Peter Parler and his family, and Matthias of Arras, who also worked on the reconstruction of Sasau Monastery.</paragraph><paragraph>New castles no longer served just a defensive function, but were also intended to serve as royal residences. They were therefore more spacious and elaborate and had extensive gardens.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Chorts are the inhabitants of hell from myths and fairly tales specific to the Slavic cultural context. While in the rest of Europe people usually call demonic creatures devils and deem their intentions to be purely negative, in the Czech folklore, we tend to see chorts as malevolent, malicious and oftentimes stupid creatures depicted with goat horns, tail and hooves, who are subordinated to the will of Lucifer, the ruler of hell.</paragraph><paragraph>Medieval mythology attributed all sorts of things to chorts. Every other castle had a gateway to hell in its cellar, every other mill or abandoned building served as their dwelling. Chorts smelled bad, were noisy and made chickens stop laying, milk go sour, and food go bad.</paragraph><paragraph>While other originally pagan superstitions were refuted by the Church, chorts were assimilated by the Church for its own purposes and remade into tempters and punishment for believers who were not God-fearing enough.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Demons (Chorts) are mythical and fairy-tale inhabitants of hell specific to Slavic cultural context. While in the rest of Europe people refer to demonic creatures as devils and attribute purely negative intentions to them, in Czech folklore we lean towards the image of demons as mischievous, malicious, and often foolish beings depicted with goat horns, a tail, and hooves on their feet, subservient to the will of the ruler of hell, Lucifer.</paragraph><paragraph>Medieval magical thinking attributed various qualities to demons. Many a castle had a notorious gate to hell in its basement, many a mill or abandoned building served as their abode. Demons smelled bad, caused disturbances, and were blamed for hens not laying eggs, milk souring, and food spoiling.</paragraph><paragraph>While the church refuted other originally pagan beliefs, it assimilated demons for its purposes, portraying them as tempters and punishment for believers who weren't devout.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Devil's Den is still today one of the smallest settlements in the Kuttenberg region. Unfortunately, no records of its appearance in 1403 have survived, but in the 16th century, the infamous <accent>Devil's tavern</accent> stood on its site, where the Kuttenberg scum often gathered, and which served as a model for our Devil's Den.</paragraph><paragraph>The name of the settlement and the tavern comes from a legend, according to which, devils were supposed to come out of the local mines and fly over Kuttenberg at midnight. They were driven out of their dens by water, which later flooded the mines.</paragraph><paragraph>We also learn about the dark character of the former inn from the memoirs of Mikuláš Dačický: 'Michal, a messenger of the mining authority, killed the innkeeper Št'astný with a spear in the Devil's tavern near Kuttenberg, where there was a habitat of robbers and whores. They were fighting over some gloves.'</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Devil's Den is still today one of the smallest settlements in the Kuttenberg region. Unfortunately, no records of its appearance in 1403 have survived, but in the 16th century, the infamous <accent>Devil's tavern</accent> stood on its site, where the lowlifes of Kuttenberg often gathered, and which served as a model for our Devil's Den.</paragraph><paragraph>The name of the settlement and the tavern comes from a legend, according to which, devils were said to come out of the local mines and fly over Kuttenberg at midnight. They were only driven from their dens by water, which later flooded the mines.</paragraph><paragraph>We also learn about the dark character of the former inn from the memoirs of Mikuláš Dačický: 'Michal', a messenger of the mining authority, killed the innkeeper Št'astný with a spear in the Devil's tavern near Kuttenberg, where there was a den of rogues and whores. They were fighting over some gloves.'</paragraph>

<paragraph>A location, known also as <accent>Bohemian Paradise</accent>, about 90 km north-east of Prague with a great number of natural and cultural monuments. The main landmarks of the region are Kozákov Mountain and <accent>Trosky Castle</accent>, while other important sites include, for example, the Prachov and Klokoči rock formations, the castles Kost, Waldstein and Sychrov, and a number of fish ponds.</paragraph><paragraph>Its picturesque landscape is mainly underscored by the ubiquitous sandstone rocks, characterised by their steep and rugged reliefs and towers.</paragraph><paragraph>It is an important protected landscape area and a popular destination for climbers. Nowadays the locality is interwoven with a dense network of tourist paths, so aficionados of nature and ancient monuments will definitely find a lot to enjoy.</paragraph><paragraph>This was quite a busy place in the Middle Ages, especially due to the number of castles, fortresses and fortifications, which are located almost literally on every hill.</paragraph>

<paragraph>An area, also known as <accent>Bohemian Paradise</accent>, about 90 km north-east of Prague with a great number of natural and cultural monuments. The main landmarks of the region are Kozákov Mountain and <accent>Trosky Castle</accent>, while other important sites include, for example, the Prachov and Klokoči rock formations, the castles Kost, Waldstein and Sychrov, and a number of ponds.</paragraph><paragraph>Its picturesque landscape is mainly underscored by the ubiquitous sandstone rocks, characterised by their steep and rugged reliefs and towers.</paragraph><paragraph>It is an important protected landscape area and a popular destination for climbers. Nowadays the area is crisscrossed with a dense network of tourist trails, making it a haven for nature lovers and enthusiasts of historical landmarks.</paragraph><paragraph>In the medieval period the region was quite bustling, particularly due to the numerous castles, fortresses and fortifications, which are located almost literally on every hilltop.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The meaning of the word <italic>honour</italic> in the Middle Ages did not only include <italic>honesty</italic>, but especially <italic>living in accordance with the conventions of one’s position</italic>. A craftsman who followed the rules of the guild and attended the church, while nothing derogatory could be said about him was considered honourable. Honour was sacred and preserving it was a matter of prestige and social status.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Losing one’s honour</accent> meant ending up on the margins of society. Thus, it was not only important to build up one’s honour, but also to defend it. Honour could be lost not only through a violation of the social order (an illegitimate child, loss of virginity before marriage), but also a violation of unwritten conventions (shaking hands with an executioner, the treatment of a dead person or animal) or simply by not resisting when someone questioned your honour.</paragraph><paragraph>In the medieval perception of the world, there were also <italic>honourless people</italic>, meaning those who had no honour. These included executioners, knackers, prostitutes and beggars. In certain periods of history, millers were also considered to be honourless. Calling someone a sexual organ or animal was not nearly as insulting as calling him dishonourable. Such an insult ended at the bailiff’s, the court, or even in a duel.</paragraph><paragraph>A <accent>knight’s honour</accent>, or chivalry, was a chapter in and of itself. It was often the theme of literary invention and can seem almost comical from today’s perspective.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The meaning of the word <italic>honour</italic> in the Middle Ages encompassed not only <italic>honesty</italic> but particularly <italic>living in accordance with the conventions of one's status</italic>. An honourable craftsman was one who followed the guild's rules, attended church, and had no disreputable remarks made about him. Honour was sacred, and preserving it was a matter of prestige and social status.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Losing one's honour</accent> meant ending up on the fringes of society. Thus, honour had to be not only built but also fiercely defended. Honour could be lost not only by transgressing social norms (such as having an illegitimate child or losing virginity before marriage) but also by violating unwritten conventions (such as shaking hands with an executioner, handling a dead body or carcass) or simply by failing to defend one's honour when it was challenged.</paragraph><paragraph>In medieval perception, there were also so-called <italic>dishonourable people</italic>, those who had no honour at all. This group included executioners, knackers, prostitutes, and beggars. At certain times in history, millers were also considered dishonourable. Calling someone a sexual organ or an animal was not nearly as insulting as calling them dishonourable. Such insults often ended up before the bailiff, the court, or even in a duel.</paragraph><paragraph>A special chapter is devoted to <accent>knightly honour</accent>, which was often a theme in literary works and, from today's perspective, can seem almost comical.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Travel was dangerous in the Middle Ages, but necessary, especially for traders. The roads differed by their purpose – <accent>trade</accent> routes had river-fords, bridges, inns, signposts, milestones and so on. <accent>Pilgrimage</accent> routes were without such luxuries.</paragraph><paragraph>A person was able to cover about 25-30 km per day by wagon. Wayfarers would overnight at inns near road junctions, their goods stored in a depot.</paragraph><paragraph>In times of instability and chaos - the kind in which the KCD story takes place - traders and travellers would often be waylaid by marauders, which led to travelling in groups with a hired armed escort. </paragraph><paragraph> Bohemia imported canvas, silk and other textiles, weapons, wine, salt, seafood, salt-water fish, southern fruit, spices and other exotic and luxury goods. Goods exported included wheat, butter, honey, beeswax, beer, malt, freshwater fish, cheeses and other local products.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Travel in the Middle Ages was dangerous but essential, especially for merchants. The nature of the roads differed according to their purpose - <accent>trade</accent> routes featured fords, bridges, inns, signposts, milestones, and the like, while such luxuries were absent on <accent>pilgrimage</accent> routes.</paragraph><paragraph>People could travel 25-30 km per day with a cart. They would stay overnight in inns at crossroads, and goods would be left at a warehouse.</paragraph><paragraph>During times of destabilisation and chaos, such as those depicted in Kingdom Come: Deliverance, merchants and travellers were often attacked by bandits or robber knights, so people usually travelled in groups, often with hired armed escorts.</paragraph><paragraph>Into Bohemia, goods such as linen, silk, and other fabrics, weapons, salt, wine, seafood, sea fish, southern fruits, spices, and other exotic and luxury items were imported. Exports included grain, butter, honey, beeswax, beer, malt, freshwater fish, cheese, and other local products.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The term <italic>charity</italic> was understood as <accent>good works</accent> to one's brethren. Christian iconography depicts charity as a Pelican, feeding its young with its own flesh.</paragraph><paragraph>Society, inspired by the teaching of the Church and Old Testament stories, showed compassion by giving alms, free medical aid, food and wine to the poor or travellers, sometimes even to the exiled. It was deemed that such acts of <accent>mercy</accent> secured salvation and a place in Heaven, and were more about formally securing indulgences, rather than being spontaneous acts of mercy.</paragraph><paragraph>The Church often established hospitals, hostels, hospices, but also granted pardons to prisoners, and the poor were allowed to beg in front of the church and visit the baths at least twice a year at the expense of the town.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The term <italic>charity</italic> was understood as <accent>benevolence</accent> to one's brethren. Christian iconography depicts charity as a Pelican, feeding its young with its own flesh.</paragraph><paragraph>Society, inspired by the teaching of the Church and Old Testament stories, showed compassion by giving alms, free medical aid, food and wine to the poor or travellers, sometimes even to the exiled. It was deemed that such acts of <accent>mercy</accent> secured salvation and a place in Heaven, and were more about formally securing indulgences, rather than being spontaneous.</paragraph><paragraph>The Church often established hospitals, hostels, hospices, but also granted pardons to prisoners, and the poor were allowed to beg in front of the church and visit the baths at least twice a year at the expense of the town.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The construction of the church dedicated to St. Barbara began in 1388, when the local rich miners, townspeople and patrician families decided that the town needed a representative shrine. Intermittent construction and alterations continued until the beginning of the 20th century, fortunately always with sensitivity and respect for the original Gothic style.</paragraph><paragraph>The Cathedral of St. Barbara is one of the four cathedrals in Bohemia, and the fact that the building was funded by the townspeople and not by the church was later reflected in its unique decoration. The original Gothic paintings depict miners and artisans from the smelters in addition to classical church motifs. Later added stained glass windows (added since the beginning of the 20th century, the last one is from 2014) depict not only saints, but also figures performing various modern professions.</paragraph><paragraph>In the game there are many references to the townspeople and guildsmen for whom the construction of the cathedral was a matter of prestige. The rich competed to see who could be immortalised on the decoration or who would get this or that altar in return for generous sponsorship donations. Space was limited and the number of altars too, so only the most generous could go down in history...</paragraph>

<paragraph>Construction of the church dedicated to St. Barbara began in 1388, when local wealthy miners, townspeople and patrician families decided that the town needed a representative sanctuary. Intermittent construction and alterations continued until the beginning of the 20th century, fortunately always with sensitivity and respect for the original Gothic style.</paragraph><paragraph>The Cathedral of St. Barbara is one of the four cathedrals in Bohemia, and the fact that the building was funded by the townspeople and not by the church was later reflected in its unique decoration. The original Gothic paintings depict miners and craftsmen from the smelters in addition to classical church motifs. Later additions such as stained glass windows (added since the early 20th century, with the latest from 2014) depict not only saints, but also figures performing various modern professions.</paragraph><paragraph>In the game you can find many references to the cathedral from townspeople and guild members, for whom the construction of the cathedral was a matter of prestige. The wealthy competed to immortalise themselves in the decoration through generous sponsorship, including securing specific altars. Space and the number of altars were limited, so only the most generous could leave their mark in history.</paragraph>

<paragraph>It has been said that the settlement has been around since the Stone Age (about 3000 BC). Today, however, only the remains of an early medieval fortified settlement remain in the form of remnants of moats and visible ramparts.</paragraph><paragraph>Some historians (as well as folk legends) claim that Zimburg (Cimburk) Castle, owned by the <accent>Lords of Zimburg</accent>, once stood here and was even perhaps their ancestral home. Later, the descendants of the family built two more castles with the same name: Cimburk in Trnávka and Nový Cimburk in Koryčany.</paragraph><paragraph>Unfortunately nothing remains from the original castle. That's why some historians claim that such castle never stood here and the settlement rather got its name from the mine that belonged to the Zimburg family here. However, we still decided to portrait it in the game.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Settlement in the area dates back to the late Stone Age (about 3000 BC). Today, however, only traces of an early medieval fortified settlement remain in the form of remnants of moats and visible ramparts.</paragraph><paragraph>Some historians (as well as folk legends) claim that Zimburg (Cimburk) Castle, owned by the <accent>Lords of Zimburg</accent>, once stood here and was even perhaps their ancestral home. Later, the descendants of the family built two more castles with the same name: Cimburk in Trnávka and Nový Cimburk in Koryčany.</paragraph><paragraph>Unfortunately nothing remains from the original castle. Hence why some historians claim that such a castle never stood here and the settlement rather got its name from the nearby mine that belonged to the Zimburg family. Nevertheless, we decided to depict it in the game.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Maintaining law and order in the medieval town was the job of the Bailiff. From the 14th century onward, the function was taken over by the <italic>catchpole</italic>, then <italic>night watchmen</italic> and <italic>guards</italic> on towers. The catchpole, along with the Bailiff, the executioner or their henchmen also carried out the punishment of transgressors. They were not, however, allowed to enter freehold dwellings (the palaces and houses of the nobility, the ruling class), nor Church buildings or the University, a fact students took advantage of. </paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Order</accent> within the city also had to be upheld by the townsfolk themselves. They were obligated to report not only any crime, but, just like the night watchmen, to call out the hours and warn of fire, flood or tempest. For safety it was forbidden to wander at night with any open flame (torch or candle) into any castles, chambers, stables, barns or byres. Only lanterns could be used. To keep the peace at night, all taverns had to shut at sunset. </paragraph><paragraph> In the medieval city, <accent>military service</accent> was entrusted to either hired professionals or the townspeople themselves. Every healthy adult male had to serve at least a few days a year in the civic guard, the city walls being divided and allocated in sections to each district or trade, and it was here that they mustered whenever an alarm was raised.</paragraph><paragraph>In practice, the wealthy burghers bought their way out of serving in the militia, leaving other men to take their turn, and these poorer men welcomed the extra income – thus gradually forming a professional municipal gendarmerie.</paragraph><paragraph>Each man had to procure the armour and weapons needed for serving in the guards and the militia, unless his guild did so. Only the rich cities could afford to have a public issue armoury. </paragraph><paragraph><accent>The right to bear arms</accent> outside of ‘duty' was reserved for townsmen of sufficient means. Within the city walls a simple melee weapon, dagger or knife had to suffice. Only the really wealthy townsmen wore swords, taking after the nobility.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In medieval towns, law and order were maintained by the bailiff. From the 14th century, this role was taken over by the <italic>catchpole</italic>, and later by the <italic>night watchman</italic> and <italic>crier</italic> in town towers. The catchpole, along with the bailiff, executioner or their henchmen, also carried out punishments on offenders. However, they were not allowed to enter free houses (palaces and houses of nobles, rulers), church buildings, or universities, which students often exploited.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Order</accent> in the town had to be maintained by the townspeople themselves. They were required to report not only crimes but also, like the night watchmen, announce the time, and warn of fire, floods, or storms.</paragraph><paragraph>For safety reasons, it was forbidden to go to the castle, chambers, stables, barns, and byres at night with an open flame (torch or candle). Only lanterns were to be used. To maintain night peace, all taverns had to close after sunset.</paragraph><paragraph>In a medieval town, <accent>military service</accent> was performed either by hired professionals or by the town's citizens themselves. Every healthy adult man was expected to serve in the town's garrison for at least a few days a year. Different quarters or guilds had their own sections of the town walls to guard, and in the event of an alarm, the town's defenders would gather at these sections.</paragraph><paragraph>In practice, wealthy townspeople would pay others to perform guard duties for them, hiring poorer men who saw this as a welcome source of income—thus gradually forming a professional town guard.</paragraph><paragraph>Each guard and town militia member provided their own armour and weapons, unless their guild provided it. Only wealthy towns could afford their own state armoury.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>The right to bear arms</accent> outside of "service" was only granted to townspeople with a certain level of property. Inside the town walls, a simple stabbing weapon, dagger, or knife had to suffice. Only truly wealthy townspeople carried swords, following the example of the nobility.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Since ancient times, a ‘foreigner' meant not only anyone who came from outside one's town or village (and was thus a potential enemy), but also any person without legal status. Foreigners were without legal rights until they paid a surety. This matter was handled by courts of law and there were various regulations setting fees for running a business or renting a house (foreigners were not allowed to acquire or inherit ownership of them).</paragraph><paragraph> The Bohemia lands were long open to foreigners, relatively speaking, with lively trade and cultural exchanges. First were the Celts, then Germanic tribes and later the Slavs, but a large portion of the populace consisted of German-speaking people. The Germans were mainly courtiers, or worked entrepreneurs and merchants. Relations with the Germans were neutral at first, cooling off later and ending up with animosity ‘against all things German', though that was still far removed from the strident nationalism of the 19th century.</paragraph><paragraph> Worse relations existed between the Czechs and Germans, on one side, and the Jews on the other. They lived outside of society, which often (having got permission from the King for a handsome price) carried out pogroms against them.</paragraph><paragraph> Plague and disease in the mid-14th century affected migration, and fewer foreigners came to Bohemia. During the Hussite Wars, most of towns had a majority Czech citizenry. Only the main centres in Moravia remained largely German: Brno (Brünn), Jihlava (Iglau) and Olomouc (Olmütz).</paragraph><paragraph>The Czech language gradually permeated from rural society to the higher social strata. A fundamental change in how language and ethnicity was viewed came with the Hussite Wars, in which most Czech-speakers identified with the Hussites, while (most) Germans supported Sigismund and the Pope. This was exacerbated by the foreign (often German) crusades summoned by Sigismund against the “upstart Hussites”.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In ancient times, a foreigner was not only someone who did not originate from the community (and therefore a potential enemy), but also a person without legal status. Foreigners were considered without rights until they paid a surety. Courts and various regulations addressed issues such as fees for trading or renting a house (which they were not allowed to acquire or inherit).</paragraph><paragraph>The Czech lands remained relatively open to foreigners for a long time, fostering active cultural and commercial exchanges. Initially inhabited by Celts, they were later replaced by Germanic tribes and eventually by Slavs, although with a significant proportion of German speakers. Germans mostly lived on royal estates or worked as entrepreneurs and merchants. The relationship with Germans was initially neutral, but later cooled and became more strained, leading to local hostility "against all things German," although classic nationalism of the 19th century had not yet emerged.</paragraph><paragraph>Both Czechs and Germans had worse relations with Jews, who lived outside society and were often subjected to pogroms (with the king's permission and hefty payments).</paragraph><paragraph>Diseases and the Black Death in the mid-14th century influenced migration, resulting in fewer foreigners moving to the Czech lands. During the Hussite Wars, Czechs became the majority in most cities. German remained the main language in Moravia's major centres: Brno, Jihlava, and Olomouc.</paragraph><paragraph>Czech gradually evolved from a rural language into a language of the upper classes. A pivotal shift in the perception of linguistic and ethnic differences occurred during the Hussite Wars, where most Czech speakers identified with the Hussites, while Germans (for the most part) sided with Sigismund and the Pope. Foreign (often German) crusades against the "rebellious Hussites," convened by Sigismund, also contributed to these divisions.</paragraph>

<paragraph>With growing demand for processed iron there grew a demand for charcoal, which was able to raise a temperature many times higher than wood, much needed for the forging of weapons. Coal provision was the domain of charcoal burning colliers.</paragraph><paragraph>They spent most of the year living in the forest near their <italic>charcoal mounds</italic> – great piles of stacked wood covered in clay with just a few vents for air, where in a starved atmosphere the wood slowly burned down to charcoal. Each pile would smoulder giving off much smoke for several weeks, during which time it had to be delved through repeatedly. After it burned out completely the yield of the process – charcoal was unearthed from beneath the clay.</paragraph><paragraph>The charcoal was then sold at a special market bearing that name, quite separate from traders in other goods. Already under Wenceslas IV the colliers had numerous rights and freedoms as regards use of the forests, and were held in relatively high esteem.</paragraph><paragraph>Resin was for sale exclusively from <italic>coachmen</italic> or resin merchants, who themselves made pitch for oiling their wheels (tar). The charcoal burners produced resin and coal-tar only as a sundry activity. The coal-tar merchants provided tar to tanneries to impregnate leather and mixed it with tallow to grease the bearings of wheels on wagons and carriages.</paragraph>

<paragraph>With growing demand for processed iron, there grew a corresponding demand for charcoal, which could produce a temperature many times higher than unprocessed wood, much needed for the forging of steel weapons.</paragraph><paragraph>The forges were supplied by charcoal-burners, who spent most of the year living in the forest by their <italic>charcoal kilns</italic> – great piles of stacked wood covered in clay with just a few vents for air, where, in an oxygen-starved atmosphere the wood slowly pyrolyzed to charcoal. Each pile would smoulder and give off much smoke for several weeks, during which time it had to be delved through repeatedly. After it burned out completely, the yield of the process – charcoal – was unearthed from beneath the clay.</paragraph><paragraph>The charcoal was then sold at a special market bearing that name, quite separate from traders in other goods. During the reign of Wenceslas IV, the charcoal-burners already had numerous rights and freedoms regarding use of the forests, and were held in relatively high esteem.</paragraph><paragraph>Resin was sold exclusively by <italic>wagoners</italic> and <italic>resin merchants</italic>, who themselves made pitch for greasing their wheels. The charcoal burners produced resin and pitch only as a side-line. The pitch merchants provided pitch to tanneries to impregnate leather and mixed it with tallow to grease the axles of wheels on wagons and carriages.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Medieval town society was made up largely of craftsmen and merchants, who ensured its socio-economic growth. Based on their freeman rights they could exercise their craft and had the right to market.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to privileges such as the protection of and support for the town's operation, health care and food provision, it was their duty to pay taxes on every sale or exportation of goods outside the city limits. In essence the status of the municipality was dependent on them, hence it was important that they would not relocate and ply their trade elsewhere, passing their skills to following generations.</paragraph><paragraph>Within any century, several craftsmen of the same profession would be active in a town. These artisans gradually began to form themselves into groups with political-economic rules, or members' <accent>guilds</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>They had their seals of office, pennants bearing the guild crests granted by the monarch. Any member of a guild had the support of the others, and they all agreed on prices and the regulation of sales, the rules for teaching or discharging their duties. Only guild members were allowed to sell their wares.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The society of the medieval town was primarily composed of craftsmen and merchants who ensured its economic growth. Based on municipal rights, they had the right to practice their trade and market rights.</paragraph><paragraph>Apart from privileges such as the protection and support of the town in operation, healthcare, and sufficient food supply, it was their duty to pay taxes on every sale or export of goods outside the town's borders. Essentially, the status of the community depended on them, so it was important that they did not relocate, did not practice their profession elsewhere, and passed on the craft to future generations.</paragraph><paragraph>During one century, several craftsmen of the same profession worked in the town. These craftsmen gradually began to form groups with politico-economic rules, known as <accent>guilds</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>They had their own seals, stamps, and banners bearing the guild's coat of arms designated by the ruler. Those who belonged to the guild had support from others, and they collectively agreed on prices, sales regulations, training rules, and obligations. Only guild members could sell goods.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The most severe crimes in the Middle Ages were considered a murder, incest, counterfeiting money, sorcery, burglary and large-scale theft. Smaller, but still officially dealt-with offences included disorderly conduct, public drunkenness, fraud, non-payment of debts, slander and libel.</paragraph><paragraph>Some offences against the general order were punished by <accent>pillory</accent> - public display and mockery in a stocks in the square. Worse than the pillorying itself was the loss of honour for the condemned, which then dragged with them and their family for the rest of their lives.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Capital crimes</accent> were punished by hanging (the most common form of execution of men, mainly for recurring crimes) or by beheading (reserved for the nobility). For <accent>aggravated murder</accent> the punishment was the breaking wheel, which was left on the gallows hill complete with the corpse, as a warning. Other options for execution were burning at the stake (for heretics and forgers), drawing by horses, quartering and impaling. Women were typically drowned, or in retribution for killing a newborn, buried alive.</paragraph><paragraph>It was possible to <accent>redeem oneself</accent> from some wrongdoings. The penalty levied went to the town coffers, or part went to the aggrieved party in compensation. Murder could also be redeemed if the offender paid off the survivors and put up a conciliation cross.</paragraph><paragraph>A special kind of punishment was <accent>branding</accent>, which was considered one of the most severe punishments. Those branded had trouble getting an "honorable" job, as they had a reminder right on their body that they had been involved in a crime.</paragraph><paragraph>The nobility were virtually unpunishable, even if they had committed a serious crime. Only the King could condemn and punish them (which did indeed happen).</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, the most serious crimes were considered to be murder, incest, counterfeiting money, witchcraft, robbery, and major theft. Lesser but still officially addressed offences included disorderly conduct, public drunkenness, fraud, non-payment of debts, slander, and defamation.</paragraph><paragraph>Some offences against public order were punished by <accent>pillorying</accent>—public display and ridicule in the stocks in the town square. Worse than the pillorying itself was the loss of honor for the convicted, which would follow them and their family for the rest of their lives.</paragraph><paragraph>For <accent>capital crimes</accent>, punishment included hanging (the most common execution for men, especially for repeat offenders) or beheading (reserved for nobility). For <accent>robbery-murder</accent>, execution by breaking on the wheel was used, leaving the body displayed as a warning. Other execution methods included burning (for heretics and counterfeiters), tearing apart by horses, quartering, or impalement. Women were most often drowned or, as punishment for infanticide, buried alive.</paragraph><paragraph>Some offenses could be <accent>redeemed</accent>. The fine would go to the city treasury or partly as compensation to the injured party. Even murder could be redeemed if the perpetrator compensated the survivors and erected a reconciliation cross.</paragraph><paragraph>A special type of punishment was <accent>branding</accent>, considered one of the harshest penalties. Branded individuals had difficulty finding “respectable” work, as they had a permanent reminder on their body that they had been involved in a crime.</paragraph><paragraph>The nobility was practically untouchable, even if they committed serious crimes. Only the king could condemn and punish them (which often did happen).</paragraph>

<paragraph>Damascus steel, also known as damask, damascene, or damask steel, is a high-quality metal alloy produced since the early Middle Ages in Syria, Indonesia, and Central Asia. It was imported into Europe from the Syrian city of Damascus and was used by the Franks, Vikings, and Spaniards. However, this steel was not accessible to everyone, as its price was very high.</paragraph><paragraph>Damascus steel is renowned for its distinctive composition and processing, which creates alternating layers of metal. Each item thus acquired characteristic patterns, known as marbling, which are entirely unique. This unique composition gave the steel exceptional properties, particularly very high hardness and durability compared to ordinary steel.</paragraph><paragraph>For this reason, the complex and costly production of this steel was strictly guarded as a secret. Some, of course, attempted to replicate it, creating so-called welded (false) Damascus from lower-quality materials, which resembled the real thing in appearance but was nowhere near its equal in terms of properties.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Damascus steel, also known as damask, damascene, or damask steel, is a high-quality metal alloy produced since the early Middle Ages in Syria, Indonesia, and Central Asia. It was imported into Europe from the Syrian city of Damascus and was used by the Franks, Vikings, and Spaniards. However, this steel was not accessible to everyone, as its price was very high.</paragraph><paragraph>Damascus steel is renowned for its distinctive composition and processing, which creates alternating layers of metal. Each item thus acquired characteristic patterns, known as marbling, which are entirely unique. This unique composition gave the steel exceptional properties, particularly very high hardness and durability compared to ordinary steel.</paragraph><paragraph>For this reason, the complex and costly production of this steel was strictly guarded as a secret. Some, of course, attempted to replicate it, creating so-called welded (false) Damascus from lower-quality materials, which resembled the real thing in appearance but was nowhere near its equal in terms of properties.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A 'tithe' is the name for a <accent>compulsory tax</accent> levied since ancient times. It was paid to the parish priest or other religious institution. The term comes from Old English and means the amount of one tenth of the value of the harvest.</paragraph><paragraph>The inhabitants of monastery estates had the misfortune to be taxed twice by the Church – once in the form of a tithe, the second time as a mandatory levy for their occupation of Church land.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A 'tithe' was a <accent>compulsory tax</accent> levied since ancient times. It was paid to the parish priest or other religious institution. The term comes from Old English and means an amount of one tenth of the value of the harvest.</paragraph><paragraph>The inhabitants of monastery estates had the misfortune to be taxed twice by the Church – once in the form of a tithe, the second time as a mandatory levy for their occupation of Church land.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the pre-Hussite period the Church held extensive estates, sometimes exceeding in value the property of the nobility or even the King himself. The Church also collected various taxes and fees, which led to conflicts not only between the Church and the secular world, but within the Church itself.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to the clergymen, priests and their helpers, the ecclesiastical establishment was also represented by votaries, archbishops, church officials, clerics and monks – altogether, the Church nourished and employed about a tenth of the population.</paragraph><paragraph>High running costs and failure to ensure either the physical or spiritual wellbeing of the people, coupled with the numerous woes of wars and pestilence, led to a radical weakening of ecclesiastical power and loss of confidence in the Church as an institution in the 14th century. Causing the first signs of a <accent>reformation movement</accent>, as well as many alternative ‘heretical' sects and renewed interest in old pagan traditions.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>mass</accent> was at that time more of a social occasion than a spiritual one, bringing people together. They would enjoy themselves, even flirt or make deals. This changed with the Hussite reformation movement and the return to ‘true devotion'.</paragraph><paragraph>Declining trust in the Church was encouraged by the first Czech translations of the Bible, thanks to which the ideas actually contained in the Bible could finally spread by word of mouth even among the illiterate population. The spark of revolution had been struck.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the pre-Hussite period, the church owned extensive property, sometimes exceeding the wealth of the nobility or even the king himself. The church also often collected various taxes and fees, which led to conflicts not only between the church and the secular world but also within the church itself.</paragraph><paragraph>Besides priests, clergymen and their assistants, the church also included monks, archbishops, church officials, clerics and monks – altogether the church supported and employed about a tenth of the population.</paragraph><paragraph>The high costs of operation and the inability to ensure people's welfare or salvation, along with numerous wars and plagues, led in the 14th century to a radical weakening of church power and a loss of people's trust in the church as an institution. The first signs of the <accent>reformation movement</accent> appeared, as well as many alternative "heretical" sects or a return to old pagan traditions.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Mass</accent> at that time was more of a social event than a spiritual one. People chatted, flirted, or even made business deals. This changed only with the reformation movement and the return to "true piety" during the Hussite movement.</paragraph><paragraph>The declining trust in the church was also supported by the first translations of the Bible into the Czech language, thanks to which the ideas truly contained in the Bible could finally spread even among the illiterate population. The spark of revolution had been struck.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A <accent>journeyman</accent> was the craftsman's assistant. If he went out into the world to ply his trade, he needed to have a vocational certificate and the tools of his trade.</paragraph><paragraph>Only very rarely did journeymen stay in one workshop for an entire year. Typically they were there for just a few weeks, on one week's notice, paid by the day (‘journée'). If a journeyman left without agreement (absconded), he was ‘proscribed', outlawed from hire by other workshops, his identity written down and disseminated.</paragraph><paragraph>An <accent>apprentice</accent> was a boy ceremoniously accepted into apprenticeship by the master craftsman. This entry was made possible after payment of due fees in cash and beeswax. The wealthy would be taught and would minister for as little as one year, the poorer sort would have to pay off their indebtedness by service over several years.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A <accent>journeyman</accent> was a craftsman's assistant. If he went out into the world to ply his trade, he needed to have a vocational certificate and the tools of his trade.</paragraph><paragraph>Rarely did journeymen stay in one workshop for an entire year. Typically they were there for just a few weeks, on one week's notice, paid by the day (‘journée'). If a journeyman left without agreement (absconded), he was ‘proscribed', outlawed from hire by other workshops, his identity written down and disseminated.</paragraph><paragraph>An <accent>apprentice</accent> was a boy accepted into apprenticeship by a master craftsman in a special ceremony before other guild masters. Entry was made possible by paying a fee in cash and beeswax. Wealthier boys might complete their apprenticeship in as little as one year, while poorer ones had to work off their debt over several years.</paragraph>

<paragraph>While Wenceslas was imprisoned in Vienna, Sigismund attacked Kuttenberg in December 1402.</paragraph><paragraph>The city remained loyal to the king, especially the miners defended the city tenaciously. When they finally surrendered, they had to follow Sigismund to his camp at Kolin to kneel before him in the mud. In addition, they also had to take huge sums of money to him so that the city would not be ransacked. The surrounding villages were not so lucky and many were plundered or burned down. </paragraph><paragraph> By capturing the city, Sigismund seized the largest silver deposits in the country, which allowed him to continue his campaign. The city's treasury then contained valuable jewels as well as money; all of which fell prey to the enemy.</paragraph><paragraph> When King Wenceslas IV. returned to the throne, he valued the wealth seized by Sigismund at one million gold coins of that period. </paragraph><paragraph> At the time of our game, the city is under Sigismund's control, though the army itself is camped elsewhere. The top officials and members of the city council have been replaced, but otherwise the city has continued to be left to its own self-government.</paragraph>

<paragraph>While Wenceslas was imprisoned in Vienna, Sigismund attacked Kuttenberg in December 1402.</paragraph><paragraph>The city remained loyal to the king, and the miners in particular defended the city tenaciously. When they finally surrendered, they had to follow Sigismund to his camp at Kolin to kneel before him in the mud. Additionally, they had to pay him huge sums of money to prevent the city from being plundered. The surrounding villages were not so lucky and many were looted or burned down.</paragraph><paragraph>By capturing the city, Sigismund seized the largest silver deposits in the country, which enabled him to continue his campaign. The city's treasury contained valuable jewels as well as money; all of which fell prey to the enemy.</paragraph><paragraph>When King Wenceslas IV returned to the throne, he estimated the wealth seized by Sigismund at one million gold coins of that period.</paragraph><paragraph>At the time of our game, the city is under Sigismund's control, though the army itself is camped elsewhere. The top officials and members of the city council have been replaced, but otherwise the city has been left to its own self-government.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Throughout the Middle Ages, animals were seen only in purely utilitarian terms: the same was true of dogs and cats.</paragraph><paragraph>Although the Church claimed that animals had a soul, their souls were mortal (unlike those of humans) and could not find salvation. They were therefore inferior beings and subordinate to man. (The Ottoman law of 1502, which regulates the use of draft animals, was a breakthrough in this area and can be considered to be possibly the first law against animal cruelty. In Europe, a similar law did not appear until 1822.)</paragraph><paragraph>At the time of our game, <accent>dogs</accent> were used for hunting or guarding and could be trained. It therefore comes as no surprise that they enjoyed certain privileges compared to the other animals.</paragraph><paragraph>People were breeding and cross breeding dogs already in the Middle Ages, but not to such an extent as a few centuries later, when various domestic, miniature, or specialised breeds were beginning to emerge. Most of the medieval breeds were focused purely on hunting and guarding, and looked similar to Henry's Mutt.</paragraph><paragraph>Compared to that, <accent>cats</accent> do whatever they want, and perhaps that is why they were perceived negatively as an embodiment of the devil and did not enjoy much popularity (hence their surviving miniatures, which often look more like hellish creatures).</paragraph><paragraph>The opposite was true for Muslims. Christian travellers in Arab countries were very surprised to find that cats were as popular there as dogs were in Europe.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Throughout the Middle Ages, animals were viewed purely for their utility: this was no different for dogs and cats.</paragraph><paragraph>Although animals, according to the Church, had souls, these souls were mortal and could not attain salvation, unlike human souls. Thus, animals were considered inferior beings, subordinate to humans. (A groundbreaking perspective can be seen in the Ottoman law of 1502, which regulates the use of draught animals and is arguably the first law against animal cruelty. A similar law in Europe appeared only in 1822.)</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>dog</accent> in this period served humans for hunting or guarding and could be trained. It is no wonder that, among other animals, dogs enjoyed certain privileges.</paragraph><paragraph>Breeding and crossbreeding of dogs did occur in the Middle Ages, but not nearly to the extent seen a few centuries later, when various domestic, miniature, or narrowly specialized breeds began to emerge. Most medieval breeds were focused solely on hunting and guarding and looked similar to Henry's Mutt.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>cat</accent>, on the other hand, did what it wanted, and perhaps for this reason, it was viewed negatively as an embodiment of the devil and was not very popular (as evidenced by surviving illuminations, where it often appears more like a demonic creature).</paragraph><paragraph>Conversely, the situation was entirely different among Muslims. Christian travelers in Arab countries were amazed to find that cats were as beloved there as dogs were in Europe.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages a significant part of any property ownership consisted of livestock: horses, goats, cattle and poultry.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Horses</accent> were highly prized, and until the 12th century were only available for the nobility for military purposes and for light hauling. The change came in the 12th and 13th centuries, when horses came to be used for transport and tillage.</paragraph><paragraph> In Bohemia, horses began to be shod from the 11th and 12th century - up to the 13th only as a rule on the front hooves, and later, when horses were used for heavier work, on all four.</paragraph><paragraph> Almost every serf in the Middle Ages would prefer to own a <accent>cow</accent> than a piece of arable land, so even some landless folk had access to food by way of milk. Curiously enough, in the Middle Ages milk and dairy goods were not traded much – for one thing, many people had a cow of their own, but also because no effective means of milk and dairy product preservation was yet known.</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Sheep</accent> were kept by both serfs and the upper classes, largely for their wool. The poorest often kept a goat for milk and cheese.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Pigs</accent> were left to forage in the woods all year round, feeding on beechnuts and acorns. Medieval pigs were much like wild boar and had little in common with today's pink animals.</paragraph><paragraph> The most commonly kept poultry were <accent>chickens</accent>, and only rarely geese or ducks.</paragraph><paragraph> All cattle grazed freely on the meadows around the village. In heavy winters the livestock was kept inside the house, even sharing the same room with the people and serving as a source of heat.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, a significant portion of people's wealth consisted of livestock: horses, goats, cattle, and poultry.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>horse</accent> was highly valued and, until the 12th century, was kept only for the nobility, for military purposes, and light draught work. This changed during the 12th and 13th centuries, when horses came to be used for transportation and ploughing.</paragraph><paragraph>In Bohemia, horses were shod with horseshoes from the 11th and 12th centuries. Until the 13th century, horseshoes were mostly applied only to the front hooves, but later, as horses began to be used for heavy work, all hooves were shod.</paragraph><paragraph>Almost every serf in the Middle Ages preferred to own a <accent>cow</accent> rather than a piece of arable land, so even landless peasants had access to food in the form of milk. Interestingly, milk and dairy products were not in high demand during the Middle Ages. This was partly because almost everyone kept a milking cow, but also because reliable methods of preservation were not yet known.</paragraph><paragraph>Both serfs and the nobility kept <accent>sheep</accent>, primarily for their wool. The poorest people kept goats for milk and cheese.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Pigs</accent> grazed in the forests all year round, feeding mainly on beechnuts and acorns. Medieval pigs resembled wild boars and had little in common with today's pink pigs.</paragraph><paragraph>The most commonly raised poultry were <accent>chickens</accent> and only rarely geese or ducks.</paragraph><paragraph>All livestock grazed freely in the meadows outside the village. Cattle were only stabled in the cottages during the harsh winter, when people sometimes shared the same room with the animals, which also served as a source of heat.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Or a <italic>sponsor</italic> as we would say now. It was a wealthy nobleman or burgher who spent money on the construction or acquisition of some property and then donated it to someone else together with a deed of gift.</paragraph><paragraph>In the context of the Middle Ages, we are talking mostly about donors to the Church. Most of the monasteries were built through <accent>donations</accent>, for example the Church of St. Barbara in Kuttenberg, in which altars were dedicated to the most generous donors. Being a donor was both a matter of prestige and of faith: whoever sponsored the Church had a pre-paid place in the Kingdom of Heaven.</paragraph><paragraph>By donating, a wealthy sponsor committed not only to the purchase or construction, but also to the subsequent maintenance and operation.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In today's language, a <italic>sponsor</italic>. It referred to a wealthy nobleman or burgher who expended resources on the construction or acquisition of some material estate, and then, together with a deed of gift, donated it to someone else.</paragraph><paragraph>In the context of the Middle Ages, we are mainly talking about church patrons. <accent>Through donations</accent>, most monasteries were built, or for example, the Church of St. Barbara in Kuttenberg, where altars were dedicated to the most generous patrons. Being a patron was a matter of both prestige and faith: whoever sponsored the church had a prepaid place in the kingdom of heaven.</paragraph><paragraph>By making a donation, a wealthy sponsor committed not only to the purchase or construction itself but also to the subsequent maintenance and operation.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Knowledge of paleontology and the early periods of life on our planet was not exactly the forte of medieval education, much less of illiterate commoners. According to the Bible, the world was created in seven days, there was simply no room for the long stages of prehistory.</paragraph><paragraph>Therefore, even the occasional rare <accent>finds of fossil remains</accent> of prehistoric life were attributed more to mythical creatures: <italic>dragons</italic>, <italic>basilisks</italic>, <italic>griffins</italic> and <italic>wyverns</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>Several references to the discovery of <italic>dragon bones</italic>survive from the Middle Ages. Sometimes they were the remains of real dinosaurs, sometimes they were imported bones of exotic animals unknown in our basin.</paragraph><paragraph>Crocodiles were particularly popular at that time because of their appearance, and one of them even entered the iconography as a dragon that St. George was supposed to fight.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Knowledge of paleontology and the early periods of life on our planet was not exactly the forte of medieval education, much less of illiterate commoners. According to the Bible, the world was created in seven days which simply left no room for the epochs of prehistory.</paragraph><paragraph>Therefore, even the occasional rare <accent>finds of fossil remains</accent> of prehistoric life were attributed more to mythical creatures: <italic>dragons</italic>, <italic>basilisks</italic>, <italic>griffins</italic> and <italic>wyverns</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>Several references to the discovery of <italic>dragon bones</italic>survive from the Middle Ages. Sometimes they were the remains of real dinosaurs, sometimes they were imported bones of exotic animals unfamiliar to people in this region.</paragraph><paragraph>Crocodiles were particularly popular at the time because of their appearance, and one of them even entered the iconography as the dragon that St. George was said to have fought.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The profession of executioner dates back to ancient Egypt and Rome, reappearing in Europe in the 13th century. Before this, capital punishment was meted by the judges themselves, or the prosecutors or relatives of the condemned, or other persons as suited. It was only with the advent of the executioner that all tasks were under his remit.</paragraph><paragraph>Although the executioner by his profession came in to considerable money and it was a status symbol for a town to have its own, the hangman or headsman would be a social outcast. For an honest citizen to make any contact with the executioner was to lose respect, and the executioner himself had to endure a lot of discriminatory measures – sitting at a separate place in the church and at the inn, not taking part in social functions and celebrations, etc.</paragraph><paragraph>The executioner took charge of punishments such as hanging, breaking knees, quartering, burning and torturing, drawing by horses, or beheading. He had his assistants--his henchmen – who helped him with preparation and took away the bodies of the executed. Other tasks done by the executioner included the role of the knacker, who cleared away animal cadavers, caught stray dogs and even sometimes just cleaned up filth from the streets.</paragraph><paragraph>The executioner might also oversee the town brothel, was somewhat familiar with surgery, could set broken bones, dislocated limbs, or to amputate them in cases of gangrene.</paragraph><paragraph>Sometimes the executioner sold articles directly related to the an execution to the superstitious, for example, the hanging ropes or the hanged man's fingers or amulets made from his hair.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The profession of executioner dates back to ancient Egypt and Rome; in Europe, it reappeared again in the 13th century. Before that, executions were carried out by judges themselves, or prosecutors or relatives of the condemned, or other individuals. It was only with the advent of the executioner that all tasks shifted to them.</paragraph><paragraph>Although executioners made decent money from their profession, and having their own executioner was a status symbol for every town, executioners themselves lived on the fringe of society. Associating with an executioner meant a loss of honor for respectable persons, and the executioner themselves had to face many discriminatory measures – separate place in church and at the inn, exclusion from social events, etc.</paragraph><paragraph>The executioner was responsible for punishments such as hanging, breaking on the wheel, burning at the stake, and torture, as well as quartering and beheading. They had assistants – henchmen – who helped with the preparation and disposal of executed bodies. Other tasks of the executioner included the removal and disposal of dead animals, catching stray dogs, and sometimes even cleaning up filth from the streets.</paragraph><paragraph>The executioner also sometimes oversaw the city brothel, had partial knowledge of surgery, could treat fractures, reset dislocated limbs, or amputate them in case of gangrene.</paragraph><paragraph>Sometimes, the executioner deceitfully sold items directly related to executions to superstitious people, such as ropes or fingers of the hanged, or amulets made from their hair.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, forgery of various documents was quite common. Few people could read or write, so few people could judge the authenticity of a particular record.</paragraph><paragraph>High-ranking lords could not read most of them and only dictated documents to scribes - <accent>trust in the written word</accent> was therefore not high and it was rather assumed that the content of correspondence could be false.</paragraph><paragraph>More reliance was placed on the word, promise and honour of the other person.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the medieval period, forging various documents was quite common. Few people were literate, so it was difficult for many to assess the authenticity of any given record.</paragraph><paragraph>High-ranking lords often could not read and dictated documents to scribes – <accent>trust in the written word</accent> was therefore low, with an expectation that correspondence could be falsified.</paragraph><paragraph>More reliance was placed on spoken word, promises, and the honor of the other person.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Clothing for villagers and common folk had to be comfortable, durable and practical. It consisted of a simple shirt and a tunic. Men also wore <italic>braies</italic> (knee-length linen trousers). In winter they wore hooded cloaks, furs and hats. All rather in natural colours without decorations. The exception was <accent>festive clothing</accent> for festive occasions and religious holidays.</paragraph><paragraph>In the city, clothing reflected status, wealth, but also affiliation to a particular group, such as craftsmen, soldiers or apprentices. Belts, bags, gloves, hats and other headgear were used as accessories.</paragraph><heading>Hairstyles</heading><paragraph><accent>Unwed young women</accent> had long hair, which they wore down or in braids.
