Women in towns adorned their hair with ribbons, pearls, wreaths and vines. Older <accent>married women</accent> wore pearled nets on their heads, white or coloured veils or hats. Fashionable <accent>men</accent> had long, coiffured hair, they liked to shave their chins and wear various headwear.</paragraph><heading>Jewellery</heading><paragraph>Jewellery was fashioned from gems, wood, leather and metals. The most common types of jewellery were <accent>earrings</accent>, various types of crosses and, in the High Middle Ages, <accent>rings</accent>, which were both representative and symbolic. Floral and animal themes as well as figural motifs inspired by religious themes predominated in decoration.</paragraph><heading>Footwear</heading><paragraph>Shoes were made of leather, but also of grass, straw, bast, wood, cloth or felt. In the countryside, people often went barefoot in summertime. <accent>Soles</accent> (left and right) on shoes first appeared in the mid 14th century while heels were added in the 15th century.The most common type of footwear consisted of sandals and slippers made of wood or cork. Stitched shoes were called either <italic>škrpály</italic> (low shoes) or <italic>škorně</italic> (above the ankle).</paragraph>

<paragraph>Clothing for villagers and common folk had to be comfortable, durable and practical. It consisted of a simple shirt and a tunic. Men also wore <italic>braies</italic> (knee-length linen drawers). In winter they wore hooded cloaks, furs and hats. All typically in natural colours without embellishments. The exception was <accent>festive attire</accent> for special occasions and religious holidays.</paragraph><paragraph>In the city, clothing reflected status, wealth, but also affiliation to a particular group, such as craftsmen, soldiers or apprentices. Belts, bags, gloves, hats and other headgear were used as accessories.</paragraph><heading>Hairstyles</heading><paragraph><accent>Unwed young women</accent> had long hair, which they wore down or in braids. Women in towns adorned their hair with ribbons, pearls, wreaths and vines. Older <accent>married women</accent> wore pearled nets on their heads, white or coloured veils or hats. Fashionable <accent>men</accent> had long, coiffured hair, they liked to shave their chins and wear various headwear.</paragraph><heading>Jewellery</heading><paragraph>Jewellery was fashioned from gems, wood, leather and metals. The most common types of jewellery were <accent>earrings</accent>, various types of crosses and, in the High Middle Ages, <accent>rings</accent>, which were both representative and symbolic. Floral and animal themes as well as figural motifs inspired by religious themes predominated in decoration.</paragraph><heading>Footwear</heading><paragraph>Shoes were made of leather, but also of grass, straw, bast, wood, cloth or felt. In the countryside, people often went barefoot in summertime. <accent>Soles</accent> (left and right) on shoes first appeared in the mid 14th century while heels were added in the 15th century.The most common type of footwear consisted of sandals and slippers made of wood or cork. Stitched shoes were called either <italic>škrpály</italic> (low shoes) or <italic>škorně</italic> (above the ankle).</paragraph>

<paragraph>Feudalism is a political system based on land ownership, which originated in the early Middle Ages and followed on from the decline of the Holy Roman Empire.</paragraph><paragraph>Its foundation was <accent>a fiefdom</accent> (<italic>feudum</italic>), this being a certain area (territory, land) that the owner loaned out to others. The ruler – either secular or religious – was the natural <accent>feudal senior</accent> (<italic>sovereign liege</italic>) and those afforded his fiefdoms were his <accent>fiefs</accent> (or <italic>vassals</italic>).</paragraph><paragraph>The handover itself came with pomp and ceremony, during which the vassal promised allegiance and military aid (or other services) to his feudal lord. The contract could be cancelled only by the death of one of the parties or by a material breach.</paragraph><paragraph>Not only could the liege have several vassals, a vassal could have several liege lords. In the event of a war one had to choose sides by one's contractual tenure.</paragraph><paragraph>Feudalism also determined the relations of poorest layers — the serfs, who worked on the leased land, paid dues out of what they made of it and provided for their master, his soldiers and officials or for the monastery. It was called a <accent>quit-rent</accent> – a source of wealth, mainly for the nobility. Portions of the lands were subleased so the king's vassal in turn became the liege lord of his own vassals.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Feudalism is a political system based on land ownership that emerged in the early Middle Ages, following the decline of the Roman Empire.</paragraph><paragraph>Its foundation was the <accent>fiefdom</accent> (<italic>feudum</italic>), a certain area (territory, land) that an owner would grant to others. The ruler – either secular or ecclesiastical – was the <accent>feudal liege</accent> (<italic>suzerain</italic>) and those afforded his fiefdoms were his <accent>liege subjects</accent> (or <italic>vassals</italic>).</paragraph><paragraph>The handover itself came with pomp and ceremony, during which the vassal promised allegiance and military aid (or other services) to his feudal lord. The contract could only be annulled by the death of one of the parties or by a severe breach of the agreement.</paragraph><paragraph>Not only could the liege have several vassals, a vassal could also serve several liege lords. In the event of war, the vassal had to choose one side according to the feudal contract.</paragraph><paragraph>Feudalism also determined the conditions of the poorest class — the serfs, who worked on the leased land, paid taxes from it, and supported their master, his soldiers and officials, or a monastery. It was called a <accent>feudal rent</accent> – a source of wealth, mainly for the nobility. Portions of the fiefs were subleased so the king's vassal in turn became the liege lord of his own vassals.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Weapons made of wood, stone, bone and antler were used by mankind as early as the Paleolithic era. At first, due to the materials used, stabbing weapons were widespread - spears, knives, arrows..., later, with the technology of metalworking, weapons of the chopping type began to be produced: daggers, axes, swords... In addition to these two traditional types, we also know striking, throwing, handguns, artillery and positional weapons. In the Middle Ages, there were spears, halberds and crossbows. In the village, agricultural tools were often used as weapons. From the 14th century, gunpowder cannon began to be used in Europe (known in China for a long time) and firearms in general slowly spread. We have surviving records of the use of small firearms in Bohemia from the reign of Wenceslas IV - they were used in 1398 during the conquest of the archbishop's court at Kyje near Prague.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Humans have been using weapons made of wood, stone, bone, and antlers since the Paleolithic era. Initially, due to the materials used, piercing weapons like spears, knives, and arrows were the most common. Later, with advancements in metalworking techniques, slashing weapons such as daggers, axes, and swords began to be produced. Besides these two traditional types, we also know of striking, throwing, hand-held firearms, artillery, and positional weapons. In the medieval period, spears, halberds, and crossbows were common. In villages, agricultural tools were often used as weapons. From the 14th century, cannons using gunpowder (known in China much earlier) started to be used in Europe, and firearms began to spread gradually. Records of the use of hand-held firearms in Bohemia date back to the reign of Wenceslaus IV, with their use documented in 1398 during the siege of the archbishop's court in Kyje near Prague.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Fishing was one of the most traditional ways of making a living. Fishing in flowing water had been the same for centuries, only in the 13th century did monasteries begin to establish fishery ponds, particularly for breeding carp.</paragraph><paragraph>Fish were considered lent food and, as such, given the frequency of religious holidays and fasting days (up to a third of the days in a year) they became an unmissable part of the diet. The greatest boom in fisheries and fish farming in the Czech Lands came in the 15th and 16th centuries.</paragraph><paragraph>Fishing methods made use of various tools and traps, such as bones and wicker baskets, bottomless baskets, fishing line or rod with hook, hemp nets with stone weights.</paragraph><paragraph>Every river belonged to the King and the city had leased access. Fishing was permitted only on prescribed days and hours. Some noblemen, despite this regulation, banned townspeople from fishing on pain of death.</paragraph><paragraph>Nets were set by day, because fishing at night was prohibited. Rod and line fishing was allowed even by those without a net fishing permit, since the success rate of rod fishing was insignificant.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Fishing was one of the oldest methods of making a living. Fishing took place in flowing waters, and it was not until the 13th century that monasteries began establishing ponds primarily for carp farming.</paragraph><paragraph>Fish were considered fasting food, and with the frequency of religious holidays and fasting days at that time (up to one-third of the year), they became an integral part of the popular diet. The greatest development of pond farming and fish breeding in the Czech lands occurred in the 15th and 16th centuries.</paragraph><paragraph>Various tools and traps were used for fishing, such as bones, wicker baskets, baskets without bottoms, fishing rods with lines, or rods with hooks, and hemp nets with stone weights.</paragraph><paragraph>All rivers belonged to the king, and were leased to towns. Fishing was only allowed on certain days and hours. Despite this regulation, some nobles prohibited townspeople from fishing under threat of capital punishment.</paragraph><paragraph>Nets were laid during the day because fishing at night was forbidden. Fishing with a rod was permitted even for those who did not have permission to fish with a net, as the success rate of fishing with a rod was minimal.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, whether at a village or the Royal Court, the <accent>foodstuffs</accent> used were mainly those sourced locally – vegetables: primarily cabbage, onions, parsnips, turnips, beets and garlic, and to a lesser extent carrots, celeriac, parsley, cucumbers and melons; legumes: peas, lentils, vetches and beans; fruit: apples, pears, cherries and plums, and berries, nuts, seeds and cereals. Eggs, milk and cheese were available all year round.</paragraph><paragraph>Depending on wealth, availability and the seasons, there was <accent>meat</accent> (venison, poultry, fish) and from abroad spices, fruits and condiments, including saffron, dates, figs, nutmeg, pepper, sugar, ginger and cardamom. Food was flavoured with oil, vinegar, salt, honey and herbs.</paragraph><paragraph> The most popular kinds of food in the 14th and 15th centuries, especially in countryside, were thick broth soups, purées and sauces for dunking bread in. The bread was rye, with white bread only available at Court. Meat was expensive and hunting in the forests prohibited (all game belonged to the aristocracy), which was mostly compensated for by eating fish.</paragraph><paragraph> During <accent>feasts</accent> there were fish dishes - using herring, for example - roast meats, sausages, minced meat and black pudding. Desserts were made with almonds, marzipan, sweet purées with fruit boiled in milk or with added cream, jams and preserves, baked, fresh or dried fruits and assorted cakes.</paragraph><paragraph> Many ingredients that are common today were unavailable in the Middle Ages, such as potatoes, tomatoes, sweetcorn, peppers and rice, which later made their way to Europe after the discovery of America or as imports from Asia.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, both in villages and at royal courts, primarily <accent>locally available foods</accent> were used. Vegetables included cabbage, onions, parsnips, turnips, beets, garlic, with smaller quantities of carrots, celery, parsley, cucumbers and melons. Legumes such as peas, lentils, vetch and broad beans were common, alongside fruits like apples, pears, cherries, plums, berries, nuts, seeds and grains. Eggs, milk and cheeses were available year-round.</paragraph><paragraph>Depending on wealth, availability and the season, <accent>meat</accent> (game, poultry, fish) and imported goods like spices, fruits and delicacies such as saffron, dates, figs, nutmeg, pepper, sugar, ginger and cardamom were also consumed. Meals were seasoned with oils, vinegar, salt, honey and herbs.</paragraph><paragraph>The most popular dishes in the 14th and 15th centuries, especially in rural areas, were hearty soups, thickened porridges, and sauces served with bread. Rye bread was common, while white bread was reserved for the court. Meat was expensive, and hunting in forests (reserved for nobles) was prohibited, so fish often compensated for its scarcity.</paragraph><paragraph>During a <accent>lavish feast</accent>, dishes with fish like pike, various roasted meats, sausages, minced meat, black pudding and legumes were essential. Desserts included almonds, marzipan, sweet porridges with fruit cooked in milk or with added cream, jams, baked, raw and dried fruits, and assorted pastries.</paragraph><paragraph>In the Middle Ages, many of today's common ingredients were unavailable, such as potatoes, tomatoes, corn, peppers, rice or beans, which generally arrived in Europe only after the discovery of the Americas or through Asian imports.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The safe-conduct document was issued by a member of the highest social tier to guarantee the bearer's <accent>safety</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>Most often it gave protection in a particular territory during the journey, and sometimes the bearer was also provided with an armed escort.</paragraph><paragraph>For example, Jan Hus received a letter of safe-conduct from Sigismund of Luxembourg when he went to the Council of Constance. He did indeed survive the journey in good health, though the safe conduct did nothing to save him from death by the flame.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A safe-conduct pass was a document issued by a member of the highest social class to ensure the holder’s <accent>safety</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>Most often, it provided protection in a specific territory during a journey, and sometimes the holder was given an escort along with the safe-conduct pass.</paragraph><paragraph>For example, Jan Hus received a safe-conduct pass from Sigismund of Luxembourg when he traveled to the Council of Constance. He indeed survived the journey to the council, but it did not save him from death in the flames after the ecclesiastical trial…</paragraph>

<paragraph>Also known as the Great State or the Ulus of Jochi, it was a large Mongol-Tatar state formation extending across Eastern Europe and Siberia. It was originally formed as part of the Mongol Empire, became a fully independent state in 1260, and later embraced Islam. Until the mid-14th century, it was the largest and militarily strongest state in all of Eastern Europe, occupying much of what is now Ukraine or Russia, with unimaginable profits from the taxes levied on its conquered territories. However, as a result of internal divisions and waning momentum, the khanate's power gradually began to decline, until in 1380, at the First Battle of Kulikovo, the horde was significantly defeated by the Russian princes for the first time.</paragraph><paragraph>The core of the Mongol-Tatar army was light cavalry with bows and arrows, whose mobility and 'hit-and-run' capability was unmatched by the then low-mobility armoured armies. The main strategy of the advancing hordes, then, was cruel plundering and scorched earth tactics, as this was the only way to deter conquered lands from attempting to resist.</paragraph><paragraph>We write about the horde in particular because it was the basis of the Cuman ethnicity and warfare, and because it strongly shaped the migration and warfare of the time.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Also known as the Great State or the Ulus of Jochi, it was a large Mongol-Tatar state entity extending across Eastern Europe and Siberia. It was originally formed as part of the Mongol Empire, became a fully independent state in 1260, and later embraced Islam. Until the mid-14th century, it was the largest and militarily strongest state in all of Eastern Europe, occupying much of what is now Ukraine and Russia, with unimaginable profits from the taxes levied on its conquered territories. However, as a result of internal divisions and waning momentum, the khanate's power gradually began to decline, until in 1380, at the First Battle of Kulikovo, the horde was significantly defeated by the Russian princes for the first time.</paragraph><paragraph>The core of the Mongol-Tatar army was light cavalry with bows and arrows, whose mobility and 'hit-and-run' capability was unmatched by the slow moving heavily armoured armies of the time. The main strategy of advancing hordes was ruthless pillaging and scorched earth tactics, aimed at deterring subjected lands from attempting resistance.</paragraph><paragraph>We write about the horde in particular because it was the basis of Cuman ethnicity and warfare, and because it strongly shaped the migration and warfare of the time.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The gravedigger's profession took care of the graves and their surroundings and was inherited. The beginning of the professionalization of the profession was associated with the introduction of Christian cemeteries.</paragraph><paragraph>The gravedigger lived in a wooden hut, right in the cemetery, next to the main entrance and took care of the running of the entire cemetery. He performed his work not only in the village, where he lived, but also visited the surrounding villages. He was also responsible for exhuming the human remains and placing the bones in the ossuary, thus ensuring enough space in the cemetery.</paragraph><paragraph>A proper burial was far from being affordable for all the townspeople. In some places, the poor dead were cared for by so-called 'grave people', who carried them to mass pits in cemeteries. The gravedigger was also not allowed to be present at the funerals of the unchurched in the eyes of the church, such as suicides or delinquents, for whom denial of burial represented the church's ultimate punishment for breaking its laws.</paragraph><paragraph>Gravediggers belonged among the undesirables on the margins of society, the only one who came into contact with them was the parish priest.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The gravedigger profession took care of graves and their surroundings and was hereditary. The beginnings of the professionalisation of this occupation was associated with the introduction of Christian cemeteries.</paragraph><paragraph>The gravedigger lived in a wooden hut, right in the cemetery, next to the main entrance and took care of the running of the entire cemetery. He performed his work not only in the village, where he lived, but also visited surrounding villages. He was also responsible for exhuming human remains and placing bones in the ossuary, thus ensuring enough space in the cemetery.</paragraph><paragraph>A proper burial was far from affordable for many townspeople. In some places, the deceased poor were cared for by so-called 'grave people', who carried them to mass graves in cemeteries. The gravedigger was also not allowed to be present at the funerals of those deemed dishonourable in the eyes of the church, such as suicides or delinquents, for whom denial of burial represented the church's ultimate punishment for breaking its laws.</paragraph><paragraph>Gravediggers belonged among the undesirables on the margins of society, the only one who came into contact with them was the parish priest.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The village was founded by miners sometime in the mid-13th century, when silver ore began to be mined in the area. In the 1370s, according to records, 300 miners and their families were already permanently settled on the nearby Kuklík hill. Legends say that when King Přemysl Otakar II went to battle and needed horses for his army, he picked up 500 of them in Kuklík alone, which interrupted mining for a while and the miners had to leave.</paragraph><paragraph>Under Wenceslas II, new silver veins were discovered, which attracted new miners. The village began to expand and the German name for it became <italic>"Grunt in Mariae"</italic> (Valley or Mine of the Virgin Mary, abbreviated to Grunta in Czech). In addition to residential houses, infrastructure for processing the extracted ore also began to appear, as well as facilities for sorting, crushing or smelting. The waste from mining was enormous, so the remaining tailings and slag began to be exported around the area and new landforms were created.</paragraph><paragraph>In the village there is also the Church of the Visitation of the Virgin Mary. Already in records from 1305 it is written that it was dilapidated, so it is not surprising that in 1367 a new church was built by local miners and townspeople of Kutná Hora.</paragraph><paragraph>The mining and metallurgical area operated here intermittently until the 15th century, when silver reserves were almost exhausted (it is estimated that 80% of the ore was mined here in less than three centuries).</paragraph>

<paragraph>The village was founded by miners sometime in the mid-13th century, when silver ore began to be mined in the area. In the 1270s, according to records, 300 miners and their families were already permanently settled on the nearby Kuklík hill. Legends say that when King Přemysl Otakar II of Bohemia went to battle and needed horses for his army, he took 500 of them from Kuklík alone, which interrupted mining for a while and the miners had to leave.</paragraph><paragraph>Under Wenceslas II, new silver veins were discovered, which attracted new miners. The village began to expand and the German name for it became <italic>'Grunt in Mariae'</italic> (Valley or Mine of the Virgin Mary, abbreviated to Grunta in Czech). In addition to residential houses, infrastructure for processing the extracted ore also began to appear, as well as facilities for sorting, crushing or smelting. The waste from mining was enormous, so the remaining tailings and slag began to be exported around the area and new landforms were created.</paragraph><paragraph>In the village there is also the Church of the Visitation of the Virgin Mary. Already in records from 1305 it is written that it was delapidated, so it is not surprising that in 1367 a new church was built by local miners and townspeople of Kuttenberg.</paragraph><paragraph>The mining and smelting premises operated here intermittently until the 15th century, when silver reserves were almost exhausted (it is estimated that 80% of the ore was mined here in less than three centuries).</paragraph>

<paragraph>Firearms first appeared in Europe in the 14th century and began to see widespread use by the early 15th century.</paragraph> <paragraph>In the Kingdom of Bohemia, they became pivotal during the Hussite Wars. Interestingly, the Hussites influenced the naming of early firearms, which spread worldwide. For example, the English word <italic>pistol</italic> for the lightest handheld firearm originates from the Czech <italic>píšťala</italic>, originally meaning a pipe or flute.</paragraph> <paragraph>This weapon featured a relatively short forged barrel with a socket mounted on a wooden shaft, allowing the shooter to hold it under their arm. The ammunition included solid balls, grapeshot or specially-shaped projectiles that whistled in flight to frighten horses.</paragraph> <paragraph>Gunpowder was poured into the barrel, sealed with wadding and the projectile was inserted, all then tamped down with a ramrod. It was ignited through a touchhole using a smouldering fuse or a heated piece of iron. Early firearms were highly inaccurate and had a short range, barely a few dozen metres, but even at that distance, they could pierce solid armour.</paragraph> <paragraph>Another popular handheld firearm in Central Europe was the hook gun. It featured a steel or bronze barrel with an average calibre of 20 to 30 mm, mounted on a wooden stock. Like the píšťala, it had a hook under the muzzle, which allowed the weapon to be braced against a wall, parapet or the edge of a battle wagon during firing, significantly reducing its heavy recoil.</paragraph> <paragraph>For besieging cities or fortresses, much larger and heavier firearms were used, such as wall guns, howitzers and cannons.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Firearms first appeared in Europe in the 14th century and began to see widespread use by the early 15th century.</paragraph> <paragraph>In the Kingdom of Bohemia, they became pivotal during the Hussite Wars. Interestingly, the Hussites influenced the naming of early firearms, which spread worldwide. For example, the English word <italic>pistol</italic> for the lightest handheld firearm originates from the Czech <italic>píšťala</italic>, originally meaning a pipe or flute.</paragraph> <paragraph>This weapon featured a relatively short forged barrel with a socket mounted on a wooden shaft, allowing the shooter to hold it under their arm. The ammunition included solid balls, grapeshot or specially-shaped projectiles that whistled in flight to frighten horses.</paragraph> <paragraph>Gunpowder was poured into the barrel, sealed with wadding and the projectile was inserted, all then tamped down with a ramrod. It was ignited through a touchhole using a smouldering fuse or a heated piece of iron. Early firearms were highly inaccurate and had a short range, barely a few dozen metres, but even at that distance, they could pierce solid armour.</paragraph> <paragraph>Another popular handheld firearm in Central Europe was the hook gun. It featured a steel or bronze barrel with an average calibre of 20 to 30 mm, mounted on a wooden stock. Like the píšťala, it had a hook under the muzzle, which allowed the weapon to be braced against a wall, parapet or the edge of a battle wagon during firing, significantly reducing its heavy recoil.</paragraph> <paragraph>For besieging cities or fortresses, much larger and heavier firearms were used, such as wall guns, howitzers and cannons.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Black powder is the oldest known explosive, discovered around the 9th century in China. Initially, it was used in medicine and widely experimented with by alchemists. However, when it failed to yield the anticipated elixir of immortality, its powerful explosive properties began to be used for ammunition production. It likely arrived in Europe as early as the 13th century, although some experts believe that Europeans discovered black powder independently of China.</paragraph><paragraph>The European inventor of gunpowder is typically attributed to either the German alchemist Berthold "The Black"Schwarz, or, according to other sources, the German friar Albertus Magnus, who was familiar with the recipe for gunpowder as early as 1275. Another mention can be found in the work of the alchemist Marcus Graecus, who included a black powder recipe in his writings around 1300. However, at this time, gunpowder was not yet commonly used in combat.</paragraph><paragraph>Originally, a fine particle mixture known as “meal powder,” produced by grinding the individual components, was used for shooting. Later, methods were developed to produce larger grains, which significantly improved the consistency of ballistic properties and accuracy in shooting.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Black powder is the oldest known explosive, discovered around the 9th century in China. Initially, it was used in medicine and widely experimented with by alchemists. However, when it failed to yield the anticipated elixir of immortality, its powerful explosive properties began to be used for ammunition production. It likely arrived in Europe as early as the 13th century, although some experts believe that Europeans discovered black powder independently of China.</paragraph><paragraph>The European inventor of gunpowder is typically attributed to either the German alchemist Berthold "The Black" Schwarz, or, according to other sources, the German friar Albertus Magnus, who was familiar with the recipe for gunpowder as early as 1275. Another mention can be found in the work of the alchemist Marcus Graecus, who included a black powder recipe in his writings around 1300. However, at this time, gunpowder was not yet commonly used in combat.</paragraph><paragraph>Originally, a fine particle mixture known as “meal powder,” produced by grinding the individual components, was used for shooting. Later, methods were developed to produce larger grains, which significantly improved the consistency of ballistic properties and accuracy in shooting.</paragraph>

<paragraph>While in the medieval quarries the hard work was done by rock cutters and stone masons, in the mines skilled labourers worked for wages - <accent>miners</accent>. It was a tough work. Only with the help of hammers and chisels (these tools are depicted on the first Kuttenberg coat of arms) and the light of small hand-held lamps, did they extract the valuable ore.</paragraph><paragraph>The mining in the rock was slow, but thanks to the perseverance and shift work, they eventually dug underground tunnels reaching hundreds of metres (sometimes up to 450m). This created larger and conveniently passable horizontal and vertical shafts - underground pits - from which smaller galleries ran out in chains, where miners literally had to crawl on all fours. Safe movement in such conditions was ensured by a unique, durable clothing, the most essential part of which was a leather apron and knee pads.</paragraph><paragraph>The demanding and prolonged work was quickened by the so-called <italic>fire planting</italic>. A fire was lit at the end of the shaft, cracking the rock, and making it easier to chip away. Even so, mining was dangerous and exhausting. Therefore, the miners' wives often became widows many times over.</paragraph><paragraph>Each miner was thoroughly searched when leaving his shift, because the silver belonged to the king and there were severe penalties for theft. Still, they did occur, for as the age-old saying goes: 'The brazen miners on the rocks, have work until Saturday, but money only until Sunday.'</paragraph>

<paragraph>While in the medieval quarries the hard work was done by rock cutters and stone masons, in the mines skilled labourers - <accent>miners</accent> worked for wages. It was tough work. Using only hammers and chisels (these tools are depicted on the first Kuttenberg coat of arms) and by the light of small hand-held lamps, did they extract the valuable ore.</paragraph><paragraph>Mining in the rock was slow, but thanks to perseverance and shift work, they eventually dug underground tunnels reaching hundreds of metres (sometimes up to 450m). This created larger and more passable horizontal and vertical shafts - underground pits - from which smaller galleries ran out in chains, where miners had to literally crawl on all fours. Safe movement in such conditions was ensured by unique, durable clothing, the most essential parts of which were a leather apron and knee pads.</paragraph><paragraph>The arduous and prolonged work was expedited by a method called <italic>fire setting</italic>. A fire was set at the end of the shaft, cracking the rock, and making it easier to chip away. Even so, mining was dangerous and exhausting, and miners' wives often became widows many times over.</paragraph><paragraph>Every miner was thoroughly searched after his shift, because the silver belonged to the king and there were severe penalties for theft. Still, they did occur, for as the age-old saying goes: 'The brazen miners have work till Saturday, but coin only till Sunday.'</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Leshy, also known as Heykal or simply the Wild Man of the Woods, is a forest demon according to Czech mythology. His appearance is similar to the East Slavic Leshy, but also to the classical fauns and satyrs or the Western European tradition.</paragraph><paragraph>He has no soul and lives apart from human society – deep in forests, caves or rocks. His body is covered in fur or moss, sometimes only sparsely clothed, and he got the name Heykal from his terrifying call (Czech hýkat means "to bray"). This sound must not be imitated by humans; otherwise, the Leshy will pursue them, jump on their back and chase them through the forest, or tear them apart. It is said that the most dangerous demons were found in the Plzeň region.</paragraph><paragraph>People believed that the wild men would capture young girls and take them as wives, and if a girl escaped, they would tear her child apart. Leshies also enjoyed frightening travellers and leading them astray. Protection against them could be achieved by swithing over one's shoes, turning pockets inside out or carrying a piece of bread.</paragraph><paragraph>The female counterparts of the Leshy are Divozhenkas, Forest Maidens or Fairies.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Leshy, also known as Heykal or simply the Wild Man of the Woods, is a forest demon according to Czech mythology. His appearance is similar to the East Slavic Leshy, but also to the classical fauns and satyrs or the Western European tradition.</paragraph><paragraph>He has no soul and lives apart from human society – deep in forests, caves or rocks. His body is covered in fur or moss, sometimes only sparsely clothed, and he got the name Heykal from his terrifying call (Czech hýkat means "to bray"). This sound must not be imitated by humans; otherwise, the Leshy will pursue them, jump on their back and chase them through the forest, or tear them apart. It is said that the most dangerous demons were found in the Plzeň region.</paragraph><paragraph>People believed that the wild men would capture young girls and take them as wives, and if a girl escaped, they would tear her child apart. Leshies also enjoyed frightening travellers and leading them astray. Protection against them could be achieved by swithing over one's shoes, turning pockets inside out or carrying a piece of bread.</paragraph><paragraph>The female counterparts of the Leshy are Divozhenkas, Forest Maidens or Fairies.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Heraldry is the doctrine of <accent>characters</accent> and <accent>symbols</accent> depicted on the <accent>coats of arms</accent>, governed by fixed rules, and the relevant know-how was privy to nobles and knights.</paragraph><paragraph>It was a necessity, because Europe of that time had so many noble families, they simply could not be memorized. By applying heraldic symbolism and rules, however, the wearer and his dynasty could be identified from his battle pennants and coat of arms.</paragraph><paragraph>Simplified heraldic symbolism was also used on the arms and equipment of urban militias and the attire of soldiers of a feudal lord.</paragraph><paragraph>Even today one can use formal expert heraldic terminology, collectively referred to as <accent>Blazonry</accent>, to describe any shield. An expert can thus very precisely produce any coat of arms or emblem solely from a verbal description. The description always begins on the top right from the wearer’s perspective, meaning the top left from the observer’s perspective. It includes details of the individual <accent>tinctures of the fields</accent>, <accent>heraldic charges</accent> and <accent>escutcheons</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>For our purposes we have endeavoured to keep the art of <accent>blazonry</accent> authentic, including period terms. However, we have modified some for better clarity and ease of orientation in painting shields.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Heraldry is the doctrine of <accent>characters</accent> and <accent>symbols</accent> depicted on the <accent>coats of arms</accent>, governed by fixed rules, and the relevant know-how was privy to nobles and knights.</paragraph><paragraph>It was a necessity, because Europe of that time had so many noble families, they simply could not be memorized. By applying heraldic symbolism and rules, however, the wearer and his dynasty could be identified from his battle pennants and coat of arms.</paragraph><paragraph>Simplified heraldic symbolism was also used on the arms and equipment of urban militias and the attire of soldiers of a feudal lord.</paragraph><paragraph>Even today one can use formal expert heraldic terminology, collectively referred to as <accent>Blazonry</accent>, to describe any shield. An expert can thus very precisely produce any coat of arms or emblem solely from a verbal description. The description always begins on the top right from the wearer’s perspective, meaning the top left from the observer’s perspective. It includes details of the individual <accent>tinctures of the fields</accent>, <accent>heraldic charges</accent> and <accent>escutcheons</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>For our purposes we have endeavoured to keep the art of <accent>blazonry</accent> authentic, including period terms. However, we have modified some for better clarity and ease of orientation in painting shields.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The settlement on the border of the Kolín and Kutná Hora regions has probably been inhabited since time immemorial. In the 1970s, a borehole discovered a prehistoric granary with remains of pottery of the so-called Knovíz culture (8th-6th century BC).</paragraph><paragraph>As far as the preserved records are concerned, Hořany is mentioned in 1299, when Václav II handed it over to the Sedlec monastery and Markvart Šik of Kutná Hora. In 1437, Sigismund of Luxembourg (by then already Emperor) pawned the village to the "Hussite king" Jiri of Poděbrady.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The settlement on the border of the Kolin and Kuttenberg regions was likely inhabited since ancient times. In the 1970s, a borehole discovered a prehistoric granary with remains of pottery of the so-called Knovíz culture (8th-6th century BC).</paragraph><paragraph>Regarding preserved records, Horschan is mentioned in 1299, when Wenceslas II handed it over to the Sedletz monastery and Markvart Šik of Kuttenberg. In 1437, Sigismund of Luxembourg (by then already Emperor) pledged the village to the 'Hussite King', George of Podiebrad.</paragraph>

<paragraph>For the proper organization, administration, and control of Kuttenberg mining, it was necessary by the end of the 13th century to appoint a considerable number of royal and supervisory officials and overseers.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to stewards who collected taxes from the mined ore, mining offices also employed urban clerks, miners, judges, or senior steigers. The internal operation of the mines was managed by mining <accent>overmen</accent> (<italic>hormasters</italic>, from the German <italic>Bergmeister</italic>), other clerks, foremen, and other overseers.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Steigers</accent>, or royal chief miners, oversaw the adherence to fiscal regulations within the mines.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>chief mining officer</accent> leased mines and presided over mining courts. He was someone from the Kuttenberg council.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1386, the office of <accent>mintmaster</accent> was established, responsible for the administration of the mines, the quality and minting of coins, the collection of mining taxes, and the operation of mining activities.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Mining offices</accent> not only supervised the miners and awarded benefits to the miners but also helped secure wages, provided for the families of miners in case of their death, and supported those who worked in difficult conditions. Those who took on flooded and abandoned mines were granted reduced mining taxes and other benefits.</paragraph>

<paragraph>For the proper organization, administration, and control of Kuttenberg mining, it was necessary by the end of the 13th century to appoint a considerable number of royal and supervisory officials and overseers.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to stewards who collected taxes from the mined ore, mining offices also employed urban clerks, miners, judges, or senior steigers. The internal operation of the mines was managed by <accent>mine masters</accent> (<italic>hormasters</italic>, from the German <italic>Bergmeister</italic>), other clerks, foremen, and other overseers.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Steigers</accent>, or royal chief miners, oversaw the adherence to fiscal regulations within the mines.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>chief mining officer</accent> leased mines and presided over mining courts. He was someone from the Kuttenberg council.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1386, the office of <accent>Mint Master</accent> was established, responsible for the administration of the mines, the quality and minting of coins, the collection of mining taxes, and the operation of mining activities.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Mining offices</accent> not only supervised the miners and awarded benefits to them but also helped secure wages, provided for the families of miners in case of their death, and supported those who worked in difficult conditions. Those who took on flooded and abandoned mines were granted reduced mining taxes and other benefits.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In itself, the Czech word for a tavern, ‘hospoda' may originate from the Latin <italic>‘hospes'</italic> – guest, </italic>‘hospitium'</italic> – hospitality, shelter. But the more likely etymology is from the old Slavonic <italic>‘gospod, gospodja'</italic> – the Master of the House.</paragraph><paragraph>Pubs were an integral part of all medieval villages. Originally, beer was drawn in what was called the <italic>maashouse</italic>, an area on the ground floor of the Municipal House, whose owner had beer brewing rights, and special-purpose taverns and inns came along later. These served as places for social games, meetings, trading or overnighting.</paragraph><paragraph>Some inns had rooms for overnight guests and special stables and spaces for carriages – these were called coaching inns and were located out of town at crossroads or along trade routes. The seating arrangements were more often indoors rather than out.</paragraph><paragraph>It was said of Wenceslaus I that he very much liked to visit taverns and bars to listen to what local people had to say about him. He would also check to see if the owners were complying with his edicts.</paragraph><paragraph>In the Middle Ages, no one took exception to alcohol, that's for sure. The Germans, Russians and Czechs in particular were Europe's fabled drinkers. There was a formal curfew at dusk, or ‘when the night watchman begins his rounds', although drinking and feasting often went on until the early morning hours.</paragraph><paragraph>In KCD we have tried to keep the image of medieval taverns faithful to surviving records.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Czech word for tavern, ‘hospoda', may originate from the Latin <italic>‘hospes'</italic> – guest, <italic>‘hospitium'</italic> – hospitality, shelter, though the more likely etymology is from the old Slavonic <italic>‘gospod, gospodja'</italic> – the Master of the House.</paragraph><paragraph>Alehouses were an integral part of all medieval villages. Originally, beer was drawn in what was called the <italic>maashouse</italic>, an area on the ground floor of a townhouse whose owner had brewing rights, while special-purpose taverns and inns came along later. These served as places for social events, meetings, trading and lodgings.</paragraph><paragraph>Some inns had rooms for overnight guests and special stables and spaces for carriages – these were called wagoners' inns and were located out of town at crossroads and along trade routes. The seating was more often outdoors than indoors.</paragraph><paragraph>It was said of Wenceslas IV that he was fond of visiting taverns and alehouses to eavesdrop on what the locals had to say about him and to check that the owners were complying with his edicts.</paragraph><paragraph>In the Middle Ages, no one took exception to alcohol. The Germans, Russians and Czechs, in particular, were Europe's fabled drinkers. There was a formal curfew at dusk, or when the night watchman began his rounds, although drinking and feasting often went on until the early morning hours.</paragraph><paragraph>In KCD we have tried to keep the image of medieval taverns faithful to surviving records.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The core of the house in the Middle Age, whether in a village or town, consisted of a <accent>kitchen</accent>, a <accent>hall</accent> and <accent>living room</accent> (hearth room).</paragraph><paragraph>All were on the ground floor. Since the 15th century, upper storeys started to be added. The walls were insulated from the outside with clay daub, which also gave the house some fire protection. To save heat, windows were kept very small or nonexistent.</paragraph><paragraph>The grounds of the house were usually fenced in and the courtyard had gates broad enough to admit a covered wagon. Attached to the houses were <accent>utility buildings</accent>: barns, stables, outhouses, forges and wood sheds or food granaries. Waste was taken outside the house, into the fields, or disposed of in cesspits. Outside the house would be toilets built over sewage pits.</paragraph><paragraph>A typical village house was single-storey, with the front door leading in from the courtyard into a central space, off which was a living room and a chamber. The houses were built of wood on stone foundations.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>jizba</accent>, or main room of the village households, constituted the living space and kitchen, with an oven and a hearth. Above the hearth was a smoke hole to the roof space. Other areas served as stores for cereals, tools, food in jars or chests etc.</paragraph><paragraph>Lighting was provided by torches, candles in pottery candlesticks and most of all by firelight from the hearth. The floor was compacted clay mixed with straw, leaves or animal hair. The roof was typically thatched (sheafs of rye or reed straw, often doubled).</paragraph><paragraph>In front of the house was a garden and a courtyard with farm buildings for poultry, pigs and cattle.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The core of a late medieval house in both village and town consisted of a <accent>kitchen</accent>, a <accent>hall</accent>, and a <accent>living chamber</accent> (hearth room, parlour).</paragraph><paragraph>Everything was located on the ground floor. From the 15th century, additional floors were built, and the first multi-story houses appeared. The walls were insulated from the outside with a clay mixture, which also protected the house from fire. Windows were made very small or omitted altogether to retain heat.</paragraph><paragraph>The property was usually fenced, with a gate wide enough for a cart to enter the courtyard. Attached to the house were <accent>outbuildings</accent>: stables, barns, outhouses, ovens, and shelters for wood or food storage. Waste was taken outside the house, to the fields, or to dug-out cesspits. Toilets were built over these cesspits in front of the house.</paragraph><paragraph>A typical single-story, three-section village house had entrance doors from the courtyard leading into the central room, from which there were doors to the living room and the chamber. The houses were made of wood on stone foundations.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>hearth room</accent>, the main area of a village household, served for living and as a kitchen, containing an oven and a hearth. Above the hearth was a chimney leading to the attic. Other areas were used for storing grains, tools, food in containers or chests, and so on.</paragraph><paragraph>Torches, ceramic lamps, and mainly the fire from the hearth provided lighting. The floor was made of compacted clay, often mixed with straw, leaves, or animal hair. The roof was typically covered with thatch (bundles of rye straw or reeds, often double-layered).</paragraph><paragraph>In front of the house was a garden and a yard with outbuildings, where poultry, pigs, and cattle were kept.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Gords, sometimes called Burgwalls, were fortified settlements of various sizes, established from the Neolithic period right through to the early Middle Ages. They were built using the natural terrain or the protection of waterways, on islands or hills. Within the outer walls there would typically be a central fort.</paragraph><paragraph>These strongholds were mostly built from timber, with an outer palisade (stockade) and ditch or moat. The stronghold fulfilled a protective and strategic function in times of war and also served as a stopover on trade routes or as goods transfer stations.</paragraph><heading>Semine hillfort</heading><paragraph>Not far from the Semine fortres is the largest documented <accent>Celtic gord</accent> in the Czech lands - the Semine hillfort. The hardly accessible site, in the middle of forests and rocks, above the confluence of rivers, ideally fulfilled the conditions for a strategic settlement. The Celts probably built here an oppidium - an early Middle Age form of fortified settlement - or a refugium - a temporary asylum during wars.</paragraph><paragraph>According to research, the fortress had three ramparts and moats in addition to natural fortifications. Inside, pottery from the La Tène period and remains of masonry made of black basalt, which was also used at Trosky Castle, were found. This suggests that the hillfort may even have been surrounded by a stone wall.</paragraph><paragraph>According to some hypotheses, the Celts also had a <accent>sacred place</accent> here, because at the time of the solar equinox, the sunset can be seen from the top of Semine hill between the rocks on which Trosky Castle stands.</paragraph><paragraph>Since 2018, a reconstruction of the hillfort has been standing on the site, where it is possible to learn about the history of Bohemian Paradise.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Gords or hillforts, sometimes called Burgwalls, were fortified settlements of various sizes, established from the Neolithic period right through to the early Middle Ages. They were built using natural terrain or the protection of waterways, on islands or hills. Within the outer walls there would typically be a central fort.</paragraph><paragraph>These strongholds were mostly built from timber, with an outer palisade (stockade) and ditch or moat. The stronghold fulfilled a protective and strategic function in times of war and also served as a stopover on trade routes or as goods transfer stations.</paragraph><heading>Semine hillfort</heading><paragraph>Not far from the Semine fortress is the largest documented <accent>Celtic gord</accent> in the Czech lands. The hardly accessible site, in the middle of forests and rocks, above the confluence of rivers, ideally fulfilled the conditions for a strategic settlement. The Celts probably built an oppidium here - an early Medieval form of fortified settlement - or a refugium - a temporary refuge during wars.</paragraph><paragraph>According to research, the fortress had three ramparts and moats in addition to natural fortifications. Inside, pottery from the La Tène period and remains of masonry made of black basalt, which was also used at Trosky Castle, were found. This suggests that the hillfort may have even been surrounded by a stone wall.</paragraph><paragraph>According to some hypotheses, the Celts also had a <accent>sacred place</accent> here, as during the solar equinox, the sunset can be seen from the top of Semine hill between the rocks on which Trosky Castle stands.</paragraph><paragraph>Since 2018, a reconstruction of the hillfort has been standing on the site, where it is possible to learn about the history of Bohemian Paradise.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Gamekeeping and hunting in the Middle Ages were not only for amusement, but chiefly a source of great profit for the King and the nobility who owned the woods. The feudal <accent>huntsmen</accent> also undertook woodsmanshi, in addition to their obligation to look after the game, they took charge of the forest and its protection.</paragraph><paragraph>In the forests it was prohibited to hunt deer, fallow-deer, boar or any other game, violation of which was a criminal act subject to heavy fines, or even, in the case of repeated infringements, physical punishment. The same was true for unauthorized logging and collecting of timber.</paragraph><paragraph>Many <accent>poachers</accent> came from the ranks of the poor and had not very much to lose, which quite often resulted in physical conflicts with the huntsman when they were caught red-handed.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Hunting in the Middle Ages was not only a pastime but also brought significant economic profit to the king and the nobility who owned the forests. The noble <accent>hunters</accent> also acted as forest managers, taking care of the game as well as maintaining and protecting the forest.</paragraph> <paragraph>It was forbidden to hunt deer, fallow deer, roebucks, wild boars, and indeed any other game in the forests. Violating this prohibition was punishable by a high fine, or in the case of repeated offenses, even physical punishment. The same applied to unauthorized wood gathering and logging.</paragraph> <paragraph>Many <accent>poachers</accent> came from poorer social classes and had little to lose, so physical confrontations with the gamekeepers who caught them in the act were not uncommon.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Sufficient supplies of drinking water constituted a crucial matter for the medieval town. The townspeople often solved the issue by excavating <accent>wells</accent> in the grounds of their houses or even in the cellar. Apart from these, there were also public wells.</paragraph><paragraph>The same usually applied in castles, where a well was often dug out to collect water from a nearby source, such as a stream. Well-building was very costly and not possible everywhere. Castle wells could reach enormous depths, in extreme cases even more than 100m deep.</paragraph><paragraph>It proved more effectual to build a cistern - a tank that resembled a well, but did not have its own water source. They usually collected rain water, which was filtered, and would be emptied out once a year.</paragraph><paragraph> As well as the obtaining fresh water, <accent>drainage</accent> was necessary. The building of simple sewers or drains is attested to by instructions from aldermen regulating that these sewers be dug and maintained, follow the shortest route and covered from above. Especially in towns, open ditches along paved roads served as drains.</paragraph><paragraph>Such a system of sewage disposal was a nuisance to the populace, a source of unpleasant smells and spread infectious diseases and epidemics. Hence the originally open ditches were progressively covered over, eventually replaced by brick <accent>sewers</accent>, which diverted rainwater from the streets and roofs to the nearest watercourse or pond. The regularly recurring epidemics spreading around Europe later demanded a more radical solution.</paragraph>

<paragraph>An adequate supply of drinking water was a crucial issue for medieval towns. Townspeople often addressed this problem by building a <accent>well</accent> on their property or digging one directly in their cellar. Public wells were also established alongside private ones.</paragraph><paragraph>Similarly, on castles, a well was often dug to channel water from water sources such as a nearby stream. Castle wells could reach enormous depths, in extreme cases over 100 meters.</paragraph><paragraph>Building a well was very expensive and not always possible. A more economical solution proved to be the installation of a cistern, a reservoir that resembled a well but did not have its own water source. Most often, rainwater was directed into such a cistern, where it was filtered and would be emptied out once a year.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to acquiring water, its <accent>drainage</accent> was also addressed. The emergence of simple drains or conduits is evidenced by council regulations that required these drains to be deepened and maintained, led by the shortest route, and covered from above. In towns, especially, open ditches alongside paved roads were used for drainage.</paragraph><paragraph>Such a waste disposal system was bothersome to the population and was a source of odor, spreading infectious diseases and epidemics. Therefore, the originally open ditches were gradually covered, and later, brick <accent>sewers</accent> were constructed to channel rainwater from the streets and roofs of houses to the nearest watercourse or pond. However, the regularly recurring epidemics that spread across Europe demanded more radical solutions.</paragraph>

<paragraph>From the 13th century on, waste was dumped behind the house or buried in pits. <accent>Toilets</accent> consisted of cesspits topped with a wooden superstructure with a seat or just a board. There were water drainage systems and no lack of free-standing latrines or outhouses, or at castles 'privies'. It was not uncommon for a latrine to be shared between several dwellings.</paragraph><paragraph>In the inhospitable and badly-heated castles, there were sometimes <accent>bathrooms</accent> with bathtubs or even plunge pools. Swimming was attractive not just as a means of cleansing the body, but also for pleasure. In private houses a bathroom was a sign of luxury and high status. This did not mean that wealthier residents washed more often, just that they were more readily able to put on clean clothes. </paragraph><paragraph> The most common acts of hygiene included hand washing. Even the poorest homes affording a basin with a water pitcher or a suspended water cistern with a faucet. The cleanest people were villagers, who would often wash in the stables or the river. </paragraph><paragraph> The Church was generally against cleansing the body, and so allowed the priests or monks to bathe only twice a year--at Christmas and on the feast day of some chosen patron.</paragraph><paragraph>In spite of this there were <accent>public baths</accent> in each town where people went not just to get clean, but to socialize. Contrary to today's notions, the people of that time were not very prudish and men and women shared the bathhouse together. Even the urban poor had the right to visit the baths, paid for by the municipality.</paragraph>

<paragraph>From the 13th century on, waste was dumped behind dwellings or buried in pits. <accent>Toilets</accent> consisted of cesspits topped with wooden structures with a seat or just a board. There were water drainage systems and no lack of free-standing latrines and outhouses, or at castles 'privies'. It was not uncommon for a latrine to be shared between several dwellings.</paragraph><paragraph>In inhospitable and badly-heated castles, there were sometimes <accent>bathrooms</accent> with bathtubs or even plunge pools. Bathing was attractive not just as a means of cleansing the body, but also for pleasure. In private houses a bathroom was a sign of luxury and high status. This did not mean that wealthier residents bathed more frequently; rather, they were able to put on clean clothes more often. </paragraph><paragraph> The most common hygiene practice was handwashing. Even in the poorest homes it was possible to find a basin with a water pitcher or a suspended water cistern with a faucet. The cleanest people were countryfolk, who would often wash in the stables or the river. </paragraph><paragraph> The Church was generally against bodily cleanliness, and so allowed priests or monks to bathe only twice a year--at Christmas and on the feast day of some chosen patron.</paragraph><paragraph>In spite of this there were <accent>public baths</accent> in each town where people went not just to get clean, but to socialize. Contrary to today's notions, the people of that time were not very prudish and men and women shared the bathhouse together. Even the urban poor had the right to visit the baths, paid for by the municipality.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Inquisition (from Latin <italic>inquisitio</italic> - to search, to inquire) was founded in the 12th century as a response to the massive heretical movement of the Albigensians (Cathars). Originally it was intended to serve more as a tool to punish and direct the clergy, but later its main mission became to fight all the heretics. It was directly subordinate to the Pope, and thus became more or less an independent power.</paragraph><paragraph>The Inquisition had <accent>three main tasks</accent> - to search for heretics; to interrogate them and convict or bring them to reparation; and to refer the unrepentant to the secular authorities for punishment.</paragraph><paragraph>The incoming inquisitor first reported to the local bishop and then had a solemn mass and sermon celebrated. He then received reports (denunciations) of heresy from the local people. Heretics were given a so-called <italic>period of mercy</italic> in which they could declare themselves and ask for forgiveness. The inquisitor evaluated the reasonings and began his own process, which was more intended to confirm the accusations, rather than objectively examine them.</paragraph><paragraph>Although in the common consciousness, the Inquisition is mainly associated with cruel practices, fanatical actions, and a great fear of inquisitors, one of the intended purposes of the Inquisition and its operation, was to rationalize and legalize the trial of heretics and to suppress the practice of <italic>ordeals</italic> - <accent>the godly trials</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>The Inquisition process was therefore based primarily on the testimony and interrogation of the accused. The latter, however, had almost no rights and could be subjected to torture. The Inquisition trial was conducted in secret, but the proceedings were recorded in writing for the use of the Inquisition. These records were intended to prevent the manipulation of testimony.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Inquisition (from Latin <italic>inquisitio</italic> - to search, to inquire) was founded in the 12th century as a response to the massive heretical movement of the Albigensians (Cathars). Originally it was intended to serve more as a tool to punish and direct the clergy, but later its main mission became the fight against all the heretics. It was directly subordinate to the Pope, and thus became more or less an independent power.</paragraph><paragraph>The Inquisition had <accent>three main tasks</accent> - to search for heretics; to interrogate them and convict or bring them to repentance; and to refer the unrepentant to the secular authorities for punishment.</paragraph><paragraph>The incoming inquisitor first reported to the local bishop and then had a solemn mass and sermon celebrated. He then received reports (denunciations) of heresy from the local people. Heretics were given a so-called <italic>period of mercy</italic> in which they could declare themselves and ask for forgiveness. The inquisitor evaluated the reasonings and began his own process, which was more intended to confirm the accusations, rather than objectively examine them.</paragraph><paragraph>Although in the common consciousness the Inquisition is associated with cruel practices, fanatical actions and great fear of inquisitors, one of the intentions of the Inquisition's operations was to rationalize and legalize trials of heretics and to suppress the practice of <italic>ordeals</italic> - <accent>Divine trials</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>The Inquisition process was thus based primarily on the testimony and interrogation of the accused. The accused, however, had almost no rights and could be subjected to torture. The Inquisitorial trial was conducted in secret, but the proceedings were recorded in writing for the needs of the Inquisition. These records were intended to prevent manipulation of testimonies.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The origins of the religion are linked to the <accent>prophet Muhammad</accent> and the book of the <accent>Koran</accent>, which according to tradition was dictated to the prophet by the archangel Gabriel.</paragraph><paragraph>Chronologically, the most important year is 622 AD, when Muhammad and his followers moved from Mecca to Medina. From there, during the 8th century, it spread rapidly throughout much of the Mediterranean, Persia, and the entire Iberian Peninsula (present-day Spain). Even then, it had split into two dominant branches: the <italic>Shias</italic> (related to the prophet) and the <italic>Sunnis</italic> (who regard Ali as Muhammad's successor).</paragraph><paragraph>Islam teaches that God is one and indivisible. According to Muslims, Islam is the sole and original version of the faith proclaimed by earlier prophets such as Adam, Abraham, Moses and Jesus. According to them, the Koran is literal and unalterable.</paragraph><paragraph>The teachings are based on five pillars: the profession of faith (<italic>Shahada</italic>), daily prayer (<italic>Salah</italic>), almsgiving (<italic>Zakat</italic>), fasting in the month of Ramadan (<italic>Sawm</italic>), and the obligatory pilgrimage to Mecca (<italic>Hajj</italic>). Islamic law is called <italic>Sharia</italic> and touches every aspect of life from social organization to the environment, welfare and banking.</paragraph><paragraph>Although the major monotheistic religions (Christianity, Judaism and Islam) are similar in many ways, their believers still wage exhausting bloody wars with each other.</paragraph><paragraph>At the time of our game, the Arabian Peninsula is in a full bloom and is a center of culture, science, and scholarship. Although echoes of the Crusades still reverberate, trade with the Arabs is brisk and migration is ongoing.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The origins of Islam are linked to the <accent>prophet Muhammad</accent> and the book <accent>Qur'an</accent>, which according to tradition was dictated to the prophet by the archangel Gabriel.</paragraph><paragraph>Chronologically, the most important year is 622 AD, when Muhammad and his followers moved from Mecca to Medina. From there, during the 8th century, it spread rapidly throughout much of the Mediterranean, Persia, and the entire Iberian Peninsula (present-day Spain). By then, it had already split into two dominant branches: <italic>Shiites</italic> (who believe that Muhammad designated Hazrat Ali as his successor) and <italic>Sunnis</italic> (who believe that Muhammad did not declare a successor).</paragraph><paragraph>Islam teaches that God is one and indivisible. According to Muslims, Islam is the sole and original version of the faith proclaimed by earlier prophets such as Adam, Abraham, Moses and Jesus. According to them, the Qur'an is literal and unalterable.</paragraph><paragraph>The teachings are based on five pillars: the profession of faith (<italic>Shahada</italic>), daily prayer (<italic>Salah</italic>), almsgiving (<italic>Zakat</italic>), fasting in the month of Ramadan (<italic>Sawm</italic>), and the obligatory pilgrimage to Mecca (<italic>Hajj</italic>). Islamic law is called <italic>Sharia</italic> and touches every aspect of life from social organization to the environment, welfare and banking.</paragraph><paragraph>Although the major monotheistic religions (Christianity, Judaism and Islam) are similar in many ways, their believers still engage in exhausting bloody wars.</paragraph><paragraph>At the time of our game, the Arabian Peninsula is in a full bloom and is a center of culture, science, and scholarship. Although echoes of the Crusades still reverberate, trade with Arabs is brisk and migration is ongoing.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In our historical epoch, Italy as we know it today did not yet exist. Instead, there were a number of independent states and kingdoms with their own rulers and policies, which were not unified until the 19th century. Among the most important of these are Lombardy, Tuscany, the Principality of Venice and the Papal State based in Rome.</paragraph><paragraph>City states or maritime republics often fought disputes and wars with each other. The common denominator at the time being mainly language and the legacy of the great history of ancient Rome, on its cultural foundation much of Europe at the time was built.</paragraph><paragraph>Due to its strategically important location in the heart of the Mediterranean, the territory of the Italian states was often mainly focused on <accent>trade</accent>. Goods from Africa and the Arab world flowed through the region, and the local navy dominated the entire Mediterranean, serving as an indispensable transport force during, for example, the Crusades. It is no exaggeration to say that a large part of the exotic export goods available in the Czech lands had to pass through an Italian port.</paragraph><paragraph>Beyond trade, however, the Italian kingdoms and principalities of the time also had indispensable <accent>cultural role</accent>. It was here, in our epoch, that for a long time dominant discourse and philosophical and artistic movement called <italic>Renaissance</italic> was born. It must be added, however, that it took a few more decades, before Renaissance ideas reached the heart of Europe.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In our historical epoch, Italy as we know it today did not yet exist. Instead, there were a number of independent states and kingdoms with their own rulers and policies, which were not unified until the 19th century. Among the most important of these are Lombardy, Tuscany, the Duchy of Venice and the Papal State based in Rome.</paragraph><paragraph>City states or maritime republics often engaged in disputes and wars. The common bond at the time being mainly language and the legacy of ancient Rome, upon whose cultural foundation much of contemporary Europe was built.</paragraph><paragraph>Due to its strategically important location in the heart of the Mediterranean, the territory of the Italian states was mainly focused on <accent>trade</accent>. Goods from Africa and the Arab world flowed through the region, and the local navy dominated the entire Mediterranean, serving as an indispensable transport force during, for instance, the Crusades. It is no exaggeration to say that a large portion of the exotic export goods available in the Czech lands had to pass through an Italian port.</paragraph><paragraph>Beyond trade, however, the Italian kingdoms and principalities of the time also played a significant <accent>cultural role</accent>. It was here, in our epoch, that the long-dominant discourse and, philosophical and artistic movement called the <italic>Renaissance</italic> emergred. It must be added, however, that it took a few more decades for Renaissance ideas to spread to the heart of Europe.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Ius Regale Montanorum is regarded as the oldest Czech mining code of law. It was issued in 1300 by King Wenceslas II in Latin. This legal document aimed to address shortcomings in the mining administration of the time and clearly define the rights and obligations of miners and landowners in areas where mineral resources were extracted within the Kingdom of Bohemia. The text was created not only by the monarch and royal officials, but also by prominent legal experts, such as the Italian professor Gozzio ab Orvieto.</paragraph><paragraph>To facilitate navigation through the sometimes complex text, the code was divided into four sections: the Book on Persons, on Mines, on Concessions, and on Claims. This code influenced the development of mining law in surrounding countries, such as Poland, and remained in force in Bohemia until 1854.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Ius Regale Montanorum is regarded as the oldest Czech mining code of law. It was issued in 1300 by King Wenceslas II in Latin. This legal document aimed to address shortcomings in the mining administration of the time and clearly define the rights and obligations of miners and landowners in areas where mineral resources were extracted within the Kingdom of Bohemia. The text was created not only by the monarch and royal officials, but also by prominent legal experts, such as the Italian professor Gozio ab Orvieto.</paragraph><paragraph>To facilitate navigation through the sometimes complex text, the code was divided into four sections: the Book on Persons, on Mines, on Concessions, and on Claims. This code influenced the development of mining law in surrounding countries, such as Poland, and remained in force in Bohemia until 1854.</paragraph>

<years>c. 1370 - 6 July 1415</years><paragraph>Jan Hus was a priest, thinker and one of the most important Czech and European religious reformers and preachers. His works, inspired by the theological writings of John Wycliffe, played a key role in underpinning the essence of the Church Reformation</paragraph><paragraph> As of 1398 he taught and spread his views at Prague University and from 1402 he preached at the Bethlehem Chapel in Prague. From there he initiated discussion among the broad classes of the burghers on current religious and secular issues. For his strong, but very popular, criticism of conditions in the Church, he was eventually excommunicated by the Pope in 1412 and had to take refuge in the countryside.</paragraph><paragraph> At the Council of Constance, where he was invited by Emperor Sigismund to defend his views, he was condemned and burned as a heretic. His legacy, however, sparked a strong uprising in the Czech lands against the existing order. This began a period known as the <accent>Husitte Wars</accent> (1420-1434).</paragraph>

<years>c. 1370 - 6 July 1415</years><paragraph>Jan Hus was a priest, thinker and one of the most important Czech and European religious reformers and preachers. His works, inspired by the theological writings of John Wycliffe, was key to understanding the essence of the Church Reformation</paragraph><paragraph> As of 1398 he taught and spread his views at Prague University and from 1402 he preached at the Bethlehem Chapel in Prague. From there he initiated discussion among the broad classes of burghers on current religious and secular issues. For his strong, but very popular, criticism of conditions in the Church, he was eventually excommunicated by the Pope in 1412 and had to take refuge in the countryside.</paragraph><paragraph> At the Council of Constance, where he was invited by Emperor Sigismund to defend his views, he was condemned and burned as a heretic. His legacy, however, sparked a strong uprising in the Czech lands against the existing order. This began a period known as the <accent>Husitte Wars</accent> (1420-1434).</paragraph>

<years>c. 1355 - 28 September 1410</years><paragraph>Jan Sokol of Lamberg was a military leader, provincial governor, son of Jaroslav of Kninice and a friend of Radzig Kobyla.</paragraph><paragraph>Actively involved in internal disputes of the members of the Luxembourg dynasty, in which he sided with Wenceslas IV. For his loyalty, the king gave him the village Horky and the castle of Skalitz near Kostelec in Bohemia after his liberation.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1404, Jan fought against Sigismund of Luxembourg at Znojmo. As a member of Wenceslas' retinue, he met Jan Zizka in 1409, with whom he went into battle against the Rosenbergs. He fought in the Battle of Grunwald, where he sided with the Polish-Lithuanian coalition. After the battle, he was probably poisoned at a banquet at the court of King Władysław Jagiellon of Poland.</paragraph>

<years>cca. 1355 – 28 September 1410</years><paragraph>Jan Sokol of Lamberg was a military leader, provincial governor, son of Jaroslav of Kninice, and a friend of Radzig Kobyla.</paragraph><paragraph>He actively participated in the internal disputes of the Luxembourg dynasty, siding with Wenceslas IV. For his loyalty, the king rewarded him with the village of Horky and the castle of Skalitz near Kostelec in Bohemia.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1404, Jan fought against Sigismund of Luxembourg at Znojmo. As a member of Wenceslas's retinue, he met Jan Zizka in 1409 and went into battle against the Rosenbergs with him. He fought in the Battle of Grunwald, where he sided with the Polish-Lithuanian coalition. After the battle, he was likely poisoned at a feast at the court of Polish King Władysław Jagiełło.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The slaughterhouse, or the so-called <italic>shambles</italic>, was located on the edge of town. This was the only place that animals could be slaughtered, with butchers' stalls springing up around them.</paragraph><paragraph>The cattle were examined by the guild master – only if he vouched for their health could they be slaughtered and sold by the butchers. Butchering elsewhere was punishable by a fine.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Slaughterhouses, known as <italic>shambles</italic>, were fenced areas located on the outskirts of towns. Only here was it permitted to slaughter animals, and butcher shops were built nearby.</paragraph><paragraph>The livestock was inspected by the guild master – only if he deemed the animals healthy could the butchers slaughter and sell them. Slaughtering elsewhere was punishable by a fine.</paragraph>

<paragraph>...were a fairly common method of dealing with socio-political issues.</paragraph><paragraph>The most commonly used <accent>poisons</accent> were the alkaloids of henbane, datura flower (Devil's snare), hemlock, or of toadstools, mixed into food or drink.</paragraph><paragraph>Among the most popular <accent>drugs</accent> were <italic>abortives</italic> (inducing abortion), <italic>aphrodisiacs</italic> (stimulating sexual arousal), <italic>analgesics</italic> (relieving pain), <italic>antiseptics</italic> (killing bacteria), <italic>digestives</italic> (improving digestion), <italic>laxatives</italic>, <italic>narcotics</italic> (inducing sleep and having soothing effects), or <italic>tonics</italic> (revitalizing and giving sustenance to the body).</paragraph><paragraph>One of the worst cases of food poisoning that impacted the wider rural society involved rye infected with the parasitic ergot fungus – before the source of the poisoning was discovered, thousands of people could be affected, which often led to accusations against some local ‘witch' (since ergot, in a sub-lethal dose, brings on delirium and hallucinations).</paragraph><paragraph>Indeed, quite often the underlying cause of ‘witchery' superstitions and allegations was nothing other than intoxication by psychoactive substances sometimes used in the making of lotions and potions.</paragraph>
