<paragraph>...were a relatively common way of solving socio-political problems.</paragraph> <paragraph>The most commonly used <accent>poisons</accent> were alkaloids from hemlock, henbane, deadly nightshade, or poisonous mushrooms added to food or drinks.</paragraph> <paragraph>Among the most popular <accent>drugs</accent> were <italic>abortives</italic> (inducing abortion), <italic>aphrodisiacs</italic> (stimulating sexual excitement), <italic>analgesics</italic> (relieving pain), <italic>antiseptics</italic> (destroying bacteria), <italic>digestives</italic> (improving digestion), <italic>laxatives</italic> (promoting bowel movements), <italic>narcotics</italic> (inducing sleep with calming effects), and <italic>tonics</italic> (acting regeneratively and nutritively on the body).</paragraph> <paragraph>One of the worst food poisonings that affected broader rural society involved rye contaminated with the parasitic ergot fungus - before identifying the source of the poisoning, thousands of people fell victim to it, often resulting in accusations against local "witches" (ergot in lethal doses causes delirium and hallucinations).</paragraph> <paragraph>Indeed, the origins of "witchcraft" beliefs and accusations often stemmed from intoxication by psychedelic substances, sometimes used in the production of potions and ointments.</paragraph>

In the Middle Ages, horses were distinguished more by their use than by their breed. The sturdy warhorses of the knights (<italic>destriers</italic>) were complemented by the more agile <italic>palfreys</italic> favoured by the nobility. For the remaining members of the less wealthy classes, there were the versatile horses called <italic>rouncey</italic>. Different types of draft horses could be seen in the fields, caravans, or mining trains.</paragraph><paragraph>The most important piece of equipment was the <accent>saddle</accent>. This was typically a seat made of a single piece of wood, mostly without any padding. It was, however, surprisingly comfortable to ride on. This was helped not only by the wide cut-out on the sides of the saddle for better contact with the horse's sides, but also by the raised front and especially the rear cantle, which served as a back support.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>bridle</accent>, consisting of a bit (most often of the snaffle, later of the curb type) and reins, was used to steer the horse. Of considerable equestrian but also social importance were the <accent>spurs</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>Frequent accessories of knightly or noble horses were ornate <accent>harnesses</accent> or <accent>breastplates</accent>. Warhorses could be seen with metal <accent>shanfrons</accent> protecting their heads. During tournaments or battles, the horses were then dressed in <accent>caparisons</accent> with different patterns, colours and heraldry. The most common was the caparison covering the horse's entire body, or the so-called <italic>croup</italic>, which protected only the horse's back and rump.</paragraph><paragraph>The medieval rider expected to be comfortable and safe while on the horse's back. The design of the saddle thus directly defined his seat. The rider was more upright and leaned back, transferring weight to his legs. The reins held him firmly in the saddle and protected him from attacks from the ground. However, being locked firmly in the saddle had its drawbacks.</paragraph><paragraph>Jumping on a horse was almost impossible, and dismounting quickly was as well. It was therefore not uncommon for many injuries or deaths to be caused while in the saddle rather than by falling from the horse.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, horses were distinguished more by their use than by their breed. Sturdy war horses of knights (<italic>destriers</italic>) were complemented by more agile <italic>palfreys</italic>, favoured by the nobility. For the less wealthy classes, there were versatile horses called <italic>rounceys</italic>. Various types of draft horses could be seen in fields, caravans, or mine trevails.</paragraph><paragraph>The most important part of the equipment was the <accent>saddle</accent>. It was characterised by a seat made from a single piece of wood, usually without any padding. However, riding on it was surprisingly comfortable. This was aided not only by the wide cut on the sides of the saddle for better contact with the horse's flanks but also by the raised front and especially the back pommel, which served as a backrest.</paragraph><paragraph>To control the horse, a <accent>bridle</accent> was used, consisting of a bit (most commonly a snaffle, later of the curb type) and reins. Spurs also had significant riding as well as social importance.</paragraph><paragraph>Common accessories for knightly or noble horses included decorated <accent>harnesses</accent> and <accent>breastplates</accent>. War horses could be seen with metal <accent>chamfrons</accent> protecting their heads. During tournaments or battles, horses were dressed in <accent>caparisons</accent> of various cuts, colours, and heraldry. The most widespread was the caparison covering the entire body of the horse, or the so-called <italic>croupiere or crupper</italic>, which protected only the horse's back and hindquarters.</paragraph><paragraph>A medieval rider expected his time on horseback to be comfortable and safe. The design of the saddle directly defined his seat. The rider was more upright and leaning back, transferring weight to his legs. The supports firmly held him in the saddle and protected him from attacks from the ground. However, being firmly locked in the saddle also had its disadvantages.</paragraph><paragraph>Jumping on a horse was almost impossible and dismounting quickly was also difficult. It was not uncommon for many injuries or deaths to be caused more by the saddle itself than by falling from the horse.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The period up to the 13th century was characterized by <accent>Slavonic names</accent>, mostly of pagan origin.</paragraph><paragraph>Common people would keep names short and simple like Odolen (the robust), Dobroš (the good), Chval (the praised). Names were also given according to place in society. Compound names such as Drahomíra (who values peace), Boleslav (more famed, more fabled) and Ludmila (dear to the people) were reserved for royalty and the nobility.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Christian names</accent> were derived from Latin (Paul, Silvester, Florian), Hebrew (James, Daniel, John) and Greek (Andrew, Nicholas, Peter).</paragraph><paragraph> In late Middle Ages, only names belonging to <accent>Christian martyrs</accent> were permitted. In the towns and the countryside the prevailing names were John, Peter, Margaret, Catherine and Anna, while the nobility retained the privilege of using names like Sophia, Elizabeth, Jacob, Ulrich or Hermann.</paragraph><paragraph>Additional bynames added information about the location of the family seat, social or religious standing, or about relationships with relatives, for example Diviš z Talmberka (in KCD Divish of Talmberg), Jan Ptáček z Pirkštejna (Hans Capon of Pirkstein), Hanuš z Pirkštejna, syn Jindřicha (Hanush of Pirkstein, son of Henry). In addition, sometimes an epithet would be used, for example Jan Zajíc (Hanekin Hare) of Valdek, Jan the Younger of Hradec etc.</paragraph><paragraph> The growing population and the limited number of first names gave rise to the surname as we know it today. The <accent>surname</accent> was derived from the place where the person lived (like in English, for example Hill, Woods, Forest), from their occupation (Coachman, Miller, Smith), from their physiognomy or appearance (Ruddy, Small, Brown), or were patronymics - derived from the father's forename (Davis, Littlejohn) or matronymics - derived from the mother's forename (Marriott, Beaton).</paragraph>

<paragraph>The period up to the 13th century was characterized by <accent>Slavonic names</accent>, mostly of pagan origin.</paragraph><paragraph>Common people would keep names short and simple like Odolen (the robust), Dobroš (the good), Chval (the praised). Names were also given according to social status. Compound names like Drahomíra (values peace), Boleslav (more famed, more fabled) and Ludmila (dear to the people) were reserved for royalty and nobility.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Christian names</accent> were derived from Latin (Paul, Silvester, Florian), Hebrew (James, Daniel, John) and Greek (Andrew, Nicholas, Peter).</paragraph><paragraph> In the late Middle Ages, only names belonging to <accent>Christian martyrs</accent> were permitted. In the towns and the countryside names like John, Peter, Margaret, Catherine and Anna were common, while the nobility retained the privilege of using names like Sophia, Elizabeth, Jacob, Ulrich or Hermann.</paragraph><paragraph>Additional bynames added information about the location of the family seat, social or religious standing, or about relationships with relatives, for example Diviš z Talmberka (in KCD Divish of Talmberg), Jan Ptáček z Pirkštejna (Hans Capon of Pirkstein), Hanuš z Pirkštejna, syn Jindřicha (Hanush of Pirkstein, son of Henry). In addition, sometimes an epithet would be used, for example Jan Zajíc (Hanekin Hare) of Valdek, Jan the Younger of Hradec etc.</paragraph><paragraph> The growing population and limited number of first names led to the creation of modern surnames. The <accent>surname</accent> was derived from the place where the person lived (like in English, for example Hill, Woods, Forest), from their occupation (Carter, Miller, Smith), from their physiognomy or appearance (Ruddy, Little, Brown), or were patronymics - derived from the father's forename (Davis, Littlejohn) or matronymics - derived from the mother's forename (Marriott, Beaton).</paragraph>

<paragraph>Collecting and preserving written records goes back to ancient times, but the barbarians who sacked Rome in the 5th century destroyed a great many, so a lot of rare manuscripts have only been preserved indirectly, via the Arab world.</paragraph><paragraph>Various materials were used to write on: pieces of fabric, papyrus or vellum (fine animal leather). Parchment was expensive and was therefore used primarily for codices and deeds of privilege, due to its significantly longer lifespan. The most widely used material was paper. The <accent>writing implements</accent> used included the quill pen, engraver, brush or reed cane, charcoal and chalk sticks.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>transcription of books</accent> was the monks' domain. Each book was unique, carefully decorated, the text enriched with bounteous illuminations, all done by hand. The production of a book took many years, making them very expensive.</paragraph><paragraph>Major works of that time came into being in Latin, but during the Middle Ages some literature began to appear in the respective national languages.</paragraph><paragraph>Books were very heavy (therefore difficult to steal), and contained a great many pages. Although there were some miniature handbook formats, too, there were books so massive that they couldn't be carried by one man.</paragraph><paragraph>Not only because of their value, but to protect them from destruction, important writings were often kept in chests or cabinets. Only later did <italic>libraries</italic> come into being, where the volumes would be tethered to the reading desk by a chain.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Libraries</accent> were needed by administrative offices and places of learning, especially universities. The largest collections were to be found at the Sorbonne, Oxford and University of Prague, where there were books donated by Emperor Charles IV himself. Notable members of the nobility or the Church also boasted private collections, despite the fact that not all of them could read.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Collecting and preserving written records goes back to ancient times, but the barbarians who sacked Rome in the 5th century destroyed a great many, so a lot of rare manuscripts have only been preserved indirectly, via the Arab world.</paragraph><paragraph>Various materials were used to write on: pieces of fabric, papyrus or parchment (fine animal leather). Parchment was expensive and was therefore used primarily for codices and deeds of privilege, due to its significantly longer lifespan. The most widely used material was paper. The <accent>writing implements</accent> used included the quill pen, engraver, brush or reed cane, charcoal and chalk sticks.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>transcription of books</accent> was the monks' domain. Each book was unique, carefully decorated, the text enriched with bounteous illuminations, all done by hand. The production of a book took many years, making them very expensive.</paragraph><paragraph>Major works of that time came into being in Latin, but during the Middle Ages some literature began to appear in the respective national languages.</paragraph><paragraph>Books were very heavy (therefore difficult to steal), and contained a great many pages. Although there were some miniature portable forms, there were also books so massive that they couldn't be carried by one person.</paragraph><paragraph>Not only because of their value, but also to protect them from damage, important writings were often kept in chests or cabinets. Later so-called <italic>chained libraries</italic> come into being, where the volumes would be tethered to the reading desk by a chain.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Libraries</accent> were needed by administrative offices and places of learning, especially universities. The largest collections were to be found at the Sorbonne, Oxford and the University of Prague, where there were books donated by Emperor Charles IV himself. Notable members of the nobility or the Church also boasted private collections, despite the fact that not all of them could read.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Conciliar councils were gatherings of church representatives who discussed and debated the faith and dealt with the governance of the church.</paragraph><paragraph>The Great Council of Constance (1414-1418), for example, lasted four years and dealt with the Reformation and the papal schism.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Ecuminical councils were gatherings of church representatives who negotiated and discussed matters of faith and addressed church governance.</paragraph><paragraph>For example, the great Council of Constance (1414-1418) lasted four years and addressed issues of reformation and the papal schism.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Church fixtures and fittings comprised the liturgical devices used in Church services and statues, paintings and frescos, which served to enlighten the uneducated populace in simple terms about Biblical stories and religious observance.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Pulpit</accent> – the raised platform from where the priest gives sermons or readings.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Altar</accent> – where the sacrifice of Communion is consecrated. This could be in the main or side aisle, often highly ornate.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Ciborium</accent> – the receptacle for the Eucharist, the transformed sacred host</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Chalice</accent> – the Eucharistic goblet for the wine (transformed into the blood of Christ)</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Paten</accent> – the shallow bowl or plate used to hold the sacred host (body of Christ)</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Monstrance</accent> – the ornate casket to hold the Eucharist (host)</paragraph>

<paragraph>The church inventory consisted of liturgical vessels used during services, sculptures, paintings, and wall paintings which presented biblical stories and church regulations in a simple form to the uneducated populace.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Pulpit</accent> – an elevated space from which the priest preached or readings were delivered.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Altar</accent> – the place where the sacrifice is performed. It can be main or side, often richly decorated.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Ciborium</accent> – vessel used to store the consecrated host.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Chalice</accent> – used for wine (the Blood of Christ) during communion.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Paten</accent> – holds the host (the Body of Christ).</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Monstrance</accent> – ornate vessel used to display the Eucharist (the host).</paragraph>

<paragraph>The church was not just a place of worship, but also an important communication centre in medieval society.</paragraph><paragraph>Its basic layout consisted of the central nave or aisle (sometimes with side naves) and a <italic>sanctuary</italic>, which included the chancel. This housed the main altar, where mass was served. Most churches were aligned with the chancel at the eastern end. At the main entrance was a baptismal font. Another important element was the pulpit, from which the priest addressed the congregation.</paragraph><paragraph>By contrast with today, the sermon was separate from the mass. During the <accent>church service</accent>, the priest stood with his back to the congregation and, in keeping with Papal instructions, the mass was said in Latin, which was not generally comprehensible to the congregation. In compensation, the church walls were richly decorated with painted scenes, intended to bring the mystery of the liturgy and especially biblical scenes come alive for the illiterate common people.</paragraph><paragraph>When not used for religious services, the church premises would serve, for example, as a temporary storage of grain and other goods that were being traded, or as a place of assembly of the citizenry if the need arose to address some important public issue.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The church was not just a place of worship, but also an important communication center in medieval society.</paragraph> <paragraph>Its basic areas included the nave or naves (main and side) and the <italic>presbytery</italic>, also known as the sanctuary. This housed the main altar, where Mass was celebrated. Most churches were oriented with the sanctuary on the eastern side. The baptismal font was placed near the main entrance. Another important feature was the pulpit, from which the priest addressed the people.</paragraph> <paragraph>Unlike today, sermons were conducted separately from the Mass. During the <accent>church service</accent>, the priest faced away from the people and, according to the Pope's decree, Mass was conducted in Latin, which no one understood. This was compensated by rich visual decorations on the church walls, which aimed to explain the mysteries of the liturgy and especially biblical scenes to ordinary illiterate people.</paragraph> <paragraph>After the church service, the church space was used, for example, as a temporary storage for grain and other traded goods, or as a gathering place for the community to discuss important matters.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Anyone who has ever visited the tavern frequented by Kuttenberg's poor bearing the unflattering nickname of <accent>Hole in the Wall</accent> surely noticed a local peculiarity: a skeleton sitting at a table.</paragraph><paragraph>We borrowed it from the book <italic>Staré / Nové kutnohorské pověsti (Old/New Kuttenberg Tales)</italic> by Jitka Jelínková, who wrote that there used to be a gambling house in the Lower Town, where miners would go to drink and gamble. But the miners' wives would not stand for it, so they hatched a secret plan. They bought a skeleton from the executioner's hand and hung it in the gambling house in the closet where the cards were being kept. They hoped that this would scare the men and make them give up their habit forever.</paragraph><paragraph>But instead, the drunk men pulled the skeleton out of the closet, sat it down at a table and began to drink with it. To their dismay, the skeleton came to life as midnight struck and started to actually drink its beer while thrashing the inn.</paragraph><paragraph>For our purposes, we have taken the liberty of borrowing the first part of the story.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Anyone who has ever visited the tavern frequented by Kuttenberg's poor, bearing the unflattering nickname of <accent>Hole in the Wall</accent> surely noticed a local peculiarity: a skeleton sitting at a table.</paragraph><paragraph>We borrowed it from the book <italic>Staré / Nové kutnohorské pověsti (Old/New Kuttenberg Tales)</italic> by Jitka Jelínková, who wrote that there used to be a gambling house in the Lower Town, where miners would go to drink and gamble. But the miners' wives would not stand for it, so they hatched a secret plan. They bought a skeleton from the executioner's assistant and hung it in the gambling house in the closet where the cards were kept. They hoped this would scare the men and make them give up their habit forever.</paragraph><paragraph>But instead, the drunk men pulled the skeleton out of the closet, sat it at a table and began to drink with it. To their dismay, the skeleton came to life as midnight struck and started to actually drink its beer while thrashing the inn.</paragraph><paragraph>For our purposes, we have taken the liberty of borrowing the first part of the story.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Originally, it was a fortified castle from the 13th century overseeing the safety of miners and the storage of mined material, but later the character of the building changed and instead of a fortress it began to perform a more spectacular and representative function, although it was still the best guarded place in Kuttenberg.</paragraph><paragraph>Massive reconstruction began under Wenceslas II, who centralised the production of coins, until now scattered throughout the kingdom, and started the minting of the <accent>Prague groschen</accent>, which was initially helped by the famous mint masters from Florence (the north of Italy was called 'Vlachy', hence the 'Vlaššký Dvůr'). The court thus became a sort of equivalent of a central bank.</paragraph><paragraph>During the reign of Wenceslas IV, the mint underwent a massive palace rebuilding and a chapel was added, but its purpose and exclusivity in terms of producing 'hard currency' remains. From the very beginning, high-quality coins with up to 94% pure silver content were minted here and quickly became Europe's hard currency.</paragraph><paragraph>Today, 'Vlašský dvůr' is registered as a National Cultural Monument of the Czech Republic with a museum at the place. The rich wall paintings on the walls of the court are not to be found, nor are their models preserved. It is rather our artistic license.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Originally, it was a fortified castle from the 13th century overseeing the safety of miners and the storage of mined material. However, over time the character of the building changed and instead of a fortress, it began to perform a more lavish and representative function, although it was still the best guarded place in Kuttenberg.</paragraph><paragraph>Massive reconstruction began under Wenceslas II, who centralised the production of coins, until now scattered throughout the kingdom, and started the minting of the <accent>Prague groschen</accent>, which was initially helped by the famous Mint Masters from Florence (the north of Italy was called 'Vlachy', hence the 'Vlašský Dvůr'). The court thus became the equivalent of a central bank.</paragraph><paragraph>Under Wenceslas IV, the mint underwent massive palace-style rebuilding and a chapel was added, but its purpose and exclusivity in terms of producing 'hard currency' remained. From the very beginning, high-quality coins of up to 94% pure silver content were minted here and quickly became a European stable currency.</paragraph><paragraph>Today, 'Vlašský dvůr' is registered as a National Cultural Monument of the Czech Republic and houses a museum. The rich wall paintings of the court no longer exist, nor are there any preserved originals. This detail is rather, artistic license on our part.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Under the Christian doctrine, baptism is the ritual shedding of original sin and Salvation cannot occur without it (original sin means people are doomed to death ever since Adam).</paragraph><paragraph>In the early Middle Ages, adults who knowingly entered into the Christian fold were the ones baptized, at the height of the Middle Ages baptism came to include even younger children. If the child died prematurely (i.e. unbaptized), the child's soul could not go up to Heaven, nor could the body be buried in hallowed ground.</paragraph><paragraph>Baptisms took place mainly on religious holidays (especially at Easter), and churches would have a special baptismal fonts for the occasion – <italic>the baptiserium</italic>.</paragraph>

<paragraph>According to Christian doctrine, baptism is the ritual removal of original sin, and without it, salvation cannot be achieved (original sin dooms people to death from the time of the forefather Adam).</paragraph><paragraph>In the early Middle Ages, mainly adults were baptized, who consciously joined the Christian community, but in the High Middle Ages, younger children also began to be baptized. If a child died prematurely (i.e., unbaptized), their soul could not enter heaven, nor could their body be buried in consecrated ground.</paragraph><paragraph>Baptisms took place mainly on church holidays (especially Easter), and special baptismal fonts – <italic>baptisteries</italic> – were established for this purpose at churches.</paragraph>

<paragraph>During the last couple of years of its era, the late medieval world was shaking at its foundations, old certainties were crumbling and new dangers and risks were emerging. This crisis was reflected especially in the demographic, political and religious (cultural and ideological) spheres.</paragraph><paragraph>Since the middle of the 14th century, Europe was ravaged by plague epidemics, but the Czech lands were mostly spared. Even before the outbreak of the plague, agriculture was experiencing a crisis, as its production was no longer sufficient to feed the growing continental population.</paragraph><paragraph>The west was torn apart by the war between England and France, the so-called Hundred Years' War, while in the east of Europe the Teutonic Order was fighting a long war against the Polish state in the Baltic region. The Russian state was subjugated by the Mongol rulers of the Golden Horde and further south, the Ottoman Empire, which would later become a traditional enemy of Europe in the early modern period, was growing ever stronger. In addition to these major conflicts, there were numerous peasant uprisings, especially in the west.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Universal unity</accent>, an important pillar of the medieval world order, was shaken by papal schisms, the long-term inability to resolve this situation, and conflicts within the Church itself, but also by the weakening of the Emperor's position. During the Middle Ages, the imperial power, as the secular opposite pole of the Universal unity, was limited to the ruler of the Central Europe, especially the German lands, and even there with varying degrees of real power.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the late middle ages, the world was shaken to its foundations, old certainties were crumbling as new dangers and risks emerged. This crisis was particularly evident in demographic, political and religious (cultural and ideological) spheres.</paragraph><paragraph>From the mid 14th century, Europe was ravaged by plague epidemics, but the Czech lands were mostly spared. Even before the outbreak of plague, agriculture was experiencing a crisis, as its production was no longer sufficient to feed the growing continental population.</paragraph><paragraph>The west was ravaged by the Hundred Years' War between England and France, while in Eastern Europe the Teutonic Order and the Polish state were engaged in a long term conflict in the Baltic region. The Russian state was subjugated by the Mongol rulers of the Golden Horde and further south, the Ottoman Empire, which would later become a traditional enemy of Europe in the early modern period, was growing ever stronger. In addition to these major conflicts, there were numerous peasant uprisings, especially in the west.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Universal unity</accent>, an important pillar of the medieval world order, was shaken by papal schisms, the long-term inability to resolve this situation, conflicts within the Church itself, and the weakening of the emperor's position. During the Middle Ages, imperial power, the secular counterpart of universal unity, was limited to rulers over Central Europe, especially the German lands, albeit with varying degrees of real power.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Since earliest times, it was the task of the educated members of the Court or spiritual leaders to take on the writing of chronicles, i.e. literary works describing contemporary events, the lives of their rulers, great battles and sometimes even everyday life.</paragraph><paragraph>Records were kept in chronological order, and as well as giving the dates, they provide a wealth of historical information. They are among the best sources for investigating and revisiting the history of the country, famous people, places, buildings and day-to-day affairs.</paragraph><paragraph>There are different <accent>types of chronicles</accent>: world, national, episcopal, monastic, royal, dynastic, provincial (tracking genealogy), urban, biographical or autobiographical, travel journals and more.</paragraph><paragraph>The most important Czech chronicles include those of <italic>Cosmas</italic> and <italic>Dalimil</italic>, the Canon of Vyšehrad, the writings of the Sasau Monk and the <italic>Zbraslav Chronicle</italic>. The chroniclers generally enjoyed the most favourable conditions – most lived at the courts, had free access to older written records and courtly life and plenty of time to devote to writing.</paragraph><paragraph>Although chronicles are the most valuable historic source, when reading them and extrapolating, their <accent>historical ideological subtext</accent> has to be borne in mind: for example, Kosmas wrote his chronicle with unabashed sympathy for the Přemyslid dynasty, while Dalimil showed great antipathy against the Germans. Both occasionally mix up facts with myths and legends (e.g. beginning Czech history with the building of the Tower of Babel).</paragraph><paragraph>Some of the books to be found in the game are a transliteration of chapters from Kosmas or Dalimil - e.g. the account of Forefather Čech, the Maidens' War etc.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Since ancient times, educated members of the court or clergy dedicated themselves to writing chronicles, i.e. literary works describing contemporary events, the lives of rulers, great battles, and sometimes everyday life..</paragraph><paragraph>These records were kept chronologically and, beyond the mere dates, they provide a rich source of period information. Chronicles are one of the best sources for studying and reconstructing the history of a country, notable figures, places, buildings, and general realities of the time.</paragraph><paragraph>There are different <accent>types of chronicles</accent>: world, national, episcopal, monastic, royal, dynastic, provincial (tracking genealogy), urban, biographical or autobiographical, travel journals and more.</paragraph><paragraph>Among the most significant Czech chronicles are those of <italic>Cosmas</italic> and <italic>Dalimil</italic>, the Canon of Vyšehrad, the writings of the Sasau Monk and the <italic>Zbraslav Chronicle</italic>. The chroniclers generally enjoyed the most favourable conditions – most lived at courts, had free access to older written records and court life, and ample time devoted solely to writing.</paragraph><paragraph>Although chronicles are the most valuable historic sources, it is important to consider their <accent>historical ideological subtext</accent> when reading and reconstructing them: for example, Cosmas wrote his chronicle with unabashed sympathy for the Přemyslid dynasty, while Dalimil showed great antipathy against the Germans. Both occasionally mixed facts with myths and legends (e.g. the beginning of Czech history with the building of the Tower of Babel).</paragraph><paragraph>Some of the books to be found in the game are a transliterations of chapters from Cosmas or Dalimil - e.g. the account of forefather Čech, the Maidens' War and others.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Medieval kitchens differed in the countryside, the city and at court. In earlier times, everything was cooked outdoors, while later (at the time of our narrative), stove hearths were built, which served for heating the home as well as cooking.</paragraph><paragraph>Some kitchens had an open fireplace indoors, with the smoke drawn off by small windows and fume hoods. When we speak of the so-called <italic>smoke-kitchen</italic> or <italic>black kitchen</italic>, this was largely a feature of taverns, mills, presbyteries and manors, which go its name from the smoke-blackened walls around it.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Medieval kitchens differed in the countryside, the city and at court. In earlier times, everything was cooked outdoors, while later (at the time of our narrative), stove hearths were built, which served for heating the home as well as cooking.</paragraph><paragraph>Some kitchens had an open fireplace indoors, with the smoke drawn off by small windows and fume hoods. When we speak of the so-called <italic>smoke-kitchen</italic> or <italic>black kitchen</italic>, this was largely a feature of taverns, mills, presbyteries and manors, which got its name from the smoke-blackened walls around it.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Cumans (also called Kunok in Hungary) were a nomadic people, belonging to the large group of Middle Eastern people called the Kipchaks (Polovtsians), who came to Europe in the 13th century as they fled from the Black Sea region to escape the increasing raids of the expanding Mongol Empire.</paragraph><paragraph>They settled with the permission of King Béla IV in Hungary, where they later acquired their autonomous territory called Cumania. They gradually assimilated with the native population: they embraced Christianity, started families with Hungarians, and fought alongside the Hungarian kings, including in wars with the Bohemian Přemyslids.</paragraph><paragraph>The last time they invaded the Bohemian lands was with Sigismund of Luxembourg, who could afford no better mercenaries than the Cumans. Estimates speak of several thousand warriors. For example, Silver Skalitz, the birthplace of the protagonist of our game, fell to their forces.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Cumans (also known as Kunok in Hungary) were a nomadic people belonging to the larger group of Kipchaks (Polovtsians) from the Middle East, who came to Europe in the 13th century, fleeing from the expanding Mongol Empire in the area of the Black Sea.</paragraph><paragraph>They settled in Hungary with the permission of King Béla IV, where they later acquired their autonomous region called Cumania. Gradually, they assimilated with the local population: adopting Christianity, marrying Hungarians, and fighting alongside Hungarian kings, including in wars against the Bohemian Přemyslids.</paragraph><paragraph>They last invaded the Czech lands with Sigismund of Luxembourg, who could not afford better mercenaries than the Cumans. Estimates speak of several thousand warriors. Their army's rampage led to the destruction of places like Silver Skalitz, the birthplace of the main character in our game.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Courtliness or <accent>courtesy</accent> stand for courtly etiquette. The cradle of courtesy was France, and later England, where the patterns of beauty, education, diplomacy and the arts were formulated.</paragraph><paragraph>The origins of courtesy are considered to be the chivalry of a knight toward his Lady: adoration, versifying, greetings, gestures and obedience. Not overlooked were rules for conduct during feasts, stylized movement (e.g. mounting a horse or sitting down at table), as well as protecting the ladies and the weaker, or the manner of divulging one's own feelings and emotions. Important elements in this were language, the playing of musical instruments and dance.</paragraph><paragraph>Many considered courtesy to be effete, but despite this, for quite a long time it dominated high society's approach to manners and the arts.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Courtliness or <accent>courtesy</accent> stand for courtly etiquette. The cradle of courtesy was France, and later England, which shaped the patterns of beauty, education, diplomacy and the arts.</paragraph><paragraph>The origins of courtesy are considered to be the chivalry of a knight toward his Lady: adoration, versifying, greetings, gestures and obedience. Not overlooked were rules for conduct during feasts, stylized movement (e.g. mounting a horse or sitting down at table), as well as protecting ladies and the weak, or the manner of divulging one's own feelings and emotions. Important elements in this were language, the playing of musical instruments and dance.</paragraph><paragraph>Many considered courtesy to be effete, but despite this, for quite a long time it dominated high society's approach to manners and the arts.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Kuttenberg (Kutná Hora) is located 70 km east of Prague. The founding of Kuttenberg (which is the official name of the town in the Middle Ages) was determined by the discovery of silver ore deposits in the vicinity and its location next to Sedletz Cistercian Monastery, the commercial and economic centre of the region.</paragraph><paragraph>City rights were acquired by Kuttenberg in 1318, after which time the economic activity of the city was taken care of by the so-called Urburer, or Royal Clerk. The operation of the mint and the mines was kept at a high standard and safe thanks to a list of legal edicts, the so-called <italic>Ius Regale Montanorum</italic> (the Mining Regulative).</paragraph><paragraph>The city soon became rich and had a comparable powers to the Old Town of Prague. The wealthiest population of Kuttenberg was made up of its German inhabitants, while the lower class consisted of those employed in mines, smelters, mints, services or crafts. Almost every city-dweller had some connection to silver mining, minting coinage or trading.</paragraph><paragraph>The treasures of found and mined silver supported the development of other Czech cities, including the construction of new buildings in Prague. The architecture of Kuttenberg is due to Wenceslas IV, when during his reign, houses were rebuilt in brick or half-timbered, churches, a mint and other public buildings, were built. We can still feel the Gothic style in Kuttenberg until today.</paragraph><paragraph>The game is based on the real geography of present Kuttenberg, even though, we had to modify the layout of the city a little. Some neighborhoods are a little different, some we've made smaller or omitted, and to optimize map loading we've added walls and gates in places where they probably never existed. Even so, we feel that we have managed to preserve the character of the medieval city like no other.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Kuttenberg (Kutná Hora) is located 70 km east of Prague. The founding of <accent>Kuttenberg</accent> (as it was called in the Middle Ages) was determined by the discovery of silver ore deposits in the area and its location near the Sedletz Cistercian Monastery, which was the trade and economic center of the region.</paragraph> <paragraph>Kuttenberg obtained municipal rights as early as 1318, and from that time on, its economic activities were overseen by the so-called Urbarer, a royal official. The safe operation of the mines and mints and the maintenance of their high standards were ensured by a set of legal regulations, the <italic>mining code (Ius Regale Montanorum)</italic>.</paragraph> <paragraph>The city quickly became wealthy and had comparable privileges to Prague's Old Town. The wealthiest residents of Kuttenberg were Germans, while the lower classes were made up of people employed in mines, smelters, mints, or services, and craftsmen. Nearly every resident of the city was involved in silver mining, coin minting, or trade.</paragraph> <paragraph>Kuttenberg's silver treasures supported the development of other Czech towns and the construction of new buildings in Prague. The architecture of Kuttenberg was significantly influenced by Wenceslas IV, during whose reign houses were rebuilt as brick or timber-framed structures, churches were built, and the Royal Mint and other public buildings were constructed. Thanks to this, we can still admire Gothic architecture here today.</paragraph> <paragraph>The city in the game is based on the real geography of modern Kuttenberg, although we had to adjust the layout of the city. Some districts were moved, reduced, or omitted, and for optimization purposes, walls and gates were added in places where they likely never existed. Even so, we hope we managed to preserve the medieval character of the city.</paragraph>

<paragraph>It originated around Rome in the 7th century BC and eventually became the official language of the Holy Roman Empire, from where it spread to the surrounding areas during the Roman expansion.</paragraph><paragraph>Over time, its humanized version (so-called <italic>vulgar</italic>) evolved into the Romance languages of today (French, Italian, Spanish, etc.), and it also strongly influenced English.</paragraph><paragraph>After the collapse of the Empire, Latin continued to be used as the <accent>universal language</accent> of scholars, the Church and diplomacy. It had to be understood and spoken by anyone who considered themselves educated. Latin was written in learned books, spoken in universities and church councils, and was the official language of documents. Without exaggeration, it was the only language that could be spoken from Britain all the way to the Byzantine Empire.</paragraph><paragraph>As an international language, Latin survived until the 15th century. With the arrival of <accent>renaissance</accent>, it was then replaced by national languages.</paragraph>

<paragraph>It originated around Rome approximately in the 7th century BC and subsequently became the official language of the Roman Empire, from where it spread to surrounding areas during Roman expansions.</paragraph><paragraph>Over time, its colloquial version (known as <italic>Vulgar Latin</italic>) evolved into the modern Romance languages (French, Italian, Spanish, etc.), and it also strongly influenced English.</paragraph><paragraph>After the fall of the Roman Empire, Latin continued to be used as the <accent>universal language</accent> of scholars, the church, and diplomacy. Anyone who considered themselves educated had to understand and speak it. Learned books were written in Latin, it was spoken at universities and church councils, and it was the official language of documents. Without exaggeration, it was the only language that could be used for communication from Britain to the Byzantine Empire.</paragraph><paragraph>As an international language, Latin persisted until the 15th century. With the advent of the <accent>Renaissance</accent>, it was then replaced by national languages.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Also known as the <accent>Apostolic nuncio</accent>, he is the Pope’s representative and delegate, defending his political interests. The Legate is sent directly by the Pope to mediate negotiations with a King or to sit on an important council.</paragraph><paragraph>Apart from diplomatic power, the Legate also had ecclesiastical power and could decide on the internal affairs of the Church, for example, to establish a bishopric or to excommunicate offenders.</paragraph><paragraph>Legates enjoyed great respect, and the monarch himself had to be careful before them, because according to medieval custom secular power was appointed and sanctified by the power of the church.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Also known as an <accent>Apostolic Nuncio</accent>, he is a representative and delegate of the papal throne defending its political interests. The legate is sent directly by the pope to mediate negotiations with the king or to sit on a significant council.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to diplomatic power, the legate also had ecclesiastical power and could make decisions on internal church matters, such as establishing bishoprics or excommunicating offenders.</paragraph><paragraph>Legates were held in high esteem, and even the monarch had to be wary of them, for according to medieval customs, secular power was appointed and consecrated by the church.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Forests belonged to the King, especially along the border zones, and played not only an <accent>economic</accent>, but also a <accent>strategic role</accent> – felled trees were used as an important part of fortification.</paragraph><paragraph>Since the 14th century, it was considered proper to look after forests, and only the ruler could decree whether his subjects could cut down trees for construction. The ruler could also allow farmers rights to graze their livestock or to make charcoal, but on condition that the hinds and does could bear their young unhindered.</paragraph><paragraph>The subjects had to cut the grass and dry the hay on forest meadows and were allowed to catch hares. Hunting of other game by anyone except the appointed huntsman was, however, prohibited under strict penalties.</paragraph><paragraph>In the forests of the time the tree cover was largely of beech and fir and mixed oak, in which only certain timber varieties would be felled: oak for water structures, beech for charcoal-burning etc.</paragraph><paragraph>Overall, forest cover in the Middle Ages suffered considerable intervention and in some places was completely wiped out.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Forests belonging to the monarch, especially near borders, played not only an <accent>economic</accent> but also a <accent>strategic role</accent>—felled trees formed an important part of fortifications.</paragraph><paragraph>From the 14th century onwards, efforts were made to protect forests, with only the ruler having the authority to decide, for instance, whether peasants could fell trees for construction. The monarch could also permit farmers to graze cattle or burn charcoal on their lands, provided that deer could safely birth their young.</paragraph><paragraph>Peasants were tasked with mowing grass and drying hay in the forest meadows and were allowed to catch hares. Hunting other game was strictly forbidden for anyone except the lord of the forest, under severe penalties.</paragraph><paragraph>At that time, forests were predominantly composed of beech-fir and mixed oak, where only certain trees were felled: oak for water constructions, beech for charcoal burning, etc.</paragraph><paragraph>Overall, forest cover suffered significant damage during the Middle Ages and was completely eradicated in some areas.</paragraph>

<paragraph>While medieval church chants celebrated God and the Holy Trinity with dignity, folk songs were inspired by the cycle of the village year and often accompanied by group dance and music.</paragraph><paragraph>Homemade musical instruments included bagpipes, drums, horns, or various types of flutes. Wandering musicians called <italic>vagantes</italic> also carried more expensive string instruments such as the psaltery, mandora, or quinterna. It was they who helped to spread the mischievous and satirical vagante poetry composed by university students from the 13th century onwards. These wittily took potshots at human vices and satirically commented on the sins of the church prelates.</paragraph><paragraph>The songs were passed on verbally without the knowledge of the authors. What remains exceptional, therefore, is the collection of them in the manuscript <italic>Carmina Burana</italic>.</paragraph>

<paragraph>While medieval church chants solemnly celebrated God and the Holy Trinity, folk songs were inspired by the village year's cycle and often accompanied by group dances and musical accompaniment.</paragraph><paragraph>Homemade musical instruments included bagpipes, drums, horns, and various types of flutes. Wandering minstrels called <italic>vagantes</italic> carried with them more expensive string instruments such as the psaltery, mandora, or quintern. They were responsible for spreading the playful and satirical vagantes poetry, which was composed by university students from the 13th century. These poems humorously targeted human vices and satirically commented on the sins of church prelates.</paragraph><paragraph>Songs were passed down orally without knowledge of their authors. Exceptionally, their collection remains in the manuscript <italic>Carmina Burana</italic>.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the late 14th and early 15th centuries, both Czech and German were spoken in the Czech Lands.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>German</accent> first appeared after German colonization and made its way largely into the towns, the upper classes, and literature - love poems and bureaucratic language. <accent>Czech</accent> had evolved from old Slavonic and was spoken by the poorer residents, becoming an official language only during the reign of Charles IV.</paragraph><paragraph> Apart from these two languages there was <accent>Latin</accent>, the language of books, chronicles, learned treatises, official deeds and documents. Latin was the language of the Church and the Bible, and served as the medium of international communication.</paragraph><paragraph>The development of the Slavic language and its emancipation was the domain of the monasteries, including Sasau, from the early Middle Ages on. The preacher Jan Hus was one of the pioneers of fostering the Czech language.</paragraph><paragraph> As for <accent>literature</accent>, Czech found its due place from the early 14th century in various genres: spiritual and secular lyricism (love stories), epics and dramas. Among the oldest examples were legends, e.g. about Judas Iscariot, Pontius Pilate, the lives of the Saints, knightly epics, chronicles and satires. Apart from official documents in Latin, correspondence was written in Czech from the end of the 14th century.</paragraph>

<paragraph>At the turn of the 14th and 15th centuries, both Czech and German were spoken in the Czech lands.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>German</accent> appeared after German colonisation and spread mainly to towns, higher social strata, love poetry, and bureaucratic language. <accent>Czech</accent> developed from Old Church Slavonic and was used by poorer inhabitants, becoming the official language only during the reign of Charles IV.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to these two languages, <accent>Latin</accent> was also present, used for writing books, chronicles, scholarly treatises, official documents, and records. Latin was the ecclesiastical and biblical language and served as an international means of communication.</paragraph><paragraph>From the early Middle Ages, monasteries such as Sasau cared for the development and emancipation of the Slavic language. A pioneer in the cultivation of the Czech language in our region was Jan Hus.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Czech literature</accent> became fully established from the early 14th century in various genres: spiritual and secular lyrics (love poetry), epic poetry and plays. The oldest examples of prose included legends, e.g. about Judas, Pilate, the lives of saints, as well as chivalric epics, chronicles and satires. Besides official documents in Latin, letters were written in Czech from the late 14th century.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Even though we recognize locking systems dating back to ancient times, locksmithing, as a separate craft, came into being roughly between 1390-1408. Before this time the work was done by blacksmiths. In rural settlements, even after locksmithery came into its own, the work might well be done by an above average blacksmith.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 14th century the lock was still fitted to the outside of the door, made of iron and its mechanism was rather complicated. The locksmith decorated the lock cover and keyhole plates.</paragraph><paragraph>People even made a point of showing off with their locks, until the time locksmiths amalgamated into guilds and their creativity became restricted by security regulations.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Even though we know of locking systems dating back to ancient times, locksmithing, as a separate craft, came into being roughly between 1390 and 1408. Before this time, the work was done by blacksmiths. In rural settlements, even after locksmithing came into its own, the work might well be done by an above-average blacksmith.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 14th century, the lock was still fitted to the outside of the door, made of iron, and its mechanism was rather complicated. The locksmith decorated the lock cover and keyhole plates.</paragraph><paragraph>People even regarded their fancy locks as a status symbol, until the locksmiths amalgamated into guilds and their creativity began to be restricted by security regulations.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Whether Loretz was already standing at the time of our game is not clear, as the first written mention of it dates back to 1418.</paragraph><paragraph>There were probably no vineyards around the fortress, which were still a hot new thing in the Lands of the Bohemian Crown at that time, but beer was brewed there. From sources dating back to 1544, we learn that Zdislav Zvířetický of Wartenberg bought the local hop farm with a malt house and brewery. In 1593, the production of beer called Kumperské beer was preserved, in 1680 Konvent beer, from 1899 it was lager Dačický and 'health beer' Mincmistr.</paragraph><paragraph>Loretz Municipal Brewery in Kuttenberg has changed owners several times during its history, but beer is still brewed here, with minor interruptions, until today.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Whether Loretz was already standing at the time of our game is not clear, as the first written mention of it dates back to 1418.</paragraph><paragraph>It's unlikely that vineyards surrounded the fortress, as they were still a hot novelty in the Lands of the Bohemian Crown at that time, but beer was brewed there. From sources dating back to 1544, we learn that Zdislav Zvířetický of Wartenberg bought the local hop farm with malt house and brewery. In 1593, the production of beer called Kumperské was documented, in 1680 Konvent beer, from 1899 it was Dačický lager and the 'health beer' Mincmistr.</paragraph><paragraph>Loretz Municipal Brewery in Kuttenberg has changed owners several times during its history, but beer has been brewed here, with minor interruptions, to this day.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Thievery and robbery was a 'dishonourable profession', whose practitioners were known in the wider area - that is, if they could evade justice long enough.</paragraph><paragraph>Petty theft most often happened in villages, town markets or taverns. In short, where robbers could hide in the crowd. But people were in greater danger in the open countryside, outside their settlements, or in remote villages, where the victim could hardly call for help. Robbers therefore often threatened merchants and travellers on the road, especially around the richer towns, where they flocked to do business.</paragraph><paragraph>Some <accent>bands of robbers</accent> were organised and robbed under the auspices of resistant nobles who profited from their actions. Sometimes they even resorted to raiding entire villages or towns. They would then sell off their loot in markets or taverns.</paragraph><paragraph>The execution books give us evidence of the fate of those, who became involved with the robbers. In one of them, we can also read about Jan Zizka, that: <italic>'He steals herrings and killed a Rosenberg's hired hand.'</italic></paragraph>

<paragraph>Thievery and banditry were 'dishonourable professions', whose practitioners were often known in the wider area - that is, if they could evade justice long enough.</paragraph><paragraph>Petty theft most often happened in villages, town markets or taverns. In short, where thieves could hide in the crowd. But people were in greater danger in the open countryside, outside their settlements, or in remote villages, where victims could rarely call for help. Bandits therefore often threatened merchants and travellers on the road, especially around the richer towns, where they flocked to do business.</paragraph><paragraph>Some <accent>bands of robbers</accent> were organised and operated under the auspices of rebelious nobles who profited from their actions. At times they even resorted to raiding entire villages or towns. They would then sell off their loot in markets or taverns.</paragraph><paragraph>The execution books give us evidence of the fate of those, who became involved with bandits. In one of them, we read about Jan Zizka, that: <italic>'He steals herrings and killed a hired hand of the Rosenberg's.'</italic></paragraph>

<paragraph>During the early Middle Ages, agriculture and the rapid growth of towns took its toll on forests, with massive clearing. There was no reforestation done in those days, so in the 15th century some areas had even less forest cover than today, while the towns themselves were surrounded by zones of pure devastation.</paragraph><paragraph>Logging was done by woodcutters (<italic>lumberjacks</italic>). Their basic tool was a large single-sided axe on a long handle or haft; while various wooden wedges and hammers were used to split the lumber.</paragraph><paragraph>Transport of lumber from distant areas was difficult, which led to using navigable waterways, down which the lumber was left to drift freely.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the early Middle Ages, agriculture and the rapid growth of towns required extensive deforestation. Reforestation was not yet being done, so by the 15th century, some areas had even fewer forests than today, and the regions around towns were completely devastated.</paragraph><paragraph>Logging was done by <italic>woodcutters</italic>. The primary tool was a large single-sided axe on a long handle or haft; while various wooden wedges and hammers were used to split the lumber.</paragraph><paragraph>Transport of lumber from distant areas was difficult, which led to using navigable waterways, down which the lumber was left to drift freely.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The erection of the maypole is an old pagan custom that has survived in our country to this day and has been assimilated throughout society.</paragraph><paragraph>Traditionally, it is a <accent>celebration of the arrival of spring</accent>, during which the boys of the village cut down the tallest tree in the forest and place its cleared trunk in the village square, decorated at the top with a wreath and ribbons.</paragraph><paragraph>According to rural tradition, the boys of the village had to guard the erected maypole, while boys from neighbouring villages tried to cut down the maypole and steal the wreath. Both guarding and stealing the maypole was a matter of prestige for the whole village and not infrequently lives were lost in the process.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Erecting maypoles is an old pagan custom that has been preserved in our country to this day and has been assimilated into society as a whole.</paragraph><paragraph>Traditionally, it is a <accent>celebration of the arrival of spring</accent>, during which boys from the village cut down the tallest tree in the forest and erect its cleaned trunk on the village green, decorated at the top with a wreath and ribbons.</paragraph><paragraph>According to village tradition, the boys from the village had to guard the erected maypole, while boys from neighbouring villages tried to cut it down and capture the wreath. Guarding or capturing the maypole was a matter of prestige for the whole settlement, and it was not uncommon for there to be loss of life in the process.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The name of the village is derived from the legend of a wealthy Kuttenberg burgher named Malesh (Maleš), who founded a woodcutter colony here to supply the nearby silver mountains with charcoal.</paragraph><paragraph>We first learn about the village in 1303. The fortress is first mentioned later in 1359, with Purkard of Maidberk selling his village to the Sedletz Monastery and the monastery subsequently passing the village on to the Ruthards, a patrician family from Kuttenberg, in 1364. When the family was raised to a knightly status in the early 15th century, they began to call themselves the Ruthards of Maleshov. They did not enjoy the fortress for long, however, because in 1411 it falls to the king's supporter, Martin Kladný of Těchlovice.</paragraph><paragraph>The surroundings of Maleshov are literally interwoven with history. For example, in 1421, Martin Kladný defended the fortress against the army of Praguers, which wanted to install its own mint master in Kuttenberg. Maleshov became an important fortress especially during the Hussite Wars in 1424.</paragraph><paragraph>Today, a five-story tower with Gothic windows and remnants of late Gothic fortifications has been preserved from the fortress and it is a favourite destination for the Warhorse team.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The name of the village is derived from the legend of a wealthy Kuttenberg burgher named Malesh (Maleš), who founded a woodcutter colony here to supply the nearby silver mountains with charcoal.</paragraph><paragraph>The first mention of the village dates back to 1303. The fortress is first mentioned in 1359, when Purkard of Maidberk sold his village to the Sedletz Monastery which subsequently passed the village onto the Ruthards, a patrician family from Kuttenberg, in 1364. When the family was enobled in the early 15th century, they began to call themselves the Ruthards of Maleshov. They did not enjoy the fortress for long, however, because in 1411 it was given to the king's supporter, Martin Kladný of Těchlovice.</paragraph><paragraph>The area around Maleshov is steeped in history. For example, in 1421, Martin Kladný defended the fortress against an army of Praguers, that wanted to install its own Mint Master in Kuttenberg. Maleshov became an important fortress especially during the Hussite Wars in 1424.</paragraph><paragraph>Today, the remains of the fortress include a five-story tower with Gothic windows and remnants of late Gothic fortifications making it a favourite destination for the Warhorse team.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Beer or ale was for a long time a drink brewed by anyone, only in the 13th century did it gradually come to be regulated. Under the rules beer could only be brewed and sold by a full citizen who owned a house within the city walls. The right to brew closely relates to the one mile right, namely that none but citizens of a city were allowed to conduct city trades within a one mile radius of the city.</paragraph><paragraph>The technicalities were supervised by the chief <accent>brewer</accent>, the making of the malt and beer was dealt with by the <accent>maltster</accent>, the <accent>brewster</accent> handled the fermentation and brewing – in home breweries all the activities being down to the same person.</paragraph><paragraph>The shelf life of beer depend on whether the finished brew was filtered or not. Yeast remained in the brew, as well as acetic or lactic bacteria, contaminating it. Beer then, quite unlike today, resembled a thick mush, and was very nutritious (hence known as ‘liquid bread'). It had to be drunk through a straw to keep the dirt out. Only later did beer come to be filtered and became the classic liquid we think of.</paragraph><paragraph>St Wenceslas was the patron saint of maltsters in Bohemia, the patron saint of brewsters was Gambrinus. The brewing tradition had been kept going to this day, Czech beer has its place among the world's best.</paragraph>

<paragraph>For a long time, anyone who wished could brew beer. It was only in the 13th century that brewing gradually came to be regulated. The rules stated that beer could only be brewed and sold by a full-fledged citizen who owned a house within the town walls. The right to brew closely relates to the 'one-mile right', which dictated that none but citizens of a town were allowed to conduct 'urban' trades within a one mile radius of the city.</paragraph><paragraph>The overall process was supervised by the <accent>master brewer</accent>, the making of the malt and beer was dealt with by the <accent>maltster</accent> and a <accent>brewer</accent> handled the fermentation and brewing. In domestic breweries, all these jobs would be done by one man.</paragraph><paragraph>The shelf life of beer depended on whether the finished brew was filtered or not. Yeast remained in the brew, as well as acetic or lactic bacteria, contaminating it. Beer then, quite unlike today, resembled porridge, and was very nutritious (hence known as ‘liquid bread'). It had to be drunk through a straw to filter out foreign matter. Only later was beer filtered to become the classic liquid we think of today.</paragraph><paragraph>St. Wenceslas was the patron saint of maltsters in Bohemia, while the legendary Gambrinus, though not a saint, was regarded as the patron of brewing. The Bohemian brewing tradition thrives to this day and Czech beer is amongst the best in the world.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The mortuary was a small, simple building made of wood or stone, built next to the church in the corner of the cemetery. It was used for storing coffin stretcher, <italic>biers</italic> and for keeping coffins of the dead.</paragraph><paragraph>Here the family watched over the body of the deceased and prepared the body for burial.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A mortuary was a small, simple structure made of wood or stone, built next to the church in the corner of the cemetery. It housed the coffin stands, called <italic>biers</italic>, and stored coffins with the deceased.</paragraph><paragraph>Here, the family would keep vigil over the body of the deceased and prepare it for burial.</paragraph>

In the Middle Ages the relationships between townsfolk and villagers were not particularly good. Townspeople (not only those enjoying the freedom of full city rights, but also the poor) regarded themselves as higher ranking than agricultural peasants in villages. Often enough they did indeed have higher social standing, due to their trade and business profits.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Towns</accent> were the economic and cultural centres, but it was the <accent>country</accent> that provided the goods, especially foodstuffs. In a medieval town, the best properties around the square and the market were owned by rich Councillors and merchants. Around them lived the craftsmen and artisans, and the poor by the city walls. The townspeople's livelihoods stemmed largely from trade, skilled crafts and many associated professions. Like today, the townsfolk bought their food at the market.</paragraph><paragraph>According to some sources, Prague at the time of Charles IV had some 40,000 inhabitants. At this time London had about 80,000. Paris was comparable to Prague, although the Czech capital covered a larger area. The nobles did not generally live in the cities, but resided on their own estates.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In medieval times, the relationships between town and village inhabitants were not very good. Townspeople (not just those fully enjoying municipal rights, but also the poor) considered themselves superior to the rural farmers. This was often true due to their significantly higher profits from trade and business.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Towns</accent> served as economic and cultural centres, while the <accent>countryside</accent> provided goods and, most importantly, food. In a medieval town, the best plots around the square and market were owned by wealthy councillors and merchants. Artisans lived around them, and the poor lived near the walls. Townspeople's livelihood mainly came from trade, crafts, and many associated professions, and they went to the market for food, just as they do today.</paragraph><paragraph>According to some sources, Prague could have had around 40,000 inhabitants during the reign of Charles IV. London at the same time had about 80,000. Paris was comparable to Prague, although the Czech city covered a larger area. Nobles did not live in towns; they resided in their own estates.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The city gates (they were always at least two) served to watch over the comings and goings of the city dwellers, and tolls and duties were collected there from traders for goods brought in and sold. The ground level housed the armoury and storage facilities, the highest level featured an astronomical clock or town clock.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>typical gate tower</accent> was a rectangular tower of greater or lesser height with a passage through and a drawbridge over a frontal moat. The walls of some cities also included a water gate, through which the townspeople made their way to the water supply. There were also dedicated gates for the executioner and his henchmen, for unclean people, as well as Jewish gates.</paragraph><paragraph>After closing time, it was only possible to enter the city with a special permit from the Councillors. Anyone who failed to make it back in time had to spend the night outside the city walls. The gate was locked with a key that was kept overnight with the Bailiff or the Head of the City Council.</paragraph>

<paragraph>City gates (there were always at least two) controlled the comings and goings of the city dwellers, and collected tolls and duties from traders for goods they brought and sold. The ground level housed the armoury and storage facilities, while the upper level featured an astronomical clock or town clock.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>typical gate tower</accent> was a lower or higher rectangular tower with a passageway and a drawbridge over the front moat. The walls of some cities also included a water gate, through which townspeople made their way to a water supply. Special entrances included gates designated for the executioner and his assistants, unclean people, and the so-called Jewish gates.</paragraph><paragraph>After closing time, entry into the city was only possible with special permission from the councilors. Those who did not return in time had to sleep outside the walls. The gate was locked with a key, which was kept at night by the Bailiff or the Head of the City Council.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Metallurgy is the process of working metal or its alloys, known and refined over millennia, dating back to the earliest civilisations.</paragraph><paragraph>Metals can be processed by various methods, such as casting, forging, cold forming, rolling, extrusion, sintering, metalworking, shearing, and shaping.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 14th century, mining and metal processing were organised through guilds that regulated production quality and ensured compliance with labour standards. Guilds played a crucial role in protecting the rights and interests of their members.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Metallurgy is the process of working metal or its alloys, known and refined over millennia, dating back to the earliest civilisations.</paragraph><paragraph>Metals can be processed by various methods, such as casting, forging, cold forming, rolling, extrusion, sintering, metalworking, shearing and shaping.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 14th century, mining and metal processing were organised through guilds that regulated production quality and ensured compliance with labour standards. Guilds played a crucial role in protecting the rights and interests of their members.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A village 5 km southwest of Kuttenberg.</paragraph><paragraph>The first written mention of the village is from 1384, and then only from 1445, when the village was sold to the Sasau Monastery. Otherwise, all we know about the village is that in 1932 there were 192 inhabitants living here and the village had two inns and two blacksmiths, while in the earlier times, we have mentiones of only 45 inhabitants.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A village 5 km southwest of Kuttenberg.</paragraph><paragraph>The first written mention of the village is from 1384, and then another from 1445, when the village was sold to the Sasau Monastery. Otherwise, all we know about the village is that in 1932, there were 192 inhabitants and the village had two inns and two blacksmiths, while in the earlier times, we have mentions of only 45 inhabitants.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Milling is one of the oldest crafts in the Czech lands, the construction of water mills being well known since earliest times. Over the centuries the mechanism was perfected, and in the Middle Ages there was a mill practically in every village. There were also windmills or those powered by oxen or a horsemill. Millers belonged among the so-called freelance professions, while also ensuring trade in the village, among their other roles.</paragraph><paragraph>With the increasing number of water mills and other water-powered equipment there was a need settle relationships between the Millers. Already by the mid-14th century a chancery of provincial Millers – experts in the field of water law, was set up, with powers to survey watercourses, stipulate the scale of mill earthworks, to assess the technical condition of the mills and so on. They also drew up a code of conduct for millers to go by, so as to ensure their use of water for grinding caused no harm to others.</paragraph><paragraph>Since the mills stood apart from the other village houses, millers were often the subject of gossip and were accused of earn money on the side in nefarious ways – from selling customers short on flour, to outright witchcraft, or thievery and trafficking in stolen goods. Especially the latter accusations are quite underhand and without a grain of truth, not valid in the least.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Milling is one of the oldest crafts in the Czech lands, with the construction of water mills being known since ancient times. Over the centuries, the mechanism was perfected, and by the Middle Ages, a mill was present in almost every village. There were also windmills and mills powered by oxen, known as "jentour". Milling was one of the so-called free trades, and millers also ensured trade in the village.</paragraph><paragraph>With the increasing number of water mills and other water-powered devices, it became necessary to establish relationships between individual millers. As early as the mid-14th century, a board of sworn millers – experts in water law – was established. They were primarily tasked with measuring watercourses, determining the levels of mill weirs, assessing the technical condition of mills, and so on. They also established a set of principles that millers had to follow to ensure that the use of water for milling did not harm others.</paragraph><paragraph>Since mills were often located away from other rural buildings, millers frequently became the subject of gossip and were attributed many negative side activities – from cheating customers on flour to witchcraft, theft, and trafficking in stolen goods. These last accusations are particularly abhorrent and completely unfounded.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Two officials in a medieval mint whose job was to check the quality of coins minted and punish counterfeiters. One of them was appointed by the king and the position was hereditary. The other official was elected by the Bohemian lords. The penalty for poor performance of the office or for allowing poor quality coins into circulation was death.</paragraph><paragraph>This was a high rank with great importance for the entire Bohemian kingdom, so the names of all the mintmasters and their officials are well documented. We select from them the persons who appear in the game:</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Petr of Písek</accent>, Coinmaster, 1395</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Adam of Zaříčí</accent>, Coin Scribe, 1401</paragraph><paragraph><paragraph><accent>Konrád of Vechta</accent>, coin clerk, 1401-1402, later still 1403</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Oldřich Vavák of Hradec</accent>, mintmaster, 1402-1403</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Kryštof</accent>, mintmaster, 1403</paragraph>

<paragraph>Two officials in a medieval mint whose job it was to check the quality of coins minted and punish counterfeiters. One of them was appointed by the king and the position was hereditary. The other was elected by the Bohemian lords. The penalty for poor performance of duties or for allowing poor quality coins into circulation was death.</paragraph><paragraph>This was a high ranking position of great importance for the entire Bohemian Kingdom, so the names of all the Mint Masters and their officials are well documented. We list those who appear in the game:</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Peter of Pisek</accent>, Mint Master, 1395</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Adam of Zarzitz</accent>, coin scribe, 1401</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Konrad of Vechta</accent>, coin clerk, 1401-1402, later still 1403</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Ulrich Vavak von Neuhaus</accent>, Mint Master, 1402-1403</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Christopher</accent>, assayer, 1403</paragraph>

<paragraph>The mine leaseholder is usually referred to as a wealthy burgher who leased the land for mining and employed miners. Experienced mine leaseholder were also able to discern suitable terrain and judge whether it would be rich in ore. Therefore, they could also sit in various offices regulated by the mining law and participate in the successful growth of mining towns in the Bohemian Kingdom.</paragraph><paragraph>They ensured, among other things, that both breweries and churches (dedicated mainly to St. Barbara or St. James the Great, the patron saints of miners) were built in the mining villages. In fact, they ensured that miners and workers were willing and able to move to the mining areas with their entire families.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Mine leaseholders were usually wealthy burghers who leased the land for mining and employed miners. Experienced mine leaseholders were also able to recognise suitable terrain and judge whether it would be rich in ore. Therefore, they could also sit in various offices regulated by mining law and participate in the successful growth of mining towns in the Bohemian Kingdom.</paragraph><paragraph>They ensured, among other things, that both breweries and churches (dedicated mainly to St. Barbara or St. James the Great, the patron saints of miners) were built in the mining villages. In fact, they ensured that miners and workers were willing and able to move to the mining areas with their entire families.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The first mention of the village can be found in 1309, when it belonged to Nechval and Peškov of Miskowitz. In 1358, part of the village falls under the Skalitz Monastery. Until 1805, Miskowitz was closed by three gates, but it is not known for sure whether there was a wall between them.</paragraph><paragraph>The fortress in the village stood since time immemorial and the first written mention dates back to 1419, when it belonged to a Kuttenberg burgher Vaněk Píšek.</paragraph><paragraph>The surrounding area of the village is rich in water and the spring of St. Adalbert, which supplied Kuttenberg in the Middle Ages, can be found here.</paragraph>
