<paragraph>The first mention of the village can be found in 1309, when it belonged to Nechval and Peškov of Miskowitz. In 1358, part of the village was taken over by the Skalitz monastery. Until 1805, Miskowitz was enclosed by three gates, but it is not known for sure whether there was a wall between them.</paragraph><paragraph>The fortress in the village stood since time immemorial and the first written mention dates back to 1419, when it belonged to a Kuttenberg burgher Vaněk Píšek.</paragraph><paragraph>The area surrounding the village is rich in water and the spring of St. Adalbert, which supplied Kuttenberg in the Middle Ages, can be found here.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The earliest prayers were dedicated to the Virgin Mary – <italic>Hail Mary</italic> (in Latin: <italic>Ave Maria</italic>), Beneath Thy Protection (Sub tuum praesidium) with a rosary and numerous litanies. The prayers followed the pagan formulations, which were modified with the adoption of Christianity, to fit the new doctrine.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to the Marian prayers, the more frequently chanted were the <italic>Lord's prayer</italic>, the <italic>Credo</italic> (declaration of faith), and the <italic>Angel of the Lord</italic>. Litanies were dedicated primarily to Christ, but also to other saints. The priest would incant and the people respond <italic>Kyrie Eleison</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>The monks knew and used many more prayers, relating to the daily cycle. Hermits and others who dedicated themselves to God in solitude, recited the scripture and psalms.</paragraph><paragraph>During the liturgy the prevailing language was Latin, with some prayers or songs in the vernacular, e.g. <italic>Lord, be kind unto us</italic> or <italic>Saint Wenceslas</italic>.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The oldest prayers were dedicated to the Virgin Mary – e.g. <italic>Ave Maria</italic> <italic>(Hail Mary)</italic>, the rosary, and many litanies. The original form of prayers were pagan formulations, which were adapted to the new doctrine upon the acceptance of Christianity.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to Marian prayers, the <italic>Our Father</italic> (the Lord’s Prayer) and the <italic>Credo</italic> (creed), and the <italic>Angelus</italic> were recited and even more frequently sung. Litanies were primarily dedicated to Christ, but also to other saints - the priest would chant and the people would respond with <italic>Kyrie eleison</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>Monks knew and used many more prayers related to the daily cycle. Hermits and others who devoted themselves to God and solitude recited the Holy Scriptures and psalms.</paragraph><paragraph>During the liturgy, Latin was predominantly heard, but there were also prayers or songs in the vernacular, e.g. <italic>Lord, Have Mercy on Us</italic> or <italic>Saint Wenceslas</italic>.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Currency in the Middle Ages took the form coins minted in denominations corresponding to the quantity of precious material used (gold or silver).</paragraph><paragraph>In Bohemia, the silver <accent>Prague Groschen</accent> long served as legal tender. The decimal system was not in general use - one Groschen divided into 7 'pennies', and those in turn into 14 hellers. Similarly, counting and calculating was done in dozens (12) and threescores ('kopa' - 60). However, since this would be rather confusing for us today, the smallest unit of value in the game is 0.1 Groschen.</paragraph><paragraph>Coins were circular and marked with the Czech lion in a square on the reverse in Bohemia, substituted by an eagle in Moravia</paragraph><paragraph>Around the year 1400, the quality (and hence the value) of the Groschen dropped significantly, with other metals being added to the silver. This was to do with overexploitation of the mining deposits of the most valuable metals around Kuttenberg, Central Bohemia, and Jihlava (Iglau) in Moravia and a shortage of goods for exchange with foreign countries.</paragraph><paragraph>Economic and financial problems at that time led to growing anti-Semitism, a rise in crime and, ultimately, the collapse of the Czech currency. Counterfeit coins were in circulation alongside genuine ones, despite the fact that <accent>counterfeiting</accent> was one of the most serious crimes and was punished by burning at the stake.</paragraph><paragraph>Smaller silver coins were minted right up to the Hussite wars marked with a crown or the crowned head of the monarch on the obverse. The mint employed two mint-masters to vouch for the precious metal quality of the coins, under mortal oath. The prices of goods and articles varied locally and changed frequently.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, money took the form of minted coins, with values corresponding to the amount of usable precious material (gold or silver).</paragraph><paragraph>In Bohemia, the long-standing silver <accent>Prague groschen</accent> was in use. However, in the Middle Ages, the decimal system was not used in everyday life, so one Prague groschen was divided into 7 pence, which were further divided into 14 heller. Similarly, counts were made in dozens (12) and threescores ('kopa'- 60). Since this would be somewhat confusing for people today, the smallest unit in the game is 0.1 groschen.</paragraph><paragraph>The coins were circular in shape and were decorated on the reverse with the Bohemian lion in a square, while in Moravia they depicted an eagle.</paragraph><paragraph>Around the year 1400, the quality of the groschen noticeably declined (and thus its value), and more other metals began to be added to the silver. This was related to the excessive exploitation of the richest metal deposits around Kuttenberg and Jihlava (Iglau) in Moravia, and a shortage of goods for exchange with foreign countries.</paragraph><paragraph>The economic and financial problems at the time led to growing antisemitism, an increase in crime, and ultimately the collapse of the Bohemian currency. In addition to genuine coins, counterfeit coins (forgeries) were also in circulation. <accent>Counterfeiting</accent> was one of the most serious crimes and was punishable by burning at the stake.</paragraph><paragraph>Small silver coins were minted until the Hussite wars. On the obverse was a crown or the crowned head of the ruler. The quality was checked in the mint by two Mint Masters, who confirmed the metal content with an oath upon their lives. The prices of goods and items varied locally and were valid for only a very short time.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Until the 11th century, music and singing were mostly liturgical, though also associated with everyday activities. In the world of religion, there were the <italic>Gregorian chants</italic> (taking their name from Pope Gregory the Great), or musical forms with Latin singing unaccompanied by instruments, used in the rites of the Roman Catholic Church.</paragraph><paragraph>The Middle Ages were not averse to singing, but a difficult time for <accent>musical instruments</accent>, since the Church frowned upon any kind of music other than vocal. For centuries, therefore, the instruments of old continued to be used and no new ones were invented. Instrumental music in its own right gained prominence only in the 14th century, in the <italic>‘ars nova'</italic> or <italic>New Art</italic> period.</paragraph><paragraph> The concept of an original musical work or composition was as yet unknown; music arose mostly from improvisation and musical works were learned off by heart and spread by oral transmission.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Until the 11th century, music and singing were primarily liturgical, though also associated with everyday activities. In the ecclesiastical world, there were <italic>Gregorian chants</italic> (taking their name from Pope Gregory the Great), which were musical forms for Latin singing unaccompanied by instruments, used in Roman Catholic ceremonies.</paragraph><paragraph>The Middle Ages were not averse to singing, but it was a difficult time for <accent>musical instruments</accent>, since the Church frowned upon any kind of music other than vocal. For centuries, therefore, only ancient instruments were used without any new innovations. Instrumental music in its own right gained prominence only in the 14th century, in the <italic>‘ars nova'</italic> or <italic>New Art</italic> period.</paragraph><paragraph> The concept of an original musical work or composition was as yet unknown; music arose mostly from improvisation and musical works were learned by heart and spread by oral transmission.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The theatre as we know it today was not that widespread in the Middle Ages and was used more for church purposes (passion plays). Art in the high court, on the other hand, was not comprehensible to commoners, so the profession of a folk entertainer was established for a variety of purposes.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Minstrels</accent> were seen at fairs and markets; they made the rounds of the taverns and were even hired by wealthy merchants or nobles. The minstrel’s repertoire could include singing, playing musical instruments, juggling, staged scenes or the narration of humorous stories.</paragraph><paragraph>The content of their work was mostly light and cheerful themes, but often also satire or criticism of political conditions, whether coming from the minstrels themselves, or paid for by their employer and tailored to his intentions. Most of the minstrels had no employer, but they belonged to the margins of society and had to get by from day to day through alms.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Musicians</accent> enjoyed a bit more respect and their music, apart from entertaining, could also be used during religious services. The most popular medieval instruments were flutes, trumpets, shawms, or lutes, harps and drums. The production was most often improvised, though the first scores did appear at this time.</paragraph><paragraph>There were both professional musicians employed by the court or the church and travelling musicians playing in markets and at celebrations.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Theatre as we know it today was not widespread in the Middle Ages and was used more for church purposes (passion plays). Art in the high court, on the other hand, was not comprehensible to commoners, so the profession of folk entertainer was established for a variety of purposes.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Minstrels</accent> were seen at fairs and markets; they made the rounds of taverns and were even hired by wealthy merchants or nobles. The minstrel’s repertoire could include singing, playing musical instruments, juggling, staging scenes or narrating humorous stories.</paragraph><paragraph>The themes of their work were mostly light and cheerful, but often included satire or criticism of political conditions, whether coming from the minstrels themselves, or paid for by an employer and tailored to their intentions. Most of the minstrels had no employer, they belonged to the margins of society and had to get by from day to day through alms.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Musicians</accent> enjoyed a bit more respect and besides entertainment, their music could also be used during religious services. Popular medieval instruments included flutes, trumpets, shawms, as well as lutes, harps and drums. Their performances were mostly improvised, but early musical notations also began to appear at this time.</paragraph><paragraph>There were both, professional musicians employed at court or churches and travelling musicians playing in markets and at celebrations. This craft was predominantly pursued by men.</paragraph>

<paragraph>At the end of the 15th century Bohemian furniture was made of planks with more or less complex construction. Oak, fir, walnut, linden, ash, larch or spruce were used. The surface was painted with beeswax or linen fermé. Towards the end of the Gothic period, shellac polish was used. It was dyed by smoking, with water from fermented cabbage, and bleached with lime water.</paragraph><paragraph>Tables and seating furniture had the same construction with flat sides or "X" shaped boards. The chests varied in size and were used to store bulk materials, clothing or other small possessions. City dwellers slept on beds with curtains, while in the village the furnishings were very simple. The peasants made their furniture from split and cleaned planks and posts. In the peasant's cottage, they slept on hay laid on the ground (straw).</paragraph><paragraph>Truppers and carvers decorated furniture with ornaments. The most expensive furniture was decorated with metal elements, which, in addition to improving the appearance, had a strengthening function.</paragraph><paragraph>In KCD, most of the furniture is based on medieval examples from the 12th-16th centuries.</paragraph>

<paragraph>By the end of the 15th century, Bohemian furniture was made from planks with more or less complex construction. Oak, fir, walnut, linden, ash, larch, or spruce were used. The surface was coated with beeswax or linseed oil. Towards the end of the Gothic period, shellac polish was used. Colouring was done by smoking, water from fermented cabbage, and bleaching with lime water.</paragraph><paragraph>Tables and seating furniture had the same construction with flat sides or boards in the shape of an "X". Chests varied in size and were used to store bulk materials, clothing, or other small possessions. City dwellers slept in beds with curtains, while in the countryside, the furnishings were very simple. Peasants made furniture from split and cleaned planks and posts. In a peasant's hut, people slept on hay laid on the ground (a straw mattress).</paragraph><paragraph>Cabinetmakers and carvers decorated the furniture with ornaments. The most expensive furniture was adorned with metal elements, which not only enhanced its appearance but also served a reinforcing function.</paragraph><paragraph>In KCD, most of the furniture is made according to medieval examples from the 12th to 16th centuries.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Although the more educated or higher-born tried to keep invective and vulgarities out of their speech, swearing has been part of the vernacular since time immemorial. <accent>Profanity</accent> was not only verbal, but often appeared in written form in documents that sought to defame and humiliate those addressed.</paragraph><paragraph> Some of the <accent>slurs</accent> arose by corrupting foreign-language expressions, others were derived from animals and their attributes. Often used as insults were onomatopoeic words (articulated noises) or metaphors, words derived from adjectives, attitudes towards work, criminal offences, political stances, professions, psychological malaise or people's names.</paragraph><paragraph>The worst kind of <accent>insult</accent> questioned the honour of the individual – such swearwords quite often led to court cases or duels. It was common practice that anyone not prepared to defend their honour would indeed lose it in the eyes of those around.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Although the more educated or higher-born tried to keep invective and vulgarities out of their speech, swearing has been part of the vernacular since time immemorial. <accent>Profanity</accent> was not only verbal, but often appeared in written form in documents that sought to defame and humiliate those addressed.</paragraph><paragraph> Some of the <accent>slurs</accent> arose by corrupting foreign-language expressions, others were derived from animals and their attributes. Often used as insults were onomatopoeic words (articulated noises) or metaphors, words derived from adjectives, attitudes towards work, criminal offences, political stances, professions, psychological malaise or people's names.</paragraph><paragraph>The worst kind of <accent>insult</accent> questioned the honour of the individual – such swearwords quite often led to court cases or duels. It was common practice that anyone not prepared to defend their honour would indeed lose it in the eyes of the public.</paragraph>

<paragraph>There were shortages of clean drinking water (due to pollution of watercourses by human activities around rural settlements) and fruit juices were available only in season. Hence everyone, including children, drank beer.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>beer</accent> brewed at home was weaker and heavier than today, contained 1-5% alcohol, and served instead of soup. It had no head of foam, was brewed from wheat - so-called <italic>white beer</italic>, or from barley - so-called <italic>old beer</italic>. Only in the 15th century, did hops come to be added for better beer quality, bringing out a bitter flavour.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Wine</accent> was drunk primarily at the Court and in the monasteries. It differed from today's by its spicy, very sweet taste. It would be condensed into a thick syrup and diluted with water.</paragraph><paragraph>Spirits were altogether rare. Distillation took place in small volumes. Fruit and cereal distillates were again weaker than today's (about 15-20%). The most popular drink was mead, made from fermented honey dissolved in water.</paragraph>

<paragraph>There were shortages of clean drinking water (due to pollution of watercourses by human activities around rural settlements) and fruit juices were available only in season. Hence everyone, including children, drank beer.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>beer</accent> brewed at home was weaker and heavier than today, containing 1-5% alcohol, and was served in place of soup. It had no head of foam, was brewed from wheat - so-called <italic>white beer</italic>, or from barley <italic>old beer</italic>. Only in the 15th century, did hops come to be added for better beer quality, bringing out a bitter flavour.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Wine</accent> was drunk primarily at the Court and in the monasteries. It differed from today's wine with its spiced, very sweet taste. It was condensed into a thick syrup and diluted with water.</paragraph><paragraph>Spirits were altogether rare. Distillation took place in small volumes. Fruit and cereal distillates were again weaker than today's (about 15-20%). The most popular drink was mead, made from fermented honey dissolved in water.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The basic agricultural tools in a Czech medieval village included Henry's trusty shovel (spade), and then adzes, hoes, spades, shears, knives, axes, flails, scythes, rakes, forks and also ploughing tools such as the beamed plough, turn-plough, ard-plough and harrow. Each craft had need of its own special equipment and tools.</paragraph><paragraph>Later on agricultural instruments played, among other things, a decisive role in the hands of skilled farmers during the Hussite wars, when, with minor improvements, they proved surprisingly useful not only for threshing grain, but also for enemy knights (Catholics).</paragraph><paragraph>The versatility of the tools and also the ingenuity of the medieval people is evidenced by a preserved poem from the Jihlava (Iglau) region on the border of Bohemia and Moravia:</paragraph> <paragraph><italic>Jihlava maidens are fine folk,</italic></paragraph> <paragraph><italic>they curl their hair with dung fork.</italic></paragraph>

<paragraph>Basic agricultural tools in a Czech medieval village included Henry's trusty shovel (spade), and then adzes, hoes, spades, shears, knives, axes, flails, scythes, rakes, forks and also ploughing tools such as the beamed plough, turn-plough, ard-plough and harrow. Each craft had need of its own special equipment and tools.</paragraph><paragraph>Later, agricultural instruments played, among other things, a decisive role in the hands of skilled farmers during the Hussite wars, when, with minor improvements, they proved surprisingly useful not only for threshing grain, but also enemy knights (Catholics).</paragraph><paragraph>The versatility of the tools and also the ingenuity of the medieval people is evidenced by a preserved poem from the Jihlava (Iglau) region on the border of Bohemia and Moravia:</paragraph> <paragraph><italic>Jihlava maidens are quite fine folks,</italic></paragraph> <paragraph><italic>they curl their hair with manure forks.</italic></paragraph>

<paragraph>A large number of people were illiterate during the Middle Ages. For them, art was a tool for education and communication between the different layers of society. For this reason, surviving works of art are one of the best sources of information about the Middle Ages. Murals, whether sacred or profane, often reveal very detailed information about the lives of our ancestors.</paragraph><paragraph>While <accent>religious paintings</accent> focused mainly on spreading piety and humility towards God, <accent>secular paintings</accent> represented cultural and historical moments in local history. Among the most popular motifs were allegorical scenes from the Bible, images of courtly life or chivalric legends, and we also encounter portraits of saints (usually the patron saints of a given village) or prominent clergymen. The paintings also depict events such as the foundation of buildings, the coronation of rulers or the handing over of city rights.</paragraph><paragraph>Figures were most often depicted in period or slightly archaic clothing, even if the scenes were hundreds of years old. The architecture depicted, as a rule, contains characteristic Romanesque or Gothic elements and is enlivened by a number of symbolic floral and animal motifs.</paragraph><paragraph>Large-scale murals were often created with the contribution of several artists whose styles were visibly inspired by the work of contemporary masters of one area or another, as evidenced by similarities in subject matter as well as in the composition or colouring of the paintings.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A large part of the population was illiterate during the Middle Ages. Therefore, art was a tool for education and communication among different layers of society. For this reason, preserved works of art are among the best sources of information about the medieval period. Wall paintings, whether sacred or profane, often reveal very detailed information about the lives of our ancestors.</paragraph><paragraph>While <accent>religious paintings</accent> focused primarily on spreading piety and humility towards God, <accent>secular painting</accent> represented cultural and historical moments of local history. Among the most popular motifs were allegorical scenes from the Bible, images of court life or knightly legends, and we also encounter portraits of saints (mostly patrons of the given communities) or significant clergy. The paintings also include events such as the founding of buildings, coronations of rulers, or the granting of city rights.</paragraph><paragraph>Figures were most often depicted in contemporary or slightly archaized clothing, even if the scenes depicted were perhaps hundreds of years old. The depicted architecture typically contains characteristic Romanesque or Gothic elements and is enriched with a number of symbolic floral and animal motifs.</paragraph><paragraph>Large-scale murals often came into being with the contribution of multiple artists, whose styles were visibly inspired by the works of contemporary masters of this or that region, as evidenced by similarities in themes, as well as the composition or colorfulness of the paintings.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The castle was probably built at the end of the 13th century on a promontory above the Nebák pond, surrounded on all sides by steep cliffs and water. In order to build the fortress, the rock underneath it had to be manually hewn away and levelled, which at that time represented a rather complex process for a mere noble’s castle of little importance.</paragraph><paragraph> According to archaeological research, the three-part layout with a courtyard and a fortified keep, connected to other parts of the complex by a bridge spanning a rocky moat.</paragraph><paragraph> The first mention of the castle only appeared in the sources in 1455. The castle burned down at the end of the 15th century and from 1538 it had been described as derelict and abandoned. From the fortification, only the ramparts, moats and notches in the rock have been preserved to this day.</paragraph><paragraph> We tried to reconstruct the castle so that its appearance corresponds as much as possible to the archaeological research.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The castle was likely built at the end of the 13th century on a promontory overlooking Nebak pond, surrounded on all sides by steep cliffs and water. To construct the fortress, the rock beneath it had to be manually hewn away and levelled, which was a relatively complex process for its time, given it was a small noble castle of little significance.</paragraph><paragraph>According to archaeological research, it had a three-part layout with a courtyard and a fortified keep, connected to other parts of the complex by a bridge spanning a rocky moat.</paragraph><paragraph>The first mention of the castle in historical sources only appears in 1455. The castle burned down at the end of the 15th century and from 1538 is described as abandoned and in ruins. The ramparts, moats and notches in the rock are all that remain of the fortifications today.</paragraph><paragraph>We endeavoured to reconstruct the castle in the game in an appearance that aligns as much as possible with archaeological findings.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Diseases spread due to poor hygiene, natural disasters, crop failures, famine, cold, humidity, wars or animal-borne contagion.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to the most common medieval disease – the plague, otherwise called the <accent>black death</accent> – other prevalent diseases were whooping cough, cholera, influenza, malaria, tuberculosis, typhus, leprosy, anthrax and diphtheria.</paragraph><paragraph>Great risks stemmed from general mouldiness or from giving birth. People commonly suffered from parasites, having bladder problems, kidney stones or hernias. Fractures were commonplace. Cataracts could be excised by a surgeon or an executioner.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Diseases spread due to poor hygiene, natural disasters, crop failures, famine, cold, humidity, wars or animal-borne contagion.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to the most common medieval disease – the plague, otherwise called the <accent>black death</accent> – other prevalent diseases were whooping cough, cholera, influenza, malaria, tuberculosis, typhus, leprosy, anthrax and diphtheria.</paragraph><paragraph>Other risks stemmed from general fungal infections or childbirth. People commonly suffered from parasites, bladder problems, kidney stones or hernias. Fractures were commonplace. Cataracts could only be excised by a surgeon or an executioner.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Battle of Nicopolis took place on <accent>25 September 1396</accent> between Sigismund of Luxembourg King of Hungary and the Turks, led by Sultan Bayezid.</paragraph><paragraph>Sigismund's army was made up of soldiers from France, Burgundy, Germany, England, Italy, Bohemia, Poland and other countries. In total, it numbered between 10 and 15 thousand men. The Ottomans, to whom the Balkans belonged at the end of the 14th century, numbered nearly 20 thousand.</paragraph><paragraph>The experienced Turkish warriors completely crushed the Christian knights, mainly due to undisciplined French knights who disobeyed orders, they attacked the Turkish vanguard thinking it was the main army, and were subsequently crushed.</paragraph><paragraph>Those who did not die on the battlefield were brutally executed - reportedly up to 3,000 men. The richest were captured and saved only by ransoms, which they repaid over decades. When news of the defeat reached Paris, no one believed it, and those who initially spread it were sentenced to death by drowning for "spreading the lies."</paragraph><paragraph>The Ottoman victory was a triumph of Islam over Christianity. Turkish troops posed a real threat to European countries, especially to Hungary.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Battle of Nicopolis took place on <accent>25 September 1396</accent> between the Hungarian king, Sigismund of Luxembourg and the Ottoman Turks, led by Sultan Bayezid.</paragraph><paragraph>Sigismund's army was made up of soldiers from France, Burgundy, Germany, England, Italy, Bohemia, Poland and other countries. In total, it numbered between 10 and 15 thousand men. The Ottomans, to whom the Balkans belonged at the end of the 14th century, numbered nearly 20 thousand.</paragraph><paragraph>The experienced Turkish warriors completely crushed the Christian knights, mainly due to undisciplined French knights who disobeyed orders, they attacked the Turkish vanguard thinking it was the main army, and were subsequently crushed.</paragraph><paragraph>Those who did not die on the battlefield were brutally executed - reportedly up to 3,000 men. The richest were captured and saved only by ransoms, which they repaid over decades. When news of the defeat reached Paris, no one believed it, and those who initially spread it were sentenced to death by drowning for "spreading lies."</paragraph><paragraph>The Ottoman victory was a triumph of Islam over Christianity. Turkish troops posed a real threat to European countries, especially to Hungary.</paragraph>

<paragraph>As the name suggests, the village probably owes its foundation to the abbots (opati) of the nearby Sedletz Monastery, who from the 13th century tried to colonize the local inhospitable and largely uninhabited region. The first written mention of the village dates back to the second half of the 14th century, when it belonged to the Kuttenberg burgher Jan Glenc.</paragraph><paragraph>The farmstead of Opatowitz was founded sometime during the 14th century by the monastery, which subsequently supported it before it was sold to another wealthy Kuttenberg burgher, Wenceslas Bartosch (Václav Bartoš), in 1379.</paragraph>

<paragraph>As the name suggests, the village probably owes its foundation to the abbots (opati) of the nearby Sedletz Monastery, who from the 13th century tried to colonise this inhospitable and sparsely populated region. The first written mention of the village dates back to the latter half of the 14th century, when it belonged to the Kuttenberg burgher Jan Glenc.</paragraph><paragraph>The farmstead of Opatowitz was founded sometime during the 14th century by the monastery, which subsequently supported it until it was sold to another wealthy Kuttenberg burgher, Wenceslas Bartosch (Václav Bartoš), in 1379.</paragraph>

<years>1399 - 1452</years><paragraph> Otto IV called Young Bergow of Trosky, was a member of the League of the Lords, the son of Otto III. He fought against the Hussites and ransacked the Opatowitz Monastery.</paragraph><paragraph> As well as daughters he had only one son, John II, with whose death in 1455, the family died out by the sword.</paragraph>

<years>1399 - 1452</years><paragraph> Otto IV, called Young Bergow of Trosky, was a member of the League of Lords and the son of Otto III. He fought against the Hussites and ransacked the Opatowitz Monastery.</paragraph><paragraph> As well as daughters he had only one son, John II, with whose death in 1455, the family died out by the sword.</paragraph>

<paragraph>At the turn of the 14th century, when the Czech currency was losing value due to the substitution of silver with cheaper metals, counterfeiting of money got better, despite the stringent prosecution and death penalty it entailed.</paragraph><paragraph>One example of such counterfeiting consisted of coins that were silver plated over a lead core. This could be tested by biting the coin (since lead is softer than silver).</paragraph><paragraph><accent>The counterfeiters' workshops</accent> were often hidden away in karst and sandstone caves, and featured a compact laboratory, as the silver-plating of the base metal was a chemical process requiring special equipment.</paragraph>

<paragraph>At the turn of the 14th century, when the quality of Czech currency deteriorated due to the replacement of silver with cheaper metals, counterfeiting also improved. This happened despite strict prosecutions and the death penalties that were imposed for such offenses.</paragraph><paragraph>One example of such counterfeiting included lead coins plated with silver. The authenticity could be detected by biting the coin (lead is soft, while silver is not).</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Counterfeiters' workshops</accent> were often hidden in karst and sandstone caves and equipped with small laboratories, as silvering the metal was a chemical process requiring special tools.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Until the late Middle Ages, a painter's work consisted primarily in the skilled craftsmanship and faithful execution of a commissioned work, not in the artist's personal expression. Although he could decide on the technique of the work, he had little influence on the subject, the colours or the size of the commissioned painting.</paragraph><paragraph>Apart from commissions for large-scale murals in sacred or representative spaces, most painters devoted themselves mainly to decorating wooden furniture, ceilings and even weapons. The most renowned painters were then allowed to show their skills by painting on altars. Classical paintings on canvas, as we know them today, were rare until the end of the 14th century and served more as a display of wealth than for decorative purposes.</paragraph><paragraph>The paintings were often created in <accent>painters' workshops</accent> under the supervision of the master and involved the work of several painters, who specialized in different parts of the paintings - figures, ornaments, animals, backgrounds, etc. Painting was seen more as a collaborative craftsmanship than as an individual artistic endeavor.</paragraph><paragraph>For this reason, the names of specific artists have largely not survived in early paintings. Although the first <accent>signatures</accent> appear in Italy as early as the 12th century, they did not become common in central Europe until the turn of the 14th and 15th centuries. Therefore, to distinguish the supreme artists of Czech Middle Age paintings, auxiliary names referring to the places where their works were preserved are used, such as Master of the Vyšebrod Altar, Master of the Třeboň Altar or Master of the Litoměřice Altar.</paragraph><paragraph>The names of the many monk-artists who created the carefully crafted and exuberant illuminations in contemporary books and manuscripts, will unfortunately never be traced again.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The work of painters until the late Middle Ages primarily involved skillfully executing commissioned works, rather than expressing the artist's personal vision. While they could decide on the technique of creation, they had little influence over the subject, colours, or size of the commissioned artwork.</paragraph><paragraph>Apart from commissions for large-scale murals in sacred or ceremonial spaces, most painters devoted themselves mainly to decorating wooden furniture, ceilings and even weapons. The most esteemed painters could showcase their skills in altar paintings. Classical canvas paintings, as we know them today, were rare until the end of the 14th century and served more as a display of wealth than for decorative purposes.</paragraph><paragraph>Paintings were often created in <accent>painters' workshops</accent> under the supervision of a master and involved the work of several painters, who specialized in different parts of the paintings - figures, ornaments, animals, backgrounds, etc. Painting was seen more as a collaborative craft than an individual artistic endeavor.</paragraph><paragraph>As a result, the names of specific artists from early paintings are largely unknown. Although the first <accent>signatures</accent> appear in Italy as early as the 12th century, they did not become common in central Europe until the turn of the 14th and 15th centuries. Therefore, to distinguish the prominent artists of Czech medieval paintings, auxiliary names referring to the places where their works were preserved are used, such as Master of the Vyšebrod Altar, Master of the Třeboň Altar or Master of the Litoměřice Altar.</paragraph><paragraph>The names of the many monk-artists who created the carefully crafted and exuberant illuminations in contemporary books and manuscripts, will unfortunately never be known again.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, smuggling referred to taking any goods in or out of the city without paying export or import duties.</paragraph><paragraph>Smugglers had to know alternate routes and how to avoid the tax collectors. When smuggling through the gates they made use of false bottomed vehicles or baskets, or even resorted to scrabbling over the walls by night.</paragraph><paragraph>Articles smuggled included textiles, spices, wine and other less freely available goods subject to high taxation.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, smuggling was regarded as taking any goods in or out of a town without paying export or import duties.</paragraph><paragraph>Smugglers had to know alternate routes and how to avoid the tax collectors. When smuggling through the gates, they made use of false-bottomed vehicles or baskets, or even resorted to climbing over the walls by night.</paragraph><paragraph>Contraband included fabrics, spices, wine and other scarce goods subject to high taxation.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The medieval nobleman spent his leisure time hunting, playing games, singing or playing a musical instrument. Special entertainments consisted of tournaments, dances and plays. Books were rarely read, because they were rare and expensive and most of the nobility was illiterate.</paragraph><paragraph> In the countryside, there were also many opportunities for amusement. Work was strictly forbidden on Church holidays and on Sundays, and there were many more feast days than there are today. In the case of certain professions, the working week could also be interrupted due to weather or unpredictable events. Usually people worked about 190 days a year, which comes out to an average of 4-5 days a week, but the work was not evenly distributed during the year. For example, there was much more work around harvest season than in winter.</paragraph><paragraph> The most popular medieval <accent>board games</accent> were chess, draughts (checkers), backgammon, Mill (also called Nine Men's Morris), Hnefatafl, Fox and Geese and dice. <accent>Ball games</accent> were also played. Chess was costly and time consuming to play and was therefore restricted mainly to noble circles. Burghers favoured draughts and common folk were fond of the simpler games of dice and Mill. Cards and card games already existed in Europe at the end of the 14th century, but only spread more widely later with the spread of printing.</paragraph><paragraph>The bourgeois, emulating the nobility in their leisure time, took to <accent>bird shooting</accent>, for example. During the 15th century archery fellowships began to form in the townships.</paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Gambling</accent> was also widespread throughout the Middle Ages, regardless of gender or status, which is evidenced, for example, by the <italic>Maiestas Carolina Act</italic> of December 1357, in which Emperor Charles IV himself forbade gambling at Christmas time and commissioned Prague Archbishop Arnošt of Pardubice to penalise offenders of any social class with fines as well as spiritual penance (in extreme cases, even excommunication).</paragraph>

<paragraph>A medieval nobleman spent his leisure time hunting, playing games, singing, or playing musical instruments. Special diversions included tournaments, dances, or theatre. Books were read very rarely because they were rare, expensive, and most nobles were illiterate.</paragraph><paragraph>In the countryside, there were also plenty of opportunities for entertainment, especially because work was strictly forbidden during church holidays and Sundays, which were much more frequent than today. Certain professions could have their work days disrupted by weather or unforeseen events. Typically, people worked around 190 days a year, averaging about 4-5 days a week, but work was not evenly distributed throughout the year. For example, there was much more work around harvest time than in winter.</paragraph><paragraph>Among the most popular medieval <accent>board games</accent> were chess, backgammon, mill (also called nine men's morris), draughts, hnefatafl, dice, and fox and geese. Of course, <accent>ball games</accent> were also common. Chess was time-consuming and costly, so it was more popular among the nobility. Backgammon was favoured by townspeople, while the common folk enjoyed simpler games like dice or nine men's morris. Playing cards and card games appeared in Europe by the late 14th century, but due to limited paper production, they became widespread much later.</paragraph><paragraph>Townsmen sought to emulate the nobility in their leisure activities, engaging, for example, in <accent>bird shooting</accent>. During the 15th century, archery fellowships even began to form in cities.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Gambling games</accent> were widespread across medieval society regardless of gender or social status. This is evidenced, for example, by the <italic>Maiestas Carolina</italic> legal code from December 1350, where Charles IV himself forbade playing games during Christmas time, and empowered the Archbishop of Prague, Arnošt of Pardubice, to prosecute offenders of any status with fines or spiritual penalties (in extreme cases, excommunication).</paragraph>

<paragraph>Hunting was always a source of meat and furs, mainly for the lesser nobility. For the aristocracy, courtly hunting was more for enjoyment, being much cheaper entertainment than tournaments, while providing similar thrills. It became a favourite pastime and chasing game with dogs became almost a ritual.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Hunting weapons</accent> were similar to those used in battle: bows, crossbows, spears, daggers. <accent>Dogs</accent> were used to track and chase down game until the exhausted animal stood its ground in last defence. Then came the moment for the hunters (up till then only following the sound of the baying hounds), to down the animal with an arrow or spear. Finishing off on the ground was done with a sword or dagger. </paragraph><paragraph> <accent>Falconry - hunting with a falcon</accent> (originating in the Orient) and other specifically trained raptors (goshawks and sparrowhawks) was more of a fashion, a pursuit for both men and women.</paragraph><paragraph>The poorer classes were not allowed to hunt in the forests, subject to strict penalties (with the exception of hare-hunting).</paragraph>

<paragraph>Hunting always provided sustenance and furs, mainly for the lower nobility. For the aristocracy, refined court hunting became more of a pastime, as hunting was significantly cheaper than tournaments, while providing similar excitement. It became a favorite diversion, with hunts for wild animals using dogs being almost ritualistic.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Hunting weapons</accent> were the same as those used in warfare: bows, crossbows, javelins, and hunting knives. <accent>Dogs</accent> were used to track and scare the game and then chase it until the exhausted animal stood its ground. Only then did the hunters (following on horseback to the sound of the dogs’ barking) arrive to kill it with arrows or spears. The final kill on the ground was done with a sword or hunting knife.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Falconry</accent> (originally a pastime from the Orient), and hunting with other specially trained birds of prey (hawks and goshawks) was more of a fashionable activity and could be pursued by women as well.</paragraph><paragraph>For the lower classes, hunting in the lord’s forests was strictly prohibited under severe penalties (with the exception of hunting hares).</paragraph>

<paragraph>Religious pilgrimages were an important part of the Christian world. There were many reasons to go on pilgrimage. To seek forgiveness of sins, to save the soul of the pilgrim or his or her loved ones from a stay in purgatory, to ask for healing or other heavenly help, to express thanksgiving, or to express deep piety and seek to deepen it.</paragraph><paragraph>The purpose of pilgrimages was to visit places associated with Christ's residence and ministry or places of rest of the saints.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>The most important places</accent> were the city of Jerusalem and the site of the Holy Sepulchre. In Europe, Rome, the seat of the popes associated with the ministry of St. Peter, and Santiago de Compostella, with the relics of St. James, were among the most visited places. In the Czech lands, the most important place of pilgrimage was Prague, where the relics of several saints were laid to rest over time, most notably the country's patron saint, St. Wenceslas, who rested in St. Vitus Cathedral.</paragraph><paragraph>To undertake a pilgrimage was to undertake an arduous and often dangerous journey, whether over land or partly by sea, and was one of the great feats of individual achievement. To provide shelter and assistance to a pilgrim was considered a matter of good manners. But of course, the development of pilgrimage was also linked to economic and commercial factors, especially around pilgrimage sites and travel inns.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>The pilgrim</accent> could often be identified by his <accent>specific clothing</accent>, which is also seen in many depictions. This was most often a sack, cloak, pilgrim's staff, pilgrim badges, and a frequent motif, or even symbol, was the St. James scallop. It was a popular item and it was believed that such a shell brought back from a pilgrimage was blessed and therefore had supernatural powers. This shell was therefore sometimes placed, for example, at the bottom of a well to ensure the purity of the water.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Religious pilgrimages were an important part of the Christian world. There were many reasons to embark on a pilgrimage: seeking forgiveness for sins, shortening the stay in purgatory for the pilgrim's soul or that of their loved ones, asking for healing or other divine help, expressing gratitude, or deepening one's piety and devotion.</paragraph><paragraph>The destinations of pilgrimages were places associated with Christ's presence and activities or the places of action or rest of saints.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>The most significant place</accent> was the city of Jerusalem and the site of the Holy Sepulchre. In Europe, the most visited places included Rome, the seat of the popes and associated with the activities of St. Peter, and the city of Santiago de Compostela with the relics of St. James. In the Czech lands, the most important pilgrimage site was Prague, where the relics of several saints rested over time, the most significant being the national patron St. Wenceslas, who was interred in St. Vitus Cathedral.</paragraph><paragraph>Undertaking a pilgrimage meant enduring a challenging and often dangerous journey, whether by land or partially by sea, and it was considered a significant achievement for the individual. Providing shelter and help to a pilgrim was regarded as a matter of good manners. The development of pilgrimage also had a commercial aspect, especially around pilgrimage sites and travel inns.</paragraph><paragraph>A <accent>pilgrim</accent> could often be recognized by their <accent>specific attire</accent>, which is frequently depicted in various images. This typically included a satchel, cloak, pilgrim's staff, pilgrim badges, and the scallop shell of St. James was a common motif or symbol. The scallop shell was a popular item, believed to be blessed and thus endowed with supernatural abilities. Such a shell was sometimes placed at the bottom of a well to ensure the purity of the water.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The medieval <accent>platner</accent> fashioned armour from metal plates or sheets – the cuirass breastplate, various pieces for the legs and arms, helmets and gauntlets. Specialists in chainmail armour were called <accent>byrniers</accent>, and an ironclad would need both types of armour. The chainmail went underneath, the plate armour on top.</paragraph><paragraph>A common soldier would have only partial armour (the breastplate, helmet and gauntlets), a complete suit of armour was beyond his means. Ornate or tailor-made armour was the prerogative of the rich nobility.</paragraph><paragraph>Platners were assisted by <accent>polishers</accent>, who polished or buffed up the armour.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The medieval <accent>armourer</accent> made armour from metal plates or sheets – cuirasses, leg and arm protection, helmets, and gauntlets. A specialist in chainmail was called a <accent>maille smith</accent>, and in practice, equipping a heavily armoured soldier required both. Chainmail was worn underneath, with plating on top.</paragraph><paragraph>An ordinary soldier used only parts of the armour (cuirass, helmet, and gauntlets), as few could afford full armour. Decorated or custom-made armour was the privilege of the wealthy nobility.</paragraph><paragraph>Armourers were assisted by <accent>polishers</accent>, who polished and buffed the armour.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The pagan ways survived in Bohemia even after the adoption of Christianity, mainly in the form of the folk traditions and customs. These contained elements from the culture of the Celts, Germans and Slavs, and respective influences intermingled, becoming more and more adapted to Christianity as time went on. </paragraph><paragraph> Some customs have kept their original form, e.g. folk superstition and rhymes. Others gave way to Church pressure completely.</paragraph><paragraph>Paganism in the Slavic countries has survived in motifs adorning jewellery and objects, in folk medicine or in the form of holidays – the winter and summer Solstice, the Mardi Gras, Easter, Walpurgis night, Midsummer night, All-souls', Advent, and Christmas; all follow the original pagan celebrations, but have been renamed under Christianity and modified in content.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Pagan traditions persisted in the Czech lands even after the adoption of Christianity, mainly in the form of folk customs and traditions. They included elements from Celtic, Germanic, and Slavic cultures, and the various influences mixed and increasingly adapted to Christianity over time.</paragraph><paragraph>Some customs remained in their original form, such as folk superstitions and poems. Others disappeared completely under the pressure of the Christian church.</paragraph><paragraph>Paganism in Slavic lands survived in the motifs of jewelry and object decoration, in folk healing, or in the form of festivals – the winter and summer solstices, carnival, Easter, Walpurgis Night, Midsummer, All Souls' Day, Advent, and Christmas all mirror original pagan celebrations, but were renamed and their meanings adapted to Christianity.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The evidence for burial is as old as mankind itself, but Christianity changes all burial practices quite radically, and links death inextricably with the need for religious ritual and blessing. Before death, it was necessary to rid oneself of sins and to receive the last rites; in cases where death was neither certain nor excluded (going into battle), rituals were performed preventively.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>place of final rest</accent> was also important. It was considered best to be buried inside the church (walls, floor) or near it, where cemeteries were created. These cemeteries were an integral part of towns and villages and were often located in their centre. It was common for people to meet, trade and make contracts there.</paragraph><paragraph>The cemetery as we know it today did not exist - the dead and the living lived side by side. Only suicides, criminals, the sick, infidels, executioners, unknown strangers and unbaptized children were buried outside the cemetery, in unhallowed ground.</paragraph><paragraph>During plague epidemics and wars, burials in cemeteries were temporarily abandoned and mass graves were used. In later centuries, for reasons of hygiene and water contamination, most of the old cemeteries were abandoned, and sometimes the bodies were exhumed, and burial moved outside the city.</paragraph><paragraph>It was common for people to make at least an oral <accent>Will</accent> before dying. In the case of some property, at least part of it had to go to the church for "mediating" the passage to the afterlife.</paragraph><paragraph>Burials were in plain wooden coffins or sacks, and the dead were dressed in shrouds. Costly and elaborate ceremonies were conducted at the funerals of rich people and rulers. Royal funerals were attended by thousands of people. Wealthy families had stone tombstones made at their final resting places, the custom of building separate mausoleums came later.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Evidence of burials is as old as mankind itself, but Christianity radically influenced all burial practices, and inextricably linked death with the need for church ritual and blessing. Before death, it was necessary to rid oneself of sins and to receive the last rites; in uncertain cases (such as going into battle), rituals were performed preventively.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>place of final rest</accent> was also important. It was considered best to be buried inside the church (walls, floor) or nearby, where cemeteries emerged. These cemeteries were an integral part of towns and villages and were often located in their centre. It was common for people to meet, trade and make contracts there.</paragraph><paragraph>The piety of cemeteries as we know it today did not exist - the dead and the living lived side by side. Only suicides, criminals, the sick, heretics, executioners, unknown strangers and unbaptized children were buried outside the cemetery, in unconsecrated ground.</paragraph><paragraph>During plague epidemics and wars, burials in cemeteries were temporarily abandoned and mass graves were used. In later centuries, for hygiene reasons and to avoid water contamination, most of the old cemeteries were abandoned, sometimes bodies were exhumed, and burial moved outside the city.</paragraph><paragraph>It was common for people to make at least an oral <accent>Will</accent> before dying. In the case of some property, at least part of it had to go to the Church for "mediating" the passage to the afterlife.</paragraph><paragraph>Burials were in plain wooden coffins or sacks, and the dead were dressed in shrouds. Costly and elaborate ceremonies were conducted at funerals of rich people and rulers. Royal funerals were attended by thousands of people. Wealthy families had stone tombstones made at their final resting places, the custom of building separate mausoleums came later.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the territory of Poland at the turn of the 14th and 15th centuries, similarly to the Czech lands, wars for control, territory and faith were fought. The country's prosperity and its cultural and economic growth were hampered in particular by the unabated attacks of the Teutonic Knights from the so-called Teutonic Knights' dominions on the northern Polish territories, defended by the need to Christianise and suppress the still dominant paganism in the Baltic.</paragraph><paragraph>Unfortunately, Poland was not united for long, as after the death of Casimir III. The Piast dynasty, for many years the unifying and ruling dynasty, ceases to exist by the sword. Casimir's cousin, King Ludwig I of Hungary of Anjou, is given the crown, but he has difficulty winning the obedience of the Polish nobility, and his rule and his ability to unite a larger coalition against the Crusader invasion are thus very limited.</paragraph><paragraph>The best solution was ultimately the marriage of Ludwig's daughter Hedwig to Jagell, Grand Duke of Lithuania. He took the name Vladislav, was accepted as King of Poland, and was baptized along with the rest of Lithuania. Thus the Polish-Lithuanian coalition was formed, which took the wind out of the sails of the Teutonic Knights.</paragraph><paragraph>However, the Crusaders would not surrender so easily, and so the war continued for many more years. The turning point in this conflict was the Battle of Grunwald in 1410, in which the Crusader armies were defeated head on by the Polish-Lithuanian army. Many Czech fighters fought on the side of the Poles at that time: among others Jan Žižka or Jan Sokol of Lamberk.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In Poland at the turn of the 14th and 15th centuries, similar to the Czech lands, wars over governance, territory, and faith were occurring. The country's prosperity and its cultural and economic growth were particularly hampered by the relentless attacks of the Teutonic Knights from the so-called Crusader states on northern Polish territories, justified by the need for Christianization and the suppression of the still dominant paganism in the Baltic region.</paragraph><paragraph>Unfortunately, Poland was not unified for long, because after the death of Casimir III the Great, the Piast dynasty, which had long unified and ruled the country, ended in the male line. The crown was taken by Casimir's cousin, Ludwig I of Anjou, the King of Hungary, but he struggled to gain the obedience of the Polish nobility, and his rule and ability to unite a larger coalition against the Crusader invasion were thus very limited.</paragraph><paragraph>The most suitable solution eventually was the marriage of Ludwig's daughter Hedwig to Jagell, the Grand Duke of Lithuania. He took the name Vladislav, was accepted as the King of Poland, and, along with the rest of Lithuania, was baptized. This created the Polish-Lithuanian coalition, which significantly weakened the Teutonic Order.</paragraph><paragraph>However, the Crusaders did not want to give up so easily, and the war continued for many more years. A turning point in this conflict was the Battle of Grunwald in 1410, in which the Teutonic forces were decisively defeated by the Polish-Lithuanian army. Many Czech fighters fought on the side of the Poles at that time, including Jan Zizka and Jan Sokol of Lamberg.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In our time, unfortunately, obstetrics and child care was a very underdeveloped field. Educated doctors did not want to take it up and education was not accessible to women, so as a result, obstetrics became more of a specialty for spinsters and midwives.</paragraph><paragraph>Childbirth was done sitting up or on a special chair. The so-called <italic>caesarean section</italic> was only used in extreme cases, when the life of the mother could not be saved anyway, or the life of the child was more precious.</paragraph><paragraph>Given the poor sanitary conditions or inadequate diet and the inability to breastfeed, infant mortality rates in the population were as high as 80%. Childbirth was often dangerous for the mother herself due to the inability to deal with most complications. A well-built and healthy woman spent most of her reproductive years either pregnant or breastfeeding. Eight or even twelve children (few of whom lived to adulthood) were no exception.</paragraph><paragraph>It was not until the Renaissance, when the process of the birth of a new life finally came into the view of medicine, that the approach to childbirth and obstetrics changed in part.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In our time, unfortunately, obstetrics and child care was a very underdeveloped field. Educated doctors did not want to take it up and education was not accessible to women, so as a result, obstetrics became more of a specialty for spinsters and midwives.</paragraph><paragraph>Childbirth was done sitting up or on a special chair. The so-called <italic>caesarean section</italic> was only used in extreme cases, when the life of the mother could not be saved anyway, or the life of the child was more precious.</paragraph><paragraph>Given the poor sanitary conditions or inadequate diet and the inability to breastfeed, infant mortality rates in the population were as high as 80%. Childbirth was often dangerous for the mother herself due to the inability to deal with most complications. A well-built and healthy woman spent most of her reproductive years either pregnant or breastfeeding. Eight or even twelve children (few of whom lived to adulthood) were no exception.</paragraph><paragraph>It was not until the Renaissance, when the process of the birth of a new life finally came into the view of medicine, that the approach to childbirth and obstetrics changed in part.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In medieval patriarchal society, the man was the representative of the family, the role of the woman was determined by her relationship to him - daughter, sister, wife, mother or widow. Girls had a short childhood, according to municipal documents reaching the age of majority between 12 and 15 years of age, while boys at age of 15.</paragraph><paragraph>Women were mainly expected to take care of the household and family, while men spent most of their time in crafts or trade. Only a widow could obtain permission to conduct a shop or carry out a trade with the help of journeymen.</paragraph><paragraph>The domestic activities of the wealthier women included mainly embroidery, cleaning, childcare, shopping and playing musical instruments. In the village, women worked in the fields or in the pasture, engaged in bee-keeping, weaving, spinning, food preparation, knitting or sewing. Women were also involved in some occupations, such as midwives, maids, innkeepers, bath-maids, or usurers.</paragraph><paragraph>Women did not leave their homes unnecessarily. Some rules about venturing out were dictated by social class. While townswomen and noblewomen could venture beyond the home only when accompanied by their spouse or servants, the wives of artisans, merchants and peasants could walk about unaccompanied.</paragraph><paragraph>The beauty ideal of the High Middle Ages was a thin, pale woman with long blonde hair, rounded small breasts, not very wide hips and a narrow waist, with an emphasis on health and fertility. Pregnancy was very common from the beginning of women's sexual maturity. Childbirth was complicated and follow-up care inadequate, so the risk of death in childbirth was also high. Abortions were also common.</paragraph><paragraph>Unmarried daughters and/or unwed mothers brought shame to the family and were even marginalized. Girls did not inherit a trade; parents had to accumulate a dowry, and pay it to the groom.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the medieval patriarchal society, the male was the head of the family, and a woman's role was defined by her relationship to him—daughter, sister, wife, mother, or widow. Girls had a short childhood, reaching adulthood between the ages of 12 and 15 according to municipal documents, while boys reached adulthood at 15 years old.</paragraph><paragraph>Women were primarily expected to take care of the household, home, and family, while men spent most of their time engaged in crafts or trade. Only a widow could obtain permission to run a business or practice a craft with the help of journeymen.</paragraph><paragraph>For wealthier women, domestic activities included mainly embroidery, cleaning, child care, shopping, or teaching musical instruments. In the countryside, women worked in the fields or pastures, engaged in beekeeping, weaving, spinning, food preparation, knitting, or sewing. Women were also employed in some professions, such as midwives, servants, innkeepers, bathhouse attendants, or moneylenders.</paragraph><paragraph>Women rarely left their homes unnecessarily. The rules for outings were defined by the relevant social class. While townswomen and noblewomen could move outside the home only accompanied by their husbands or servants, the wives of craftsmen, traders, and farmers could go out alone.</paragraph><paragraph>The ideal of beauty in the high Middle Ages was a thin, pale woman with long blonde hair, small round breasts, not too wide hips, and a narrow waist, with an emphasis on health and fertility. Pregnancy was very common from the onset of sexual maturity in women. Births were complicated and subsequent care inadequate, making the risk of death during childbirth high. Miscarriages were also frequent.</paragraph><paragraph>Unmarried daughters or single mothers brought disgrace to their families and were even marginalized in society. Girls did not inherit trades; parents had to accumulate a dowry and pay it to the groom.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The basic form of greeting was <accent>bowing</accent>, with numerous variations depending on the occasion and the mutual status of the participants. A light bow with the hand on the heart would befit two noblemen of equal rank. A deeper bow was a more respectful greeting (to a guest or someone of higher standing).</paragraph><paragraph>The next level was to <accent>kneel</accent> on the left knee and bow the head in deference to rulers, barons or high ranking commanders and it expressed allegiance. The person would have to remain in this position until invited by the superior to rise. The most subordinate level was to bow while down on both knees – an expression of complete subjugation, often combined with a plea (typically for mercy).</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Doffing</accent> headwear was a practice that came in with ‘Burgundian fashion' in the 15th century. Loyalty was expressed by kissing the rings of magnates and prelates. It was not proper to kiss the hands of ladies, but they were given a deeper bow than their social rank alone would elicit.</paragraph><paragraph>Particular forms of <accent>salutation</accent> also applied when addressing a certain person (e.g. in writing): for example, a townsman was to be addressed as ‘Honest', a Baronet as ‘Esteemed' and a titular Lord as ‘Highborn'. </paragraph><paragraph>In the countryside, people greeted each other according to their nature, often mentioning in the greeting wishes of good health, prosperity and God's blessing, or making reference to Christian tradition (<italic>God bless</italic>, <italic>Christ be praised</italic> etc.)</paragraph>

<paragraph>The basic form of greeting was a <accent>bow</accent> and varied according to the occasion and the importance of the person being greeted. A slight bow with a hand gesture to the heart was used by nobles of equal rank. A deeper bow was considered a more respectful greeting (guest, respect to a higher-ranking individual).</paragraph><paragraph>The next level was <accent>kneeling</accent> on the left knee and lowering the head. This greeting was used towards rulers, barons, or high-ranking commanders and expressed subservience. Rising was only allowed upon the invitation of the person being greeted. The final level was bowing on both knees, a gesture of complete subjugation, often associated with a plea (especially for mercy).</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Doffing</accent> headwear began to be practiced under the influence of "Burgundian fashion" in the 15th century. Loyalty was expressed by kissing the rings of magnates and prelates. Women's hands were not kissed, but they were given a deeper bow than would be appropriate given their status.</paragraph><paragraph>Precise conventions also applied to <accent>addressing</accent> or mentioning a particular person (e.g., in text): for example, a townsman should be referred to as "honest," a squire as "worthy," and a banner lord as "noble." </paragraph><paragraph>In the countryside, people greeted each other according to their nature, often mentioning in the greeting wishes of good health, prosperity and God's blessing, or making reference to Christian tradition (<italic>God bless</italic>, <italic>Christ be praised</italic> etc.)</paragraph>

<paragraph>Execution places were situated on hilltops, at crossroads and out of town, as they were considered unclean.</paragraph><paragraph>These were deserted places that everyone avoided; no craftsman would work nearby for fear of losing his reputation. The only one to be seen thereabouts was the executioner, who often lived near the site.</paragraph><paragraph>Common folk would approach the gallows or execution place for the sole purpose of witnessing an execution. Executions became popular folk entertainment, often with the whole town gathering to watch. However, only some towns were allowed to exercise the <accent>right of the throat</accent>, and by no means all of them had their own executioner.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Execution sites were located on hills, crossroads, and outside the city, as they were considered unclean places.</paragraph><paragraph>These were desolate locations that everyone avoided; no craftsman wanted to work there for fear of losing their honour. The only person who frequently moved nearby was the executioner, who often lived close to the execution site.</paragraph><paragraph>Ordinary people visited the execution site only for one purpose: when an execution was taking place. Executions were a popular public spectacle, often attracting the entire town. <accent>Capital punishment</accent> could only be carried out by certain towns, and not all of them had an executioner.</paragraph>

<paragraph><accent>Capital</accent> of the Kingdom of Bohemia. For many centuries it was rather a close neighbourhood of several different towns on both banks of the Vltava River.</paragraph><paragraph>Its greatest prosperity was brought about by Charles IV, who united these towns into a single unit and made it the residence of his imperial court. He began building strong fortifications, contributed to significant changes in the city's architecture, started the construction of the first Czech cathedral and founded the first European university north of the Alps, Charles University, thus elevating the city to a European metropolis.</paragraph><paragraph>At the turn of the 14th and 15th centuries, according to surviving records, there were 4,000 houses in Prague and the number of permanent inhabitants ranged from 40-50,000. To this must be added the students and the royal court. Although Prague could still not compare to the size of Florence or Paris, it was still the largest city in Central Europe.</paragraph><paragraph>With its convenient location at the crossroads of trade routes, Prague was an important trading location and, thanks to the University, a cosmopolitan centre with a large foreign population.</paragraph>

<paragraph><accent>Capital</accent> of the Kingdom of Bohemia. For many centuries it was rather a close neighbourhood of several different towns on both banks of the Vltava River.</paragraph><paragraph>Its greatest prosperity was brought about by Charles IV, who united these towns into a single unit and made it the residence of his imperial court. He began building strong fortifications, contributed to significant changes in the city's architecture, started the construction of the first Czech cathedral and founded the first European university north of the Alps, Charles University, thus elevating the city to a European metropolis.</paragraph><paragraph>At the turn of the 14th and 15th centuries, according to surviving records, there were 4,000 houses in Prague with a permanent population ranging from 40-50,000. Additionally there were students and the royal court. Although Prague could not compare to the size of Florence or Paris, it was still the largest city in Central Europe.</paragraph><paragraph>With its convenient location at the crossroads of trade routes, Prague was an important trading location and, thanks to the University, a cosmopolitan centre with a large foreign population.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The pillory was located in the middle of the square and minor punishments for offences such as perjury, slander or fraud were carried out there.</paragraph><paragraph>It was a wooden or stone pillar to which convicts were chained for a certain period of time (hours or even days). Punishment was then carried out on them by the whole society - spitting, insults, ridicule and now and then a blow were the order of the day.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The pillory was located in the middle of the square and was used to administer minor punishments for offenses such as perjury, slander, or fraud.</paragraph><paragraph>It was most often a wooden or stone column to which the condemned were chained for a certain period (hours or even days). The punishment was then carried out by the entire community – spitting, insults, mockery, and the occasional blow were common.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the heat of battle in the Middle Ages, where most of the combatants had the same or similar equipment, the pennant or banner was often the only sign differentiating friend from foe. Pennants also helped lift morale and to organize the various units during troop movements.</paragraph><paragraph>At the turn of the 14th and 15th centuries, pennants and banners were the shape of extended triangles, upright rectangles or squares. Flags were fashioned from coloured canvas or silk and the depictions or emblems were painted onto them, most often the coats of arms of the respective feudal lords.</paragraph><paragraph>Cavalry carried small pennants on their spears and craftsmen who were members of the guilds also had their own banners. The <accent>guild banner</accent> was emblematic of the profession and was shown at public ceremonies and at army and other ostentatious events.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>banner of the Bohemian lands</accent> dates back to the 13th century and depicts ‘gules, a lion rampant queue forchée argent' i.e. a two-tailed silver lion raised on its hind legs, on a red background.</paragraph><paragraph>If the banner is topped with a triangular point, we speak of a <italic>standard<italic>.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the heat of battle in the Middle Ages, where most of the combatants had the same or similar equipment, the standard, banner or pennant was often the only way to differentiate friend from foe. Standards also helped lift morale and organize the various units during troop movements.</paragraph><paragraph>At the turn of the 14th and 15th centuries, standards and banners were the shape of extended triangles, upright rectangles or squares. Flags were fashioned from coloured canvas or silk and the depictions or emblems were painted onto them, most often the coats of arms of the respective feudal lords.</paragraph><paragraph>Cavalry carried small standards on their spears and craftsmen who were members of the guilds also had their own banners. The <accent>guild banner</accent> was emblematic of the profession and was shown at public ceremonies and at army and other ostentatious events.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>banner of the Bohemian lands</accent> dates back to the 13th century and depicts ‘gules, a lion rampant queue forchée argent' i.e. a two-tailed silver lion raised on its hind legs, on a red background.</paragraph><paragraph>If the banner is topped with a triangular point, it is reffered to as a <italic>pennant<italic>.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The priests were among the elite in medieval society, and among the few who had any education.</paragraph><paragraph>Village priests were less educated than those of the larger parishes. They could barely read or write, had no library, and learned the liturgy by heart. They were none too well-off, typically working in the fields or raising livestock, like lay farmers. They were not celibate, enjoyed folk entertainment and games, dancing and going to the tavern.</paragraph><paragraph>As time went on, looser morals and educational decline spread to the towns and monasteries. By contrast, the priests in the larger parishes and towns owned more property, and with the exception of service to God, did not have to resort to any manual work. </paragraph><paragraph><accent>The duties of the priest</accent> encompassed preparation and serving of mass, hearing confessions, taking care of the church (its operation and decoration), visiting the poor and the sick, arranging charity collections, collecting dues, conducting baptisms, weddings, last rites and funerals.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Priests in medieval society were part of the elite and among the few who had some education.</paragraph><paragraph>Village priests were not as educated as those from larger parishes. They were not good at reading or writing and did not maintain a library; instead, they memorised liturgical texts. They were also not very wealthy, often working in the fields or raising livestock like other peasants. They did not observe celibacy, engaged in folk entertainment and games, danced, and frequented taverns.</paragraph><paragraph>Lax morals and declining education later appeared in towns and monasteries. In contrast, priests in large parishes and towns possessed more wealth and did not need to do manual labour except for serving God.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>duties of a priest</accent> included preparing and conducting mass, hearing confessions, taking care of the church (its operation and decoration), visiting the poor and sick, organising collections for charity, collecting taxes, baptisms, weddings, last rites, and funerals.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Towns and cities always had to look after their budgets, so they collected taxes, customs duties, tolls and 'ungelt' goods tariffs. The most common form of tax was paid twice a year, in an amount dependent on the assets of each respective citizen. Fees and taxes were paid by the city residents based on their business, levied on products sold or services provided.</paragraph><paragraph>Another source of civic revenue money were monies made by the City Council or the City Court for the making of contracts, documents, records, and other ongoing activities. The treasury also collected money for interest payments, fines, building funds, loans and various forms of letting and rentals to serfs. Written records were maintained of all revenues.</paragraph><paragraph>The City Council paid out some of the money for the purchase of real estate, paid the nobility for defence and security, invested in schools, civic cultural development, churches, administration and the salaries of city officials, construction, operation and maintenance and the upkeep of municipal buildings.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Towns and cities always had to look after their budgets, so they collected taxes, customs duties, tolls and 'ungelt' goods tariffs. The most common form of tax was paid twice a year, in an amount dependent on the assets of each respective citizen. Fees and taxes were levied on the economic activities, sales of goods, or services provided by the city's inhabitants.</paragraph><paragraph>Another source of civic revenue was money made by the City Council or the City Court for the making of contracts, documents, records, and other routine activities. The treasury also collected money from interest payments, fines, building funds, loans and various rents and feudal dues.
