Written records were maintained of all revenues.</paragraph><paragraph>The City Council allocated funds for the purchase of real estate, paid the nobility for defence and security, invested in schools, civic cultural development, churches, administration, salaries of city officials, construction, operation and maintenance of municipal buildings.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The first written mention of the village Pschitoky dates back to 1141, according to which it was in possession of the Olomouc archbishopric. In 1249, Pschitoky was briefly held by Havel of Löwenberk, and a year later the Olomouc bishop Bruno of Schauenberk ceded the village to the Sedletz Monastery.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 14th century, the farmstead with a part of the village belonged to various patrician families from Kuttenberg, such as Ondřej Puša, under which a Gothic fortress was added to the village and the farmstead. In 1397, Wenceslas Bartosch (Václav Bartoš) became the owner, and pledged to paying a permanent fee to the Kuttenberg almshouse from the farmstead.</paragraph><paragraph>After the Hussite Wars, Hanush Ferydan held Pschitoky, burdening the farmstead and keep with many debts that he refused to pay, so in 1443 the highest mint master decided that Hanush and his descendants 'from now and for all time' had to pay 50 dozen groschen to the Kuttenberg almshouse every year. The last burgher owner of Pschitoky was Voršila Cihelníková, who sold the estate to Václav Materna of Květnice in 1501. The Maternas rebuilt the Gothic fortress in the Renaissance style.</paragraph><paragraph>To this day, only the Gothic vaulted cellar has remained, though in a very poor condition.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The first written mention of the village Pschitoky dates back to 1141, according to which it was in possession of the Olomouc archdiocese. In 1249, Pschitoky was briefly held by Havel of Löwenberk, and a year later the Olomouc bishop Bruno of Schauenberk ceded the village to the Sedletz Monastery.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 14th century, the farmstead and part of the village belonged to various patrician families from Kuttenberg, such as Ondřej Puša, under whom a Gothic fortress was added. In 1397, Wenceslas Bartosch (Václav Bartoš) became the owner, and pledged to pay a permanent fee to the Kuttenberg almshouse from the farmstead.</paragraph><paragraph>After the Hussite Wars, Hanush Ferydan held Pschitoky, burdening the farmstead and fortress with many debts which he refused to pay, so in 1443 the chief Mint Master decided that Hanush and his descendants 'from now and for all time' had to pay 50 dozen groschen to the Kuttenberg almshouse every year. The last burgher to own Pschitoky was Voršila Cihelníková, who sold the estate to Václav Materna of Květnice in 1501. The Maternas rebuilt the Gothic fortress in the Renaissance style.</paragraph><paragraph>To this day, only the Gothic vaulted cellar remains, though in a very poor condition.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In Bohemia, brothels were called a <italic>“hampejz”</italic>, <italic>‘whorehouse'</italic> or <italic>‘house of shame'</italic>, but not a <italic>‘brothel'</italic>. Prostitutes were simply <italic>‘whores'</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>The profession encompassed several categories. The most deprived prostitutes were homeless and provide services in the streets. Others visited their customers in their homes disguised as bread sellers, yet others were ‘to hand' at a given court. Then were those who proffered their services in brothels of various price categories, whose clients were townsmen, officials and nobles (or conversely, the most menial clientèle, in the most down-market dives).</paragraph><paragraph>Brothels were run not only by the townspeople, but often even by the spiritual leaders, or prelates (for example, the Parish Priest of the Church of St Giles under Vyšehrad). Often a brothel was directly connected to the bath-house.</paragraph><paragraph>During the Hussite wars many brothels were abolished, but boomed at once afterwards. Their legalization was also helped the Church of Rome, which considered prostitution a lesser evil than adultery. It speaks volumes to note that prostitutes accounted for almost 10% of the population of Papal Rome.</paragraph><paragraph> There were numerous regulations and laws covering brothels and the ‘oldest profession', as well as a special tax. Laws also covered considerate treatment of prostitutes and protected them from violence.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In Bohemia, brothels were called <italic>“hampejz”</italic>, <italic>‘whorehouse'</italic> or <italic>‘house of shame'</italic>, but not <italic>‘brothel'</italic>. Prostitutes were simply called <italic>‘whores'</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>The profession encompassed several categories. The most deprived prostitutes were homeless and provided services in the streets. Others visited their customers in their homes disguised as bread sellers, while others were ‘at hand' at a given court. Then were those who offered their services in brothels of various price categories, whose clients were townsmen, officials and nobles (or conversely, the most vulgar clientèle, in the cheapest brothels).</paragraph><paragraph>Brothels were run not only by townspeople, but often by clergy (for example, the Parish Priest of the Church of St Giles under Vyšehrad). Often a brothel was directly connected to a bath-house.</paragraph><paragraph>During the Hussite wars many brothels were abolished, but flourished again afterwards. Legalization was aided by the Roman Catholic Church, which considered prostitution a lesser evil than adultery. It's telling that prostitutes made up nearly 10% of the population in Papal Rome.</paragraph><paragraph> There were numerous regulations and laws covering brothels and the ‘oldest profession', as well as a special tax. Laws also covered considerate treatment of prostitutes and protected them from violence.</paragraph>

<paragraph>He is a high religious authority in Judaism. The term translates as 'teacher', or also originally as 'lord' or 'master'. The title was first applied to scholars who derived their learning in a continuous line from Moses; today it is more associated with the spiritual leaders of the Jewish community. The designation 'Rabbi' can also mean a sense of respect and humility for any person educated in matters of Judaism and the so-called Halakha (body of religious law). A Rabbi is someone within the community who makes decisions about its affairs and has the final say in them. Often also the one who communicates externally.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A high religious authority in Judaism. The term translates as 'teacher', or also originally as 'lord' or 'master'. The title was first applied to scholars who could trace their learning in a continuous line back to Moses; today it is more associated with spiritual leaders of the Jewish community. The designation 'Rabbi' can also mean a sense of respect and humility for any person educated in matters of Judaism and the so-called Halakha (body of religious law). A Rabbi is someone within the community who makes decisions about its affairs and has the final say in them. Often also the one who spoke for the community externally.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Rabstein Castle (from German: <italic>'Rabe'</italic> - raven, and <italic>'Stein'</italic> - stone, therefore sometimes also known as Krkavec Castle or Raven's Stone) was built in the 14th century by Nicolaus Rabenstein, a rich townsman from Kuttenberg.</paragraph><paragraph>The settlement apparently stood on a promontory above the Vejvanovský pond, flowing into the Vrchlitz (Bach) river. A mill called <accent>Rabštejnka</accent> was later built near the castle. Sources mention the castle until its demise in 1455. Local floods often occurred in the vicinity of Vrchlitz river, so today most of the ruins are flooded.</paragraph><paragraph>We know that after Rabenstein's death, the property belonged to other rich families from Kuttenberg: the Rotlevs, after 1416 the Piseks, and then the Lems. For the purposes of our game, however, we have decided to present the site in the form of a romantic ruin.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Rabstein Castle (from German: <italic>'Rabe'</italic> - raven, and <italic>'Stein'</italic> - stone, therefore sometimes also known as Krkavec Castle, Raven's Stone or Crow Stone) was built in the 14th century by Nicolaus Rabenstein, a wealthy burgher from Kuttenberg.</paragraph><paragraph>The settlement likely stood on a promontory above the Vejvanovský stream which flows into the Vrchlitz (Bach) river. A mill called <accent>Rabštejnka</accent> was later built near the castle. Sources mention the castle until its demise in 1455. Local floods often occurred in the vicinity of Vrchlitz river, so today most of the ruins are submerged.</paragraph><paragraph>We know that after Rabenstein's death, the property belonged to other rich families from Kuttenberg: the Rotlevs, after 1416 the Piseks, and then the Lems. For the purposes of our game, however, we have decided to present the site in the form of a romantic ruin.</paragraph>

<paragraph>At the head of the town was the <accent>Bailiff</accent> appointed by the monarch (the role was hereditary), and the City Council, consisting of <accent>aldermen</accent> (<italic>councillors</italic>). The Council was chaired by the <accent>Bürgermeister</accent> or <accent>Subcamerarious</accent> (<italic>Deputy Chamberlain</italic>).</paragraph><paragraph>The aldermen were mostly wealthy townspeople and their tenure in the function varied with the status of the town, whether royal, signorial or free.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>Council</accent> decided on the most important topics relating to the town and its inhabitants. Court hearings, conferences, dossiers, deeds of sale or donations of property, registers, contracts and other documents were written up and kept at the Town Hall.</paragraph>

<paragraph>At the head of the town stood a <accent>bailiff</accent> appointed by the monarch (his office was hereditary), and a city council consisting of <accent>aldermen</accent> (known as <italic>councillors</italic> or <italic>elders</italic>). The head of the council was the <accent>Bürgermeister</accent> or <accent>underchamberlain</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>The council members were mostly wealthy townsmen, and their rotation in office depended on whether it was a royal, manorial, or free city.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>council</accent> decided on the most important matters concerning the city and its inhabitants. Courts, consultations, records, the sale or donation of property, registers, contracts, and other documents were prepared and stored at the Town Hall.</paragraph>

<years>? - 1416</years><paragraph>Radzig Kobyla was a Bohemian yeoman, the Royal Hetman of Wenceslas IV and, between 1410 and 1415, Burgrave of Vyšehrad. In 1403 he was the hetman in Silver Skalitz, where he oversaw silver mining. The king was known for his favour towards the lower nobility, to whom he awarded high positions in return for their loyalty. Radzig was probably one of these and it can be assumed that he was the king’s friend.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1403 Skalitz was besieged and burned to the ground by King Sigismund and his Cuman army. For his service and loyalty, the King Wenceslas IV permitted Radzig to build his own castle at Veselí nad Sázavou.</paragraph><paragraph>He was killed in 1416 in a tavern in Kuttenberg by a mob of miners, incited by preachers. "They seized them in the inn where they were staying, cut their bodies into pieces and threw them out onto the street, where the mob vigorously stomped on their remains and, singing joyful songs, went to the preachers' house to be praised for the act they had been encouraged to commit."</paragraph><paragraph>This occured when he was there to collect taxes for the king. The strange thing is that six years earlier he had apparently been a robber knight. From the sources is not clear, how he returned to the king's service.</paragraph>

<years>? - 1416</years><paragraph>Radzig Kobyla was a Bohemian yeoman, the Royal Hetman of Wenceslas IV and, between 1410 and 1415, Burgrave of Vyšehrad. In 1403 he was the hetman in Silver Skalitz, where he oversaw silver mining. The king was known for his favour towards lower nobility, to whom he awarded high positions in return for their loyalty. Radzig was probably one of these and likely a friend of the king.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1403 Skalitz was besieged and burned to the ground by King Sigismund and his Cuman army. For his service and loyalty, King Wenceslas IV permitted Radzig to build his own castle at Veselí nad Sázavou (Sasau).</paragraph><paragraph>He was killed in 1416 in a tavern in Kuttenberg by a mob of miners, incited by priests. "They seized them in the inn where they were staying, cut their bodies into pieces and threw them into the street, where the mob vigorously stomped on their remains and, singing joyful songs, went to the priests' house to be praised for the act they had been encouraged to commit."</paragraph><paragraph>This occured when he was there to collect taxes for the king. Interstingly, six years earlier he had likely been a robber knight. It is unclear from the sources, how he returned to the king's service.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The first written mention of Ratboř appears in 1362. At that time, the adjacent village belonged to Mikuláš Velkuš, a townsman from Kutná Hora, who sold it to Mikuláš Wonderbute between 1386-9.</paragraph><paragraph>The rapid change of owners is characteristic of the fortress to this day: after his death it passed to King Wenceslas IV, from whom it was acquired by another Kutná Hora burgher, Martin Oderin.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1402, the fortress and the village were burnt down by King Sigismund of Hungary during the siege of Kutná Hora. The remains of the fortress continued to change hands during the 15th century until they came under the administration of King Jiří of Poděbrady and from there to the governor of Kolín, Jan Hrabaň, at Přerubnice. The list of other owners is endless. </paragraph><paragraph> Today the fortress (converted into a castle) is privately owned. Only part of the masonry of the south-east corner and one room with a rib vault have been preserved from the original Gothic building.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The first written mention of Raborsch appears in 1362. At that time, the adjacent village belonged to Mikuláš Velkuš, a townsman from Kuttenberg, who sold it to Mikuláš Wonderbute between 1386-1389.</paragraph><paragraph>The rapid change of owners is characteristic of the fortress, even to this day: after his death it passed to King Wenceslas IV, from whom it was acquired by another Kuttenberg burgher, Martin Oderin.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1402, the fortress and the village were burnt down by King Sigismund of Hungary during the siege of Kuttenberg. The remains of the fortress continued to change hands during the 15th century until they came under the administration of King George of Podiebrad and from there to the captain of Kolin, Jan Hrabaň, at Přerubnice. The list of subsequent owners is extensive.</paragraph><paragraph>Today the fortress (rebuilt into a castle) is privately owned. Only part of the masonry of the south-east corner and one room with a ribbed vaulting have been preserved from the original Gothic building.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Manual coin minting was a complex process in the Middle Ages.</paragraph><paragraph>After the raw silver was mined and processed, bars, so-called <italic>cans</italic>, were made from an alloy of the precious metal. The bars were then hammered into thin, narrow strips by the <accent>minters</accent>, from which squares, so-called <italic>farfule</italic>, were cut with large scissors and then rounded. The slices were then hammered into a circular shape on the anvil and then flattened on the anvil by means of the so-called <italic>lapping</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>Only then could the <accent>coiner</accent>, the so-called <accent>pregéř</accent>, enter the scene and insert the coin between two stamps at the minting tables and struck it with a hammer. Since great strength was required, the coiner had to be a mountain of a man: one hand was needed to hold the two stamps together, the other to pound them with the heavy hammer. Later on, when thalers began to be minted instead of the Prague groschen, even two people were needed for minting.</paragraph><paragraph>The work was very noisy and had to be well guarded. Most of the coiners became deaf after a while and were not allowed to wear clothes to work with loose folds or pockets in which something could be hidden.</paragraph><paragraph>The failed pieces were collected and then re-melted into new coins.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Manual coin minting was a complex process in the Middle Ages.</paragraph><paragraph>After the raw silver was mined and processed, ingots, known as <italic>cans</italic>, were made from the precious metal alloy. The ingots were then hammered into thin, narrow strips by the <accent>minters</accent>, from which squares, so-called <italic>farfule</italic>, were cut with large shears and then rounded. The slices were then hammered into a circular shape on the anvil and then smoothed by a process known as <italic>clipping</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>Only then could the <accent>coiner</accent>, known as a <italic>pregéř</italic>, step in to insert the coin between two dies at the minting tables and strike it with a hammer. Since great strength was required, the coiner had to be a mountain of a man: one hand was needed to hold the two stamps together, the other to pound them with a heavy hammer. Later on, when thalers replaced Prague groschen, two people were needed for minting.</paragraph><paragraph>The activity was very noisy and had to be well-guarded. Most engravers eventually became partially deaf and were not allowed to wear clothing with loose folds or pockets, which could be used to conceal something.</paragraph><paragraph>Imperfect coins were collected and subsequently melted down to be reminted.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A type of unarmed combat known as <accent>Ringen</accent> (from the German <italic>Ring Kunst</italic>, meaning <italic>art of wrestling</italic>) is one of the oldest martial systems widespread in medieval Europe.</paragraph><paragraph>In an effort to defeat the opponent, the wrestler did not rely so much on brute strength as on a combat strategy that used the whole body, aiming to throw the opponent off balance and bring him to the ground. Kicks, holds and strikes with fists or the edge of the hand were often aimed at the joints. Attacks on the eyes or finger-breaking were also not uncommon.</paragraph><paragraph>Ringen was taught in swordfighting schools, where medieval masters placed great emphasis on comprehensive schooling in combat. One of those who wrote extensively about refining Ringen techniques was Johannes Liechtenauer, the master of one of the most prominent swordfighting schools of the late Middle Ages, located in Nuremberg.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A type of unarmed combat known as <accent>Ringen</accent> (from the German <italic>Ring Kunst</italic>, meaning <italic>art of wrestling</italic>) is one of the oldest martial systems widespread in medieval Europe.</paragraph><paragraph>In an effort to defeat the opponent, the wrestler did not rely so much on brute strength as on a combat strategy that used the whole body, aiming to throw the opponent off balance and bring him to the ground. Kicks, holds and strikes with fists or the edge of the hand were often aimed at the joints. Attacks on the eyes or finger-breaking were also not uncommon.</paragraph><paragraph>Ringen was taught in swordfighting schools, where medieval masters placed great emphasis on comprehensive schooling in combat. One of those who wrote extensively about refining Ringen techniques was Johannes Liechtenauer, the master of one of the most prominent swordfighting schools of the late Middle Ages, located in Nuremberg.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Merchants played an important role in the developed mining process of Kuttenberg – independent entrepreneurs known as <italic>ore merchants</italic>, who bought ore from the king's vassals (feudal miners or the miners themselves) and processed it in their own smelters. They smelted the mined ore and then were obliged to deliver the produced silver to the Kuttenberg mint at an agreed price. Thus, they were important links in the entire process of silver production.</paragraph><paragraph>The <italic>ore merchants</italic> were naturally aware of their importance in the mining industry, and therefore they founded their own association to protect their properties and interests.</paragraph><paragraph>It was not uncommon for greed to lead the <italic>ore merchants</italic> to violate the law for their benefit – for example, secretly pressuring to lower the price of ore, thereby increasing their profits at the expense of the miners and the ruler.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Merchants played an important role in the developed mining process of Kuttenberg – independent entrepreneurs known as <italic>ore merchants</italic>, who bought ore from the king's vassals (feudal miners or the miners themselves) and processed it in their own smelters. They smelted the mined ore and then were obliged to deliver the produced silver to the Kuttenberg mint at an agreed price. Thus, they were important links in the entire process of silver production.</paragraph><paragraph>The <italic>ore merchants</italic> were naturally aware of their importance in the mining industry, and therefore they founded their own association to protect their properties and interests.</paragraph><paragraph>It was not uncommon for greed to lead the <italic>ore merchants</italic> to violate the law for their benefit – for example, secretly pressuring to lower the price of ore, thereby increasing their profits at the expense of the miners and the ruler.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Town Hall is the seat of the <accent>Bailiff</accent> and the <accent>Council</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>Originally it was an ordinary town house, gradually transforming into the local government office or Town Hall. In Bohemia the first Town Hall was established at the end of the 14th century.</paragraph><paragraph>The buildings were usually of masonry, at least in the lower floors, many rooms having vaulted ceilings. The ground floor of the municipal building hosted shops, a tavern, the site of the public scales, a sentry room and an armoury.</paragraph><paragraph>The room housing the public scales (which set the standard for all other scales in shops) had a cubit length measure set in the wall and samples of other small measures and weights, which were universally valid throughout the town's administrative domain.</paragraph><paragraph>On the first floor of the Town Hall was the Council Hall, the chapel (in an oriel), the scribe's study and residential chambers. The upper floors served as a granary or warehouse. In the cellar there was a jail and a goods store.</paragraph><paragraph>The Council Hall hosted the meetings of the City Council and its armoires contained documents, deeds, charters and privileges and the town archive.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Town Hall is <accent>the seat of the Bailiff</accent> and <accent>the Council</accent>.</paragraph><paragraph>Originally it was an ordinary town house, gradually transforming into the local government office or Town Hall. In Bohemia the first Town Hall was established at the end of the 14th century.</paragraph><paragraph>The buildings were usually of brick, at least the lower floors, with many rooms having vaulted ceilings. The ground floor of the municipal building hosted shops, a tavern, the site of the public scales, a sentry room and an armoury.</paragraph><paragraph>The room housing the <accent>public scales</accent> (which set the standard for all other scales in shops) had a cubit length measure set in the wall and samples of other small measures and weights, which were universally valid throughout the town's administrative domain.</paragraph><paragraph>On the first floor of the Town Hall was the Council Hall, the chapel (in an oriel), the scribe's study and residential chambers. The upper floors served as a granary or warehouse. In the cellar there was a jail and storage for goods.</paragraph><paragraph>The Council Hall hosted the meetings of the City Council and its cabinets contained documents, deeds, charters, privileges and the town archive.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The first Orders of Knighthood emerge at the end of the 11th century, especially in connection with the Crusades. It is a combination of ecclesiastical order and military organisation appealing to Christian values as well as chivalric traditions and service to society. In addition to the noble knights, a large number of commoners were also <accent>members of the Order</accent>: foot soldiers, archers, sailors or auxiliary military professions.</paragraph><paragraph>Becoming a member of a knightly order might seem like a suitable career choice for a young medieval man, but often the opposite was true. Life was subject to strict regulations and organization, often involving compulsory celibacy, living in a closed convent, or long fasts. In the event of capture, for example, the <italic>Templars</italic> forbade giving ransom for their men, hence to fall into enemy hands meant only imprisonment or death.</paragraph><paragraph>In the high Middle Ages of the 13th and 14th centuries, the orders experienced their greatest expansion, their armies numbering tens of thousands of warriors and in some cases even founding their own states (for example in the Baltic, or later in Malta). In more recent history, their religious and ecclesiastical overtones disappear and the orders focus more on charity. </paragraph><paragraph>The <italic>Templars</italic> are the most known order of Knighthood, followed by the <italic>Order of St. John</italic> (Knights of Malta), the <italic>Teutonic Order</italic>, the <italic>Order of the Holy Sepulchre</italic>, and the <italic>Order of St. Lazarus</italic>.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The first knightly orders emerged at the end of the 11th century, primarily in connection with the Crusades. They were a combination of religious order and military organization, appealing to Christian values as well as chivalric traditions and service to society. Besides noble knights, the <accent>members of the order</accent> also included a large number of common people: foot soldiers, archers, sailors and auxiliary military professions.</paragraph><paragraph>Becoming a member of a knightly order might have seemed like a suitable career choice for a young medieval man, but often the opposite was true. Life was subject to strict rules and organization, often requiring celibacy, life in a closed convent or long fasts. For example, the <italic>Templars</italic> forbade paying ransom for their members, so falling into enemy hands meant imprisonment or death.</paragraph><paragraph>In the High Middle Ages of the 13th and 14th centuries, the orders underwent their greatest expansion, with their armies numbering tens of thousands of fighters, and in some cases, they even founded their own states (such as in the Baltic region or later in Malta). In more recent history, their religious and ecclesiastical context has faded, and the orders have focused more on charity.</paragraph><paragraph>The most famous knightly orders were the <italic>Templars</italic>, the <italic>Order of St. John</italic> (or Knights of Malta), the <italic>Teutonic Order</italic>, the <italic>Knights of the Holy Sepulchre</italic>, and the <italic>Knights of St. Lazarus</italic>.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The physical training of a boy to become a knight began before he was 7 years old. He had to know how to run, jump and climb well, and also to be able to swim. He strengthened his arms by throwing hefty rocks. Over the years boys had to become proficient in spear throwing, archery, unarmed wrestling, horsemanship, parrying with a shield and attacking. Their training also encompassed joining the hunt.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>seven knightly skills</accent> according to the classical tradition were horse-riding, swimming, archery, fighting with sword and unarmed, hunting, as well as playing chess and composing poetry.</paragraph><paragraph> Similarly, burghers practised combat with different types of weapons, which came into its own especially in town defence.</paragraph><paragraph>The towns more than anywhere else spawned sword-fighting and archery fellowships, where swordplay would be taught, initially according to the so-called German school (Deutsche Fechtschule), later in the Renaissance dominated by the Italian and Spanish schools. Shooting fellowships were devoted to archery with bows and crossbows, and with the development of gunpowder firearms came into play.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Physical training for a boy to become a knight began before his 7th year of life. He had to be able to run well, jump, climb, and swim proficiently. To strengthen his arms, he threw large stones. Boys had to learn to wield a lance, shoot a bow, wrestle, handle a horse safely, use a shield, and attack. Training also included participation in hunts.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>seven knightly virtues</accent> according to classical tradition included: horse riding, swimming, archery, sword fighting and wrestling, hunting, playing chess, and composing verses.</paragraph><paragraph>Swordsmanship with various types of weapons was similarly diligently practiced by townspeople, particularly for defending their cities.</paragraph><paragraph>In towns, swordfighting and marksmanship guilds were more common than anywhere else, where swordplay was initially taught according to the so-called German school (Deutsche Fechtschule), later dominated by Italian and Spanish schools in the Renaissance. Marksmanship guilds focused on archery and crossbow shooting, and with the development of gunpowder, firearms came into play.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A schism is a split in the Catholic Church in which multiple popes hold office simultaneously.</paragraph><paragraph>The longest of these began in 1378, when the papal see was moved back to Rome from Avignon, where it had been forcibly relocated to for 70 years by the King of France due to disagreements with Roman church dignitaries. However, the new Pope of Rome Urban VI, refused to share the government with the cardinals who had elected him. They therefore declared the election invalid and installed a new, second pope Clement VII, based in Avignon again.</paragraph><paragraph> Clement VII was recognised by Scotland, Castile, Aragon, Navarre and Portugal. Germany, Bohemia, England and Ireland, Flanders, Poland, Hungary and Italy sided with Pope Urban VI. After their deaths, Boniface IX in Rome and Pope Benedict XIII in Avignon took offices.</paragraph><paragraph>All attempts to restore the unity of the Catholic Church were unsuccessful. The crisis of faith was strongly influencing the society of the time, and the voices of the Church's critics (such as John Wycliffe and Jan Hus) were growing louder.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1409, there was even a move by the cardinals to declare both popes invalid and elect a third, John XXIII. However, neither pope was relegated. </paragraph><paragraph>Only after <accent>The Council of Constance</accent> (1414-1418), convoked by Sigismund of Luxembourg and John XXIII, was to be the beginning of reforms in the Church. It resulted in the relegation of all three popes and, in 1317, the election of a new pope, who was based in Rome. The schism was thus brought to an end.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A schism represents a split within the Catholic Church where multiple popes hold office simultaneously.</paragraph><paragraph>The longest of these began in 1378, when the papal see was moved back to Rome from Avignon, where it had been forcibly relocated for 70 years by the King of France due to disagreements with Roman church officials. However, the new Pope of Rome, Urban VI, refused to share power with the cardinals who had elected him. They therefore declared the election invalid and installed a new, second pope Clement VII, once again based in Avignon.</paragraph><paragraph>Clement VII was recognised by Scotland, Castile, Aragon, Navarre and Portugal. Germany, Bohemia, England and Ireland, Flanders, Poland, Hungary and Italy sided with Pope Urban VI. After their deaths, Boniface IX took office in Rome and antipope Benedict XIII in Avignon.</paragraph><paragraph>All attempts to restore the unity of the Catholic Church were unsuccessful. The crisis of faith strongly affected society at the time, and voices of Church critics (such as John Wycliffe and Jan Hus) grew stronger.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1409, there was even a move by the cardinals to declare both popes invalid and elect a third, John XXIII. However, neither pope was relegated.</paragraph><paragraph>Only after <accent>The Council of Constance</accent> (1414-1418), convened by Sigismund of Luxembourg and John XXIII, were there to be reforms in the Church. It resulted in the deposition of all three popes and, in 1417, the election of a new pope, who was based in Rome. The schism was thus brought to an end.</paragraph>

<paragraph>His main activity was to keep records of the Territorial Court and the meetings of the City Council. He was one of the few in medieval society who knew how to read and write, making his services welcome in almost every city.

<paragraph>Their main activity was keeping records from the regional court and city council meetings. In medieval society, they were one of the few people who could read and write, making their services highly sought after in almost every town.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Medieval villages comprised some 90% of the populace, the majority occupied with agriculture and livestock farming.</paragraph><paragraph>Even though farmers were freemen and had always owned their homesteads, the land beneath it was on lease from the monarch, or rather from the nobleman who had obtained it from the King in fiefdom. They would pay a portion of their annual earnings in rent – whether in cash, honey, wheat or other crops.</paragraph><paragraph> Sometimes they were also required to labour for the nobility, i.e. to work unpaid on farmlands belonging to the liege Lord.</paragraph><paragraph> The Territorial Diets (councils) of the 15th and 16th centuries decreed that the common country folk could not bear arms or engage in hunting. With special permission from the liege Lord, they were allowed to hunt hares or small birds.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In medieval times, about 90% of the population lived in villages, most of whom were engaged in agriculture and animal husbandry.</paragraph><paragraph>Although peasants were free and had owned their farms from time immemorial, the land beneath them was only leased from the sovereign or, respectively, from the nobleman who had received it as a fief from the king. For the lease of the land, they had to pay part of their annual yields – whether in money, honey, grain, or other crops.</paragraph><paragraph>Sometimes they were also required to perform corvée labour for the lord, that is, to work without pay on the fields belonging to the feudal noble.</paragraph><paragraph>The Land Diets in the 15th and 16th centuries voted that the village folk were not allowed to carry weapons or practice hunting. With the special permission of the lord, the peasants were allowed to hunt hares or small birds.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The ossuary is an underground chapel of the All Saints cemetery church, built in the second half of the 14th century, which originally belonged to the Cistercian abbey in Sedletz. It bears an uncanny resemblance to the underground chapels of Jerusalem where pilgrims were buried.</paragraph><paragraph>During the Hussite wars, the monastery was burnt down and abandoned together with the ossuary. It was not rebuilt until the second half of the 15th century. In 1511, the bones from the cemetery were exhumed and moved to the underground of the ossuary, where a half-blind monk put them together into famous pyramids and bone buildings. In our game, however, we decided to attribute their creation to Henry.</paragraph><paragraph>In its later history, the Sedletz ossuary underwent baroque modifications and today it is one of the most popular tourist sites in the Czech Republic. The bone buildings, made from the remains of more than 60,000 people, have undergone extensive renovation and, as a <italic>memento mori</italic>, are still a reminder that: dust you are and dust you shall turn to...</paragraph>

<paragraph>The ossuary is an underground chapel of the All Saints cemetery church, built in the second half of the 14th century, which originally belonged to the Cistercian abbey in Sedletz. It bears an uncanny resemblance to the underground chapels of Jerusalem where pilgrims were buried.</paragraph><paragraph>During the Hussite wars, the monastery was burnt down and abandoned together with the ossuary. It was not rebuilt until the second half of the 15th century. In 1511, the bones from the cemetery were exhumed and moved to the ossuary's underground , where a half-blind monk put them together into famous pyramids and bone structures. In our game, however, we decided to attribute their creation to Henry.</paragraph><paragraph>In its later history, the Sedletz ossuary underwent Baroque modifications and today it is one of the most popular tourist sites in the Czech Republic. The bone structures, made from the remains of more than 60,000 people, have undergone extensive renovation and, as a <italic>memento mori</italic>, are still a reminder that: dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return...</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Sedlec Monastery used to be the oldest Cistercian abbey in the Czech Kingdom. Founded in 1142 by the Bavarian Abbot Gerlach, it was later abandoned and reoccupied many times in its history, either due to wars or a poor financial situation.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1421, it was burnt down by the Hussites, only the Church of the Assumption and St. John the Baptist survived. After the end of the war, only a few monks returned and it remained in this dismal state until the 17th century. In 1783, the monastery was completely dissolved by an imperial decree.</paragraph><paragraph>The cemetery church of All Saints with the adjacent burial ground was originally part of the monastery, but later it began to serve as the town cemetery for Kutná Hora, because according to surviving records, burials were still taking place here long before the arrival of the monks. The cemetery was at its busiest during the wars and plague epidemics. In 1318 alone, 30,000 dead were buried here, and another 10,000 during the Hussite wars.</paragraph><paragraph>The place is shrouded in many legends. The most famous one says that the abbot of the Heidenreich monastery brought a handful of dirt from Jerusalem on his pilgrimage to the Holy Land, which he then scattered around the cemetery and the ossuary. Thus, the cemetery ground became holy and highly sought after not only by the people of Kutná Hora, but even by pilgrims and those interested in burial from all over Bohemia and neighbouring countries. Who wouldn't want to rest in the ground where Jesus Christ himself once walked?</paragraph><paragraph>Today, a cigarette factory is located on the site of the former monastery.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Sedletz Monastery used to be the oldest Cistercian abbey in the Czech Kingdom. Founded by the Bavarian Abbot Gerlach in 1142 , it was later abandoned and reoccupied many times in its history, either due to wars or poor financial situations.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1421, it was burnt down by the Hussites, only the Church of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary and St. John the Baptist survived. After the end of the war, only a few monks returned and it remained in this dismal state until the 17th century. In 1783, the monastery was completely abolished by an imperial decree.</paragraph><paragraph>The cemetery church of All Saints with the adjacent burial ground was originally part of the monastery, but later it began to serve as the municipal cemetery for Kuttenberg, because as records showed, burials were taking place there long before the arrival of the monks. The cemetery was at its busiest during wars and plague epidemics. In 1318 alone, 30,000 dead were buried there, and another 10,000 during the Hussite wars.</paragraph><paragraph>The site is shrouded in many legends. The most famous one states that the abbot of the Heidenreich Monastery brought a handful of dirt from Jerusalem on his pilgrimage to the Holy Land, which he then scattered around the cemetery and the ossuary. Thus, the cemetery ground became sacred and highly sought after, not only by the people of Kuttenberg, but also by pilgrims and those wishing to be buried there from all over Bohemia and neighbouring regions. Who wouldn't want to rest in the ground where Jesus Christ himself once walked?</paragraph><paragraph>Today, a cigarette factory is located on the site of the former monastery.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Semín (Semine) is a small village lying to the west of Troskowitz. In earlier times, it included a fortress that no longer exists today, which, according to surviving records, belonged to Jan and Oldřich of Semín in the year 1365. These two brothers, and later their children, owned the fortress until 1416, but did not reside there much because they chose other places for their seats. In 1375, Oldřich’s son Jan therefore assumed administration of Semín, and after him it passed to his sons Petr and Přibík.</paragraph><paragraph>Whether these Semín men were ancestors or relatives of the Semín of Semín line – an old Bohemian minor noble family – unfortunately can no longer be definitively proven or disproven. So far, the only discovery is that the first to bear that name was Jakub the Younger Semín of Semín, as late as 1422.</paragraph><paragraph>Even so, we decided to present the owner of the Semín fortress in our game as a representative example of impoverished nobility dwelling in pleasant countryside.</paragraph><paragraph>As for the place where the fortress is situated, the terrain bordered by steep rocky slopes, lakes, marshes and fishponds became an ideal settlement area as early as the middle of the first century BC. Remains of massive ramparts can be found here, the most prominent part being a ten-metre-high frontal rampart with a moat, which archaeological research indicates was built by the Celts.</paragraph><paragraph>In Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2, one also finds the Semín mill, which belonged to the lords of Semín for centuries, and it remains an important part of the picturesque landscape to this day.</paragraph>

So far, the only discovery is that the first to bear that name was Jakub the Younger Semín of Semín, as late as 1422.</paragraph><paragraph>Even so, we decided to present the owner of the Semín fortress in our game as a representative example of impoverished nobility dwelling in pleasant countryside.</paragraph><paragraph>As for the place where the fortress is situated, the terrain bordered by steep rocky slopes, lakes, marshes and fishponds became an ideal settlement area as early as the middle of the first century BC. Remains of massive ramparts can be found here, the most prominent part being a ten-metre-high frontal rampart with a moat, which archaeological research indicates was built by the Celts.</paragraph><paragraph>In Kingdom Come: Deliverance 2, one also finds the Semín mill, which belonged to the lords of Semín for centuries, and it remains an important part of the picturesque landscape to this day.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A herder's job depended on the weather, most commonly starting in April and ending in the autumn. The entrusted herd or flock (it was rarely their own, more commonly they were hired to supervise the grazing of others' livestock, for a fee) taking them from pasture to pasture, sleeping in rudimentary huts or shelters. Over the summer they stayed out at the pastures, returning to the village when the first frosts set in.</paragraph><paragraph>Life far away from other people forced the herders to become adept at healing themselves and their animals, so when there was no apothecary to hand, folk would turn to the shepherd.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A herder's job depended on the weather, most commonly starting in April and ending in the autumn. They took the entrusted herd or flock (it was rarely their own, more commonly they were hired to graze others' livestock for a fee) from pasture to pasture, sleeping in rudimentary huts or shelters. Over the summer they stayed out in the pastures, returning to the village when the first frosts set in.</paragraph><paragraph>Life far away from other people forced the herders to become adept at healing themselves and their animals, so when there was no apothecary to hand, folk would turn to shepherds.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The minerals mined in the Kuttenberg belts, primarily galena, sphalerite, and chalcopyrite, were characterised by a low silver content, making its smelting a rather challenging process.</paragraph> <paragraph>Work in the smelters was continuous. Furnaces with open spouts for easier handling of metal were used, or more often, those with closed spouts for better temperature regulation. This refinement process was described in great detail, for instance, in Agricola's illustrated work from 1556.</paragraph> <paragraph>The medieval <accent>process of silver extraction</accent> consisted of four stages. Almost every step had to be repeated several times to achieve the desired result. The raw material's structure and composition changed from the form of rocks and solidified slag to molten silver with lead impurities and finally to a solid "loaf" of pure silver. The primary goal was to remove unwanted impurities and reduce the ore's weight to a minimum.</paragraph> <paragraph>The final phase - silver refining through the addition of a specific amount of pure lead and the separation process (cupellation) - was known as far back as antiquity. Silver was melted with lead in a so-called <italic>cupellation bowl</italic>, where unwanted mixtures of other metals were separated through air oxidation.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The minerals mined in the Kuttenberg belts, primarily galena, sphalerite, and chalcopyrite, were characterised by a low silver content, making its smelting a rather challenging process.</paragraph> <paragraph>Work in the smelters was continuous. Furnaces with open spouts for easier handling of metal were used, or more often, those with closed spouts for better temperature regulation. This refinement process was described in great detail, for instance, in Agricola's illustrated work from 1556.</paragraph> <paragraph>The medieval <accent>process of silver extraction</accent> consisted of four stages. Almost every step had to be repeated several times to achieve the desired result. The raw material's structure and composition changed from the form of rocks and solidified slag to molten silver with lead impurities and finally to a solid "loaf" of pure silver. The primary goal was to remove unwanted impurities and reduce the ore's weight to a minimum.</paragraph> <paragraph>The final phase - silver refining through the addition of a specific amount of pure lead and the separation process (cupellation) - was known as far back as antiquity. Silver was melted with lead in a so-called <italic>cupellation bowl</italic>, where unwanted mixtures of other metals were separated through air oxidation.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Silver mining in Kuttenberg (Kutná Hora) began in the late 13th century and reached its peak during the 14th and 15th centuries. Research around the town has identified 14 to 15 previously exploited vein zones.</paragraph><paragraph>At various times, there may have been at least 20, but more commonly 50 or even up to 200 independent mines along these zones. Around the year 1400, silver was mainly extracted in four to five mining zones, known as Oselský, Rejzský, Kuklický, Grejfský, and partially Rovenský. The landscape around Kuttenberg was thus intersected by hundreds of mining corridors and typical clearings appeared due to extensive deforesting in the area.</paragraph><paragraph>The first independent mine owners, and later the monarch, were unable to ensure the smooth operation of such extensive mines, so parts of them were leased for a share of the extracted ore. Approximately 20 to 30 miners worked in a single mine, while around 700 to 1200 individuals contributed to overall silver production during this period.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to the miners themselves, many other workers processed the ore and performed various support tasks on the surface. This included operating and maintaining mining equipment, arranging material transport, and the work of craftsmen such as potters, charcoal burners, rope-makers and others. Each master of these trades had their assistants. Transporting people and materials to and from the mines required a large number of horse-drawn carts, stabling facilities and, of course, people to care for the animals.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Silver mining in Kuttenberg (Kutná Hora) began in the late 13th century and reached its peak during the 14th and 15th centuries. Research around the town has identified 14 to 15 previously exploited vein zones.</paragraph><paragraph>At various times, there may have been at least 20, but more commonly 50 or even up to 200 independent mines along these zones. Around the year 1400, silver was mainly extracted in four to five mining zones, known as Oselský, Rejzský, Kuklický, Grejfský, and partially Rovenský. The landscape around Kuttenberg was thus intersected by hundreds of mining corridors and typical clearings appeared due to extensive deforesting in the area.</paragraph><paragraph>The first independent mine owners, and later the monarch, were unable to ensure the smooth operation of such extensive mines, so parts of them were leased for a share of the extracted ore. Approximately 20 to 30 miners worked in a single mine, while around 700 to 1200 individuals contributed to overall silver production during this period.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition to the miners themselves, many other workers processed the ore and performed various support tasks on the surface. This included operating and maintaining mining equipment, arranging material transport, and the work of craftsmen such as potters, charcoal burners, rope-makers and others. Each master of these trades had their assistants. Transporting people and materials to and from the mines required a large number of horse-drawn carts, stabling facilities and, of course, people to care for the animals.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Silver Skalice is the town from which Henry comes, and which was burned down during the plot of the first part of KCD.</paragraph><paragraph>Not much is known or information is very uncertain about the war between 1402 and 1403, when Sigismund invaded Czech territory and tried to seize power. One of its known victims, however, was Stříbrná Skalice, which was burned on <accent>23 March 1403</accent>. We know the exact date because Sigismund signed a certain document in the siege camp, thanks to which we know that it was located at Skalice on that date.</paragraph><paragraph>Skalice was undoubtedly chosen by Sigismund because silver was mined there and administered by a supporter of the king, the governor Seagull Mare. Sigismund apparently wanted to stop the flow of money to the king's party.</paragraph><paragraph>Legend has it that Kobyl and his men, who had taken refuge in the castle before the attack on the village, managed to escape because a great storm had begun and the besiegers postponed their conquest until the morning. The defenders took advantage of this and fled under cover of darkness to nearby Rataj.</paragraph><paragraph>In the morning, Sigismund's men found only a goat in the empty castle (that's how we captured it in the game). Sigismund then razed the town and castle to the ground and the castle was never rebuilt afterwards. Today, only the foundation of it remains visible.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Silver Skalitz is the town which Henry comes from, and which was burned down during the events of the first part of KCD.</paragraph><paragraph>Regarding the war from 1402 to 1403, when Sigismund invaded Czech territory in an attempt to seize power, little is known or the information is quite uncertain. One of its known victims, however, was Silver Skalitz, which was burned on <accent>23 March 1403</accent>. We know the exact date because Sigismund signed a certain document in the siege camp, thanks to which we know he was there that day.</paragraph><paragraph>Skalitz was undoubtedly chosen by Sigismund because silver was mined there and administered by a supporter of the king, Sir Radzig Kobyla. Sigismund likely wanted to stop the flow of money to the king's side.</paragraph><paragraph>Legend has it that Kobyla and his people, who had taken refuge in the castle before the village was attacked, managed to escape because a great storm had begun and the besiegers postponed their attack until morning. The defenders took advantage of this and fled under cover of darkness to nearby Rattay.</paragraph><paragraph>In the morning, Sigismund's men found only a goat in the empty castle (as depicted in the game). Sigismund then razed the town and castle to the ground and the castle was never rebuilt afterwards. Today, only foundations remain visible.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Schooling did not develop until the end of the 11th century, mainly under the direction of the monasteries and the Church. The basic instruction in Latin consisted of seven liberal arts: the trivium - grammar, Latin, rhetoric, dialectic - and the quadrivium - mathematics, geometry, astronomy and church music. During the High Middle Ages, there were two-tiered Latin schools for boys - girls were rarely educated. After all - education was generally not as important as it is today, most of the nobility and wealthy bourgeoisie were illiterate and hired scribes when needed.</paragraph><paragraph>Later, centres of secular education were established in the cities, the peak of which was the founding of the University of International Studies in Prague by Emperor Charles IV in 1348.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Schooling did not develop until the end of the 11th century, mainly under the direction of the monasteries and the Church. The basic instruction in Latin consisted of seven liberal arts: the trivium - grammar; Latin, rhetoric, dialectic - and the quadrivium - mathematics, geometry, astronomy and church music. During the High Middle Ages, there were two-tiered Latin schools for boys - girls were rarely educated. In fact - education generally did not hold the same value as it does today, most of the nobility and wealthy bourgeoisie were illiterate and hired scribes when needed.</paragraph><paragraph>Later, centres of secular education were established in the cities, the peak of which was the founding of the University of International Studies in Prague by Emperor Charles IV in 1348.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The nobility (<italic>nobiles</italic>) consisted of the highest class of feudal society, which had power and legal privileges associated with the title or coat of arms of the family. They were directly subject to the king and held land only on loan, for which they had to pay tribute to the monarch and were obliged to provide military assistance in case of war.</paragraph><paragraph>The status of a nobleman was <accent>hereditary</accent>, as was the land and the obligations arising from it. The land, of course, also included its inhabitants, who had to pay rent fees to their lord and work on his fields.</paragraph><paragraph>The oldest Bohemian families included the <italic>Buzici</italic> (e.g. the Zajic von Hasenburg), the <italic>Benešovici</italic> (from Dubá, from Kravař), the <italic>Ronovci</italic> (the Lady from Leipa, the Lady from Dubá) and the <italic>Rosenbergs</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>As late as the 14th century, the word "lord" referred only to a wealthy member of the higher nobility who had the right to elect the king and sit on the provincial assembly, but during the 15th century, not only rulers, high church dignitaries and nobles, but also members of municipal governments and even ordinary townspeople were titled and addressed as "lord".</paragraph><paragraph>A <accent>Zeman</accent> was a provincial nobleman, i.e. of domestic origin, living in a given territory for a long time. A <accent>Vladyka</accent> administered numerous estates. <accent>Squires</accent>, who were part of the lower nobility, had no property of their own and served the higher nobility.</paragraph><paragraph>Initially only the higher nobility had influence on <accent>trends in art</accent>, but later the lower nobility also had influence, as they financed the works. This applied not only to buildings, paintings or sculptures, but also to clothing accessories, hairstyles and furniture.</paragraph><paragraph>A nobleman did not have to be educated, it was enough that he had a military upbringing; for administrative and physical work he had subjects and servants. His main duties were the collection of taxes, the administration of military cash and the hereditary offices.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The nobility (<italic>nobilitas</italic>) formed the highest stratum of feudal society, possessing power and legal privileges associated with their title or family crest. They were directly subordinate to the king and held land only on loan, for which they had to pay dues to the monarch and provide military assistance in times of war.</paragraph> <paragraph>The status of a noble was <accent>hereditary</accent>, as were the land and the obligations arising from it. The land included its inhabitants, who had to pay rent and work on their lord's fields.</paragraph> <paragraph>The oldest Czech noble families include: <italic>Buzici</italic> (e.g., Zajic von Hasenburg), <italic>Benešovici</italic> (of Dubé, of Kravař), <italic>Ronovci</italic> (lords of Lipá, lords of Dubá), and <italic>Rosenbergs</italic>.</paragraph> <paragraph>In the 14th century, the term "lord" referred only to wealthy members of the high nobility who had the right to vote for the king and sit in the provincial assembly. By the 15th century, the title "lord" was used for and addressed to not only rulers, high church officials, and nobles but also members of municipal councils and even ordinary townspeople.</paragraph> <paragraph>A <accent>zeman</accent> was a land nobleman, i.e., of local origin, living on the given land for a long time. A <accent>vladyka</accent> managed numerous estates. <accent>Squires</accent>, who formed the lower nobility, had no property of their own and served the higher nobility.</paragraph> <paragraph>The <accent>trends in art</accent> were initially influenced only by the higher nobility, but later also by the lower nobility, as they financed works of art. This included buildings, paintings, sculptures, as well as clothing accessories, hairstyles, and furniture.</paragraph> <paragraph>A nobleman did not need to be educated; it was sufficient for him to have military training. For administrative tasks and physical labour, he had his subjects and servants. His main duties included tax collection, managing military forces, and hereditary offices.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Mirror crosses, or just stones with a cross carved into the surface, were erected at places where tragic events or important milestones in the history of a given community or country often occurred and were closely related to criminal law - they were meant to be a symbol of confession of guilt and a plea for forgiveness. The propitiatory cross was a penance for a crime committed, erected by the penitent at his expense. In addition, atonement crosses also defined the boundaries of estates and villages.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Conciliation crosses, or simply stones with a cross carved into their surface, were erected at places where tragic events often occurred or at significant milestones in the history of a village or country, and were closely related to criminal law. They were meant to be a symbol of confession of guilt and a plea for forgiveness. A conciliation cross was an act of penance for a committed crime, constructed by the repentant offender at their own expense. Additionally, conciliation crosses marked the boundaries of estates and villages.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Since ancient times, people have been educated in medicine and have tried to provide help to others to fight illness and pain. The earliest texts of medical practices are preserved in monasteries as the first centres of medieval medicine. The Benedictines were the first to practice medicine. Unlike the city doctors, they did not charge money for their care. </paragraph><paragraph>In the 11th century, hospitals saw a visible development, especially thanks to the chivalric orders devoted to charity and the building of hospitals or shelters for travellers. The care of the sick was entrusted exclusively to men; women and nuns were forbidden to help in hospitals by the Church Council itself.</paragraph><paragraph> The treatment of wounds was most often by disinfection with hot iron or water, or by anointing the wound with various ointments or balms. It was dressed with cloth or linen. Herbs were applied to open wounds and inflammations. Soldiers often had to be able to help themselves because the field infirmaries did not move as quickly behind the military camp. The wounded often did not survive the several-day journey in an open wagon. </paragraph>

<paragraph>Since ancient times, people have been educated in medicine and have tried to help others in the fight against illness and pain. The oldest texts of medical practices have been preserved in monasteries, which were the first centres of medieval medicine. Medicine was primarily practised by Benedictines. Unlike city doctors, they did not charge money for their care.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 11th century, hospitals experienced significant development, mainly thanks to knightly orders dedicated to charity, and the construction of hospitals or shelters for travellers. Care for the sick was entrusted exclusively to men; women and nuns were forbidden to assist in hospitals by the Church Council.</paragraph><paragraph>Treatment of wounds was most often carried out by disinfecting with hot iron, water, or applying various ointments or balms to the wound. Bandaging was done with cloth or linen. Herbs were applied to open wounds and inflammations. Soldiers often had to be able to help themselves because field hospitals could not move quickly enough with the military camp. The wounded often did not survive the several-day journey in an open cart.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Old Kutna was a mining settlement, and probably one of the original settlements connected with silver mining, even before the town of Kuttenberg was founded at the end of the 13th century.</paragraph><paragraph>It was located on the north-western outskirts of today's town, as evidenced by records from as early as 1369 and later archaeological investigations that found the foundations of several buildings here. In addition, the Church of All Saints, originally a Romanesque chapel rebuilt in the Gothic style and later rebuilt several more times, still stands here, so that only the relief of an angel bearing the town's coat of arms has survived from the original building.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Old Kutna was a mining settlement and likely one of the original settlements associated with silver mining even before the establishment of the town of Kuttenberg in the late 13th century.</paragraph><paragraph>It was located on the north-western edge of today's town, as evidenced by records dating back to 1369, and subsequent archaeological surveys, that uncovered the foundations of several buildings. In addition, the Church of All Saints still stands here, originally a Romanesque chapel rebuilt in Gothic style and later rebuilt many more times, so that the only remaining element of the original buliding is a relief of an angel bearing the town's coat of arms.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Stone masons were engaged in the quarrying and dressing of stone. Among their most common activities was the quarrying of stone blocks from the rock-face, splitting them into smaller pieces, grinding, cutting and polishing, and last but not least dressing them to make building blocks or vaulting elements.</paragraph><paragraph>The first mention of an organized stonemasons guild in Bohemia comes from the 14th century. The patrons of quarriers and stonemasons are considered to be St Roch, St Joseph, and in places also St Barbara and St Procopius. Stone working found application mainly in the construction industry.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>Mason's mark</accent> was a graphic symbol, though not the maker's signature, on the surface of a finished stone piece. The number of finished and marked pieces determined payment due. Each mason either atttained his mark, or had it allocated to him at a particular point in his apprenticeship, and then kept it for life.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Stone masons were engaged in the quarrying and dressing of stone. Their activities included quarrying stone blocks from the rock-face, splitting them into smaller pieces, grinding, cutting, polishing and dressing them to make building blocks or vault elements.</paragraph><paragraph>The first mention of an organized stonemasons' guild in Bohemia dates from the 14th century. The patron saints of quarriers and stonemasons are St Roch and St Joseph, and in places also St Barbara and St Procopius. Stone-working found application mainly in the construction industry.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>mason's mark</accent> was a graphic symbol, though not the maker's signature, on the surface of a finished stone piece. The number of finished and marked pieces determined the payment due. Each mason either attained his mark, or had it allocated to him at a particular point in his apprenticeship, and then kept it for life.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Since we are in the period before the invention of the printing press, it is a specific feature of medieval literature that it was practically all disseminated only by hand copies and many of its works have not survived in their entirety. The most common genre were chronicles, legends of saints, sermons, or prayers. Later, scholarly writings or novels and the very popular chivalric novels, were added. Apart from this, there were not very often preserved joke songs, couplets or farces.</paragraph><paragraph>Literature was often written in verse and latin, with few works being written in the vernacular languages of the time. Books were expensive and contained lavish embellishments and illustrations. Since few people could read, the ownership of books was more the preserve of monasteries and educational institutions or the courts of monarchs.</paragraph><paragraph>The most important Czech literary works of our era are the verse epic Alexandreis, the Chronica Boemorum, the Chronicle of Dalimil, and the biography of Charles IV., Vita Caroli.</paragraph><paragraph>It will not have escaped the player's notice that in Kingdom Come we treat books and reading more freely. This was one of the concessions we made in favour of fun and the ability to hide information in books that would not otherwise make it into the game.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Since we are in the period before the invention of the printing press, a specific feature of medieval literature is that it was practically entirely disseminated by handwritten copies, and many of its works have not survived in their entirety. The most common genres were chronicles and annals, legends of saints, sermons, or prayers. Later, learned treatises, novellas, and very popular chivalric romances were added. Additionally, there existed less frequently preserved humorous songs, couplets, or farces, which remained out of the main focus.</paragraph><paragraph>Literature was often written in verse and in Latin, with few works being created in national languages at that time. Books were expensive and contained rich decorations and illustrations. Since few people could read, the possession of books was primarily the domain of monasteries, educational institutions, or royal courts.</paragraph><paragraph>The most significant Czech literary works of our era include the verse epic Alexandreis, Cosmas's Chronicle Boerorum, the Dalimil Chronicle, and the biography of Charles IV, Vita Caroli.</paragraph><paragraph>The player will surely notice that in Kingdom Come, we handle books and reading more freely. This was one of the concessions we made for the sake of entertainment and to be able to hide information in books that would otherwise not make it into the game.</paragraph>

<paragraph>This was a shooting competition to celebrate Pentecost, involving shooting with a bow, crossbow or rifle at a live bird tied to a pole, later replaced by a wooden bird. The Church criticized this custom and found it offensive because it was held on the feast of the descent of the Holy Spirit, the symbolic representation of the Spirit from the Holy Trinity being the bird: the dove. </paragraph>

<paragraph>It was a shooting competition to celebrate Pentecost (Whitsun), involving shooting with bows, crossbows, or guns at a live bird tied to a pole, later replaced by a wooden bird. The church criticised this custom and found it offensive because it was held on the feast of the descent of the Holy Spirit, whose symbolic representation in the Holy Trinity is precisely a bird: a dove.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The area where Stříbrná Skalice is situated today, the birthplace of our hero Henry, was probably settled in the 13th century. The construction was made possible by the flourishing of the area thanks to silver mining in the vicinity and the existence of a rectory in the nearby village of Rovná.</paragraph><paragraph>The owners of Skalice Castle were Ješek of Skalice (from 1384) and Bohdal of Drahonice (1402-1403). In 1403, it became the property of Václav IV, who gave it to the knight Racek Kobyl to manage. However, he had to leave the castle in the same year in order to save the inhabitants of Skalice from Sigismund's troops. Sigismund burnt the castle and the village, and the manor was never rebuilt.</paragraph><paragraph>In December 1403, Wenceslas IV donated the remains of the village to Jan Sokol of Lamberk. The ruins of the medieval castle and the fortifications were later used as building material for the Church of St. John of Nepomuk, only a small part of the masonry of the gate, the parkland and the walls has survived to this day.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The area where Skalitz (Skalice), the birthplace of our hero Henry, is situated today, was probably settled in the 13th century. The development of the town was prompted by silver mining in the area as well as the existence of the nearby parish of Rovná.</paragraph><paragraph>The owners of the castle included Ješek of Skalitz (from 1384) and Bohdal of Drahonice (1402-1403). In 1403, Wenceslas IV took possession of it and placed it under the governance of the knight Sir Radzig Kobyla. However, in the same year, he had to leave the castle in order to save the inhabitants of Skalitz from Sigismund's army, who torched the castle and the adjoining village; the estate was never rebuilt.</paragraph><paragraph>In December of 1403, Wenceslas IV granted the remains of the village to Jan Sokol of Lamberg. The ruins of the medieval castle and its fortifications was scavenged for building material for the Church of St. John of Nepomuk. Today, only a small part of the masonry of the gate, the bailey and the walls remain.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Gothic fortress was probably built in the 13th century on the order of one of the Kutná Hora patricians. It had the plan of a square with the tops facing the world and was surrounded by a wall, a moat and a rampart. From the northeast, the entrance to the fortress was provided by a bridge and a double gate protected by the main tower. </paragraph><paragraph> Inside the fortress, a single-storey palace was adjacent to the wall, with a smaller tower and a single-storey outbuilding further away. </paragraph><paragraph> Today, a castle stands on this site, which retains only parts of the perimeter masonry, part of the gate portal and the stone seats on the ground floor of the former tower as a reminder of the fortress.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Gothic fortress probably originated in the 13th century, commissioned by one of the Kuttenberg patricians. It had a square layout with the corners facing the cardinal points and was surrounded by walls, a moat and a rampart. From the northeast, the entrance to the fortress was secured by a bridge and a double gate protected by the main tower.</paragraph><paragraph>Inside the fortress, a single-story palace ran adjacent to the wall, with a smaller tower and a single-story outbuilding.</paragraph><paragraph>Today, a castle stands on this site, which retains only parts of the perimeter masonry, part of the gate portal and the stone seats on the ground floor of the former tower, as a reminder of the fortress.</paragraph>

<paragraph>It is not only a geographical area of countries following the glory of Rome after its collapse, but also a socio-political power formation with a great symbolic value. It was not a unified state, but a very loose union of many different states. Officially, the empire functioned from 962 until 1806, its size and member states changing frequently. The emperors of the Holy Roman Empire were chosen by election by the so-called electors until the 15th century, when the Habsburg dynasty inherited the imperial throne. The coronation of an emperor was accompanied by many political struggles, especially on the part of the Church, which claimed the so-called investiture for itself and wanted to be indispensable in this activity. Thus, each emperor had to accept his title from the hands of the Pope.</paragraph><paragraph>The Bohemian Principality became part of the Empire in the early 11th century, but thanks to Přemysl Otakar I., the Bohemian lands had a special status within the confederation: the Bohemian monarch was exempt from all obligations to the Holy Roman Empire, except for participation in the councils. The first Bohemian monarch to sit on the imperial throne was Charles IV.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Not only a geographical area of countries following the glory of Rome after its collapse, but also a socio-political power formation with a great symbolic value. It was not a unified state, but a very loose union of many different states. Officially, the empire functioned from 962 until 1806, its size and member states changing frequently. The emperors of the Holy Roman Empire were elected by the so-called prince-electors until the 15th century, when the Habsburg dynasty claimed the imperial throne hereditarily. The coronation of an emperor was accompanied by many political struggles, especially on the part of the Church, which claimed the so-called investiture for itself and wanted to be indispensable in this activity. Thus, each emperor had to accept his title from the hands of the Pope.</paragraph><paragraph>The Bohemian Principality became part of the Empire in the early 11th century, but thanks to Přemysl Otakar I, the Bohemian lands had a special status within the confederation: the Bohemian monarch was exempt from all obligations to the Holy Roman Empire, except for participation in the councils. The first Bohemian monarch to sit on the imperial throne was Charles IV.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Saint John's Eve is one of the European folk traditions, which is always held on the eve of the feast day of St John the Baptist, from 23 to 24 June.</paragraph><paragraph>Although the name in some languages refers to a Christian celebration, it is actually a much older pagan custom. This night marks the celebration of an important moment in the year - the <accent>solstice</accent> - whose legacy is carried by the names of this holiday, for example in Germanic and Scandinavian languages (<italic>Midsommer</italic>).</paragraph><paragraph>The celebration of this holiday takes place after sunset, ideally in the nature, where people dance around the fire, sing, make merry, but also take part in various rituals. Men jump over the fire, which refers to courage and skill. Women, on the other hand, show their endurance by dancing around a maypole or they're looking for their future husband through the tradition of <accent>floating a wreath</accent> of flowers. The girl has to weave it before midnight and then send it downstream. A young man who pulls her wreath out of the water is destined to her.</paragraph><paragraph>It was also believed that on Saint John's Eve, <accent>herbs have the greatest power</accent>. Therefore, at this time they were added to meals or made into medicinal infusions that could bring good luck, love or perhaps a rich harvest.</paragraph><paragraph>According to a tradition, a girl could also see the face of her chosen one if she placed <accent>nine flowers</accent> under her pillow, which she picked silently that night without looking behind her. The nine herbs consisted of daisy, rose, sticky catchfly, cornflower, stonecrop, chickweed, thyme, violet, and bellflower.</paragraph>

<paragraph>St. John's Eve is one of the European folk traditions that takes place on the eve of the feast of St. John the Baptist, from the 23rd to the 24th of June.</paragraph><paragraph>Although the name in some languages refers to a Christian celebration, it is actually a much older pagan custom. This night marks the celebration of an important moment in the year – the <accent>solstice</accent> – which is reflected in the names of this festival in Germanic and Scandinavian languages (such as <italic>Midsommer</italic>).</paragraph><paragraph>The celebration of this festival takes place after sunset, ideally in nature, where people dance around the fire, sing, make merry, and participate in various rituals. Men jump over the fire, which symbolizes courage and skill. Women demonstrate their endurance by dancing around the maypole or seek their future husband through the tradition of <accent>floating a wreath</accent> of flowers. The girl must weave the wreath before midnight and then send it down the stream. The young man destined for her is the one who retrieves her wreath from the water.</paragraph><paragraph>It was also believed that on St. John's Eve, <accent>herbs have the greatest power</accent>. Therefore, at this time, they were added to meals or brewed into healing infusions that could bring luck, love, or a bountiful harvest.</paragraph><paragraph>According to tradition, a girl could also see the face of her chosen one if she placed <accent>nine kinds of flowers</accent> under her pillow, which she had silently picked that night without looking back. The nine herbs included daisy, rose, catchfly, cornflower, stonecrop, chickweed, thyme, violet, and bellflower.</paragraph>
