<paragraph>For the coronation of Charles IV as King of Bohemia, a new unique jewel was made - the St Wenceslas' Crown. It was made from the old Přemyslid Crown and the monarch himself dedicated it to St Wenceslas. No Czech king was allowed to wear it, he could only borrow it for a fee on the occasion of his coronation. The crown is made of pure gold with precious stones and pearls, kept in a strongroom with seven locks above the chapel of St Wenceslas in the Prague Cathedral. The keys are held by the leaders of the Czech State: the President, the Prime Minister, the Archbishop of Prague etc. There is a legend that if the Crown is worn on the head of anyone other than the rightful Czech King, the wearer will soon die. It is reported that the during WWII the Nazi Reichsprotector for Bohemia and Moravia, Reinhard Heidrich, put it on – and died shortly afterwards at the hands of assassins. The story is probably apocryphal, but certainly interesting.</paragraph>

<paragraph>For the coronation of Charles IV as King of Bohemia, a new unique crown was made - the St Wenceslas Crown. It was made from the old Přemyslid Crown and the monarch himself dedicated it to St Wenceslas. No Czech king was allowed to wear it, he could only borrow it for a fee on the occasion of his coronation. The crown is made of pure gold adorned with gemstones and pearls, and is kept in a chamber with seven locks above the St Wenceslas chapel in Prague Cathedral. The keys are held by the leaders of the Czech State: the President, the Prime Minister, the Archbishop of Prague etc. There is a legend that if the Crown is worn on the head of anyone other than the rightful Czech King, the wearer will soon die. It is reported that during WWII, the Nazi Reichsprotector for Bohemia and Moravia, Reinhard Heidrich, put it on – and died shortly afterwards at the hands of assassins. The story is probably apocryphal, but certainly interesting.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Swordsmiths were originally blacksmith-cutlers specializing in blades for swords, knives, daggers and other hand-held side-arms.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 14th century, the making of armour began to specialize and separate out from the blacksmith's craft. Specialist professions came into being – armourers, plate-smiths and bascineteers, who not only produced, but also sold their wares. As regards the weapons, there were new specialized professions – the swordsmith, bladesmith, fletcher, arrowsmith, and in later centuries the gunsmith, bowyer or shieldsmith, making wooden and metal shields.</paragraph><paragraph>The price of a complete suit of armour was very high, affordable to only a wealthy nobleman. Those who could not afford a complete suit of armour would have only partial metal armour and would rely on their agility for protection in combat.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Swordsmiths were originally blacksmith-cutlers specializing in blades for swords, knives, daggers and other hand-held side-arms.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 14th century, the making of armour started to become specialised and separate from the blacksmith's craft. Specialist professions came into being – armourers, plate-smiths and helmet makers, who not only produced, but also sold their wares. As regards weapons, there were new specialised professions – the swordsmith, bladesmith, fletcher, arrowsmith, and in later centuries the gunsmith, bowyer or shieldsmith, making wooden and metal shields.</paragraph><paragraph>The price of a complete suit of armour was very high, affordable only to wealthy noblemen. Those who could not afford a complete suit of armour would have only partial metal armour and would rely on their agility for protection in combat.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A Jewish prayer room designed for worship as well as for social and educational gatherings. In Hebrew it is referred to as the 'house of prayer', in Yiddish it is labeled 'school'. It serves as a center of spiritual and social life for the Jewish community. It tends to be oriented eastward (towards Jerusalem), with a tabernacle in the eastern wall and the scrolls of Torah (scriptures) hidden there. In the middle of the synagogue there is an elevated place, a so-called bema, used for reciting prayers and reading from the Torah. In Orthodox communities there is a separate area for men and women, but in most Jewish communities the area is shared.</paragraph><paragraph>Jews celebrate their festive day on saturday (Shabbat), but prayers are held every day.</paragraph><paragraph>One of the oldest Gothic synagogues in Europe is located in Prague (the Old New Synagogue).</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Jewish prayer hall, used for religious services as well as for social and educational gatherings, is known in Hebrew as a "house of prayer" and in Yiddish as a "school." It serves the Jewish community as a center for both spiritual and social life. It is typically oriented towards the east (towards Jerusalem), with the eastern wall housing an ark that contains the Torah scrolls. In the center of the synagogue is a raised platform called the bimah, used for leading prayers and reading from the Torah. In Orthodox communities, there are separate spaces for men and women, but in most Jewish congregations, the space is mixed.</paragraph> <paragraph>Jews celebrate their holy day on Saturday (Shabbat), but prayers are conducted every day.</paragraph> <paragraph>One of the oldest Gothic synagogues in Europe is located in Prague (the Old-New Synagogue).</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, various groups of soldiers, bandits, guardsmen or lone combatants roamed the lands, often changing their place of abode. They lived in makeshift huts, shelters or tents around a central fire. Sometimes they stayed in one camp for several days, sometimes for only one night, and then moved again.</paragraph><paragraph>The availability of water, food, fodder, and wood were key factors in choosing a <accent>suitable camp location</accent>. It was unusual to camp in the villages or in and around the castle. Only noblemen's retinues and nobility spent the night there. In times of war or when on the run, they camped in the open air since there was no time to raise or break down tents.</paragraph><paragraph>The lordly armies camped in places where the summoned crown forces, reinforcements or allies gathered. The longest encampments (sometimes lasting several months) were at <accent>the siege of forts</accent> or on the banks of a river where enemy troops were waiting on the other side.</paragraph><paragraph>The tents were intentionally erected close together for security reasons (like battlements). The largest tent in the centre of the camp belonged to the commander, nearby tents housed nobles and high-ranking soldiers, surrounded by simple shelters and huts for the ordinary soldiers and their horses. The troops could camp separately in several places. In the larger camps there was a field chapel, a place to treat the wounded or a makeshift brothel.</paragraph><paragraph>Long-term camping was challenging logistically, supplies always being the responsibility of the administrator of the nearest affiliated township. If the army was on hostile territory, it would send out <italic>provisioning detachments</italic> to procure food and fuel. When supplies ran short, it was time to move or give up the campaign.</paragraph><paragraph>It was difficult to maintain adequate <accent>hygiene</accent> and <accent>moral</accent> in the camp. Soldiers were threatened by epidemics, mutual quarrels and brawls. Disputes were strictly judged to keep order.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, various groups of soldiers, bandits, guards, or lone warriors roamed the lands, often changing their place of residence. They lived in makeshift buildings, shelters, or tents erected around a central fire. Sometimes they stayed in one camp for several days, sometimes only for one night before moving again.</paragraph><paragraph>Key factors for choosing a <accent>suitable campsite</accent> included access to water, food, fodder, and wood. Camps were rarely set up in villages or near castles. Only the retinues of lords and nobility stayed there. During wars or while fleeing, they camped under the open sky, as there was no time to build or dismantle a camp.</paragraph><paragraph>The lordly armies camped at places where the summoned national militia, reinforcements, or allies gradually gathered. The longest encampments (sometimes lasting several months) occurred during the <accent>siege of fortresses</accent> or on riverbanks, where an enemy army waited on the other side.</paragraph><paragraph>Tents were intentionally set up close to each other for security (like walls). The largest, in the centre of the camp, was the commander's, and the tents nearby served nobles and officers. Simple shelters for soldiers and horses surrounded these. The army could camp separately in several locations. Larger camps often included a field chapel, a place for treating the wounded, or an improvised brothel.</paragraph><paragraph>Long-term camping was more challenging due to the need for supplies, which were always provided by administrators of nearby affiliated townships. If the army was on enemy territory, <italic>foraging units</italic> were sent out to find food and wood. If supplies were insufficient, they had to move or abandon the campaign.</paragraph><paragraph>It was difficult to maintain adequate <accent>hygiene</accent> and <accent>morale</accent> in the camp. Soldiers were threatened by epidemics, mutual quarrels, and fights. Disputes were strictly judged to maintain order.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Until the 13th century, the Tanners sold their wares for processing to Suturers and Cobblers. Cloth was made by Weavers, but traded by <accent>Clothiers</accent>, who also often they cut and sold it by the cubit, forearm length. Only later, during the high Middle Ages, did <accent>tailors</accent> sew cut pieces into garments.</paragraph><paragraph>Simple garments were sewn by women themselves, for their families. It was an issue to make sure the garments were well-sewn, since they were inherited and would often last for years, with minor repairs.</paragraph><paragraph>By the beginning of the 14th century people in larger cities were paying ever more heed to fashion. A tailor would begin to specialize in only one kind of garment, hence we find coatmakers, hosiers, hoodmakers, gantiers, hatters, capemakers, and those who did alterations and repairs to old clothes. In a small town, the tailor had to be general-purpose.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Until the 13th century, tanners sold their goods to be processed by stitchers and cobblers. Weavers prepared cloth, but it was the <accent>cloth merchants</accent> who often cut it and sold it by the yard. Later, in the High Middle Ages, <accent>tailors</accent> sewed cut pieces into clothes.</paragraph><paragraph>Simple garments were sewn by women for their families at home. Care was taken to sew clothes thoroughly, as clothing was inherited and often lasted for years, with minor repairs.</paragraph><paragraph>In the early 14th century, people in larger towns began to pay more attention to fashion. Tailors started to specialise in only one type of clothing, so in the Middle Ages, we find coat makers, hosiers, doublet makers, glove makers, hatters, cloak makers, and second-hand dealers who repaired old clothes. In smaller towns, tailors had to be able to sew anything due to lower demand.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Tanner was the artisan who prepared and treated animal skins. Once softened he then passed them on to cobblers, saddlers or other craftsmen, who turned them into garments, bags, flasks etc.</paragraph><paragraph>It was not a pleasant job, because the skin had to be quickly scraped of its fat and conserved to stop it going off, which was done by immersing in urine. In view of the unsavoury smells they gave off, tanners settled on the outskirts of towns and belonged to the same reviled group as executioners, knackers and prostitutes.</paragraph><paragraph>To turn hide into a material for shoes or clothing, after skinning the animal it must first be thoroughly soaked in water. Once softened, it is fleshed, the residual gore and membranes are scraped off, with a long dull paring knife. In order to rid the hide of fur, it had to be soaked in limewater or rubbed with slaked lime, then scudded. It was then tanned using alum (by a Currier), with fishoil (by the Chamoisier) or with tannins (dealt with by Tanner) from oak, beech or other tree bark.</paragraph><paragraph>During this whole lengthy process the hide softened, was stopped from decomposing and optionally turned a different colour. At the end of the process, the hides were submerged for a few weeks in vats or pits full of urine. The leather thus produced was then dried, possibly coated, painted or polished.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A tanner was a craftsman who tanned and processed animal hides. Once softened, these hides were handed over to cobblers, saddlers, or other craftsmen who used them to make clothing, bags, dishes, and more.</paragraph><paragraph>It was not a pleasant job, as the hides needed to be quickly stripped of fat and preserved to prevent spoilage, which involved soaking them in vats of urea. Due to the strong unpleasant odor, tanners were located on the outskirts of towns and belonged to the same reviled group as executioners, knackers, and prostitutes.</paragraph><paragraph>To transform hides into material for shoes or clothing, they had to be soaked in water after being stripped from the animal. Once softened, they were scraped of any remaining flesh and membranes using a long blunt knife. To remove fur, hides were soaked in lime water for two weeks or smeared with slaked lime. They were then tanned using either alum (handled by a tawer), fats (handled by a chamoiser), or tannins (handled by the tanner) from oak, beech, or other barks.</paragraph><paragraph>This lengthy process made the hides supple, prevented decomposition, and sometimes changed their color. At the end of the process, hides were soaked in vats or pits of urea for several weeks. The tanned leathers were then dried, sometimes oiled, dyed, and polished.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Both plant and animal fibres were used to make textiles. In the beginning, mainly bast fibres (willow, linden) and various grasses were used. Later, plants particularly suitable for textile production, such as flax and hemp, were also bred. Hemp fibre is strong, coarser and darker than flax, but not flexible, so it is not very suitable for use in clothing and has been used more for ropes and cordage. Cotton was unknown in Europe until the late Middle Ages.</paragraph><paragraph>The most common animal raw material was wool, which has good thermal insulation properties, high absorbency, is flexible and dyes well. It was combed or sheared from sheep.</paragraph><paragraph>Silk was imported from Asia as a rare import.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Both plant and animal fibres were used to make textiles. In the beginning, mainly bast fibres (willow, linden) and various grasses were used. Later, plants particularly suitable for textile production, such as flax and hemp, were also bred. Hemp fibre is strong, coarse and darker than flax, but not flexible, making it less suitable for clothing and instead was used more for ropes and cordage. Cotton was unknown in Europe until the late Middle Ages.</paragraph><paragraph>The most common animal raw material was wool, which has good thermal insulation properties, high absorbency, elasticity and dyes well. It was combed or sheared from sheep.</paragraph><paragraph>Silk was imported from Asia as a rare and luxurious commodity.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Numerous folk tales mention the “thunderstone” – an object that supposedly falls to the ground along with lightning during a storm. Sometimes it falls immediately; other times it appears only after seven days, months, or even years. Its size is said to depend on the strength of the lightning, the depth it burrowed into upon impact, and the manner in which it later surfaced.</paragraph><paragraph>This led to various popular beliefs about it, which, however, had little basis in reality. In fact, “thunderstone” referred to various prehistoric stone tools or different types of stones notable for their unusual colour, shape, or unique location in the landscape.</paragraph><paragraph>The thunderstone was reputedly believed to bring abundant crops and to protect fields from lightning, hail, and pests. One custom stemming from pagan traditions was, for example, placing a thunderstone into seeds at sowing time.</paragraph><paragraph>The stone, however, had not only a magical but also a practical function. It was used to mark territorial boundaries and served as a safeguard for clearly defined territory. Sometimes it could even become part of tools or weapons.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Numerous folk tales mention the “thunderstone” – an object that supposedly falls to the ground along with lightning during a storm. Sometimes it falls immediately; other times it appears only after seven days, months, or even years. Its size is said to depend on the strength of the lightning, the depth it burrowed into upon impact, and the manner in which it later surfaced.</paragraph><paragraph>This led to various popular beliefs about it, which, however, had little basis in reality. In fact, “thunderstone” referred to various prehistoric stone tools or different types of stones notable for their unusual colour, shape, or unique location in the landscape.</paragraph><paragraph>The thunderstone was reputedly believed to bring abundant crops and to protect fields from lightning, hail, and pests. One custom stemming from pagan traditions was, for example, placing a thunderstone into seeds at sowing time.</paragraph><paragraph>The stone, however, had not only a magical but also a practical function. It was used to mark territorial boundaries and served as a safeguard for clearly defined territory. Sometimes it could even become part of tools or weapons.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, the merchant settlements and villages on major trade routes or around castles became the first towns. They were founded by specialized businessmen, the so-called <italic>locators</italic>. Their task was to seek out settlers, to prepare and apportion the land and to build a community.</paragraph><paragraph>The ruler set down the rights and obligations concerning the locators and settlers, e.g. the level and method of collecting taxes and benefits, town privilege rules of self-government (capital justice rights), trading (market rights and 'one-mile' selling right) and brewing and handling beer (brewing rights). Newly established settlements and cities were often exempt from taxes for a certain period (hence many Czech villages are called <italic>Lhota</italic>).</paragraph><paragraph>Towns were of different types; royal, seigneurial, mining and dowry (which belonged to the Queen). Seigneurial towns were divided into ecclesiastical, secular (feudal) and those of the Royal Chamber.</paragraph><paragraph>Apart from the feudal settlements, towns were mostly rectangular in layout with streets perpendicular to a central square featuring a Town Hall, market and a church. Until the 14th century, the main streets and squares of the largest towns remained unpaved (uncobbled).</paragraph><paragraph>Waste was emptied directly into the street or thrown into waste pits dug around the houses, despite the fact that sanitation had existed since antiquity. Gutters of rammed earth carried sewage and rainwater alongside the streets and an unpleasant smell remained hovering over the town. Settlements were surrounded by wooden palisades, and from the second half of the 13th century, there had to be at least two gates through it.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, the merchant settlements and villages on major trade routes or around castles became the first towns. They were founded by specialised entrepreneurs, the so-called <italic>locators</italic>. Their task was to seek out settlers, prepare and apportion land and build a community.</paragraph><paragraph>The ruler set down the rights and obligations concerning the locators and settlers, e.g. the level and method of collecting taxes and benefits, town privilege rules of self-government (capital justice rights), trading (market rights and 'one-mile' selling rights) and brewing and handling beer (brewing rights). Newly established settlements and cities were often exempt from taxes for a certain period (lhůta) from which is derived the name of many Czech villages, <italic>Lhota</italic>).</paragraph><paragraph>Towns were of different types; royal, seigneurial, mining and dowry (which belonged to the Queen). Seigneurial towns were divided into ecclesiastical, secular (feudal) and those of the Royal Chamber.</paragraph><paragraph>Apart from the feudal settlements, towns were mostly rectangular in layout with streets perpendicular to a central square featuring a Town Hall, market and a church. Until the 14th century, the main streets and squares of the largest towns remained unpaved (uncobbled).</paragraph><paragraph>Waste was emptied directly into the street or thrown into waste pits dug around the houses, despite the fact that sanitation had existed since antiquity. Gutters of rammed earth carried sewage and rainwater alongside the streets and an unpleasant smell hovered over the towns. Settlements were surrounded by wooden palisades, and from the second half of the 13th century, walls, which had to have at least two gates.</paragraph>

<paragraph>That the European Middle Ages were not very hygienic, is well known. During these times most domestic waste did not end up more than a few steps away from the house. For one thing, there wasn't that much of it, and for another, most (if not all) of it was of organic origin. People were thrifty and were real masters at using every last bit of it.</paragraph><paragraph>Leftovers in food preparation were minimal, and the same was true for processing animal products. Old clothes were re-stitched, old dishes repaired, furniture survived generations. As a result, most waste was produced by people's own digestion. At best, this waste ended up in the compost heap, where it eventually became good and quality dirt (though the compost heap itself was just behind the house), or in the waste pit, or at worst in the river or on the street, where it formed the iconic mud.</paragraph><paragraph>Since the wells were directly under the town houses, or water from the river was taken for drinking, there was no shortage of epidemics of typhoid, cholera, or jaundice.</paragraph><paragraph>Other waste, not yet mentioned, ended just outside the city walls, or in the case of villages, behind the nearest embankment. Not infrequently the ditches along the walls were rather bottomless rubbish dumps.</paragraph>

<paragraph>It's well known that medieval Europe was not particularly hygienic. Most household waste ended up just a few meters from the house. There wasn't as much waste as today, and most of it (if not all) was organic in nature. People were frugal and true masters at using everything down to the last piece.</paragraph><paragraph>Food preparation scraps were minimal, and the same was true for processing animal products. Old clothes were remade, old dishes repaired, and furniture lasted for generations. Consequently, the most waste produced by people came from their own digestion. This waste ended up, at best, in compost, which over time became good, quality soil (though the compost heap itself was right behind the house), or in a cesspit, and at worst, in the river or on the street, where it contributed to the iconic mud.</paragraph><paragraph>Since wells were directly beneath urban houses, or water was taken from the river for drinking, epidemics of typhoid, cholera, and hepatitis were common.</paragraph><paragraph>Other waste, which we haven't yet mentioned, ended up just outside the city walls or, in the case of villages or artisanal production, behind the nearest embankment. Not infrequently, the ditches along the walls were more like bottomless rubbish dumps.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Merchants were of two types – the regular (permanent) and the travelling (occasional). The regulars had their shops permanently in towns and villages, the travelling only brought their wares to the markets.</paragraph><paragraph>Markets (held once a week) or fairs (held twice a year), also offered wares by local shopkeepers, visitors, and pedlars or hawkers – street vendors without a fixed location. Shopkeepers had their permanent shops on the square, wholesale merchants ran small shops and had the right to retail products they bought from artisans.</paragraph><paragraph>Village folk got their supplies from neighbouring artisans, in the local tavern or from a merchant who brought supplies larger municipalities. At the markets, goods from the village would change hands for goods produced and available in the town. The terms of trade were set by the ruler, for example that only local merchants in sworn possession of freedom of the city rights could sell their goods freely. Only the traders from large cities would venture abroad.</paragraph><paragraph>Many regulations and detailed rules governed trade. If it were found that a merchant is a rogue and, e.g. swindles on the scales, he was severely punished.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Merchants were of two types – settled (permanent) and travelling (occasional). The settled traders had permanent shops in towns and villages, while travelling merchants only brought their wares to the markets.</paragraph><paragraph>Markets (held once a week) and fairs (held twice a year) also offered wares by local stallholders, visitors and pedlars or hawkers – street vendors without a fixed site. Stallholders had their permanent stalls on the square, merchants ran small shops and had the right to retail products purchased from craftsmen.</paragraph><paragraph>Village folk got their supplies from neighbouring craftspeople, in the local tavern or from a merchant who brought supplies from larger townships. At the markets, goods from the village would be exchanged for goods produced and available in the town. The terms of trade were set by the ruler, for example, only local merchants who had sworn to uphold city rights could sell their goods freely. Only the traders from large cities would venture abroad.</paragraph><paragraph>Many regulations and detailed rules governed trade. If it were found that a merchant was dishonest and, for example, gave short weight, he was severely punished.</paragraph>

<paragraph>It served as a figurative description of the ideal medieval society. The theory was that God divided society into three groups: warriors, clerics and peasants. The warriors were supposed to defend society and included nobility, soldiers and executors of state power. The clergy cared for salvation and education, and those serving the church or educated scholars could also be included here. The last category included the greatest mass of society; the task of the peasants was to work and feed the whole society.</paragraph><paragraph> A well-known Latin proverb says: Tu ora, tu protege, tu labora. (You pray, you protect, you work) Though the division into classes is determinant and limits the freedom of social mobility, at the same time it guarantees social harmony. Everyone knows where his place is, what is expected of him and what plans God has for him. </paragraph><paragraph> It wasn’t until the 15th century that some church reformers began to break down the teachings. For example, Petr Chelčický (a follower of John Hus) came up with a bold thesis that all people are equal.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Serving as a figurative description of the ideal medieval society, the theory was that God divided society into three groups: warriors, clerics and peasants. The warriors were supposed to defend society and included nobility, soldiers and executors of state power. The clergy cared for salvation and education, and those serving the church and educated scholars could also be included here. The last category comprised the greatest mass of society; the task of the peasants was to work and feed the whole society.</paragraph><paragraph> A well-known Latin proverb says: Tu ora, tu protege, tu labora. (You pray, you protect, you work) Though the division into classes is determinant and limits the freedom of social mobility, at the same time it guarantees social harmony. Everyone knows their place, what is expected of them and what plans God has for them. </paragraph><paragraph> It wasn’t until the 15th century that some church reformers began to dismantle this teaching. For example, Petr Chelčický (a follower of John Hus) came up with the bold thesis that all people are equal.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Around Trosky Castle today there is a system of several ponds. Although they were built in the 16th century, we decided to leave them in place because of the amazing views that their surroundings offer.</paragraph><paragraph>The largest of the ponds is Věžák, which covers an area of 9 hectares, the others are Vidlák, Rokytňák, Krčák, Hrudka and Dolní rybník. In the Middle Ages, the Nebákov castle stood near the Nebák pond.</paragraph><paragraph>The area is now called the Podtrosecká údolí nature reserve. It is the largest complex of wetland biotopes in the Bohemian Paradise and is home to many species of strictly protected organisms. If you ever decide to visit Trosky Castle, we recommend you stop by this nearby locality as well.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Today, there is a system of several ponds around the Trosky Castle. Although they were built in the 16th century, we decided to leave them in place because of the amazing views that their surroundings offer.</paragraph><paragraph>The largest of the ponds is the Rocktower Pond, which covers an area of 9 hectares, the others are Vidlák, Rokytňák, Kerchak, Hrudka and Lower Pond. In the Middle Ages, Nebakov Fortress stood near Nebakov Pond.</paragraph><paragraph>The area is now a nature reserve, called Podtrosecká Valley. It is the largest complex of wetland habitats in the Bohemian Paradise region and is home to many species of strictly protected organisms. If you ever decide to visit Trosky Castle, we recommend you stop by this nearby locality as well.</paragraph>

<heading>Troskowitz</heading><paragraph>The first mention is found in 1388 in connection with the nearby castle, but the village probably stood here long before that. The village got its name from the rock on which the castle was later built. As the rock, actually resembled the ruins of a castle from a distance.</paragraph><heading>Tachov</heading><paragraph>A small village 1.5 km north of Troskowitz, first mentioned in sources in 1388. A nameless stream flows through it, flowing into the Krčák pond, forming cascades along the way and a waterfall about 10 metres high.</paragraph><paragraph> Today, the village is part of a protected area and the <italic>'Golden Trail of the Bohemian Paradise'</italic> passes through it.</paragraph><heading>Zhelejov</heading><paragraph>There are only a few mentions about Zhelejov, namely that in 1558, when three sons of Lord Semine sold the fortress and the village to the 'Skalské panství'. The fortress was abandoned during the wars with the Swedes.</paragraph>

<heading>Troskowitz</heading><paragraph>The first mention is found in 1388 in connection with the nearby castle, but the village probably existed long before that. The village got its name from the rock on which the castle was later built, as the rock resembled the ruins of a castle from a distance.</paragraph><heading>Tachov</heading><paragraph>A small village 1.5 km north of Troskowitz, first mentioned in sources in 1388. A nameless stream flows through it, emptying into the Krčák pond, forming cascades along the way and a waterfall about 10 metres high.</paragraph><paragraph>Today, the village is part of a protected area and the <italic>'Golden Trail of the Bohemian Paradise'</italic> passes through it.</paragraph><heading>Zhelejov</heading><paragraph>There are only a few mentions of Zhelejov. Notably, in 1558, the three sons of Lord Semine sold the fortress and the village to the 'Skalské panství'. The fortress was abandoned during the wars with the Swedes.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Trosky Castle was built around 1380 by Čeněk of Vartenberk between two basalt rock formations of a long-extinct volcano. The castle derived its name from the shape of the rock, which resembled the ruins of a collapsed castle.</paragraph><paragraph>After his death, the castle passed to King Wenceslas IV, from whom it was acquired by Otto III von Bergow, who is listed as the owner since 1399.</paragraph><paragraph>Structurally, the castle consists of two landmarks still standing today: the Crone tower, and the Maiden tower. Between them is located the elongated castle core with two palaces, on the northern side passing into a fortified forecourt. The whole castle is very rugged, and it is necessary to cover a long distance and elevation to get from one end to the other.</paragraph><paragraph>Neither of the entrance gates were protected by a moat - it was not necessary, given the other dispositions of the castle. The gate leads to the eastern part, where the three-story residential palace used to stand. On the west side there was a second palace built mainly of wood. On its ground floor was a forge, which was in use until the 17th century.</paragraph><paragraph>Today the castle is open from spring to autumn and is one of the most visited ruins in Bohemia. The ramparts and the gate have been repaired and the lower tower has a lookout tower open to the public with a far-reaching view of the entire Bohemian Paradise region.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Trosky Castle was built around 1380 by Čeněk of Vartenberk between two basalt rock formations of a long-extinct volcano. The castle derived its name from the shape of the rock, which resembled the ruins of a collapsed castle.</paragraph><paragraph>After Čeněk's death, the castle passed to King Wenceslas IV, from whom it was acquired by Otto III von Bergow, who is listed as the owner since 1399.</paragraph><paragraph>Structurally, the castle consists of two landmarks still standing today: the <accent>Crone tower</accent>, and the <accent>Maiden tower</accent>. Between them lies an elongated castle core with two palaces, transitioning into a fortified outer bailey on the northern side. The entire castle is rugged and complex, traversing it requires covering a long distance with elevation changes.</paragraph><paragraph>Neither of the entrance gates were protected by a moat - it was not necessary, given the other defenses. The gate leads to the eastern part, where the three-story residential palace once stood. On the western side there was a second palace primarily built of wood. On its ground floor was a forge, which was in use until the 17th century.</paragraph><paragraph>Today the castle is accessible from spring to autumn and is one of the most visited ruins in Bohemia. The ramparts and the gate have been restored and the lower tower has a viewing platform open to the public with a far-reaching view of the entire Bohemian Paradise region.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The first tournaments were held in France in the 10th century under Henry I. They quickly became a favourite pastime of the courts, later spreading throughout Europe and entertaining everyone of all statuses. The tournaments were multi-day celebrations accompanied by the contest itself as well as many ceremonies of symbolic significance, feasts, banquets, balls, etc.</paragraph><paragraph>Tournaments were held by the nobility to celebrate the culmination of important political negotiations or extraordinary events such as coronations, weddings and engagements of rulers, oaths of allegiance, peace negotiations, etc. The aim was to demonstrate skill and the best technique in weapons combat, to shine before others and often to come in for a fat reward. The tournaments were classic, where two knights on horseback or on foot faced each other, or mass tournaments, where two tournament teams competed in the arena. In both cases, the goal was the same - to knock the opponent down, but not to kill or injure him. Even so, injuries and deaths were common.</paragraph><paragraph>The Church initially came out strongly against tournaments, only in the 14th century abolishing the universal curse on all participants and allowing them to be held with impunity.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The first tournaments took place in France in the 10th century during the reign of Henry I. They quickly became a popular entertainment initially at courts, later spreading throughout Europe and captivating people of all social standings. Tournaments were multi-day celebrations accompanied by actual combat and numerous ceremonies with symbolic significance, solemn religious services, feasts, dances, and more.</paragraph> <paragraph>Tournaments were organized by the nobility to celebrate the culmination of important political negotiations or extraordinary events such as coronations, royal weddings and engagements, oaths of allegiance, peace negotiations, and so forth. The aim was to demonstrate skill and mastery in combat, to shine in front of others, and often to receive substantial rewards. Tournaments were either individual, where two knights faced each other on horseback or on foot, or team-based, where two teams competed in the arena. In both cases, the objective was to knock the opponent to the ground without killing or seriously injuring them. Even so, injuries and even deaths were not uncommon.</paragraph> <paragraph>The Church initially strongly opposed tournaments, and it wasn't until the 14th century that it lifted the general ban and allowed their organized and unpunished conduct.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Medieval education, unfortunately, tended to favour men, while women were not allowed to enter universities and were generally not expected to be able to read, let alone pursue an education, regardless of wealth or family background. Yet we know of a few exceptions.</paragraph><paragraph>One of them is <accent>Christine de Pizan</accent> (1364-1430), the first female author in the history of French literature, who wrote philosophical, political, legal, and even military-oriented works and advocated for women's rights.</paragraph><paragraph>Another may be <accent>Maria Hebraea</accent> (died 637), a famous Jewish alchemist whose life is shrouded in legend, or another alchemist called Cleopatra, who lived in Alexandria during the 3rd and 4th centuries and is said to have been able to produce the philosopher's stone.</paragraph><paragraph>Also deserving an important mention is <accent>Hildegard of Bingen</accent> (1098-1179), a Christian mystic, naturalist, physician, composer and writer, very influential for her time and later the often quoted author of <italic>Ordo virtutum</italic> (moral theology) or <italic>Causae et curae</italic> (medicine), among other works.</paragraph><paragraph>In later centuries, women's participation in education and literature gradually increased, although the first admission of women to a university did not take place until 1836, in Zurich.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Medieval education unfortunately favoured men, as women were not allowed entry into universities and were generally not expected to be literate or pursue education, regardless of their wealth or lineage. However, there are a few exceptions known to us.</paragraph> <paragraph>One of them is <accent>Christine de Pisan</accent> (1364-1430), the first female author in the history of French literature, who wrote philosophical, political, legal, and even militarily oriented works and advocated for women's rights.</paragraph> <paragraph>Another example could be <accent>Maria Hebraea</accent>, a famous Jewish alchemist whose life is surrounded by legends, or another alchemist known as Cleopatra, who lived in Alexandria during the 3rd-4th century and allegedly could produce the philosopher's stone.</paragraph> <paragraph>Notable mention also goes to <accent>Hildegard of Bingen</accent> (1098-1179), a Christian mystic, naturalist, physician, musical composer, and writer who was highly influential in her time and later cited author of works such as <italic>Ordo Virtutum</italic> (morality play) and <italic>Causae et Curae</italic> (medicine), among others.</paragraph> <paragraph>In later centuries, women's contributions to education and literature gradually increased, although the first admission of women to a university did not occur until 1836 in Zurich.</paragraph>

<paragraph>One of the oldest universities in Europe was Charles University, founded in 1348 by Charles IV. Students could study at the faculties of arts, theology and medicine and later also at the law faculty. The faculty of arts was intended to extend basic ecclesiastical education and to teach grammar, rhetoric, dialectics, arithmetic, geometry, astronomy and music. At the beginning of the 15th century, more than 1000 students were educated here, for whom there were also accommodation facilities, the so-called dormitories. 80% of the students at the University of Prague came from abroad (mainly from Hungary, Austria, Poland or Germany)</paragraph><paragraph>The medieval university could be graduated with a bachelor's, master's and doctoral degree. An oral examination before a committee was a prerequisite. Some fields of study took longer than today - perhaps over 10 years. After passing the final exams, the student received a diploma.</paragraph><paragraph>From the earliest times, the university was headed by the rector and the deans of the individual faculties, as well as members of the university council and, below them, numerous supervisors: professors and cantors. Among others, Jan Hus lectured and held the highest positions at the university.</paragraph>

<paragraph>One of the oldest universities in Europe was Charles University, founded in 1348 by Charles IV. Students could study at the Faculty of Arts, Theology, Medicine, and later also at the Law Faculty. The Faculty of Arts aimed to expand basic church education and teach grammar, rhetoric, dialectics, arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, and music. By the early 15th century, more than 1000 students were enrolled, accommodated in collegiate housing known as colleges. 80% of the students at the Prague university came from abroad, particularly from Hungary, Austria, Poland, and Germany.</paragraph><paragraph>In medieval times, one could graduate from university with a Bachelor's, Master's, or Doctor's degree. The requirement included an oral examination before a committee. Some fields of study took longer than today – up to more than 10 years. Upon passing the final exams, the student received a diploma.</paragraph><paragraph>Since its inception, the university has been led by a rector and deans of individual faculties, along with members of the university council and numerous instructors: professors and lecturers. Among its lecturers and prominent figures was Jan Hus, who also held high positions at the university.</paragraph>

<paragraph>At the turn of the 14th and 15th centuries, Moravia was ravaged by war conflicts between the brothers <accent>Prokop</accent> and <accent>Jobst</accent> of Luxembourg. It was mainly about the inheritance and power of the dynasty, which was trying to win the Polish and Hungarian crowns.</paragraph><paragraph>After the death of Charles IV, both brothers supported the policy of King Sigismund of Hungary, but after the imprisonment of Czech King Wenceslas IV in 1394, Prokop sided with Wenceslas. His reward was permission to occupy the bishop's castles, to which the Pope reacted by imposing a curse and Prokop was subsequently arrested by Sigismund.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1402 Sigismund again imprisoned Wenceslas IV and, together with the Czech king, he then also tricked Prokop into arresting him, who was subsequently held in Presburg (Bratislava). In the same year, Jobst defected from Sigismund to Hungary, to the side of Albrecht of Austria, where an anti-regal uprising had just broken out, and sought the release of his brother and the Czech king. Prokop gained his freedom by making peace between Sigismund and Jobst only after more than two years of imprisonment.</paragraph><paragraph>As a result of the brotherly conflict between Jobst and Prokop, a state of lawlessness arose in Moravia, which was taken advantage of by various marauding knights who raided castles and villages. After the death of Prokop, Jobst became the sole ruler of Moravia, who gradually dealt with his cousins. In 1411, Jobst died without descendants, as did Prokop, and the territory and the title of Margrave of Moravia passed to Wenceslas IV.</paragraph>

<paragraph>At the turn of the 14th and 15th centuries Moravia was plagued by wars between the brothers <accent>Prokop</accent> and <accent>Jobst</accent> of Luxembourg. At issue was the legacy and power of a dynasty that had aspired to the Polish and Hungarian Crowns. After the death of Charles IV, both brothers supported the policies of Hungarian King Sigismund, but when he imprisoned King Wenceslas IV in 1394, Prokop sided with the Bohemian King. In return he was granted the right to occupy episcopal castles which led to his excommunication by the Pope and his subsequent capture by Sigismund. </paragraph><paragraph>In 1402, Sigismund again imprisoned Wenceslas IV and tricked Prokop into captivity in Pressburg (Bratislava). That same year, Jobst switched sides from Sigismund to support Albrecht of Austria in Hungary, where an anti-royalist uprising had just begun, aiming for the release of his brother and the Czech king. Prokop gained his freedom through a peace agreement brokered between Sigismund and Jobst, after more than two years of imprisonment.</paragraph><paragraph>The fraternal conflict between Jobst and Prokop led to anarchy in Moravia, which was exploited by a whole host of robber-barons, who set about attacking castles and villages.</paragraph><paragraph> After Prokop's death, Jobst became the sole ruler of Moravia, and gradually dealt with his cousins. In 1411 Jobst died childless, just as Prokop had done, and the title of Margrave of Moravia reverted to Wenceslas IV.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Wenceslas IV was not a very capable ruler. During his reign, he was kidnapped several times in an attempt to remove him from power.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>The first time</accent> he was captured in Königshof near Beroun in 1394 and taken to Wildberg Castle (Upper Austria). </paragraph><paragraph>In 1402, Wenceslas' brother, King Sigismund of Hungary, who aspired to the Bohemian throne with the support of the high nobility, imprisoned his brother <accent>a second time</accent>. Wenceslas was taken to Vienna, from where he managed to escape in November 1403 with the help of allied lords.</paragraph><paragraph>In the meantime, however, Sigismund managed to impose higher taxes on both towns and monasteries. The towns that refused to submit to him were conquered and plundered. The conflict escalated into a long civil war, which did not subside even after Wenceslas' death.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Wenceslas IV was not a very capable ruler. During his reign, he was kidnapped several times in an attempt to remove him from power.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>The first time</accent> he was captured in Königshof near Beroun in 1394 and taken to Wildberg Castle (Upper Austria). The abduction was carried out by the oposition nobles, the so-called <accent>League of Lords</accent>.</paragraph>In 1402, Wenceslas' brother, King Sigismund of Hungary, who aspired to the Bohemian throne with the support of the high nobility, imprisoned his brother <accent>a second time</accent>. Wenceslas was taken to Vienna, from where he managed to escape in November 1403 with the help of allied lords.</paragraph><paragraph>In the meantime, however, Sigismund managed to impose higher taxes on both towns and monasteries. The towns that refused to submit to him were conquered and plundered. The conflict escalated into a long civil war, which did not subside even after Wenceslas' death.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The word <accent>urbura</accent> comes from the German <italic>Uhrbuhr</italic> and means yield or revenue. This term refers to a form of tax, a tribute that miners paid to the monarch in kind, in extracted resources, in exchange for the right to mine metals within the territory of the Kingdom of Bohemia.</paragraph><paragraph>According to mining law, it was literally the monarch’s share of the profit from metal mining. Urbura was expressed as a portion of the mined metal, which was mostly used for coin production. The collection of urbura was overseen by royal officials known as Urburers. The amount of urbura was determined based on shares and depended on the quantity of ore extracted.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The word <accent>urbura</accent> comes from the German <italic>Urbuhr</italic> and means yield or revenue. This term refers to a form of tax, a tribute that miners paid to the monarch in kind, in extracted resources, in exchange for the right to mine metals within the territory of the Kingdom of Bohemia.</paragraph><paragraph>According to mining law, it was literally the monarch’s share of the profit from metal mining. Urbura was expressed as a portion of the mined metal, which was mostly used for coin production. The collection of urbura was overseen by royal officials known as Urburers. The amount of urbura was determined based on shares and depended on the quantity of ore extracted.</paragraph>

<paragraph>War… war does not change. At least not for the rank-and-file soldiers who always took the worst of it. Nobles and the highborn had it a little easier: for one, because of the incomparably better equipment, food and accommodation during the campaign, but mainly because they had a much higher chance of surviving the battle.</paragraph><paragraph>The reason was simple, they would not be nearly as useful dead; alive, they could fetch a hefty <accent>ransom</accent> from their family or the enemy monarch, or could be exchanged for captured warriors from the captor's side.</paragraph><paragraph>It was thus an unwritten but widespread custom that noble lords would fall into the captivity of another nobleman rather than dead into the mud. The captured magnate gave his rival horses, equipment, and then also a hefty ransom.</paragraph><paragraph>Of course, a noble lord or lady (or their offspring) could be captured by an enemy even outside the heat of battle. These prisoners were also treated as precious commodities and provided with all care. Once again, the main goal was not to harm them, but rather to gain an advantage for negotiation or trade.</paragraph><paragraph>Even the Bohemian king Wenceslas IV was held prisoner at the time of our game. It did not mean he was locked up in a dungeon and given only bread and water. He was interned in luxury, but kept away from all events and with minimal power to influence the situation in Bohemia.</paragraph>

<paragraph>War… war does not change. At least not for the rank-and-file soldiers who always took the worst of it. Nobles and the highborn had it a little easier: not only because of their vastly superior equipment, food and lodging during campaigns, but mainly because they had a much higher chance of surviving the battle.</paragraph><paragraph>The reason was simple, dead nobles were of little worth; alive, they could fetch a hefty <accent>ransom</accent> from families or enemy rulers, or could be exchanged for prisoners from the captor's side.</paragraph><paragraph>It was thus an unwritten but widespread custom that noble lords would fall into the captivity of another nobleman rather than dead into the mud. The captured noble would surrender his horse, armour, and later, a hefty ransom to his captor.</paragraph><paragraph>Of course, a noble lord or lady (or their offspring) could be captured by an enemy even outside the heat of battle. These prisoners were treated as precious commodities and provided with all care. Once again, the main goal was not to harm them, but rather to gain an advantage for negotiation or trade.</paragraph><paragraph>Even the Bohemian king Wenceslas IV was a captive at the time of our game. It did not mean he was locked up in a dungeon and given only bread and water. He was interned in luxury, but kept away from all events and with minimal power to influence the situation in Bohemia.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Windmills became prevalent in Europe between the 11th and 14th centuries. The most suitable environment for their construction was to be found in the foothills of mountains, on plains and in coastal landscapes, where strong air currents abounded.</paragraph><paragraph>They were generally wooden post mills, standing on a characteristic conical trestle log base. They would <accent>rotate</accent> around the central stake to face into the wind. As a rule, the mill had four <accent>vanes</accent> - sails set in a rectangular cross mounted on the front wall of the building. As the wind leant into them, they would turn to move a wooden gearing and transfer the torque to the millstones, located on the first floor.</paragraph><paragraph>The disadvantage of windmills was their frequent need for repair and maintenance, and they were often struck by lightning. When operating, they vibrated intensely, making working in them neither pleasant nor safe.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Windmills became prevalent in Europe between the 11th and 14th centuries. The most suitable environment for their construction was to be found in the foothills of mountains, on plains and in coastal landscapes, where strong winds abounded.</paragraph><paragraph>They were generally wooden post mills, standing on a characteristic conical trestle log base. They could <accent>rotate</accent> around the central stake to face into the wind. As a rule, the mill had four <accent>vanes</accent> - sails set in a rectangular cross mounted on the front wall of the building. As the wind pushed against them, they set wooden gear mechanisms in motion and transferred torque to the millstones, located on the first floor.</paragraph><paragraph>The disadvantage of windmills was their frequent need for repair and maintenance, and they were often struck by lightning. When operating, they vibrated intensely, which was neither pleasant nor safe for those working inside.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Medieval prisons mostly consisted of castle <accent>dungeons</accent>. Later, different types of strongholds for internment of criminals came into being: municipal jails, located at the town hall, and separate prisons for debtors. Prisons held both men and women together; segregation was practiced solely on the basis of social status and the severity of the crime.</paragraph><paragraph>Prison was not intended to serve a remedial function, as nowadays, but rather as a temporary residence for the condemned before punishment of another nature, because no one wanted to have to feed prisoners long-term.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Medieval prisons were mainly castle <accent>dungeons</accent>. Later, different types of strongholds for internment of criminals came into being: municipal jails, located at the town hall or Rathaus, and separate prisons for debtors. Prisons held both men and women together; segregation was only based on social status and the severity of the crime.</paragraph><paragraph>Prison was not intended to serve a remedial function, as nowadays, but rather as a temporary stay for convicts before the execution of their sentence. No one wanted to have to feed prisoners long-term.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Czech village underwent a significant transformation at the turn of the 13th to 14th century. Peasants could inherit land and salaries, and trade began to have clear rules. The shape of villages also changed - from chaotically scattered farmsteads to organised plots with a regular geometric layout with plenty of space for roads and markets. The number of houses ranged from 20 to 25.</paragraph><paragraph>The village centre was the village square - a public space that served as a social, cultural and economic place, with fences defining the village boundaries.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Bohemian villages underwent a significant transformation at the turn of the 13th and 14th centuries. Peasants could inherit farms and wages, and trade began to have clear rules. The shape of the villages also changed – from chaotically scattered homesteads to organized plots with a regular geometric layout providing ample space for roads and markets. The number of houses ranged around 20 to 25.</paragraph><paragraph>The center of the village was the village green – a public space that served as a social, cultural, and economic hub, with fences marking the village boundaries.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Vineyards have a tradition in Europe since the ancient Greece, but it was only the Middle Ages that allowed this noble profession to develop to its full potential. Wine was brought to Bohemia by Charles IV, who liked it so much in France, that he wanted to grow it here. It was at the end of the 14th century, that vineyards were established in Kuttenberg, Mělník and Prague. The spread of vine was also helped by the fact that it was warmer in our country in the Middle Ages and that it could also be grown in locations that were otherwise uninteresting for agriculture (dry, rocky).</paragraph><paragraph>However, you would hardly find the familiar taste of today's wine in the one from the Middle Ages. Because of the lack of preservatives, spices or honey were added to the wine and it was often diluted with water for all-day drinking. It was only with the discovery of the sulphur wick that it was possible to properly disinfect casks and preserve wine for a longer period of time, so the flavourings and preservatives could be dispensed with.</paragraph><paragraph>The vineyards themselves were most often planted on southern (sunny) slopes. The wine was either grown as a ground bush or staked. Today's system of wire 'rows' was not yet in use. Work on the vineyard was year-round. It was pruned twice a year, hoed frequently, and had to be rid of the pests and fungal and mildew diseases. The highlight of the season was the vintage and the subsequent marathon of processing the berries, including pressing, straining, racking into barrels and then fermentation. Each monastery or even private winemaker had its own procedure and methodology, often carefully guarded.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Vineyards have had a tradition in Europe since ancient Greece, but it was in the Middle Ages that this noble profession truly flourished. Wine was brought to Bohemia by Charles IV, who had developed a taste for it in France and wanted it cultivated in our region. It was at the end of the 14th century that vineyards were established in Kuttenberg, Mělník, and Prague. The spread of vines was also facilitated by the warmer climate during the Middle Ages, allowing cultivation in otherwise agriculturally uninteresting locations (dry, rocky areas).</paragraph><paragraph>You would have difficulty finding the familiar taste of today's wine in medieval wine. Due to the lack of preservatives, spices or honey were added to the wine, and it was often diluted with water because it was consumed throughout the day. Only with the discovery of the sulfur wick was it possible to properly disinfect barrels and preserve wine for longer periods, allowing for the abandonment of flavorings and preservatives.</paragraph><paragraph>The vineyards themselves were most commonly planted on southern (sunny) slopes. The wine was either grown as a low bush or trained to climb poles. The modern system of wire “rows” was not yet used. Work in the vineyard was year-round. Pruning was done twice a year, the vineyards were often hoed, and pests and fungal and mildew diseases had to be managed. The peak of the season was the harvest and the subsequent marathon of processing the berries, including pressing, straining, decanting into barrels, and then wine fermentation. Each monastery or private winemaker had their own carefully guarded procedures and methods.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Christianity was adopted in the Czech lands as early as the 10th century, though certain pagan practices remained until later, especially in rural areas, blending seamlessly with rising Christianity. Some of the folk customs were later modified according to Church instructions, others continued unchanged, and yet others were eradicated completely under Church pressure.</paragraph><paragraph> In addition to a deep faith in <accent>saintly patronage</accent>: the saints Wenceslas, Vitus, Nicholas, Ludmilla, Adalbert etc., the Middle Ages revered the Virgin Mary and the various patron saints of the professions.</paragraph><paragraph> One manifestation of medieval piety consisted of <italic>wayside shrines</italic>, <accent>conciliation stones</accent> or <accent>crosses</accent>, put up in large numbers in villages, at intersections and along the main byways.</paragraph><paragraph>In Royal cities and liege towns it was important to collect holy relics, remains and memorabilia to mark the saints. The <accent>cult of saints</accent> was encouraged, and cathedrals and churches gained prestige with the relics they held. (It need not be emphasized that most of the relics were fakes, and that nobody took much issue with it.)</paragraph><paragraph> Devotion was shown in everyday life and accompanied everyone from the cradle to the grave by way of Church rituals, occasions for worship, religious holidays or regulations (for example, the numerous fasts or Lenten days). In some way or other, everyone believed in God; for complete atheism, we have to look to later centuries.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Christianity was adopted in the Czech lands in the 10th century, though certain pagan practices continued, especially in rural areas, where they blended naturally with the emerging Christianity. Some of the folk customs were later modified according to Church instructions, others continued unchanged, and yet others were eradicated completely under Church pressure.</paragraph><paragraph> In addition to a deep faith in <accent>saintly patronage</accent>: the saints Wenceslas, Vitus, Nicholas, Ludmilla, Adalbert etc., the Middle Ages revered the Virgin Mary and the various patron saints of professions.</paragraph><paragraph> Manifestations of medieval piety consisted of <italic>wayside shrines</italic>, <accent>conciliation stones</accent> or <accent>crosses</accent>, put up in large numbers in villages, at intersections and along the main byways.</paragraph><paragraph>In Royal cities and liege towns it was important to collect holy relics, remains and memorabilia to mark the saints. The <accent>cult of saints</accent> was encouraged, and cathedrals and churches gained prestige with the relics they held. (It need not be emphasized that most of the relics were fakes, and that nobody took much issue with it.)</paragraph><paragraph> Devotion was shown in everyday life and accompanied everyone from the cradle to the grave by way of Church rituals, occasions for worship, religious holidays or regulations (for example, the numerous fasts or Lenten days). In some way or other, everyone believed in God; Complete atheism is a matter of later centuries.</paragraph>

<paragraph>By the end of the 14th century, most rural towns had on average up to seven mills – water-powered forging mills, washmills, sawmills, water pumps, bellows (in foundries and smelters) and for beating hemp. </paragraph><paragraph>Each mill consisted of three parts: the engine, the transmission system and the work equipment. The driving mechanism or engine was a <accent>water wheel</accent> and the gearing or transmission system consisted of many gears to convert the force from the slow moving mill wheel to fast motion.</paragraph><paragraph>Work equipment differed according to the particular function of the mill. At the heart of grain mills were <accent>millstones</accent>: a lower, stationary so-called <italic>bedstone</italic> and an upper, rotating so-called <italic>runner</italic>. The grain was ground between the two.</paragraph><paragraph>The mill had to be well situated: the current had to be neither too weak, nor too strong, and in the Czech climate the strength of the current in the river varied greatly with the seasons. This meant the miller also had to build artificial mill runs and weirs with which to control the flow.</paragraph>

<paragraph>By the end of the 14th century, most rural towns had an average of up to seven mills. Water-powered mechanisms operated hammers, fulling mills, sawmills, water pumps, bellows (in forges and foundries), or devices for breaking hemp.</paragraph><paragraph>Each mill consisted of three parts: the motor, the transmission system, and the working device. The motor was the <accent>water wheel</accent>, and the transmission system comprised various components that changed the direction of force, ensuring a smooth transition from the slow rotation of the water wheel to a faster one.</paragraph><paragraph>The working device varied according to the purpose of the structure. The core of grain mills were the <accent>millstones</accent>: the stationary lower stone called the <italic>bedstone</italic> and the rotating upper stone called the <italic>runner</italic>. Grain was ground between these stones.</paragraph><paragraph>Proper placement was crucial for a mill: the current had to be neither too weak nor too strong, and in our climate, the strength of the river current varied significantly with the seasons. Therefore, the miller also had to build artificial channels and weirs to regulate the flow.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Water saws have existed in Europe since the 4th century and in Bohemia they date back to the Middle Ages. The earliest saws were equipped with only one machine, a single-frame, single-bladed saw that cut the log in half. Over time, this was supplemented by a circular saw with a long travelling table, which was used to cut the edge of the board vertically. Other innovations of the time included the extension and improvement of the saw frame blades, but the system itself remained unchanged. A water engine was used to power both types of machine (see Watermill).</paragraph>

<paragraph>Water powered sawmills have existed in Europe since the 4th century and in Bohemia they date back to the Middle Ages. The earliest sawmills were equipped with only one machine, a single-frame, single-bladed saw that cut the log in half. Over time, this was supplemented by a circular saw with a long movable table, which was used to cut the edge of boards vertically. Other innovations of the time included the extension and improvement of saw frame blades, but the system itself remained unchanged. Water motors were used to power both types of machine (see Watermill).</paragraph>

<paragraph>European Middle Age armies were based on the feudal obligation of nobles to serve their fief lord. However, this system, still based on late Roman tradition, applied primarily to defensive warfare, where there was no chance of spoils. If the ruler wanted to wage an offensive campaign he had to pay his knights in addition to the promise of spoils.</paragraph><paragraph>In France and Italy, where warfare was relatively frequent, hence started the formations of mercenary armed companies (<italic>rutta</italic>, <italic>routes</italic>) known as <accent>free companies</accent>. During the war, they fought for pay, but in times of peace, they extorted ransoms from the peasants and plundered on the roads.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 14th century, mercenarism became a trade for thousands of poor nobles. Among the largest groups were the French <italic>Bandes blanches</italic>, the English <italic>White Company</italic>, and the Italian <italic>Compagnia di San Giorgio</italic>. In Bohemia, there was the company around the Lords Jan Sokol of Lamberg and Hynek I of Kunstadt.</paragraph>

<paragraph>European medieval armies were based on the feudal obligation of nobles to serve their liege lord. This system, which originated from late Roman traditions, primarily applied to defensive warfare where there was no opportunity for plunder. If a ruler wanted to lead an offensive campaign, he had to not only promise his knights the prospect of loot but also pay them.</paragraph><paragraph>In France and Italy, where wars were relatively frequent, mercenary armed bands (<italic>rutta</italic>, <italic>routes</italic>) known as <accent>free companies</accent> began to emerge. These companies fought for wages during wars but extorted protection money from peasants and robbed travellers during peacetime.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 14th century, mercenary service became a profession for thousands of impoverished nobles. Among the largest groups were the French <italic>Bandes blanches</italic>, the English <italic>White Company</italic>, and the Italian <italic>Compagnia di San Giorgio</italic>. In Bohemia, there was the retinue surrounding Jan Sokol of Lamberk and Hynek I of Kunstadt.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, wagons were used for travel, agricultural work and warfare. Among the simplest wagons was the two-wheeled carriage, and there was also the ribbed wagon (called a ladder wagon) or one with fixed sides. The earliest high-wheeled wagons had a single central axle connected to the chassis. From the 14th century onwards, two-axle four-wheeled wagons were used. The front axle was not swivellable and so the turning radius was very small. The wagons also did not have trestles, so the coachman either rode one of the horses or walked beside the wagon.</paragraph>In the event of war, wagons could also be used as mobile field forts - a strategy made especially famous during the Hussite Wars, when the strategic use of "wagon forts" won the Caliphs many a battle.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the Middle Ages, carts served for travel, agricultural work, and military purposes. Among the simplest carts were two-wheeled carts, alongside ladder wagons (known as "ladder racks") or carts with solid sides. The oldest carts with tall wheels had a single central axle connected to the chassis. From the 14th century, two-axle four-wheeled carts were used. The front axle was not steerable, resulting in a very small turning radius. These carts also lacked benches, so the coachman either rode on one of the horses or walked alongside the cart.</paragraph><paragraph>In times of war, carts could be used as mobile field fortifications—a strategy notably highlighted during the Hussite Wars, where the strategic use of "wagon forts" won several battles for the Hussites.</paragraph>

<paragraph>It is the hill where in 1142, a memorable battle took place between King Vladislav II and Prince Conrad of Znojmo, supported by the rebellious nobility. The king lost the battle with great loss due to the treachery of his own people.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 13th century, an early Gothic church dedicated to the Visitation of the Virgin Mary was built on the hill, which has survived almost unchanged to the present day.</paragraph><paragraph>Today, a lookout tower with a beautiful view of the surroundings is built on the top at 471m above sea level.</paragraph>

<paragraph>It is the hill where in 1142, a memorable battle took place between King Vladislav II and Prince Conrad of Znojmo, supported by rebellious nobility. The king suffered a great loss due to the treachery of his own people.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 13th century, an early Gothic church dedicated to the Visitation of the Virgin Mary was built on the hill, which has survived almost unchanged to the present day.</paragraph><paragraph>Today, at the summit, at an elevation of 471m above sea level, stands a lookout tower with a beautiful view of the surrounding area.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In Bohemia, wine-growing began to spread from the 10th century, and this especially for liturgical reasons. Between the 11th and 13th centuries, vineyards were mainly for monasteries and the nobility, generally in similar places to where we find wine grown today: mainly in South Moravia. Due to more favourable climatic conditions vineyards were able to grow even in Bohemia, but later, after a global cooling period they died off again.</paragraph><paragraph>Taking care of vines kept vintners occupied all year round, the vintage harvest taking place from October to November, depending on the weather. Wine tended to be grown in places unsuitable for the cultivation of other plants, such as on the rocky south-facing slopes. It could take three to four years to establish a vineyard, and it would be good for thirty to forty years.</paragraph><paragraph>The grapes were gathered and put into vats where they were crushed by treading. White grapes were pressed immediately after crushing and the juice kept in wooden barrels, tarred and sanitized with sulphur, where the wine was left to ferment. Red wine was crushed, rid of grape seeds and left to ferment in open vats, stirred regularly. This produced what is termed the ‘mash', and after a few days this was pressed and the juice poured into barrels.</paragraph><paragraph>King Charles IV was a great wine-lover, who imported grapevines from France together with wine-growing know-how and granted numerous privileges to vintners.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In Bohemia, viticulture began spreading from the 10th century onwards, primarily for liturgical purposes. Between the 11th and 13th centuries, vineyards were established mainly by monasteries and the nobility in locations similar to those where grapes are grown today, especially in southern Moravia. While the favorable climate initially allowed grape cultivation even in Bohemia, a later period of global cooling caused the vines to die off.</paragraph><paragraph>Caring for grapevines occupied winemakers throughout the year, with the harvest traditionally taking place from October to November, depending on the weather. Grapes were typically cultivated in areas unsuitable for other crops, such as rocky southern slopes. Establishing a new vineyard could take three to four years, with optimal productivity lasting around thirty to forty years</paragraph><paragraph>The harvested grapes were collected and then poured into vats, where they were crushed by foot. White grapes were immediately pressed and stored in wooden, pitch-sealed, and sulfurised barrels where fermentation took place. Red grapes were crushed, destemmed, and left to ferment in open vats with regular stirring. This produced a substance known as "must," which was pressed after a few days, and the entire mixture was then transferred to barrels.</paragraph><paragraph></paragraph><paragraph>A great lover of wine was King Charles IV, who imported cultivation methods and certain grape varieties from France and granted numerous privileges to winemakers.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the country or during the wars people went outdoors to relieve themselves, to the cowshed or the dung-heap in the yard. Houses of a higher social standing had a little hut built by the dung-heap. At night, <accent>chamberpots</accent> were used, tucked under beds, emptied on the dung-heap in the morning.</paragraph><paragraph>In the castles and in wealthier homes we would find a <accent>privy</accent> – a toilet, located, whenever possible, in one of the heated rooms in a bay window on the first floor. There wasn't necessarily a door, but inside was a bench seat with a round hole.</paragraph><paragraph>Not uncommonly it was in the banquet hall itself, so one would not have to depart, and could even observe the goings on at table from the privy. Privies used to be in a niche cut in the wall, with a sloping vent shaft, leading to the outside of the building. In either case the faecal matter would fall freely along the castle walls into the ditch or down the slope.</paragraph><paragraph>Privies were gradually upgraded and rinsed through with rainwater. They might also have a flap added that discharged the excrement once the flap was moved by a foot-lever. Despite that, up to the 16th century it was common practice to empty chamberpots out of windows onto city streets.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the countryside or during wars, people would relieve themselves in nature, in the barn, or in the yard near the dung heap. Higher-status homesteads had a small wooden shed built near the dung heap. At night, <accent>chamber pots</accent> were used, kept under the bed, and emptied onto the dung heap in the morning.</paragraph><paragraph>In castles and wealthier homes, one could find a <accent>privy</accent>—a toilet, if possible, located in one of the heated rooms, in a bay window on an upper floor. It didn't always have doors and was equipped with a seat with a round hole.</paragraph><paragraph>It was often located directly in the banquet hall, so the user did not have to leave the room and could observe activities at the table from the privy. Privies were typically in a niche carved into the wall, fitted with a slanted chute that opened to the outside of the building. In both cases, faeces would freely fall along the castle walls into a moat or down a slope.</paragraph><paragraph>Over time, privies were modernised and flushed with rainwater. Additional features were added, such as a flap that released the waste outside, which only opened when stepped on. Despite these advancements, it was still common practice until the 16th century to empty chamber pots out of windows onto the street in cities.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Medicaments in the Middle Ages and Antiquity were the product of good practical knowledge of medicinal plants. Therefore, many medical schools had their own gardens so that fresh garden herbs (dried in winter) were always on hand. Likewise, gardens had their place in monasteries and hospitals.</paragraph><paragraph>In Bohemia the first secular pharmaco-botanical Garden was established in 1341 by John of Luxembourg's apothecary – Henricus Schwab. Great and aesthetically pleasing decorative gardens came along only later.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Medical remedies in the Middle Ages and Antiquity were the product of good practical knowledge of medicinal plants. Therefore, many medical schools had their own gardens so that fresh herbs (dried in winter) were always on hand. Likewise, gardens had their place in monasteries and hospitals.</paragraph><paragraph>In Bohemia the first secular pharmaco-botanical garden was established in 1341 by John of Luxembourg's apothecary – Henricus Schwab. Expansive, aesthetically pleasing ornamental gardens came along only later.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Locks and keys have been made of wood since ancient times, later of metal. The invention of the self-closing latch and the spread of key locking were a breakthrough in the year 1000. To the non-transferable locks appeared padlocks, protected by a metal box. At the same time, the medieval period saw the use of mortise lock systems with a more advanced turn-key design. According to archaeological finds, locks were common in the countryside although often ordinary petcock locks were still used.
