The wealthier townspeople and nobility had their castles lavishly decorated. As late as the 14th century, locks were only nailed to the outside of doors.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Locks and keys have been made from wood since ancient times, later from metal. A significant advancement occurred around the year 1000 with the invention of the automatically engaging latch and the widespread use of locking with a key. In addition to non-portable locks, padlocks protected by metal casings appeared. In the Middle Ages, more advanced sliding lock systems with rotating keys were also used. According to archaeological findings, locks were commonly found in rural areas, although simple latches were still frequently used. Wealthier townspeople and nobility had their locks richly decorated. Even in the 14th century, locks were still only nailed to the outer side of doors.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The marriages of the Middle Ages between members of the nobility and wealthy burghers, were marriages of convenience rather than of love. The higher the <accent>status of the newlyweds</accent>, the less likely it was that they entered into a relationship on the basis of romantic affection. It was not that the ideal of <italic>love at first sight</italic> or <italic>love beyond the grave</italic> no longer existed in the Middle Ages, it was just that the practical side of the matter was not too favourable to these ideas.</paragraph><paragraph>In the first place, there was a need to <accent>increase political influence</accent>; in the second, there was a need to ensure the <accent>continuation of the family line</accent> and succession. Marriage was a means of diplomacy and trade, passing on the crown and hereditary claims to entire empires through it. Not infrequently it was the marriage that sealed a truce between opposing parties or secured an election in the forthcoming provincial assembly.</paragraph><paragraph>Marriage of minors was often decided long before the prospective bride or groom reached sexual maturity.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Marriages of the Middle Ages between members of the nobility and wealthy burghers, were marriages of convenience rather than of love. The higher the <accent>status of the newlyweds</accent>, the less likely it was that they entered into a relationship on the basis of romantic affection. It was not that the ideal of <italic>love at first sight</italic> or <italic>eternal love</italic> didn't exist in the Middle Ages, it was just that the practical side of the matter did not favour these ideas.</paragraph><paragraph>First and foremost, there was a need to <accent>increase political influence</accent>; secondly, there was a need to ensure the <accent>continuation of the family line</accent> and succession. Marriage was a means of diplomacy and trade, through which the passing on of crowns and hereditary claims to entire empires happened. Not infrequently it was marriage that sealed a truce between opposing parties or secured an election in a forthcoming provincial assembly.</paragraph><paragraph>Marriage of minors was often decided long before the prospective bride or groom reached sexual maturity.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the 14th century, production possibilities expanded and the manufacture of stronger and often combined armour came into play. The older ring armour became plate armour thanks to steel processing techniques and the ability to forge larger pieces of plate on automatic hammers. The soldier's head was protected by helmets: e.g., kapalin (so-called iron hat), pawls, and helmets.</paragraph><paragraph>The armour was made by plate makers or helmet makers, most often from a single piece of cloudy sheet metal (skulls, pawls) or knitted from several smaller pieces (kapalin, buckets). The best armour of the early 15th century is considered to be that made in German and Italian countries. The armour of the so-called "combined type" was used by heavy cavalry - the basis was ring armour supplemented by a cloth covering of the limbs and a simpler form of cuirass, cloth coat or just a quilting. Some plate coats and breastplates have a hook on which the knight's lance was supported in battle. If the armour did not have a hook, the spear was inserted into a cut-out in the shield, which covered the left arm controlling the reins and the lower part of the helmet. A very widespread helmet was the bascinet (tread) with a distinctively shaped visor nicknamed the dog's muzzle. Furthermore, iron hats, often with one or two visors, appear abundantly in pictorial sources. The shoulders were protected either by ring sleeves or small epaulettes. A shield was an essential part of the armour.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In the 14th century, manufacturing capabilities expanded, leading to the production of stronger and often combined armours. Older chainmail armours transitioned to plate armour due to advancements in steel processing and the ability to forge larger pieces of metal on automatic hammers. Soldiers' heads were protected by helmets such as the cervelliere (known as the "iron hat"), bascinets, and helms.</paragraph> <paragraph>Armours were crafted by armourers or helmet makers, typically from a single piece of hardened plate (skull caps, bascinets) or riveted together from several smaller pieces (cervelliere, sallet). The finest armour of the early 15th century was considered that made in German and Italian lands. "Combined type" armours were used by heavy cavalry - they consisted of chainmail supplemented with plate armour covering the limbs and simpler forms of cuirasses, plate coats, or quilted jackets. Some plate coats and breastplates were equipped with a hook for the knight's spear. If the armour lacked a hook, the spear was inserted into a slot in the shield, which covered the left arm controlling the reins and the lower part of the helmet.</paragraph> <paragraph>A widely used helmet was the bascinet (sallet) with a distinctly shaped visor nicknamed the "dog snout." Additionally, iron hats with one or two eye slots are frequently depicted in visual sources. Shoulders were protected either by chainmail sleeves or small pauldrons. An indispensable part of the armour was the shield.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The armament of the military garrison or the armour of the town's cash: swords, spears, halberds, bows and arrows, crossbows, armour, helmets and other offensive and defensive armament and firearms were kept there.</paragraph><paragraph>In times of danger it was the duty of all townspeople to join the defence of the town and for this purpose the town had an armoury with armaments for the inhabitants. Even in times of peace, the townspeople were often required to take turns on guard.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The armament of the military garrison or the state armoury of a town's militia: swords, spears, halberds, bows and arrows, crossbows, armour, helmets and other offensive and defensive weapons including firearms.</paragraph><paragraph>In times of danger it was the duty of all townspeople to join the defence of the town and for this purpose the town had an armoury with weapons for the inhabitants. Even in times of peace, townspeople were often required to take turns on guard duty.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The main source of light after sunset in homes was fireplaces and hearths. If that was not enough, torches (torches) and lanterns, candle lanterns, candlesticks and candles were used to light the way or the dwelling in the Middle Ages. Ceramic or metal candlesticks were bowl-shaped and sometimes had a handle in the form of an ear. In these, the wick was dipped in oil, later supplemented by wax. In wealthier mansions, chandeliers were hung from chains from the ceiling. In the villages, simple lamps burned tallow instead of vegetable oils and used torches made of split wood. Tallow candles smelled, smelled and melted. They had to be wiped clean and the tallow collected for further use, so they were placed in candle holders with a bowl.</paragraph><paragraph>In Central Europe in the Middle Ages, beeswax was considered an extremely expensive raw material and appeared, for example, as a form of payment for guild fees ('pay in wax').</paragraph>

<paragraph>The main source of light after sunset in households was fireplaces and hearths. When that was insufficient, torches (flambeaux) were used to illuminate pathways or dwellings in the Middle Ages, along with lanterns, oil lamps and candles. Ceramic or metal oil lamps had a bowl shape, sometimes with a handle. A wick immersed in oil was used in these, and later, wax was added. In wealthier households, chandeliers were hung from the ceiling with chains. In villages, simple lamps burned tallow instead of vegetable oils, and split wood torches were used. Tallow candles were smelly, smoky, and melted quickly. They needed to be wiped, and the tallow collected for reuse, which is why they were placed in holders with a bowl.</paragraph><paragraph>In Central Europe, beeswax was considered an extraordinarily expensive commodity in the Middle Ages and was even used as a form of payment for guild fees ("payment in wax").</paragraph>

<paragraph>Although beggars were on the margins of society, they had their indelible place in it. In the cities, there were hospitals earmarked for them and the Church also provided assistance. <accent>Begging</accent> was allowed at cemetery gates and in front of churches, and each beggar could occasionally go to the baths at municipal expense.</paragraph><paragraph> Some monks were regulars among the beggars, too – called <italic>almsmen</italic> or <italic>mendicants</italic>. The beggars were well-known and tolerated in their communities, but by contrast, it was believed that foreign and wandering beggars brought misfortune.</paragraph><paragraph>There was seldom any shortage of alms, because charity and gifts to the poor were considered prerequisites for salvation.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Although beggars were on the fringes of society, they held an indelible place in it. In cities, there were hospitals designated for them and the Church also provided assistance. <accent>Begging</accent> was allowed at cemetery gates and in front of churches, and each beggar could occasionally visit baths at municipal expense.</paragraph><paragraph>Some monks regularly begged too – called <italic>almsmen</italic> or <italic>mendicants</italic>. The beggars were well-known and tolerated in their communities, but by contrast, it was believed that foreign and wandering beggars brought misfortune.</paragraph><paragraph>There was seldom any shortage of alms, because charity and gifts to the poor were considered prerequisites for salvation.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Unlike today, when the land has long been given over to agriculture, the burgeoning of farming in the Middle Ages brought the need for <accent>new fields</accent> where there were only forests or untilled land. The timber from forest clearing was used for construction, the remaining roots, stumps and scrub were burned, and the ground then levelled.</paragraph><paragraph>The finished fields were cultivated by the <italic>three-field system</italic> – a third of the land lay fallow for two years to recover nutrients - this was used for grazing livestock, which added manure. It was then returned to use and tilled, while in turn another third, which had been used for raising crops, was left to lie fallow. There was thus regular crop rotation to save exhausting the soil.</paragraph><paragraph> In the earliest times, ploughing was done with a simple device called an ard- or scratch-plough. Where the soil was stony, working it was very hard. The tiller had to keep watching the plough and used great force to push it into the ground. Similarly clumsy and imperfect were the <italic>harrows</italic> of the time. After harrowing, any remaining clods of earth would be crumbled with a mattock or wooden mallet. This work was typically done by women and children.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>most common crop</accent>, wheat, used to be full of weeds, and as such not very economical, 15 largish sheaves yielding only about 18 kg of grain, often even less. Harvesting often had to be done using only a sickle for cutting. After drying, the grain was threshed out.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Vegetables and legumes</accent> were cultivated to a greater extent than today, grown in fenced gardens next to houses. These were mostly peas and lentils, but also vetch and beans, and around the villages flax and hemp were grown extensively. Hops were grown in signorial fields for the liege lord's brewery.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Unlike today, when the land has long been given over to agriculture, the burgeoning of farming in the Middle Ages brought the need for <accent>new fields</accent> where there were only forests or untilled land. The timber from forest clearing was used for construction, the remaining roots, stumps and scrub were burned, and the ground then levelled.</paragraph><paragraph>The finished fields were cultivated by the <italic>three-field system</italic> – a third of the land lay fallow for two years to recover nutrients - this was used for grazing livestock, which added manure. It was then returned to use and tilled, while in turn another third, which had been used for raising crops, was left to lie fallow. There was thus regular crop rotation to prevent soil exhaustion.</paragraph><paragraph> In the earliest times, ploughing was done with a simple device called an ard- or scratch-plough. Where the soil was stony, working it was very hard. The tiller had to keep watching the plough and use great force to push it into the ground. Similarly clumsy and imperfect were the <italic>harrows</italic> of the time. After harrowing, any remaining clods of earth would be crumbled with a mattock or wooden mallet. This work was typically done by women and children.</paragraph><paragraph>The <accent>most common crop</accent>, wheat, used to be full of weeds, and as such not very economical, 15 large sheaves yielded only about 18 kg of grain, often even less. Harvesting often had to be done using only a sickle for cutting. After drying, the grain was threshed.</paragraph><paragraph><accent>Vegetables and legumes</accent> were cultivated to a greater extent than today, grown in fenced gardens next to houses. These were mostly peas and lentils, but also vetch and beans, and around the villages flax and hemp were grown extensively. Hops were grown in signorial fields for the liege lord's brewery.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The land cash consisted of the nobility (nobles, lords, landowners) with their retinues, troops of church dignitaries (bishops and, from 1344, archbishops), cash of royal towns, rural magistrates and correctors. It served for the defence of the country and was summoned in cases of necessity by the monarch.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The provincial treasury consisted of the nobility (nobles, lords, knights) with their retinues, units of ecclesiastical dignitaries (bishops and from 1344 also archbishops), funds from royal cities, rural bailiffs, and administrators. It served for the defense of the country and was summoned by the sovereign in times of necessity.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The earthworks were small and rather makeshift dwellings in the form of one room sunk into the ground, which was reached by stairs. The whole was covered by a simple thatched roof. They were the home of poor people or were built as a makeshift for woodcutters, charcoal burners or shepherds who did not live in them all year round.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A dugout shelter is a form of smaller and more makeshift housing, one room dug into the ground with steps leading down into it. It was covered with a simple thatched roof. These were home to poor people, or a provisional shelter for woodcutters, charcoal burners and shepherds, who did not live in them all year round.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Jews settled in Moravia and Bohemia probably before the 10th century. They lived mainly around long-distance trade routes in major centres which in the early Middle Ages were: Olomouc, Brno, Znojmo and the central Elbe River environs. However, most lived in Prague in the Old Town.</paragraph><paragraph>They were under the legal protection of decrees by Wenceslas II and then Charles IV, as the rulers could develop the trade with their support. Over the century, however, the expansion of their activities in trade and finance gave rise to protests from many common classes, especially the Church. This was then reflected in folk rumours and resulted in repeated violence.</paragraph><paragraph>As a result of the protests, their rights were restricted: they could not buy land or houses, had to live in restricted neighbourhoods, and they were only allowed to trade where they were not competitors to locals. They were also not allowed to work as craftsmen or farmers. However, they could lend money at interest (called usury), which was forbidden to the Christian population. Although only a part of the Jews engaged in this activity, it caused many social problems.</paragraph><paragraph>Segregation was also emphasized by the mandatory marking of the Jewish population - for example, they wore a yellow ring on their clothing, a hat of a different shape, women wore a yellow ribbon in their hair, and men had a mandatory beard. In addition, the Church traditionally blamed them for "murdering Christ" and maintaining pagan rituals.</paragraph><paragraph>In the Middle Ages, Jews were considered the "property of the king" and as such were protected by the king, so if the townspeople committed violent attacks against the Jewish community, burning their quarter and murdering the inhabitants (later termed "pogrom"), they had to pay a hefty "compensation" to the king. Some kings welcomed such attacks as a good source of income, others protected the Jews.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Jews settled in Moravia and Bohemia probably before the 10th century. They lived mainly around long-distance trade routes in major centres which in the early Middle Ages were: Olomouc, Brno, Znojmo and the central Elbe River environs. However, most lived in Prague in the Old Town.</paragraph><paragraph>They were under the legal protection of decrees by Wenceslas II and then Charles IV, as the rulers could develop the trade with their support. Over the century, however, the expansion of their activities in trade and finance gave rise to protests from many common classes, especially the Church. This was then reflected in folk rumours and resulted in repeated violence.</paragraph><paragraph>As a result of the protests, their rights were restricted: they could not buy land or houses, had to live in restricted neighbourhoods, and they were only allowed to trade where they were not competitors to locals. They were also not allowed to work as craftsmen or farmers. However, they could lend money at interest (called usury), which was forbidden to the Christian population. Although only a part of the Jews engaged in this activity, it caused many social problems.</paragraph><paragraph>Segregation was also emphasized by the mandatory marking of the Jewish population - for example, they wore a yellow ring on their clothing, a hat of a different shape, women wore a yellow ribbon in their hair, and men had a mandatory beard. In addition, the Church traditionally blamed them for "murdering Christ" and maintaining pagan rituals.</paragraph><paragraph>In the Middle Ages, Jews were considered the "property of the king" and as such were protected by the king, so if the townspeople committed violent attacks against the Jewish community, burning their quarter and murdering the inhabitants (later termed "pogrom"), they had to pay a hefty "compensation" to the king. Some kings welcomed such attacks as a good source of income, others protected the Jews.</paragraph>

<paragraph>At the time of our game, Jews were not allowed to settle permanently in the vicinity of the silver mines, but still, however, there was a community in the town. It was said to be located on the site of the present-day monastery of the Order of St. Vorshila, north of the town centre.</paragraph><paragraph>Otherwise, the Jews tended to concentrate around the town outskirts, and the separate district as we show it in the game never existed. The Kuttenberg synagogue was not built until 1881.</paragraph>

<paragraph>At the time of our game, Jews were not allowed to settle permanently in the vicinity of the silver mines, but still, there was a community in the town. It was said to be located on the site of the present-day Ursuline convent, north of the town centre.</paragraph><paragraph>Otherwise, the Jews tended to concentrate around the town outskirts, and the separate district as we show in the game never existed. The Kuttenberg synagogue was not built until 1881.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Every monastery, especially those of the Benedictine Order, followed specific rules regarding allocation of time, activities and positions in the monastery hierarchy. In addition to worship, devotional reading and copying or illuminating books, the monks laboured physically.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition, members of some monastic orders were not allowed to have any contact with the outside world from the moment of their ordination. They lived only in the <italic>clausure</italic> (an enclosed part of the monastery extending around an inner garden), where no layman was allowed. Only the authorized senior monks and lay brothers, who also ran the entire monastery grounds, communicated with the outside world.</paragraph><paragraph>There were exceptions, however, such as when the monastery included a <accent>school</accent>, a <accent>hospital</accent> (infirmarium), or a <accent>medical workshop</accent> where lay people could be treated in an emergency. Monks educated in medicine could also visit the sick and wounded from nearby villages and towns.</paragraph><paragraph>The monks' usual day was divided by prayers. It began early, after midnight, with the so-called <italic>vigil</italic>. Then (between 3 and 4 o'clock before dawn) the first prayer was held - <italic>lauds</italic>. Then followed <italic>prima</italic> (6am), then <italic>terce</italic> (9am), <italic>sext</italic> (noon) and <italic>none</italic> (3pm). Before sunset, <italic>vespers</italic> was served and at the end (half an hour after sunset) <italic>compline</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>After the morning mass, the brothers gathered in the Chapter Hall to hear the texts from the chapter of the Rule. Then followed the sermon and discussions concerning the monastery. The brothers confessed their sins, repented or obtained penance. Until the noon Mass (sext) they devoted themselves to work or study.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Every monastery, especially those of the Benedictine order, adhered to specific rules regarding time, activities, and the hierarchy within the monastery. Apart from worship, devout reading, and transcribing or illuminating books, monks also engaged in physical work.</paragraph><paragraph>In addition, members of some monastic orders were not allowed any contact with the outside world from the moment of their ordination. They lived only within the <italic>cloister</italic> (the enclosed part of the monastery surrounding the inner courtyard), where no layperson was allowed. Communication with the outside world was handled only by appointed elder monks and lay brothers who also managed the operation of the entire monastery complex.</paragraph><paragraph>There were exceptions, however, such as when the monastery included a <accent>school</accent>, <accent>hospital</accent> (infirmarium), or <accent>medical workshop</accent>, where in times of need, laypeople could also receive care. Monks educated in medicine could also visit the sick and wounded from surrounding villages and towns.</paragraph><paragraph>A typical day for monks was punctuated by prayers. It began early, shortly after midnight, with <italic>vigils</italic>. This was followed (between 3 and 4 in the morning) by the first service - <italic>matins</italic>. Then came <italic>prime</italic> (at 6 am), followed by <italic>terce</italic> (9 am), <italic>sext</italic> (noon), and <italic>none</italic> (3 pm). <italic>Vespers</italic> were held before sunset, and finally (half an hour after sunset) <italic>compline</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>After the morning mass, the brothers gathered in the chapter house to hear readings from the monastic rule. This was followed by sermons and discussions relevant to the monastery. Brothers confessed their sins, received discipline, or sought repentance. Between the morning mass (sext) and midday, they devoted themselves to work or study.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The military encampment was located near Kuttenberg for several months, so there must have been all the necessities of civilian life, such as field baths, an apothecary, a clergyman, a canteen, supply tents, and a large number of courtesans and prostitutes.</paragraph><paragraph>Many soldiers made the journey with their families, while hundreds more 'civilians' joined the encampment for purely practical reasons. There was always a need for shoemakers, armoursmiths, blacksmiths, bakers and others. Realistically, there were often more non-soldiers than soldiers in the camp.</paragraph><paragraph>Therefore, the so-called <italic>provisioning units</italic> were sent out from the camp into the surrounding areas. These were soldiers charged with getting provisions, whatever the cost. In calmer times, the provisioners normally paid the peasants for their food; in more tense times, they took what they could find. Getting enough sustenance for a crowd of many thousands was a question not only of survival but of morale. Without morale there is no army, without an army there is no campaign...</paragraph><paragraph>A critical factor for any military camp was hygiene, as more than one campaign ended in an epidemic of dysentery or typhoid before it even began.</paragraph>

<paragraph>A military camp near Kuttenberg remained in place for several months, requiring all the essentials of civilian life, including field baths, an apothecary, a clergyman, a mess hall, supply tents, and a sizable contingent of courtesans and prostitutes.</paragraph><paragraph>Many soldiers embarked on their journey with their families, and hundreds of other "civilians" joined the camp for practical reasons. There was always a need for cobblers, armorers, blacksmiths, bakers, and others. As a result, there were often more non-combatants than soldiers in the camp.</paragraph><paragraph>To sustain the camp so-called <italic>provisioning units</italic> were sent out into the surrounding areas. These were soldiers charged with getting provisions at whatever cost. In calmer times, the provisioners normally paid peasants for their food; in more desperate times, they took what they could find. Getting enough sustenance for a crowd of many thousands was a question not only of survival but of morale. Without morale there is no army, without an army there is no campaign...</paragraph><paragraph>Hygiene was a critical factor for any military camp, as many campaigns ended due to epidemics of dysentery or typhus before they even began.</paragraph>

<paragraph>When the young son of John of Luxembourg, Charles, inherited the title Margrave of Moravia and subsequently the Bohemian throne, the kingdom began to flourish not only economically but also culturally. This period is now known as <italic>"the Golden Age"</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>During his reign, many cities, towns and castles received new fortifications, new bridges and better infrastructure were constructed, and new churches were built. Many famous buildings are named after Charles because he initiated their construction, such as Charles Bridge or Karlstejn Castle, or one of the oldest universities in Europe, Charles University in Prague, which he founded in 1348.</paragraph><paragraph> He also liked to emphasize the role of faith in society. He contributed to the restoration of the cult of Sts. Wenceslas, Sigismund and Vitus, to whom he dedicated sacred buildings, including the cathedral at Prague Castle.</paragraph><paragraph>He used marriage policy to strengthen his position in Europe, linking his family with prominent families in neighbouring countries. He influenced the occupation of ecclesiastical offices. Thanks to his firm rule and a policy based on making alliances, he was able to maintain peace in Europe.</paragraph><paragraph>King Charles was an educated ruler with an interest in the arts, which was reflected in the architecture of the cities, especially Prague, which he chose as the seat of his court and which went through a considerable transformation during his reign.</paragraph>

<paragraph>When Charles, the young son of John of Luxembourg, inherited the title Margrave of Moravia and subsequently the Bohemian throne, the kingdom began to flourish not only economically but also culturally. This period is now known as <italic>"the Golden Age"</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>During his reign, many cities, towns and castles received new fortifications, new bridges and better infrastructure, as well as new churches. Many famous buildings are named after Charles because he initiated their construction, such as Charles Bridge, Karlstejn Castle and one of the oldest universities in Europe, Charles University in Prague, which he founded in 1348.</paragraph><paragraph>He also emphasised the role of faith in society. He was instrumental in the renewal of the cults of Saints Wenceslas, Sigismund and Vitus, to whom he dedicated sacred buildings, including the cathedral at Prague Castle.</paragraph><paragraph>He used marriage policy to strengthen his position in Europe, linking his family with prominent houses in neighbouring countries. He influenced the appointment of ecclesiastical offices. Thanks to his firm rule and a policy based on alliances, he was able to maintain peace in Europe.</paragraph><paragraph>King Charles was an educated ruler with an interest in the arts, which was reflected in the architecture of the cities, especially Prague, which he chose as the seat of his court and which went through a considerable transformation during his reign.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Danemark Mill was built above the Vrchlitz river during the economic growth of Kuttenberg, perhaps even earlier than in the 15th century.</paragraph><paragraph>It deserves to be remembered and immortalized in the game, mainly because it is the last surviving Middle Age building among many similar ones in the area. Today, however, it can be seen after an 18th century rebuilding and no longer serves as a mill.</paragraph><paragraph>Who knows, perhaps the longevity of this building was due not only to its owners, but also to the souls of the first settlers in the area. In fact, traces of a prehistoric gord, dating back to the early Eneolithic period (4,400 and 2,000 BC), have been found above the mill on the rock.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The Danemark Mill was built above the Vrchlitz river during the economic growth of Kuttenberg, possibly even earlier than the 15th century.</paragraph><paragraph>It deserves to be remembered and immortalized in the game, mainly because it is the last surviving Middle Age building among many similar ones in the area. It can be viewed today having undergone an 18th century reconstruction and no longer serves as a mill.</paragraph><paragraph>Who knows, perhaps the longevity of this building was due not only to its owners, but also to the spirits of the first settlers in the area. Traces of prehistoric settlement, dating back to the early Eneolithic period (4,400 and 2,000 BC), have been found on the rock above the mill.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The brave and determined helper of Jan Zizka of Trotznov is mostly just a fictional character, although women bearing this name played important roles in Zizka's life.</paragraph><paragraph>The first Katherine was probably his mother, although this is not certain, since according to other sources her name was Johanna. We know more about the second Katherine. In the provincial land-registry books we learn that Jan Zizka married her and acquired a farm in Čerejov as a dowry. They even had a daughter, although her name is unknown.</paragraph><paragraph>After Katherine's death, Zizka married… yet another Katherine. Again, we do not know anything about her, except that Zizka inherited her property after her death.</paragraph><paragraph>In view of the importance of this name in the life of this great figure of Czech history, we decided to approach the character of Katherine in our own way.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The brave and determined helper of Jan Zizka of Trotznov is mostly just a fictional character, although women bearing this name played important roles in Zizka's life.</paragraph><paragraph>The first Katherine was probably his mother, although this is not certain, as other sources name her Johanna. We know more about the second Katherine. In the provincial land-registry books we learn that Jan Zizka married her and acquired a farm in Čerejov as a dowry. They even had a daughter, although her name is unknown.</paragraph><paragraph>After Katherine's death, Zizka married… yet another Katherine. Again, we do not know anything about her, except that Zizka inherited her property after her death.</paragraph><paragraph>In view of the importance of this name in the life of this great figure of Czech history, we decided to interpret the character of Katherine in our own way.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In this case, Kunzlin Ruthard is a fictional character inspired by two different persons of the same name.</paragraph><paragraph>The Ruthards descended from an old branch of minor Bohemian nobility who settled in Kuttenberg and gained substantial wealth there; this led to the family's promotion to knighthood. In 1364, Kunzlin Ruthard bought the Maleshov fortress from the Sedletz Monastery and added <italic>"of Maleshov"</italic> to his family name. He died sometime around the year 1376. His descendant Wenceslas Ruthard then sold the fortress in 1407.</paragraph><paragraph>Another Kunzlin Ruthard had an altar built at the so-called <italic>Ruthard Chapel</italic> in the Tall Church in Kuttenberg.</paragraph>

<paragraph>In this case, Kunzlin Ruthard is a fictional character inspired by two different persons of the same name.</paragraph><paragraph>The Ruthards descended from an old branch of minor Bohemian nobility who settled in Kuttenberg and gained substantial wealth there; this led to the family's promotion to knighthood. In 1364, Kunzlin Ruthard bought the Maleshov fortress from the Sedletz Monastery and added <italic>"of Maleshov"</italic> to his family name. He died sometime around the year 1376. His descendant Wenceslas Ruthard then sold the fortress in 1407.</paragraph><paragraph>Another Kunzlin Ruthard had an altar built at the so-called <italic>Ruthard Chapel</italic> in the Tall Church in Kuttenberg.</paragraph>

<paragraph>He was twice appointed royal mint master and after the Hussite uprising broke out, he was one of the few representatives of the higher Bohemian nobility to join the side of the rebels.</paragraph><paragraph>We do not know anything about his life before the uprising, except that he held the office of mint master between 1402 and 1403 (or 1404), during the absence of King Wenceslas from Bohemia.</paragraph><paragraph>Only his later life is documented, when he stood up for Jan Hus and complained to King Sigismund about his burning at the stake. He initiated the negotiations on the Four Articles of Prague (which defined the direction and demands of the uprising) and, at the Congress of Tschaslau, he was elected to the provisional government as a representative of the nobility. He fought alongside Jan Zizka and in 1421, he became the Kuttenberg mint master for the second time.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Twice during his life, he was appointed Royal Mint Master, and after the outbreak of the Hussite uprising, he was one of the few representatives of the higher Czech nobility to join the rebels.</paragraph><paragraph>We know nothing about his life before the outbreak of the uprising, except that in the years 1402-1403 (or 1404), during King Wenceslas's absence from Bohemia, he held the office of Mint Master.</paragraph><paragraph>His later life is documented, during which he supported Jan Hus and complained to King Sigismund about his burning. He initiated the negotiations of the Four Articles of Prague (which defined the direction and demands of the uprising) and was elected as a representative of the nobility to the provisional government at the Congress of Tschaslau. He marched into battle alongside Jan Zizka, and in 1421, he became the Mint Master of Kuttenberg for the second time.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Based on linguistic analysis of the Romani languages, we know that their origins are in India, but why there was a westward migration between the 5th and 10th centuries AD, we can only speculate.</paragraph><paragraph>In our historical epoch of the beginning of the 15th century, several groups of nomadic Romani, numbering from tens to hundreds of people, may have already moved around the Czech lands. We know from records that they presented themselves as Christian refugees expelled from the Holy Land after its conquest by the Arabs. For this reason, they initially enjoyed respectability, and many rulers and monarchs gave them safe conducts, securing free passage and protection.</paragraph><paragraph>However, at the same time as migration to continental Europe, disagreements and clashes between cultures began to arise. The Romani, as bearers of foreign cultural practices and dress, often encountered misunderstandings.</paragraph><paragraph>Despite the difficulties of coexistence, the Romani tried to survive as best they could. They were renowned horse breeders, blacksmiths and musicians, and their ability to control the supernatural is often mentioned. The latter, however, is rather an attempt to attribute to unknown things an unearthly origin.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Based on linguistic analysis of the Romani language, we know that their origin comes from India. However, why migration to the west occurred between the 5th and 10th centuries AD can only be speculated upon.</paragraph><paragraph>In the early 15th century, several groups of nomadic Roma, numbering from dozens to hundreds of people, may already have been moving across Czech lands. Records indicate that they presented themselves as Christian refugees expelled from the Holy Land after its conquest by the Arabs. This initial portrayal earned them respect, and many rulers and sovereigns provided them with passes ensuring free passage and protection.</paragraph><paragraph>However, along with their migration into continental Europe, cultural misunderstandings and conflicts began to arise. The Roma, with their exotic cultural practices and attire, often faced incomprehension.</paragraph><paragraph>Despite the difficult coexistence, the Roma tried to survive as best they could. They were renowned horsemen, blacksmiths, and musicians, and their supposed ability to control the supernatural is often mentioned. The latter, however, is more likely an attribute of our tendency to attribute unknown things to an otherworldly origin.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Rosa Ruthard is not a real historical figure. She is inspired by Rosa/Rozina from the Kuttenberg legend portrayed by the Czech dramatist Josef Kajetán Tyl. We were intrigued by the legend, but in the end we kept only the name from the story about the daughter of a rich nobleman from the Ruthard family. The original story goes like this:</paragraph><paragraph>Rosa was the daughter of George Ruthard, a rich but very stingy and cruel burgher of Kuttenberg. She was not only very clever but also beautiful, so she had no shortage of suitors. However, this was something her father feared, as the last thing he wanted was to cut short his treasure for his daughter's dowry. He therefore insured his fortune in a very cruel way - he had his daughter walled up in the same cellar where he kept his possessions.</paragraph><paragraph>Rosa's ghost later haunted the house and its surroundings, even in the street near the house people could hear her crying at night. Often the ghost would appear to the inhabitants of the house and foretell terrible misfortune. Later, this actually happened - in 1648, the house collapsed, burying all those inside.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Rosa Ruthard is not a documented historical figure. She is inspired by Rosa/Rozina from a Kuttenberg legend, which was adapted by Czech playwright Josef Kajetán Tyl. The story intrigued us, but ultimately, we retained only her name from the tale of the daughter of a wealthy nobleman from the Ruthard family. The original legend goes like this:</paragraph><paragraph>Rosa was the daughter of George Ruthard, a wealthy but very stingy townsman of Kuttenberg. She was beautiful and intelligent, so she had no shortage of suitors. However, her father feared this, as the last thing he wanted was to diminish his treasure with his daughter's dowry. He secured his wealth in a very cruel manner - he had his daughter bricked up in the same cellar where he kept his riches.</paragraph><paragraph>Her ghost later haunted the house and its surroundings; people in the street would hear crying at night. The spirit often appeared to the house's residents and predicted terrible misfortunes. This eventually came true - in 1648, the house collapsed, burying everyone inside.</paragraph>

<paragraph>By the real name Hynek Jevišovský of Kunstadt, was a fierce and fearless soldier who became famous as a robber knight during the Moravian Margraviate Wars, in which he repeatedly raided Austria in 1401 and 1402, and continued to do so after the first capture of the Bohemian king in Vienna.</paragraph><paragraph>Only after the escape of King Wenceslas IV did the Austrian Duke Albrecht lose patience and so in 1404 he marched on Znojmo with 12,000 soldiers supported by another 12,000 soldiers of Sigismund of Luxembourg. However, the Dry Devil knew about the campaign. When the enemy troops stood in front of the town, it was already fortified and with the great help of his friend Jan Sokol of Lamberg he repelled the attack. It should be added that the epidemic of dysentery, which had spread among the enemy to such an extent that both enemy nobles were infected, also contributed greatly to this. Albrecht IV of Austria even died of the disease.</paragraph><paragraph>And so the Dry Devil continued to pillage and plunder. Eventually, however, even Wenceslas IV ran out of patience and had Hynek imprisoned in 1407. He was soon released, but did not enjoy his freedom very much, for he died in 1408.</paragraph>

<paragraph>Originally named Hynek Jevišovský of Kunstadt, he was a fierce and fearless soldier who became famous as a robber knight during the Moravian Margraviate Wars, in which he repeatedly raided Austria in 1401 and 1402, continuing even after the first capture of the Bohemian king in Vienna.</paragraph><paragraph>Only after the escape of King Wenceslas IV did the Austrian Duke Albrecht lose patience and so in 1404 he marched on Znojmo with 12,000 soldiers supported by another 12,000 soldiers of Sigismund of Luxembourg. However, the Dry Devil knew about the campaign. When the enemy troops stood in front of the town, it was already fortified and with substantial help from his friend Jan Sokol of Lamberg he repelled the attack. It should be noted that a dysentery epidemic, which had spread among the enemy to such an extent that both enemy nobles were infected, also contributed greatly to this. Albrecht IV of Austria even died of the disease.</paragraph><paragraph>And so the Dry Devil continued to pillage and plunder. Eventually, however, even Wenceslas IV ran out of patience and had Hynek imprisoned in 1407. He was soon released, but did not enjoy his freedom very long, for he died in 1408.</paragraph>

<paragraph>The invincible knight, the paragon of all chivalric virtues, the undefeated winner of all tournaments, the most famous of the famous. With these and many other nicknames was called Zavish of Garbow, probably the most famous knight of his time and certainly the most famous Pole of the early 15th century. </paragraph><paragraph>Sources state that around 1403 he served as a mercenary knight in the service of Margrave Prokop and waged an sabotage war against the Bishop of Olomouc. Later he worked at the court of Sigismund of Luxembourg, with whom he undertook a campaign to Bosnia. In 1410 he fought on the Polish side in the well known battle of Grunwald.</paragraph><paragraph>He died in 1428 in Serbia on a crusade against the Turks. </paragraph>

<paragraph>The Invincible Knight, exemplar of all knightly virtues, undefeated champion of tournaments, the most famous among the famous. With these and many other epithets, Zavish of Garbow was known, likely the most renowned knight of his time and certainly the most famous Pole of the early 15th century.</paragraph><paragraph>Sources indicate that around 1403 he served as a mercenary knight in the service of Margrave Prokop and led a guerrilla war against the Bishop of Olomouc. Later, he served at the court of Sigismund of Luxembourg, with whom he campaigned in Bosnia. In 1410, he fought on the side of Poland in the famous Battle of Grunwald.</paragraph><paragraph>He died in 1428 in Serbia during a crusade against the Turks.</paragraph>

Charisma represents how good you look. It plays a role when using skillchecks and trading.

Your total charisma is the average of the charisma values of the individual pieces of your clothing or armor that are visible. Layers hidden under others don't count, so a man's shirt under a beggar's coat doesn't help you. You must take good care of your clothing, as damaged, stained or bloodied clothing has a lower Charisma value. Wash yourself from time to time, too, at the bathhouse or at the vat or pier.

You can also increase your Charisma by using perfumes, which can be prepared in alchemy.

Charisma represents how good you look. It plays a role when using skillchecks and trading.

Your total charisma is the average of the charisma values of the individual pieces of your clothing or armour that are visible. Layers hidden under others don't count, so a man's shirt under a beggar's coat doesn't help you. You must take good care of your clothing, as damaged, stained or bloodied clothing has a lower Charisma value. Wash yourself from time to time, too, at the bathhouse or at the vat or pier.

You can also increase your Charisma by using perfumes, which can be prepared in alchemy.

A way to get your way in conversations thanks to your eloquence, but often using underhanded and unfair practices. People won't generally like you then, on the other hand a low reputation with them will help you succeed. Status is derived primarily from the amount of your eloquence and, to a lesser extent, charisma.

A way to get your way in conversations using your Speech, but often using underhanded and unfair practices. It won't make you many friends, though having a low reputation with them will help you succeed. This stat is derived primarily from your Speech level, and to a lesser extent your Charisma.

Conspicuousness indicates how distinctive your appearance is and affects how quickly someone recognises you when they see you. The lower the conspicuousness, the longer it will take them to notice you. If your conspicuousness is very low, for example, an enemy might notice you from a distance, but you'll be able to hide again before he realizes exactly what he saw. Conspicuousness is derived from the average conspicuousness of your outer garments. Distinctive nice clothes and expensive armor are typically very conspicuous. Bland pieces, on the other hand, less so.

Conspicuousness indicates how distinctive your appearance is and affects how long it takes for people to recognise you when they see you. The lower your conspicuousness, the longer it will take them to notice you. If your conspicuousness is very low, for example, an enemy might notice you from a distance, but you'll be able to hide again before he realizes exactly what he saw. Conspicuousness is derived from the average conspicuousness of your outer garments. Distinctive fine clothing and expensive armour are typically very conspicuous. Bland pieces, on the other hand, less so.

A way to get your way in conversations thanks to your charisma, often using threats and condescending behavior. People won't generally like you then, on the other hand a low reputation with them will help you succeed. Status is derived primarily from the amount of your charisma and to a lesser extent your eloquence.

A way to get your way in conversations using your Charisma, often using threats and condescending behavior. People generally won't like you for it, but on the other hand, having a low reputation with them will help you succesfully Dominate them. The Domination stat is derived primarily from Charisma level, and to a lesser extent your Speech level.

A way to get your way in conversations thanks to your strength of arms and intimidating appearance, often with the help of intimidation. People won't generally like you then, on the other hand a low reputation with them will help you succeed. Status is derived from how good your armour and weapons are and how physically fit you are, and to a lesser extent the amount of strength, agility and vitality you have and whether you are dirty or bloodied.

A way to get your way in conversations using your strength of arms and intimidating appearance. People won't like you much, but on the other hand a low reputation with them will help you succeed. This stat is derived from how good your armour and weapons are and how physically fit you are, and to a lesser your Strength, Agility and Vitality levels, as well as whether you're dirty or bloodied.

Visibility affects the distance oyu can be noticed from. The lower your visibility, the closer the observer must be to see you and subsequently be able to recognize you. This is especially important when you're sneaking around or up to no good.

Visibility is calculated as the average of the visibility level of your outer lazer of clothing. Shiny armor and brightly colored clothing are typically highly visible. Dark clothing, on the other hand, less so. Regardless of how you are dressed, of course, you're much easier to see in the light of day than when you're sneaking through the shadows or at night.

Visibility affects how far away you can be noticed from. The lower your visibility, the closer the observer has to be to see you. This is especially important when you're sneaking around or up to no good.

Visibility is calculated as the average of the visibility level of your outer layer of clothing. Shiny armour and brightly colored clothing are typically highly visible. Dark clothing, on the other hand, less so. Regardless of how you are dressed you're much easier to see in the light of day than when you're sneaking through the shadows or at night.

The way you assert yourself in conversations is through your charisma and good manners. A high reputation will help you succeed. This stat is derived mainly from your Charisma level, and to a lesser extend from your Speech level.

The way you assert yourself in conversations is through your charisma and good manners. A high reputation will help you succeed. This stat is derived mainly from your Charisma level, and to a lesser extend from your Speech level.
Determines your horse's load capacity. Can be improved with a better saddle and saddlebags.
Determines your horse's load capacity. Can be improved with a better saddle and saddlebags.

Titles don't honour the people that wear them - people honour the titles they hold.

Your Main level reflects your overall progress through the game and the general prowess of your character.

Your Main level will grow as your Strength, Agility, Vitality and Speech levels do, as well as through completing quests and progressing through the main story.

The maximum level for all stats and skills, as well as your Main level, is 30.

Titles don't honour the people that wear them - people honour the titles they hold.

Your Main level reflects your overall progress through the game and the general prowess of your character.

Your Main level will grow as your Strength, Agility, Vitality and Speech levels do, as well as through completing quests and progressing through the main story.

The maximum level for all stats and skills, as well as your Main level, is 30.

Stamina allows you to perform challenging physical feats such as fighting, sprinting and more. If you become completely exhausted, you will usually not be able to continue. This is especially important in combat, as strikes that stop armor will deplete some of your stamina anyway. But if there isn't enough of it, it will still hurt. This is why you can gradually wear down a heavily armored opponent, but it applies to you as well.

Your stamina will recover fairly quickly if you stay still or slow down for a while. During combat as well, but more slowly.

Your maximum stamina supply is determined by your vitality. However, if you are injured, tired, hungry, overfed or drunk, you will have less stamina available.

Stamina allows you to perform demanding physical feats such as fighting, sprinting and more. If you become completely exhausted, you will usually not be able to continue. This is especially important in combat, as even strikes that are stopped by armour will still deplete some of your Stamina. If it's low, you will incur injury. This is why you can gradually wear down a heavily armoured opponent, but the same applies to you.

Stamina will recover fairly quickly if you stay still or slow down for a while. It also regenerates during combat, but more slowly.

Your maximum Stamina supply is determined by your vitality. However, if you are injured, tired, hungry, overfed or drunk, you will have less Stamina available.
Your horse's Stamina is depleted during canter and gallop. After a while, you have to let your horse rest before nudging him to a greater speed again.
Your horse's Stamina is depleted during canter and gallop. After a while, you have to let your horse rest by walking before nudging him to a greater speed again.

A way to assert yourself in conversations thanks to your strength of arms and chivalrous appearance. A high reputation will help you succeed. Status is derived from how good your armour and weapons are and how physically fit you are, and to a lesser extent the amount of strength, agility and vitality you have.

A way to assert yourself in conversations thanks to your strength of arms and chivalrous appearance. A high reputation will help you succeed. Status is derived from how good your armour and weapons are and how physically fit you are, and to a lesser extent the amount of Strength, Agility and Vitality you have.

Your dog's obedience affects his behaviour. A dog with low obedience may not respond to all commands or may run away from you for a while. Conversely, high obedience makes your dog stronger and follows your commands better.

Your dog's obedience level affects his behaviour. A dog with low obedience may not respond to all commands or may run off from time to time. On the other hand, a high obedience level means your dog will be stronger and more likely to obey your commands.

Your total noise level is the average of the noise level of the weapons, armor, and clothing you are wearing. Iron armor usually makes the most noise.

The higher your noise level, the louder it is when you move, and thus the more likely you are to be detected by enemies. Sneaking will reduce your noise level considerably, sprinting will do the opposite.

Your total Noise level is the average of the noise level of the weapons, armour, and clothing you are wearing. Iron armour usually makes the most noise.

The higher your Noise level, the louder it is when you move, and thus the more likely you are to be detected by enemies. Sneaking will reduce your noise level considerably, sprinting will do the opposite.

A way to get your way in conversations thanks to your eloquence and cleverness. A high reputation will help you succeed. Status comes from the amount of eloquence and, to a lesser extent, charisma you possess.

A way to assert yourself in conversations using your eloquence and cleverness. A high reputation will help you succeed. The Persuasion stat is derived from your Speech level, and to a lesser extent your Charisma.

Speed is derived mainly from your agility and determines how fast you are when moving.

It can be reduced due the weight of armor you are wearing. This effect of armor load also increases stamina cost of your movement and combat actions in general but can be further mitigated by your level of agility and strenght, so with your stats high enough, you shouldn't be effected even by the heaviest of armors.

Speed is derived mainly from your Agility level, and determines how fast you are when moving.

The weight of your armour also affects your speed - wearing heavy armour increases the stamina cost of your movement and combat actions. This can be mitigated by increasing your Agility and Strength levels - with high enough stats, even the heaviest armours won't slow you down.

Speed of your horse determines how fast it can walk, trot, canter and gallop. It can be enhanced with bridles and horseshoes. On the other hand some equipment like saddles, padded caparisons or chanfrons can reduce speed of the horse.

Your horse's Speed level determines how fast it can walk, trot, canter and gallop. It can be enhanced with bridles and horseshoes. On the other hand, some equipment like saddles, padded caparisons or chanfrons can reduce your horse's Speed..
Thanks to its sense of smell, the dog can detect even enemies it cannot see. A dog can identify enemies at a greater distance if you take good care of it and are proficient in controlling it.
Thanks to its sense of smell, your dog can detect even enemies it can't see. A dog can identify enemies at a greater distance if you take good care of it and are proficient at handling it.

Thanks to alchemy you can brew various potions on the alchemy bench. You only need to know the recipe and have the necessary ingredients with you.
Using alchemy, you can brew various potions at an alchemy bench. All you need is a recipe and the right ingredients.

Where will you be cooking?
You can find alchemy benchs all over the world, and as long as it's not in a restricted area, you can cook on it without being punished. On the map they are marked with an icon.

Where can you brew?
You can find alchemy benchs all throughout the world, and as long as it isn't in a restricted area, you can use it freely. They're also marked with an icon on your map.

What will you cook?
You can find everything you can cook in the Player Menu under the Crafting tab. You can expand your knowledge by using recipes that are found all over the world and you just need to learn them.
 
What will you cook with?
To make each potion you need herbs (e.g. belladonna, mint...) or special ingredients (e.g. charcoal, boar's kale...) according to the recipe.

What can you make?
You can find all your recipes in the Player Menu under the Crafting tab. You can expand your knowledge by finding and learning recipes throughout the world.
 
What will you brew with?
Every potion requires certain herbs (e.g. belladonna, mint...) or special ingredients (e.g. charcoal, boar's tusk...) according to the recipe.
All the necessary ingredients can be found in nature or you can buy them from herbalists and apothecaries.
All the necessary ingredients can be found in nature or you can buy them from herbalists and apothecaries.
On the alchemist's table you will find all the tools you need to prepare potions.
On an alchemy bench, you'll find all the tools you'll need to prepare potions.

Working on the alchemist's bench
When you look around the bench, you will see a flag with its name on each piece of equipment. You are working with the piece of equipment you are looking at.
 
Descriptions of all the parts of the alchemy bench can be found on the next pages.

Working at an alchemist's bench
When you look around the bench, you'll see banners with names of every piece of equipment. To interact with a piece of equipment, you first have to look at it.
 
Descriptions of all the parts of the alchemy bench can be found on the next pages.
$alch_use; to use the equipment (that you're looking at)
After starting the alchemy, Henry prepares a book of recipes on the rack. When you look at it, you will be given the option to look inside it.
Once you start the alchemy activity, Henry will prepare a book of recipes on the rack. When you look at it, you'll be given the option to look inside it.

In the book you will find all the recipes you already know how to cook and if you learn a new one, it will appear in the book. You can come back to the book at any time during the cooking process.
 
While reading the recipe, you can automatically prepare all the necessary ingredients if you have them in your inventory.

In the recipe book, you'll find all the recipes you know and if you learn a new one, it'll appear in the book. You can return to the book at any time during the brewing process.
 
While reading the recipe, you can automatically prepare all the necessary ingredients if you have them in your inventory.

$alch_use; open book (by looking at it)
$read_select^; prepare all necessary ingredients

Use the waterskin to fan the flame and make the cooking more intense

Boil the cauldron using the bellows
Use the bellows to fan the flame and make the cauldron boil faster

Finish the potion by pouring it into the prepared vial

After reading the recipe, you can start the actual cooking. Making each potion starts with pouring the correct liquid base into the kettle.
After reading the recipe, you can start brewing. Making each potion starts with pouring the correct liquid base into the cauldron.

You can find out what base to use in the recipe. You have a choice of water, wine, oil and liquor.
 
You will find the bases in the jugs on the shelf to the left of the kettle. Just look at it and then choose to pour it.
 
If you pour the wrong liquid into the kettle (or make any other mistake at any time), you can start cooking again, but you will lose the ingredients you used.

You can find out what base to use in the recipe. You have a choice of water, wine, oil and spirits.
 
You can find the bases in the jugs on the shelf to the left of the cauldron. Just look at it and then choose to pour it.
 
If you pour the wrong liquid into the cauldron (or make any other mistake at any time), you can start brewing again, but you will lose the ingredients you used.

$alch_use; pour the base into the kettle (by looking at it)
$alch_reset^; you start cooking again

$alch_use; to pour the base into the cauldron (while looking at it)
$alch_reset^; to start brewing again
Lay out the necessary ingredients on the table from your inventory. Most often it will be herbs and occasionally you will use some special ingredients.
Lay out the necessary ingredients on the table from your inventory. These will usually be herbs, with the occasional special ingredient.

You unload ingredients by opening the inventory and selecting them. You can have up to three types of herbs and three special ingredients. All of them are located right of the cauldron.
 
Herbs
You pick up herbs by the handful and can only take one handful at a time. After picking them up, you can toss them into the cauldron with the base poured over them, into a mortar, or into a storage bowl.
 
Special Ingredients
They behave just like herbs, except you can only have one of each. Some can't be crushed in a mortar for obvious reasons.

You can prepare the ingredients by opening your inventory and selecting them. You can have up to three types of herbs and three special ingredients. All of them are located to the right of the cauldron.
 
Herbs
You pick up herbs by the handful and can only take one handful at a time. After picking them up, you can toss them into the cauldron with the base poured over them, into the mortar, or into the storage bowl.
 
Special Ingredients
They behave just like herbs, except you can only have one of each. Some can't be ground in a mortar for obvious reasons.

$alch_open_inventory; open inventory to select ingredients
$alch_use; collect or place ingredient/use

$alch_open_inventory; to open your inventory to select ingredients
$alch_use; to pick up or put down ingredient/use
You can pour the necessary amount of herbs into the disposal bowl, even crushed, so that they can be added to the kettle all at once.
You can put the necessary amount of herbs into the storage bowl, even ground, so that they can be added to the cauldron all at once.
In the mortar you can crush herbs or some special ingredients. You can use the mortar to crush the ingredient first. You can also crush multiple ingredients at once, but you can't separate them.

You can grind herbs and certain special ingredients in the mortar. First add the ingredients, then you can use the pestle to grind them in the mortar. You can also grind multiple ingredients at once, but you can't separate them.
You regulate the boiling of the kettle by its height above the fire and the bellows you use to fan the fire. The cooking time is then measured by turning the hourglass.
You regulate the boiling of the cauldron by adjusting its height above the fire and using the bellows to fan the fire. The brewing time is then determined by turning the hourglass.

Cauldron
The cauldron can be hung above the fire at two heights. High above the flame (I), it won't cook. If you put it directly over the fire (II), it will start to cook slightly after a while. You can tell when it's boiling by the bubbles on the surface. If you move the kettle up, the cooking will stop immediately.
 
If you press the waterskin to the boiling kettle, you will blow the fire and the kettle will start boiling intensely (III).
 
Spinning Clock
The spinning clock is found to the right of the kettle and the cooking time is measured by the number of turns it makes, but beware. The contents of the kettle are cooked whether the clock is currently timing or not.

Cauldron
The cauldron can be hung above the fire at two heights. High above the flame (I), it won't boil. If you put it directly over the fire (II), it will start to boil after a while. You can tell when it's boiling by the bubbles on the surface. If you move the cauldron up, it will stop boiling immediately.
 
If you blow the bellows beneath the cauldron, you will fan the flame and the cauldron will start boiling intensely (III).
 
Sandglass
The sandglass is found to the right of the cauldron and you can use it to measure your cooking time. But beware: the cauldron's contents will boil regardless of whether you're measuring time or not.

$alch_move_pot; change the hanging of the cauldron
$alch_use_bag; grip the bellows
$alch_use_sandglass; turn the hourglass

$alch_move_pot; to adjust the height of the cauldron
$alch_use_bag; to use the bellows
$alch_use_sandglass; to turn the hourglass
<label>If the pot is high above the fire, the contents will not cook.</label>
<label>If the cauldron is too high above the fire, it won't boil.</label>
<label>If it is directly over the fire, the contents will begin to boil.</label>
<label>If it is directly over the fire, the contents will begin to boil.</label>
<label>If you blow the fire by squeezing the bellows, the cauldron will boil strongly.</label>
<label>If you fan the fire by using the bellows, the cauldron will boil faster.</label>
<label>Tip: Temperature is essential in alchemy. Some recipes require a gentle boil and others a strong boil.</label>
<label>Tip: Temperature is essential in alchemy. Some recipes require a gentle boil and others a strong boil.</label>
To complete the potion, take the bottle and then choose one of the three ways to complete it. The way you must finish the potion is always written in the recipe.
To complete the potion, take the bottle and then choose one of the three ways to complete it. The way you must finish the potion is always written in the recipe.

Pouring a potion
You can only pour a potion. To do this, just look at the cauldron with the vial in your hand and finish the potion.
 
Distillation
You can distill the potion. To do this, with the bottle in hand, just look at the distillation pot to finish the potion.
 
Dust Collection
This method is only for finishing gunpowder. Once you're done, look at the mortar and finish the potion. You don't need the bottle.

Pouring the potion
You can only pour the potion. To do this, just look at the cauldron with a vial in hand and finish the potion.
 
Distillation
You can distill the potion. To do this, look at the still with a vial in hand and finish the potion.
 
Powder collection
This method is only for finishing gunpowder. Once you're done, look at the mortar and finish the potion. You don't need a vial.
If you manage to brew the potion correctly, a table with its description will appear.
If you manage to brew the potion correctly, a table with its description will appear.

You can tell from it what quality of potion you have brewed. Potions can have up to four qualities. The final quality of the potion is influenced by the correctness of the procedure, the length and temperature of the brewing process, and the freshness of the herbs.
 
If you made a mistake somewhere during the brewing process, Henry will comment on it at the end and suggest what went wrong.

This will show you what quality of potion you brewed. Potions can be brewed in four different qualities. The final quality of potion is influenced by how closely you followed the procedure, the length and temperature of the brewing process and the freshness of the herbs.
 
If you made a mistake somewhere during the brewing process, Henry will comment on it at the end and suggest what went wrong.

God's hand guided your weapon, and thanks to it not a single soldier was left alive in the camp of the Pragueers. But now is not the time to celebrate! Your friends and silver are still in danger! Saddle your horse and rush for help!

God's hand guided your weapon and thanks to it, not a single soldier was left alive in the Praguers' camp. But now is not the time to celebrate! Your friends and the silver are still in danger! Saddle your horse and hurry for help!
For a small fee, you can have the barber change your hairstyle or trim your beard.
For a small fee, you can have the barber change your hairstyle or trim your beard.
You can use the barber's services at the bathhouse by the Zhelejov wagoner's inn in the Trosky region or Adam's bathhouse in Kuttenberg. They're marked with an icon on your map.
You can use the barber's services at the bathhouse by the Zhelejov wagoner's inn in the Trosky region or Adam's bathhouse in Kuttenberg. They're marked with an icon on your map.
All barbers have the same prices and offers, though the price may be influenced by your reputation.
All barbers have the same prices and offers, though the price may be influenced by your reputation.

Fighting is easy to learn, but hard to master. Below, you can see the basics.
Fighting is easy to learn, but hard to master. Below, you can see the basics.

When in combat, a combat rosette will be displayed on your opponent. This allows you to select one of four directions to attack from. The three long points are used for slashing attacks, wheareas the short bottom point is used for stabs.

When in combat, a combat rosette will be displayed on your opponent. This allows you to select one of four directions to attack from. The three long points are used for slashing attacks, wheareas the short bottom point is used for stabs.
To be effective in combat, you'll have to select the correct attack directions to hit uncovered areas on your opponent, while also blocking their attacks.
To be effective in combat, you'll have to select the correct attack directions to hit uncovered areas on your opponent, while also blocking their attacks.
